If you come here on a Monday morning when it opens you will sit, and you will inhale the best seafood in San Francisco. Let me repeat that: THE FRESHEST/BEST SEAFOOD IN SAN FRANCISCO LIVES AT SWAN OYSTER DEPOT.

If you come here on a sunny Saturday you will wait for DAYS and it wont be worth slapping down $200 on everything you eat (and alcohol). Don't be ridiculous and do these guys a favor and keep your bad review at bay... it's not thir fault you decided your cure for a hangover would be a plate of their oysters.

Musts:
Oysters (duh) do a mix - the locals are sometimes smallish
Clam Chowder - do a cup, you need room in that belly
Scallop sashimi with olive oil drizzle and capers
smoked salmon on bread
White wine all day

I also got an education here on oysters - first of all, you can buy and take home. YES! Secondly, if you buy oysters that have been shucked, you can put them in fresh water to 'juice' them up and they are fried perfectly after this process. I will be doing this on my next special occasion. 

Seats are horrifyingly unpleasant and uncomfortable. Thats ok, you have oysters. The staff seems like family and they're mostly male, I saw one female in the kitchen. All the guys are really nice, know their seafood, try to get through language barriers, and owner is ever present. I like that. Business owners who are involved. Always a good thing. 

Now if I could only find out who their supplier is...!!!

EAT HERE AT LEAST OE TIME IN YOUR LIFE!!!!!
author: nina B.

description: Well for this yelp the Chronicle did it for me so I you have to do is read Sundays cover story in the food and home section San Francisco Chronicle Secret menu for its regulars was the heading if I'm not mistaken. Take a peek at the pictures it's my favorite lunchspot anywhere Not just the bay area
author: Peter M.

description:
Best advice I ever received on Yelp was to arrive at this location early at 10:15ish, and wait in line before they open. We arrived even earlier at 10am on Friday morning, and found parking right across the street. Honestly, there is nothing to see near the area so waiting seemed to be the only option, so we did. A short wait later, they finally opened and we sat ourselves at the comfy bar. 

We ordered: jumbo shrimp cocktail, clam chowder, mixed oysters (from various regions), little necks, smoked salmon, and of course, the fresh sea urchin. Everything was phenomenal, and the staff was also extremely friendly. I would love to visit again if I'm ever in town, but seriously, remember to get there before 10:30am; most people who came later ended up waiting until we finished all our food (around 1.5 hrs).
author: Franco L.

description:
Excellent and friendly customer service, they made our first experience great and made us want to come back for more!

I love seafood, and decided to come here to try their oysters specifically. We ordered a dozen oysters, as well as half a dozen little neck clams (they gave us a couple extra of the clams). Both were so good, but the clams definitely stole the show. I just might not want to eat cooked clams again! We also ordered the sashimi plate, although the way it was prepared was unfamiliar, it was very tasty. Unfortunately, they didn't have any crabs or sea urchin that day so we were a tad bit bummed. That just means we have another reason to go back ASAP!
author: Lisa N.

description:
I went back and forth between 3 and 4 stars because overall, Swan Oyster Depot has incredibly fresh seafood. However, the wait (and we're talking hours here, folks) and the crowded dining area, make it really hard to fully enjoy the experience as a whole. We got in line on a random weekday at around 11:30 and then line was already past the neighboring building. There was nothing to make the wait easier on my hungry stomach; on one hand I would recommend eating before getting in line, but then again, you want to be hungry for your meal. 

By the time we got sat down I was feeling pretty hangry, and we ended up at the farthest end of the bar where we waited a significant about of time to be helped. We ordered the clam chowder, some oysters, the shrimp salad, and the half cracked crab. All of the seafood was very fresh, and served without much fanfare. I suppose if this restaurant was one of its kind, I would have been more enthused, but there are so many other fresh seafood restaurants in the city that don't make you wait two hours to eat.
author: Regina L.

description: Awesome fresh seafood.   The clam chowder was excellent and the crab cocktail was even better.  Cash only, and no BS.  Just great fresh seafood and a small bar/Counter.
author: David B.

description: Long line but definitely worth the wait! Super good service too. Even though there's a line out the door, they take their time with you. :)
author: Elle S.

description:
If I had to go by the gigantic, fresh crab salad and clam chowder I had, I'd give this place a solid 4. Service was really poor but compensated a little by another nice server who helped me out. I'm still debating whether this place is worth the 1 hr+ wait, especially in this city of delicious things. And remember that it's cash only (bring a lot because it's expensive).

I waited in line for about 1.5 hrs and it wasn't too bad since I was expecting it. Listen to a podcast or daydream while you wait. The store front is fun to gaze at since all the seafood is displayed for passerbys. The restaurant is about row of bar seats deep and you just have to wait your turn to sit. Once you're seated, one of the servers greets you.

I started with the clam chowder, which was okay, but not great. I would avoid this. The broth was watery and had a strong tap water taste to it. The clams, however, were nice and chewy.

I also had the crab salad (Dungeness), which was delicious. Get this! They pile the crab meat very high and have about 4-5 legs included (all unshelled). Be careful though as mine had bits of shell in it. The "salad" part is that they place the crab on top of iceburg lettuce, which is no more than garnish in my mind. The bread they serve with this is awesome- crunchy on the outside and soft on the inside. 

Condiments are really nice here- pickled scallions, housemade horseradish, and lots of sauces.

I sat for very long periods of time waiting for my server (he kept ignoring me and tending to other people) but a really nice server ended up helping me out. 

The meal (I thought it was worth the price) with tip came out to ~$40. I would come back to try the oysters and sashimi here but I think I need to let the serving experience become a distant memory first.
author: Jumi Y.

description:
A memorable experience . . . 

PROS: oysters on the half shell and pints of cold Anchor Steam . . . I could expire today a happy man!  Kumamoto oysters remain my favorite--they're like butter. The Miyagis and Bluepoints were exceptional, as well. Just wonderfully fresh and full of flavor. I like a quick squeeze of lemon over my oysters, and occasionally a tad of horseradish or red onion in vinegar. Swan's also has a Thai chili sauce--heavy on the garlic and packs a punch. In the end, however, the oysters at Swan's stand on their own, and I ate most of them unadorned. Wonderful. The staff at Swan's were great, and our service was excellent. They seem to like their gigs.  Lastly, while there was a line out the door for one of the maybe 20-odd counter seats, we were never rushed by the staff to vacate our bar stools--I appreciate that!  Lastly, did I mention the cold Anchor Steam? Damn!

CONS: my first visit, but based on my conversations w/ locals, if you come here on a weekend, you're gonna wait in line to get in. For us on a Saturday in September, it was 1.5 hrs . . . but worth it!

If you're debating between Hog Island and Swan's, I'll assume you haven't been to the latter, because it's a no-brainer . . . So glad we made it to Swan's!

Cheers!
RS
author: Rich S.

description:
My daughter was visiting from college and Swan was our first stop during our day in the City. First visit and we quickly recognized that this is one of the those places that requires patrons to embrace the "old school" restaurant experience where staff banters with patrons. Thick skin and sense of humor is helpful. If you are looking for an upscale dining experience where you have ample space and overly courteous staff, then this is not the place for you. We chose to embrace the atmosphere and were handsomely rewarded. We waited for 45 minutes for a spot at the bar and then squeezed on to our two bar stools. From the outset Jimmy, our server (all staff is behind one long bar that seats about 18), entertained us with conversation ranging from our shared Sicilian heritage and politics to instructing my daughter on how to make chicken soup for her college roommates! We felt like family. For the younger generation like my daughter who rarely engage with strangers in public environments, this was a truly memorable experience. She LOVED it!

Now to the food: Ordered a dozen mixed variety oysters that were fresh, delicious and shucked personally by Jimmy right in front of us. Next up was the dungeness crab salad served with a side of louie dressing. Simply crab on chopped lettuce. Sweet, fresh and highlighted the crab as the star. The food is not cheap, but we loved the overall experience and will be back.
author: Matt C.

description:
The clam chowder was four stars. The clams and oyster were five stars. The owner made a special dipping sauce from the clam fat for the bread which was excetpional. 

The staff was exceptionally friendly.  The decor has not changed for years, sort of funky  and unique.

It was expensive but the quality was worth it.

Jack H
Playa Vista
author: Jack H.

description:
Strictly for tourists.  I was almost sick at seeing the staff shoveling seafood onto plates with their bare hands (and with a cash-only system, the cleanliness is even less likely).  

With the extensive wait, I had about an hour and a half of watching these men handle the food and money without using gloves or washing.  I cringed. My boyfriend insisted on going here, so we did. Never again. 

Expensive, as well!! A tourist trap, for sure. Don't waste your time/money. 

Yes, the staff seem like nice folks. That doesn't make up for the fact that their hygiene is poor and the prices are ridiculous. Oh, and "cash only". 

Beyond arrogant.
author: Deirdre T.

description:
Man, how I wanted to love this place...  Let me take you back.  Back to a time before I lived in San Francisco.  I was living in NYC.  It was winter, and it was cold.  I used to spend hours sitting on yelp and google maps, exploring San Francisco from 3000 miles away.  I would look up all the best restaurants.  And visit them on the street.  I browsed through all the yelp photos.  Swan Oyster Depot was one of the first places I spent a lot of time looking up.  Such great reviews.  Fresh seafood at a reasonable price.  Who could ask for anything more, right?  

Unfortunately (due to the fact that there is always a line), it took me a year and a half after moving to SF to finally check out Swan Oyster Depot.  And as you can probably tell from my star rating above, I was wholly underwhelmed.  I went on a Saturday around 1PM.  Not surprisingly there was a long line.  But I decided to wait it out!  It only took an hour, but I finally made it through the doorway.  (Where  I proceeded to wait another 20 minutes).  You see, there were several people who had finished eating, but did not realize this was a "cash only" operation.  So people proceeded to find an ATM.  

While waiting for these people I noticed that the staff used their bare hands for everything.  Like scooping up the fresh seafood onto people plates or cutting the bread.  I understand people in restaurants use their hands to pick up food.  However they are working with raw seafood, and then with cooked seafood, or people's bread, and then touch money, and then sneeze, or touch their face.  Sure they wash their hands (sometimes) but still.  There is no reason why they couldn't use tongs to pick up the seafood.  Also, they spend a lot of time opening oysters and other things with ice and water, so their hands get wet and slimy.  

I digress, let's talk about the food.  I ordered the crab salad (despite the fact I knew they were going to grab the crab with their hands).  It was actually quite delicious.  Tons of fresh crab over a bed of shredded iceberg lettuce.  The louie sauce was also a perfect accompaniment.  I also tried the cherrystone clams.  The first one I slurped in my mouth had several chunks of shell that I immediately bit into and then had trouble getting them out of my mouth without spitting the whole damn clam out.  Not super appetizing.  The smoked trout was nice.  The raw scallops were delicious and fresh.  

Total price with tax and tip was $110.  Not totally sure how a crab salad, 6 clams, a small piece of trout, two scallops, a glass of wine, and a pepsi added up to $110, but it is what it is.  I left a little hungry and a little poorer.  

So why 3 stars (and not 2 or 1) you ask? Well this place is clearly an institution.  The seafood was fresh and delicious.  If you can get over the sanitary conditions of this place, you will probably enjoy your meal.
author: Paul W.

description:
Delicious, vintage, great service, simple, must see, are all words I'd slap on this classic joint.

The smoked salmon, soup and crab were all fantastic.

No need to wear your suit and tie.  They provide an excellent casual environment.
author: Andrew H.

description:
On 11/5 after the book signing at the Passage, I gave my hubby his first oyster shooter.  Let's just say he passed while I down two of them.  Yum! 
The best.  Thank you.
author: Paula P.

description:
Service was amazing -- they make you feel welcomed and will help you with the menu.

We had the crab back, prawn cocktail, crab cocktail, Sicilian sashimi, stone cherry clams, mix oysters, clam chowder, and a Stella to wash it all down. Even got souvenirs.

Get there around 1015a; as long as you are the 1st 20 you will have a seat.
author: Michael B.

description:
Best oysters my husband and I ever had! We were so full at the end but still squeezed in another half a dozen of Miyagi oysters.

We waited in line for 2 hours on a Friday morning to get seated but once seated, we did not feel rushed at all. The staff were friendly and quirky. 

What we ordered: 
A dozen assorted Miyagi oysters 
Half a dozen Kumamoto oysters 
4 cherry clams 
Combination seafood salad
Clam chowder 
Small sashimi plate 
Total ~$110 + tip 

We didn't like the sashimi plate because we weren't use to the Italian style of it. Rather have soy sauce and wasabi. The cherry clams were good but not great. But I would try it again next time. Instead of the combination salad, I would rather order the crab salad or half a crab only. We didn't particularly like the shrimp. You can get better chowder elsewhere. I would just order oysters and crab the next time we come. 

Tips: Avoid the line and ask for take out! Order a beer once you get close to the front to begin the experience.
author: Tami T.

description: One of the best dining experiences ever and by far the coolest foodie place in San Fran. Always a like... even at 10am, but worth the wait... you can even grab a drink while you wain in line on the sidewalk. The freshest sea food and the crab back with a little dipping bread is fantastic.
author: Lindsey W.

description: Came at 4:05, sign says open until 5:30 and we were told the people in front of us were the last customers they were going to serve. Interesting approach.
author: Brian B.

description:
Never been here before. Can you believe it? I've written 2,399 reviews and never been here before. It's a good thing that review #2,400 provides the perfect opportunity for me to describe my maiden voyage to Swan Oyster Depot just this past Friday, a good Good Friday. Now it's not that I'm not familiar with the routine. I've seen that line stretch up Polk Street enough times to realize this is no drop-by place unless you make a serious time commitment. And of course, on TV, I've seen a sauntering Anthony Bourdain sop up the crab fat with chunks of sourdough and follically-challenged Lidia Bastianich get a crab meat removal lesson from one of the brother-owners.

I got up on Good Friday regaling in the fact that I didn't have to go to work but thinking maybe parked on my sofa watching episodes of Pioneer Woman and Barefoot Contessa was not the best use of my time. I happened to browse Yelp and came upon the knowledge that Swan Oyster Depot opens at 10:30AM during the week. I confirmed that by calling them and finding out that market orders start at 8AM but that the diner part itself opens at 10:30. Hmmm, maybe today is the day I try it since I can just hop on the 19 and be there by around 10:15. Smart move as it turned out since there were already a dozen people waiting.

OK, I'll wait since I assume I could get a seat during the first wave of seating. I was right again, and as I was a solitary diner, I gladly accommodated the availability of the weird, higher-than-norm stool in the middle since no one else was willing to take it. Hey, the increased elevation doesn't alter my dining experience. Funny thing was that all the to-go orders were laid out in front of me, so they had to move the white butcher paper and cartons around the counter to serve me. As I was staring intently at the menu on the wall, I was asked by one of the veteran servers whether I wanted a cup of Clam Chowder ($5) and some (Sourdough) Bread and Butter for an extra buck (see photo).

The soup was not the calorific creaminess one would expect at a Fisherman's Wharf eatery but a far more briney broth with the freshness of the clams most prominent. I went next with the alluring $21 Combination Seafood Salad. Just look at my photo. I've never seen such a luxuriant pile of crab, prawns, shrimp, lobster and calamari in my life. I couldn't even see the shredded iceberg lettuce at the bottom of the plate, but the Louie dressing was drizzled quite gently on top making all the seafood glisten under the florescent lights. Delicious, fresh and clearly more seafood than one human should eat at a single sitting. But I wasn't about to leave. No, I was determined to try the $18 Sea Urchin.

It came in small fillets in a huge spiny shell (see photo). I remember seeing the look of rapture on the face of La Folie's Roland Passot when he ate this with Bourdain on his show (see photo). So fresh that Jiro would approve, I'm sure, and the delicious flavor was subtle which I dared to kick up a notch with some hot sauce. Enough already? I don't think so. How can you visit an oyster depot and not have oysters. For $14, I ordered a half-dozen of the Blue Point Oysters with a sundae goblet of cocktail sauce (see photo). By now, it was quite clear this was one of the freshest seafood meals I've ever had in this city or frankly anywhere outside the Tsukiji Fish Market in Tokyo.

FOOD - 5 stars...fresh seafood they've prepared for over a century...I think they have it right now
AMBIANCE - 4 stars...like eating in a shack on an East Coast pier...part of its charm
SERVICE - 4.5 stars...hectic, friendly and never hurried...another part of its charm...oh and bring cash, lots of it :-)
TOTAL - 5 stars...so I can finally check it off the bucket list...it was getting embarrassing
author: Ed U.

description:
Staple in The Bay Area and most deserved ! It's not for fine dining but instead it's focus is on the freshness of the seafood with daily drives to the wharf to retrieve their bounty which is small hand chosen and prepped! I love the guys and folks at Swans! Plus they carry this killer Muscat Canelli totally dry called Bella Boo out of Lake county and goes great with their fare!  
Cheers Deano
author: Dean W.

description: Excellent quality, everything is great, but my favorite are the oysters! Go at an odd hour, it gets super crowded. Price is a steal for the quality that they seve.
author: Raymond F.

description:
I just had my very first super fresh combo seafood salad! We came at about 1125 ish, waited til about 12 to get seated. Its only bar seating, which meant there was only about 15 seats at this small amazing seafood joint. 

Well worth the wait. Im not a fan of raw seafood, oysters, clama, etc.. my friends had them all and truly enjoyed it. Looks on their face, they loved it. The service was great too, very friendly!

Good for a first time place to try out. Since im not a big fan of seafoos, I can pass on this place, but I would recommend it to others for sure!
author: Vanessa W.

description:
When you're in rome, do as the romans do. Well when you're in SF, clam chowder is a must! I know everyone raves about goin to Boudin SF, but it's a chain. I could just get it back home at downtown disney so I opted to find the best clam chowder there is in SF. Yelp led me to Swan Oyster Depot and it didn't steer me wrong

This sounds weird but I was happy to see a long line out the door when we got there around noon. Long line = food is good 'cause it's worth waiting for! It's a small store w/ just one counter that people sit at to eat. Luckily the to-go line was a lot shorter so we got a cup and a bowl of clam chowder to go as well as the combo seafood salad.

Clam chowder - Light yet hearty. This is a little different than most clam chowders 'cause it's not thick, but the flavor is definitely there. The sourdough bread that came w/ the chowders were separated w/ these paper lookin things but it's actually butter! The bread was definitely SOURdough since it was sour. It paired well w/ the butter and clam chowder. I wish there were more clams though.

Combo Seafood salad - MUST GET THIS. It was bout $20 and wasn't much of a "salad" It was lettuce and lots and lots of seafood. The combo has shrimp (small ones), prawns, and crab. The prawns were big and super fresh and sweet!! Felt like they were just caught! Crab was sweet as well.

Hint: If you order to-go, the sizes are a cup, bowl, and pint. I would say go for the bowl size. Service is very friendly, but I was a bit concerned when they were preparing the salad with their bare hands, grabbing the seafood from the bins in front of the display window. I didn't get any food poisoning so it means they're pretty good at sanitizing their hands :)
author: Tracie L.

description:
Friend I came here with loved the place... I didn't see the mass appeal, but enjoyed the food I ordered.

1.5 hour wait on a 4pm on Saturday. Sat down at the counter, ordered some oysters, Prawn cocktail, crab back, chowder and champagne. Oysters were highlight - very clean and fresh tasting with lots of mignonette and other accompaniments. Prawn cocktail was very good as well, featuring large and plump shrimp doused in good cocktail sauce (pre-doused, don't expect to dip yourself). Clam chowder really did not stick out to me; I'm not a connoisseur of chowder, it usually either merits a good or bad... this was meh. Friend's crab back was so fishy and cold that I'm not sure how Bourdain called it the "nectar of gods", but maybe just preference in levels of fishiness.

Service is ad-hoc, you just kind of yell at the guys working behind the counter. They were friendly, but hard to get their attention. I get stressed if I have to spend time trying to get someone's attention to ask for something, so this stressed me out a little bit.

Overall, decent seafood, but would not endure the line again. Unless a visitor insisted.
author: Sarah B.

description: I'm embarrassed I didn't put up my pics and review of this fine establishment when I visited back in April. It was everything and more than what I was told. Finest quality, freshness and preparation of seafood that I've ever encountered. Can't wait to come back with my mom. Outstanding. Even their sashimi was a success. It was a hybrid sashmi, Mediterranean ceviche. The capers with the olive oil really drew out the sweet, buttery notes of the fish. Well done. Worth the one hour and a half wait in the rain.
author: Sung Moo C.

description: Fancy food in a not so fancy oyster bar. The oysters are so fresh and you can sort of taste that they're from the sea. We got a dozen mixed oysters, half a dozen clams, a sashimi plate, and a cup of clam chowder. Pricey but worth it for the quality of the seafood. I love the sourdough they give you and I know this is really random but this one guy who works there has a voice like Robert DeNiro. I love it!!!
author: Hannah C.

description: Told us the they were closed with no explanation at 3 p.m. and turned people away. Lame.
author: Kimberly H.

description:
I got around 10am on a Friday morning and the line was already out the door. I didn't make the first seating but I ended up getting in around 11am. Not too bad of a wait.

Everything looks so good here and I wanted to try everything on the menu. I was only eating for one so I tried as much as I could.

-Clam chowder - thin soup but with a lot of clams flavor. 

-Smoke salmon plate - dressed with capers, pepper, oil all over a few slices of bread. The shrimp salad that came with this is just delicious.

-Bluepoint and kuma oysters - can't beat the freshness of oysters here. Top it off with some lemon and it's perfect.

-It's cash only so make sure you bring enough
-Avoid coming in a large group unless you come really early and wait. Seating is limited
author: Michael C.

description: Great food and fresh. But the line is really long here, I have been waiting for 1 hrs to get close the door.
author: Edelino C.

description:
Swan Oyster Depot being name one of the best Oyster Bar in the states (example here&here) and also being featured in Anthony Bourdain's Layover episode here, this was a must eat place during our San Francisco trip.

Opened since 1912, this tiny 18 stools oyster bar is famous for it's hour long line up by both locals and tourist alike. To avoid the long line up, we decided to head there bight and early at 10:30am their opening time. The place was filled up right away and a line start forming outside, who would have guess there would be so many people who want oysters for breakfast.

It was a very narrow space with the bar running through the whole space with memorabilia and old pictures of the place

Love the setup in front of us with the crackers, mignonette, fresh horseradish and lemons


We were quickly offered some Sourdough Bread with tons of butter... Sourdough is basically synonym with San Francisco, I wonder if every restaurant there serve just that?! Don't get me wrong I like sourdough but I tend to prefer it on it's own with butter since the flavor is pretty strong, I find it a bit overpowering paired with other food.

Clam Chowder Bowl
~ Full of clams and potatoes, it wasn't very thick and heavy as I expected but still felt very hearty.

Clam Cocktail
~ All freshly shuck with all the juices served with a huge bowl of their cocktail sauce on the side.
~ Love how they kept all the salty sweet juices since it's pure goodness.
~ I thought the cocktail sauce was a bit too sweet, I prefer it a lot better on it's own since it was so fresh and sweet.

Dozen Oyster
~ Our server did carefully explain each of the oysters but we obviously didn't have time it mark it down before digging in. 

Crab Back
~ This wasn't on the menu but eyed it by their window and I just had to ask if we can order it.
~ We usually call it Crab Shell but we were told that it should be Crab back and yes we can order it on it's own.
~ I was in heaven, after sharing one it was just not enough so we decided to order a 2nd one. 
~ SO GOOD!!! Wish we could have gone back for another round before leaving.
~ Love my Crab fat! 

Note: Cash Only

Verdict:
~ The seafood is as fresh as you can get but love the atmosphere above all with regulars chatting away while waiting for their takeouts and deliveries all happening in the small space/counter.
author: Vickie C.

description:
Frankly, I am a little embarrassed to say Bourdain's show brought me here, but oh boy, am I glad I know about this place now! It's been in my bookmark list for quite some time, but this past saturday, the bf and I finally checked it out. We arrived around 2:30, and got seated after half hour or so. Wasn't too bad of a wait (I think the morning rain helped disperse the crowd). Adding to the hoards of rave reviews, I would also regard this establishment as a must-try. It is essentially a fish market rather than a restaurant, and seating involves rusty stools and a narrow counter. There were tons of jacket/purse hooks all around. All of this adds to the charm of the place.

We started with a small plate of sashimi. Delicious! I've never had sashimi with these flavors (olive oil, salt, pepper, capers, shallots) but it was so refreshing. My first bite was the scallop and I seriously could've eaten an entire plate of just those. Then came a half dozen of a mixed plate of oysters. So good eaten simply with the mignonette. Then the crab back was something new and very adventurous for me, but OMG, dipped in the bread, it was creamy and luscious. I never thought it would taste as good as it did, and I would come back just for bread and a crab back. Super indulgent and only about $6! We also got a crab cocktail, and I made basically mini open-faced sandwiches lol. Bread, a layer of horseradish, crab meat, and then topped with some cocktail sauce. $15 for a generous bowl of crab meat and no need to get my hands dirty, soo worth it. We finished the meal with a cup of their clam chowder, and it was very homestyle. A thinner chowder with some potatoes and a few clam pieces here and there, but big clam flavor. I was stuffed. The bill came out to around $55 before tip.

Service was good. Each group kinda gets their own guy/gal to help them (they may have 2-3 groups) so it's pretty personable. Our first guy was friendly enough but he kinda made a face when I asked for sashimi (it's not on their official menu). After our 2nd course, we heard him say bye to his coworkers, but he didn't say anything to us, so then another guy took us on as customers. Kinda awkward. Other than that, it was a great experience. We ate a lot of really good seafood, and it didn't break the bank! Just make sure you bring plenty of cash.
author: Rita L.

description:
I've been wanting to come here for years. Years. 
When my office moved in 3 blocks from here, I knew my time had come. 
Here's the scoop-
It's pretty much a no-go on a Saturday (waaaaaaaay too many tourists) and they are closed on Sunday. 
Go here on a weekday and have seafood as a late breakfast/early lunch. 
I showed up at 10:40 on a Thursday and there were 6 seats available. It was perfect timing because within 20 minutes there was a line of 5 people. 
Everything is good. Order what you love and they won't disappoint. 
I ordered the crab louis salad with the dressing on the side. It was about a half crab worth of meat over some plain ol traditional iceberg lettuce. I also ordered some melted butter on the side, that for me was an absolute win. 
I also got some oysters, I probably didn't need them but they were good!
The service is great, the guys know their stuff. They are a no fuss crowd but very friendly and informative. 
If you are done and you find yourself just sitting around waiting for the rest of your party to finish - try and get your tab and leave. They try and get you in and out, meaning if you aren't eating and you are taking up space, you are not helping with their turnaround. It's a very small space and there are a lot of people that want to get in and experience the amazingness that is Swan Oyster Depot!
author: Sarah M.

description:
My coworkers and I have been planning on making the trek from FIDI out to Polk for about a week to check out Swan. We got lucky and sat down 10 mins after arriving. The sashimi was definitely the best thing we ordered. The fish is super fresh and the capers and olive oil compliment it greatly. We also had the combination seafood cocktail, combination salad, clam chowder and crab fat. Everything was very good. 

The experience of sitting up at the bar with everyone was fun. The staff was great and I didn't feel rushed at all despite the line. One thing to note is that there isn't any hot food other than the soup. Not an issue, everything tasted amazing.
author: Eddie K.

description: I can't say enough about this place! We didn't have to wait due to heavy rain, but people came after 11 and had to wait. We ordered the Crab Fat which could be warmer and spicier. Not worth the money to me since we eat crab boils in TX and like more flavor. The shrimp cocktail was absolutely amazing, very small portions but worth the money. The clam chowder was the best chowder I've ever had. We also waited to try Sea Urchin since I've always wanted to. However it's like 6 bites so up to you if that's worth your money! The service was amazing and we would love to come back just to speak to the owner and workers.
author: Kim G.

description: Although the wait and seating is a pain, the food and the people there makes it all worth it. Was looking for live uni but they were out. The sashimi plate is just plain awesome. The scallop sashimi is like butter that melts in your mouth. The clams and oyster combination plates are every shellfish eater's dream come true. The staff takes the time to explain what everything is and they are funny guys. The crab back is something unique as well. A must visit when in San Francisco!
author: Andy N.

description:
This place is famous and known for their fresh seafood. There was a line, but it didn't seemed too bad. Either way, I just opted for to-go because I just wanted to try their clam chowder. If you get to-go, you can walk in, order it, and they make it right there. 

A bowl was $5.50 and the portion was pretty small. It was buttery and salty. Salty from the clams, but not too salty where you're thirsty. There were also small chunks of potatoes. I thought it was okay, but my bf seemed to like it. I also had some of my friends seafood salad $27. Thats probably the most expensive salad I've ever try. It was cold salad, with iceberg lettuce. The crab was good, but the salad was just okay. Probably won't be back, but if you're looking for the experience, then stop by and give them a try.
author: Vy T.

description:
I had very high expectation coming here after viewing the episode from travel channel with Anthony. We got here around 2 and we waited about 30 minutes which was not bad. We ordered the crab fat, oysters, the chowder, and the crab cocktail. 
-Crab fat was just ok. Nothing spectacular about it. 
-The chowder was almost like water. We didn't find any clams in it. 
-The oysters were actually really good and fresh. 
-the crab cocktail was good with the sauce they gave us. 
Overall, it was just an ok place.
author: Nicole H.

description: First time to write a review just because one of these guys was Racist as Fk. My GF heard of this place and really want to go so we went today, and since it's a Monday afternoon so there is like no waiting at all, but we were still standing there for like 10mins to wait until the table cleaned. And after we set, there's a old guy with glasses came over and asked us what we want to starting with. No hello, no how you guys doing, just So what you guys want to start. So We ordered our drinks, a clam chowder, the combination salad and half dozen oysters. While the old guy handing the chowder to us, I picked it up and said "thanks" to him, he won't let go and yelled to me"I won't let go". Totally pissed up and feel so sorry bout him. I literally ate nothing but just finished the beer. Won't coming back again, and going to tell my friends too. Telling all my Asian friends, this place is not welcome to you all.
author: ME Z.

description:
If you don't mind the long wait and need to get there early, you'll definitely enjoy Swan's. The oyster platter is what we usually come here for, but the smoked salmon and clam chowder are also good.

Sushi fans, do note that the uni they carry is locally harvested (not imported from Japan) so it has a distinct floral flavor that's different from what your typical Japanese restaurant carries.
author: Tasha C.

description:
I don't typically crave seafood and would rarely choose it over say a big, fat juicy medium-rare steak or a slab of bacon. This place though... wow! I'd gladly eat here everyday if I could afford it, stuffing myself silly with their fresh clam chowder and deliciously full-flavored assortment of oysters. 

If you're an oyster noob like me, I'd recommend starting with their kumamoto oysters. It isn't too briny so it's easier to eat and they're just plain awesome with a squeeze of lemon or some of their house chili sauce, which was spicier than I expected so careful there! 

To the Oyster Purists: I am working on eating them straight (like I drink my whisky).
author: Adrian D.

description:
A tourist trap, I wouldn't recommend it and I live here. It's Fisherman's Warth in Nob Hill, that's all. 

Cash only. 

One of the people there smoked his cigarette in the kitchen while doing work. 

The place is filthy, ZERO hygiene was respected. 

The food is whatever, worse than what you would get at any nice sit-down restaurant for the same if not higher price, and sit at an awkwardly shaped bar that you can't tuck your knees under and awful stool.

 I am all for authentic "whole-in-the-wall" but this is downright an unkept place.
author: Cristina C.

description: My favorite oyster place ever!!! The wait is super long since they only have bar sitting but the place makes you feel like you've been taking back and though it doesn't feel so clean, it's a very homey environment. Service is fast and nice but the main part is definitely the fresh seafood! I got the oyster sample platter and o.m.g. best oysters of my lifeee! The kunamoto and miyagi were def the faves they were so sweet and plump..I feel like I never knew oysters from different places could make such an impact but they do!! They all had a different taste and sized and texture but all so fresh and delicious! Definitely try the sample platter but I think most people agree the kunamoto and miyagi are the best! Cash only place but definitely come back for the oysters which are the bestt even with the long wait!
author: Ivana D.

description:
I came here before 11:00am on a weekday per recommendations

I had just enough change for two hours of parking

I had the don't f*** with me look when people walked by as I stood second in line at 10:15am (15 minutes before they opened)

I watched the sun peek through the clouds and begin to singe my vampire skin, but I did not stand down

I needed to eat here. To be sort of cool...for once

Finally as I felt my body starting to turn to ash, we were let in. The guys in front already had a place scoped out.. I panicked thinking apparently there must be a happening spot. Then I just sat down

The place filled up IMMEDIATELY. The personalities was plentiful as were the flies and non gloved hands..

I ordered oysters. Some tiny ones and apparently some bigger ones (blue point) Little ones went down easy. Biggens tested my re-re-reflex (sorry Duran Duran moment)

They were good with clean flavors, even if I did had some shell in there. Crunch crunch

I also ordered the half crab. While I prefer my crab warm this was (and I knew) served cold. It didn't matter though because the crab was nice and fresh and really only needed a squirt of lemon. Again clean. Not a hint of fishiness

My BF got the clam chowder in a cup and a Pepsi and enjoyed as well

Total for 6 oysters, half crab, chowder and Pepsi was $41.00. Not bad for a great experience. good food and fun atmosphere

Highly recommend, but come before 11:00am. As we left around 11:30am the line was horrendous

See picture of crab here:  http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/swan-oyster-depot-san-francisco?select=rjkBzOZuVxKwsw_0e643FQ#rjkBzOZuVxKwsw_0e643FQ
author: Rachael C.

description:
mmhmm.. I love my oysters raw. 

We arrived on a rainy Saturday afternoon and although the line outside didn't seem too bad, we ended up waiting for about 45 mins. Luckily, there was a coffee shop down the street that kept us warm!

The interior at Swan Oyster Depot resembles that of a fish market. Don't come here expecting a pristine table and restroom.. you won't get either.

We started our meal with a bowl of clam chowder and some bread. Now, when one thinks of clam chowder, you'd think of this homogeneous white bowl of substance with yummy clams and potatoes. Visually? it looked gross. If you've ever been to Orenchi and ate their ramen full of broth with lard pieces swimming in it, you'll know what I'm talking about. It literally looked like lard pieces were swimming around in my soup! Nevertheless, it tasted amazing! Not too creamy or filling. However, I would have liked more clams in my bowl. I think I ate like 2 or 3.. the rest were potatoes! booo I'm not trying to carbo-load before I feast!

Next we were blessed with a combo of a dozen oysters on the half shell. All were cleaned beautifully, with my favorite from Great Britain. Then we had an order of the smoked salmon, which I actually did not particularly enjoy. While the salmon was deliciously salty, the bread underneath it was soft and chewy. I would rather have had it toasted, and I think that would have improved the dish significantly. They were out of the cherry stone clams, so we opted for the (last!) uni and half a dozen eggs (sliced scallops topped with a dot of sriracha). First, the scallops- they were deliciously rich with just the right amount of spice. I loved it.. but not as much as I loved the uni. I've had fresh uni before, but only at the farmer's market and they don't clean anything for you. However, here at Swan Oyster was probably one of the best preparations of uni I've ever had. It was so beautifully cleaned, with the uni flesh all sitting together nicely on a portion of its shell. Drool. I'd come back just to have 10 more orders of it.

I'll be back for their uni and oysters..
author: Leslie C.

description: Worth EVERY SECOND in line, I waited 1hr. I was on vacation from Los Angeles and heard so many amazing things about this place. It's awesome, I highly recommend it!
author: Derick G.

description: OK- I get the hype.  We arrived at 10 AM - doors officially open at 10:30 AM.  There was a line up the block.  We got on line and patiently waited 1.5 hours before we finally made it to the counter for the coveted 2 seats.  We proceeded with the crab salad, with the Louis dressing on the side, 1 dozen mixed oysters, 6 cherrystone clams and finished it off with a dozen little necks.  OMG, the seafood is so fresh and you get a ton of crab with the salad.  Honestly, we didn't need to order the little necks, but before I knew it, the words came out of my mouth and voila, it showed up on the bed of ice, and I happily slurped away.  Damn you Anthony Bourdain! OK, honestly, I love Anthony Bourdain, and I have to say, he's right.  This place is freaking awesome!! I will definitely come back with visitors from the East Coast and take the place in line waiting patiently to get back in for more oysters and crab!!
author: Susan C.

description:
This place is amazing! Worth every second of the long wait, we lucked out the first time and walked in, this time, we waited almost an hour. I recommend you do it too, just remember to bring cash - there is a bank around the corner, we were part way through of lunch when we found out but they deal with this a lot, it would have been nicer to know before hand!

This small family run counter provides friendly conversation with the guys that work there who are clearly passionate about what they do. We ordered a couple of local beers and shared a bunch of food, clam chowder, crab salad, and the famous crab fat with tons of sourdough bread. The bathroom is in the back of the building, through a prep area, and amongst the coats and boots of the people who work there - that's alright it was clean and I had to go.

We will be back next time we are in that neighborhood of the city!
author: Sarah S.

description:
One of my favorite places in SF. It's fantastic. 

I got some inside scoop on how to eat the Crab Back (pardon the pun).
One of the sons shared his favorite preparation. Follow these instructions for some mind-blowing results:

Order crab back
Order crab cocktail (without the cocktail sauce)
Order side of mayonnaise 
pour crab cocktail in to crab back, and mix
Mix in decent spoon of mayo
Squeeze of lemon
Eat with sourdough bread

You're left with this robust, earthy, crab flavor that is fantastic. 
If reading this and you get to eat it this way, feel free to message me and tell me what you thought.
author: Nigel T.

description: Came at the end of the day so I didn't have to wait in any line (although I was only able to order for to go). I went with the sashimi platter which was a nice mix of their catches of the day. Everything was really fresh and some were melt in your mouth level. We also ordered the crab salad which was basically a bunch of fresh crab meat (which is not a bad thing by any means). Prices are reasonable if not a little high, but considering the popularity of the place and being some if the best seafood in San Francisco I can't complain.
author: Michael S.

description: Can't believe I didn't yelp this place!  My brother and I spent the day in the city and we just had to try to get in.  Tiny little hole in the wall - original floors and bar stools.  Had a blast!  Very hard to get a seat but SO worth the wait!  It was so nice meeting all the family that runs this restaurant.  As you can see we had a GREAT TIME!
author: Annette P.

description:
Discovered this great place few years ago, was looking for a sea food "for locals". Well, wasn't disappointed at all! Great place to have a fresh sea food in san Francisco, nice & fast service though cash only, which might be the blocker for someone.

Last our visit this December it was raining cats and dogs, so there weren't many people in a line and we got by the counter in less than a few minutes. In sunny days however, there could a line to wait for about 20-30 minutes. But it still worth of it. And that was a nice touch to have our faces recognized by the guys saw us last time two years ago.
author: Yevgen L.

description: Unbelievably great food.  It was well worth the 1.5 hr. wait.   We were in town for a bachelor party weekend and decided to grab lunch at Swan Oyster Depot.  It did not disappoint.  We had a sampler of the oysters as recommended by the waiter, and they were all great. The combination salad is loaded with seafood.  All very fresh.  Definitely recommend for seafood lovers.  Counter service....not great for large groups.  The line is formed outside the door, as stools become free, the next people are seated.  It would be difficult to seat a large group over 4 together.   The staff is very friendly.
author: David A.

description: We got the Crab Louie salad to go as my husband really wanted to try this place and they stop swaying 45 minutes prior to closing.  The person that took our order and put our food together did everything by hand with NO gloves.  He grabbed the lettuce with his bare hands, crabmeat, with his bare hands, bread with his bare hands.  Oh and he also helped others at the counter with their food and utensils and plates with his bare hands while getting our food together.  Basically, if you want to enjoy your meal, don't watch them make it... cause people are using their BARE hands.  I was completely appalled .. we paid for the food.. and walked out.  The salad looked like it should've been good.. but after what I saw.. I passed.  My husband ate his... he enjoyed it.
author: LeAnn B.

description:
Alright an update after seeing the "real thing". I realized that I was lucky until now for not experiencing the notorious "wait". 

also $$ ??? You are kidding right? This is probably the most expensive lunch you can have in the city. I always end up paying $60 when I come here.
author: Gokhan T.

description:
I waited an hour in the cold just to eat here.  It was well worth the wait. 

First of all, the service is fantastic here.  One of the guys misunderstood our order so he ended up giving up throwing in some goodies on the house.  We insisted on paying, but he would not hear of it.  The guys are all hilarious too. 

The kumamoto and blue point oysters were crisp and clean.  The crab legs were meaty and satisfying.  The crab head was extra rich and paired perfectly with the sourdough bread.  And the live uni was a buttery treat.  

Tips:
- Don't be afraid to go in a sit down if you see an empty seat if you're next up in line.
- Get here early as they'll cut off the line 30 minutes before closing.
- Don't try and BS these guys by telling them it's your birthday just to get in.  (Some guy tried to do this and they actually asked him to prove it by showing them his I.D.).
author: Kathy C.

description:
LOVE this place - too bad there's a long line to get in here, but that just tells you how much San Franciscan's love this place. 

Super Fresh Seafood everyday - served at the counter on a first come first served basis - and surprisingly good wine and beer available or a non-alc drink. 

This is a MUST TRY at least one time if you live or visit the city. YUM.
author: Rew C.

description:
With 18 stools by the bar, no wonder the wait time is always over an hour. 
With the warm day I went, the oysters are served warm on the ice. Sashimi is warm.  No matter how fresh they claim their seafood is, the store front is facing the sun with no AC. 
The guy who served us couldn't even name the oysters correctly. Maybe he thought we were just tourists and couldn't care.  
I believe this place is overrated and the food is overpriced.
author: M C.

description: As a bay area native I am surprised I have never been here previously, but I truly enjoyed my first visit and will be back! The most wonderful parts of this place are in the fresh fish, its history, and they hospitality of the staff. The only item I would not recommend is the clam chowder. I had my husband taste it too just to make sure, but something is off about it...at least it was when we visited or it was just not to our taste. This tradition of this place is one of the draws - but they might want to change this one dish. On the other hand the rest of the food was wonderful. I highly recommend the dozen eggs off the secret menu (thinly sliced raw scallop with dots of hot sauce on a ponzu sauce) My other favorites were where the very fresh beautifully cooked seafood was the star in the crab and shrimp cocktails. We also really enjoyed the Sicilian Sushi (scallop, salmon, halibut, Ahi and white tuna with olive oil, capers, and onion) We added a little lemon and it was beautiful! Oysters were super fresh and the sauces were nice. This place brings out the best in both tourists and locals - lots of conversations in line and at the bar -  all sharing their favorites and excitement about this special place. You must experience it even if you have to stand in line for a while - remember your cash and enjoy the wait!
author: J M.

description:
Swan Oyster Depot is a food landmark in the city and it's a surprise that it has taken me this long to try. I liken it to visiting Alcatraz. Tourists from all over line up to try it, but locals tend to stay away. The major hurdle for me has been the line. It took nearly an hour to get three stools at the very end of the long bar. 

The thing I love about this place is its iconic look. It seems as if nothing has changed for the past hundred years from the friendly service to the way they handle the check (written on the back of a napkin and cash only). It's something everyone must try once. We started our late lunch with the clam chowder. This is classic clam chowder at its finest. You get plenty of flavor without the thick, creamy texture. Add on the sliced sourdough bread and you have the perfect starter. Next, we had the crab cocktail. Simple, fresh crabmeat served in a glass cup with a side of tartar sauce. Lastly, we had an order of a dozen mixed oysters sans the smaller kumamotos. The oysters were some of the best I've ever had. Since our server was late on our order of oysters, our Anchor Steam beer was on the house. That's the kind of service that will keep this local to go back. 

The price for seafood isn't cheap so come prepared to spend.
author: Bailey Z.

description:
Please listen to me when I tell you, this restaurant is worth the wait! The most wonderful seafood in the city.
Everyone that works here is so pleasant, and a real West Coast vibe. No one is there to rush you, they want to make sure you enjoy the food!
Don't let the line outside intimidate you, it moves through fairly regularly.
author: Sandy W.

description: We went mid-week, early afternoon and didn't have to wait too long. Proceeded to spend the rest of the afternoon sitting there, enjoying as much of the amazing seafood as we could - weren't at any point rushed through our meal or experience there. Oysters so nice that we started with them and at the end had to order another round just because we couldn't bare to leave. Sashimi plate with capers was so fresh and tasty, the crab was full of delicious crab meat and the smoked salmon the best I've had. I'm only a visitor to San Francisco but plan to return here on every visit and recommend to anyone I know who's going.
author: Amalia M.

description:
Anthony Bourdain was recently spotted at the Swan Oyster Depot filming 'Parts Unknown'.  

In his words: "I'm fully aware of the fact that's it's like every show you've ever done in San Francisco, you come to the Swan Oyster Depot. Yes, that's correct. True love cannot be denied ... [It's] a touchstone in my worldwide wanderings. A happy zone. If I read about myself dying at this counter, I'd say to myself, 'That was one lucky guy.'"

Sounds like a 5 star review to me!
author: Diana D.

description:
the cherrystone oysters were so amazing. nice pop of sea water and sweet clam, needed absolutely nothing more than just a touch of lemon. We also got live sea urchin, which was a delectable treat! so fresh, sweet and creamy! beautifully and carefully prepared, great service for those who know what they want. the poor girl sitting next to me had no idea what she wanted. after asking for recommendations twice (she was ignored both times), i just leaned over and told her what i thought was outstanding. 

oh.... the clam chowder was NOT amazing.
author: Judy L.

description:
Cash only, so come prepared! Given the cost of seafood, I really wish they took credit cards. But the rest of our experience was 5 star worthy.

We went at 10:15 am and there was already a line forming. Luckily, we were still among the 1st batch of people to be seated.

The combination seafood salad is awesome: at $20, I got more crab, prawn, and shrimp than I could finish by myself. Everything tasted so fresh, juicy, and tender, each bite felt sinful! The last time I had such good seafood was back home in Vancouver. The housemade Louie sauce was excellent, and lactose-free since it's mayonnaise-based.

The combination cocktail consists of good quality seafood too, but can be skipped, since there's nothing special about the sauce.

Definitely save room for the oysters. The offering depends on the catches of the day. We got  to try three different types. The local one was by far the best, bursting with flavors that were accentuated by the natural sea salt in the flesh.

The old gentleman that served us was very sweet & knowledgeable. He made a point to give me bread without butter upon learning of my lactose intolerance. He also gave us a souvenir postcard at the end. The staff are approachable and attentive in general, but knew to leave you alone with your foodgasm.
author: Amy Z.

description: Service is excellent, they make you feel very welcomed. Expect to wait in line, we did (2.5hrs).  A must is the sashimi plate, the scallops were off the chart! Also had an assortment of oysters, so good! Prawn cocktail, my favorite. They ran out of crab meat but one of the guys set aside a small plate for us to try once we got seated. Overall very happy we checked this place off the list of places to eat in SF.
author: Tony J.

description:
I had no idea this place existed. Luckily fate intervened and I randomly saw this joint with a huge line on my way to a tuxedo rental shop with my bf. Since he had to return the tux a few days later, I figured we'd drop by then. Best seafood EVER. Best of all, it was a Monday, and we were 2nd in line after opening and people were seated. Unfortunately it was our last full day in SF so we opted to take everything to go so we didn't get the full experience.

We ordered the seafood salad and clam chowder. Seafood salad was amazing and such a huge portion! I also saw the guy making it and he was actually careful to pick out some huge chunks of meat to go into the salad. You know how there are some places that purposely go and pick the small crap to go into our food? Not this one. What made the salad was the Louie dressing. It's unbelievably tasty. On the other hand, the clam chowder wasn't what I'm used to. It had the clam flavor and the clams, but it was a bit watery.

From what I've heard, they might not have something you want on certain days. The day we were there, they didn't have uni and something else, which the photographer behind us was telling us about, so just be sure it's not a deal breaker (otherwise you're going to be very disappointed when you wait for an hour+ in line and not get what you want). I'll be back to Swan Oyster Depot for sure the next time I'm in SF, and hopefully they have everything on my list.

Also cash only, which sucks because ordering a lot can get tricky. Good thing there is a bank right across the street.
author: Corinna W.

description:
Wtf this place is bomb-diggity-hoo-hah!!!
Also iconic, but the quality is as fresh as it cam be. 
Wow, the oysters, i could die now, please and thank you. 
I love you and will come back every weeek. I will visit you more than my own Mother.
author: Danny B.

description:
Absolutely loved my experience at Swan Oyster Depot. It's a pretty tiny little spot on Polk, just a counter no tables. 

Food: 
The oysters were phenomenal, and the smoked fish was delicious too. Couldn't have asked for better quality. 

Service:
The setting and service make the whole experience even better. The characters behind the counter are super friendly and attentive, but in a casual and funny way that makes you feel right at home. The walls are covered with old photographs and autographed memorabilia, and the cash register behind the counter looks like it's straight out of the 50s. 

This place has been around for over 100 years, and it was easy to see why it's survived (and thrived!) for so long. Overall amazing place.
author: Josh N.

description: My dad used to bring us here when we were little as he worked on Van ness doing construction. Each time I go it's still the same as when I was a little girl. Everything is fresh and awesome. The horseradish sauce is to die for just alone.  I miss my daddie Mean Gene, so this place always makes me feel a little girl all over again with my dad.
author: Andy D.

description: Loved my experience here. Waited a solid 3 hrs but it was 11 am on a Saturday. Had the chowder, Sicilian sashimi, crab back and oysters. Food was perhaps 4.5 out of 5 but I loved the experience!
author: Dave W.

description: Great and fresh seafood, although you have to wait a long time to get in, we waited more than 90 minutes, but definitely worth to wait!!!!
author: Cher H.

description:
Over the span of a couple of visits to Swan Oyster Depot, I've managed to try both of the dishes that made the 7x7 list the past few years as well as a few others. There is very limited seating here and it fills up quickly so I learned to show up as they opened at 10:30 on weekdays to avoid a wait.

Crab Louie - 2/5 - Disappointing. The salad itself was just a pile of what felt like low quality greens. The dressing was a less than impressive thousand island and the amount of crab they give on top is just not large enough to make this deserving of the $23 they charge. It's not worthy of the top 100 list and definitely not worth the price. Skip.
Half cracked crab - 3/5 - I have had better crab. I'm not saying it wasn't decent, because it was, but I think there are better places to get straight crab dishes. The total amount of crab attained is shown in the picture below. Also not worthy of a top 100 spot.
Chowder - 1/5 - Pretty sure this came out of a can. If it didn't, that's even more disheartening because it certainly tasted like something you'd buy at the grocery store.
Smoked salmon - 5/5 - I loved this dish. The quality of the salmon was so good and seeing it sliced right in front of you off of a massive fish made it that much better. A generous portion of slices on top of french bread with oil and capers resulted in an extremely smooth and delicious taste. This is what should have made the 7x7 list and not the various crab items.
Oysters - I'm not going to rate the oysters because oysters are almost always good and these were no different. There's just not enough to differentiate oysters from one place to another aside from cost.

Overall, Swan Oyster Depot disappointed me numerous times but did end up coming through on my last visit with an amazing salmon dish. If I do ever end up coming back here, the smoked salmon will be my reason for returning. "I'm a fan."
author: Mark O.

description: Worth the wait, line, and effort to get here. The food is amazing and the service is awesome. The people working here and genuinely nice and patient and you can't beat the quality
author: E R.

description: The Swan Oyster Depot has been a favorite of mine for years and only now am I finally getting around to writing a review. Swan Oyster Bar...Oh how I love thee... Let me count the ways! If you are not in the mood for waiting in line then you need to get there when it opens or shortly after because everyone is trying to get in and it's very small. "Ask a local" is what they say. It's the truth! If you want to go where the tourists go, well then, you know where the Wharf is. Yes, the locals do know about this place and so should you. The seafood here is brought in fresh daily. Is there any other way to eat seafood? Family owned and family run. The interior is old school, relaxed and cozy. Your likely to sit next to someone you don't know, but not to worry. Everyone here has the same thing in mind. Eat, Drink and be Merry! The Crab here is to die for and the clam chowder was made right before I ordered a bowl. I watched him shuck the clams while making it. Every bite I bit into had clams. Can you say, "True Love?". Next I ordered a plate of lox. They cut front a large salmon  right in front of me then added capers and sliced tomatoes.  Damn! I'm totally craving it right now. A nice cold beer to top it off and I was in Heaven. I'm sure you'll enjoy it as much as I have.
author: George S.

description:
Four of us picked up dinner here one Saturday and were very pleased.
My friends ordered the same thing - the combo salad which had lots of good, fresh seafood.
I knew I could not finish a salad so I ordered a bowl of clam chowder.  It was very good with lots of clams and potatoes.  It was thin as many have said, so they need to use less stock and more cream.
The container was so large, I ate only half of it.  I will have the remainder for lunch.
author: Philip C.

description: Awesome place to experience and an awesome staff to sit and talk with while enjoying some of the freshest seafood ever!!!  Highly recommended to anyone!!!
author: Billy F.

description: There is no finesse to this place. If you took away the hype, you'd have watery clam chowder and frozen thawed seafood chunks dumped on a plate. No thanks. I'll wait in line at Hog Island Oyster Co in the Ferry Building instead.
author: Cathy S.

description: The Best crab salad ever. It must have had a whole crab in it. I couldn't finish it. Homemade dressing. Great staff and definitely old San Francisco feel. I won't waste my money or time at Fisherman's Wharf ever again.
author: Lois D.

description:
If you're a local and curious about why SOD is famous/has lots of street cred/has lots of good reviews on Yelp, do not fret! It is not worth your monies, because it is over-priced and caters towards tourists (meaning food doesn't have to taste as good since business will boom regardless) imho! You can easily pay $40/person here for lunch, ouchies.

The famous clam chowder was the most unappetizing thing I've had in a while, among things I've made or not. When placed in front of me, I was astonished (!) that it was broken, meaning the milk was curdled by being tossed in too hot a liquid. It was very, very unappetizing to look at, and as anyone who cooks knows, is texturally displeasing. At $5 a bowl, it was manageable, and I finished it somehow (because one must not waste!). The $1 butter + bread helped. But never again. Also...this in no way reminded me of the clam chowder I had while in Boston, which was muy muy better.

The crab salad was yummy, but not worth $15 for the small size. Then again, I'm not a crab connoisseur/snob. The kumamoto oysters were $15 for 6, which was fine, but again not worth it. You can get them in South Bay for $1/oyster. 

Best clam chowder I've personally had was at Princeton by the Sea in HMB. They also serve it in bread bowls. Please try it out for yourself!! It's delicious.
author: Sarah W.

description:
The wait is worthy!!!!  We waited for 1.5 hrs for 3 dozen oysters, sashimi, clam chowder, crab cocktail, and combo cocktail.  They are amazingly delicious.  
Very old school self serve!
author: Brandy C.

description:
The seafood here is good and fresh. But the restaurant itself is kinda dirty. So I have mixed feelings about this place. When I think about the food part it makes me want to go back. But the cleanliness makes me not.

They use their bare hands to make the food and handle money. The counter tops are dirty the floor is little sticky. The seafood sits out in front of the window display in the beating sun. So be careful of what you order.

I recommend getting  the salmon lox, sashimi, bread soup or an of the cocktails. If you must get the oyster make sure you put a lot lemon juice vinegar so your chances of getting sick are reduced.
author: Gilson C.

description:
I don't really get the hype about this place.. I felt it was expensive for what we got. $22 bux for half cracked crab.. Wanted butter to go along with it and it was $5..! So expensive. We also ordered the clam chowder but it was nothing special. 

The one positive is that I can tell it was really fresh. But other than that, wouldn't spend so much money on this place again.
author: Carmen W.

description: Came here on a weekday afternoon. A little bit of a wait but not too long. It is very expensive for a little tiny bit of food. Was not worth it at all. It is a very cozy environment. But the waiter didn't try to connect with us.
author: Katy L.

description:
This 2star rating is probably due to having my expectations set too high on this place. I had heard such amazing things about their fresh seafood and how great it was. Unfortunately I was a little disappointed. 
First thing to note here is that it is VERY expensive. Over priced actually. There are other options in the city that serve fresh seafood for a much better price. I am a SF local and it was pretty obvious that this place is a tourist trap. 
Another off putting part of my visit was the fact that they had run out of prawns, crab and chowder! It was 1 o'clock on Saturday. That really doesn't make much sense. 
If you're from SF lets leave this one to the tourists and go catch some crab ourselves!
author: Sam A.

description: Just strolled in one afternoon for a quick bite. The oysters were ok (nothing special), but the cherry stone clams were AMAZING! Wish I brought more cash so I could have eaten more of those incredibly sweet and chubby clams!  Needless to say, cash only here.
author: Chase B.

description: This place is a legend! It's been around since 1912 and still going strong! You have to try this place! I lived in San Francisco for years and didn't know about this place, but now I wish I had knew about it earlier. Definitely not cheap. Only bar seating inside. This place is crazy, they are only open for a few hours a day and close pretty early in the afternoon before dinner. And there is always a long line, sometimes wrapped around the block. You have to be on the line at least a half hour before the closing time. But believe me, all this is made up for by the incredibly fresh seafood and creative dishes. The crab fat (or crab back / guts / head / mustard) is outstanding. Also my favorites are the fresh live sea urchin in it's shell and the crab cocktail. The Italian / Sicilian style sashimi is great too. You have to love this place.
author: Peter K.

description: I wish there was a 6th star to give Swan Oyster Depot -- you absolutely must come here to sample the freshest seafood and best service you will find at a San Francisco eating establishment. Need I say more? No, just do yourself a favor, wait in line with some friends, eat the awesome food and die happy -- that is all my friends
author: Aaron W.

description:
Good Golly, Miss Molly. My visit to Swan Oyster Depot has to rank high amongst the best meals I've ever had. Certainly amongst the best breakfasts. 

Yeah, you read that right. Swan Oyster Depot officially opens at 8am but really opens whenever they're ready to serve. For us, we got there at 10am, were told 20 minutes, and came back around that time later ready to eat. Fresh seafood and Anchor Steam for breakfast? That garners an "America, F Yeah" fist pump.

For those living under a rock or that don't read anyone else's Yelp reviews but mine, service is old-school counter, with about 20 seats available as first-come, first-serve. With a large party, we tried to get there early but already found four people there when we entered. As we left, the line was four deep and no doubt about to get longer.

The servers are a bit churlish with the diners, but they share an unspoken snarkiness with each other. It's an attitude that shouts, "man, I'm dang lucky to be working at a timeless place like this." It's a great ambiance if you embrace it. Like poetry in motion. The "dirtiness" in the reviews is overrated: Swan Oyster Depot looks, feels, and smells like a damn good seafood diner.

Our menu read thusly: Clam Chowder. Oyster Sampler. Cracked Crab. Smoked Salmon. Quick review: Everything phenomenal. Words can't do justice.

The clam chowder is brothy, not overly thick, and a wonderful, eye-opening starter. The hot and cold contrast of clam to Anchor, chowder to Steam is ridiculously tasty. Crackers provided but not needed.

The oysters are fresh beyond belief and taste like they've come right out of the ocean. Squeeze of lemon, scoop of horseradish, dash of Tabasco. Winner winner, oyster breakfast.

The crab, piled high on the back counter, comes perfectly cracked for easy consumption. Just steamed, it's all-natural, delectable crab taste. If your lips aren't smacking by now, I can't help you. Try with the Louis sauce and you will be, guaranteed.

The smokiness of the salmon on perfectly textured French bread is like a perfect dessert. Make sure to get the bite with red onions and capers. I liked putting a dash of the delectably sour house vinaigrette to boot.

Just phenomenally, phenomenally good. A must stop on my next visit. Go early, get seated, eat breakfast.
author: Jeffrey C.

description: Swan Oyster Depot, touristy as it is, lives up to the hype. The only way to enjoy it is to be Zen about the lines, which are usually pretty long. The day I pick up a pound of crab there, that's when the Christmas season really begins for me.
author: Nate B.

description: This is a life changing experience! I will never come to San Francisco without eating here!
author: Phil S.

description:
5 stars for neighborhood feel and excellent Oysters, Italian sashimi (cuts of raw fish drizzled with olive oil and capers), prawn salad, clam chowder, raw uni (sea urchin) rinsed and ready to be spoon-scooped, smoked salmon, and virtually anything else that is fresh.

There's often a line out-the-door and limited seating (probably 20 at most) but if you happen to grab a seat at the counter, then do go to town!

Remember what you eat because you have to recite your order at the end and pay with...

Cash only!
author: Jerry Y.

description:
Came here with a friend and found the meal to be pretty solid and a fun experience. Not sure I'd actually return any time soon, given that we did end up waiting a solid hour after arriving 10:30ish on a Saturday. 

We got the combo seafood salad, the clam chowder, and the sashimi sampler, and some oysters of course!

I liked the seafood salad, although the bed of lettuce of course didn't really add anything to the dish. It comes with a dipping sauce that's pretty good. The clam chowder for me was great--very strong clam flavor with a thin, not too creamy broth. The sashimi platter was good but a little odd--kind of like Japanese meets Italy, as the  plate was drizzled with olive oil and sprinkled with capers. Oysters were solid.

I liked eating at the long counter and watching the family team dynamic. Felt very homey and almost a throwback to another era in the way the place operates--not a ton of family joints with 3+ generations working.
author: Sam R.

description:
Worthy of a wait in line. Been on a no dairy, no carb diet for 45 days but the chowder and bread were so worth it. Also had the combo salad, 1/2 crab, and "Sicilian Sushi". The hills of SF made us hungry. 
Highly recommended because of the food, headed back next time in SF because of the staff.
author: William F.

description:
SOD just topped my list of "must visits" when spending some time in San Francisco. All the praise proved to be true, while I believe any criticism to likely stem from isolated incidents of grumpy a-holes having bad days. I mean, how can you not love this place?!

With only 19 seats at the bar and a line stacking up outside, be prepared to wait. Once inside you'll find yourself plopped at the counter, elbow to elbow with the strangers next to you. The menu rests on the wall in front of you and just like everything else in the restaurant it appears to be close to if not original. Sure, I took a look at the menu ahead of me, but thankfully I also browsed Yelp for some menu selection inspiration. I'd look at my phone, then the wall, my phone again, the wall again... decisions, decisions. This is where things take a turn for the absolute best.

I stumble upon a picture of the "Sicilian Sashimi," check the menu, check the picture, check the menu, check the picture. Dammit! It's not on the menu. I casually ask our server, (who is also our busboy, stand up comedian, chef and one of the owners) if they have it and he replies, "yeah, it's just not on the menu." I quickly replied, "I'll take it!" What arrived a few minutes later was a beautiful plate of assorted fresh fish. Thinly sliced, roughly arranged, topped with onions, capers and drizzled with olive oil - it was a thing of beauty. So beautiful in fact that it almost stopped the restaurant in its tracks and I spent the next minute or two fielding questions from other diners, "what is THAT?!" The answer is: heaven on earth. With every bite I'd set down my fork, stare at the plate and savor what was happening in my mouth. After serving up my plate I almost felt bad as about four other plates of the Sicilian Sashimi were ordered while our chef/server stated, "it happens every time."

Sure, the wait is long but the food and service is absolutely excellent. It's more than just a meal... an experience, a trip back in time, a San Francisco right of passage. Sit down, take it all in and of course, order the Sicilian Sashimi.
author: Brad B.

description:
This place is the worst.  What a joke!

I, too, got suckered in by the lines out the door -- if that many people are eating there, it must be good, right?  But no.  Total tourist trap, as others have noted.  

The clam chowder was *broken*, and it was somehow thin as well -- not a chunk to be found.  No clams, no potatoes, nothing.  And being a broken cream-based soup... well, it was pretty gross. I had two bites and then put my spoon down, and I came in *starving*.

As for the seafood "salads", meh.  Cooked shellfish on iceberg lettuce --- NOT a big portion for the price, either.  

My waiter was a gruff jerk -- I heard him be a jerk to me and the two people on either side of me, which was a shame, because all the other waitstaff were nice; I heard 'em.  At the end, they even miscalculated by bill, tacking an extra few dollars on, but by that point, I didn't even care -- I just wanted to get out of there.

Never, ever again.  Never.  Don't be a sucker!
author: Eric B.

description:
I know I'm in the overwhelming minority with my rating here.. but I'm stuck thinking how many of these reviews were posted by tourists who haven't got to shop around our cities other great restaurants. Friendly staff and decent food, but the options aren't all on the menu which is kinda lame because there's no prices and there were secret items I would have love to have tried but didn't know they existed, the line is a beast of a wait, the portions are tiny and the prices are really high for just seafood drizzled with olive oil. 

  I appreciate simplistic charm and character of grittier establishments- but this place is a bit too raw and a bit too minimal for what it's priced- your receipt comes in pen on the back of a napkin. There are many better eateries folks, this place got featured on a tv show and now gets to enjoy being overrated for what it is.
author: Ryan B.

description: This place is old school!! The service is genuine.. They don't rush you...the assorted oysters were on point.. I had the smoked salmon platter as well.. It  was to die for... We had sashimi plate, They add olive oil and capers..... Its not on the menu and not Japanese style.. Definitely recommend.. We waited 1:30 to get seated. well worth the wait
author: Jesus D.

description:
The line is worth the wait. Clam chowder is briny and thin not the usual thick and creamy but it's pretty tasty. We had the mixed oyster on the half, fish carpaccio, combination salad (my favorite,) and a bowl of clam chowder. The experience is like eating directly off from the pier because everything's fresh. They even crack the sea urchin open for you per order! Yes, with the still moving sea urchin spine and all. My favorite dish from this seating is the combination salad which comes with very very generous portion of bay shrimp, prawn, and chunks and chunks of dungeness crab. 
If you don't want to wait, definitely try to get here when you have a day off in the middle of the week.
author: Taffany H.

description: I've had yelp for years and I've finally decided to do a review for one of the best seafood restaurant I've ever been to. Growing up in Hawaii we always had fresh fish but this place brought fresh everything to the table and we absolutely loved it.
