First off, the wait will be long, even on a weekday, as this is a tourist location. Having said that, that seafood is delicious and fresh! While not exactly cheap, the price is still quite reasonable AND you can buy the seafood wholesale by the pound for a very good deal. I had an amazing sicilian sashimi platter with olive oil, capers, and onions, based on a Yelp picture that I saw and asked one of the guys to reconstruct. He was very friendly and really happy to oblige and recreated a version with really amazing seafood, including seasonal scallops which were some of the best I had in the Bay Area. When I asked him how much it would cost (since it was off-menu) he said for a small plate it would cost me $10-$12. 

At the end of the meal, when a different person came to get the check, he was rude and said that my food would cost me $22. When I informed him that the guy who made the food said it would cost me $10-$12, he didn't even blink and randomly changed the price to $15. I'm not sure where these pricing points are coming from, and I didn't want to argue over $3/5 so I just counted that as tip and paid him. I realize that Swan Oyster Depot isn't known for service, but I do feel as though I could've gotten ripped off, hence the 1-1.5 deduction.
author: Kate M.

description:
Really disappointed by this place. I feel that it is insanely overrated.
For a place that doesn't accept credit cards and always has a line out of the door, I was really expecting something special, at least a memorable experience. Got nada.

Rus and I shared the seafood combo salad. They were out of crab, so they gave us smoked salmon instead. Everything was just fine on the salad, but it was all just cold seafood. No spices, no seasoning, nothing distinguishing about it. I'm not an inspired chef at all, but I definitely could have made this thing at all. I just don't get the rave behind it.

Not sure if we're missing something here, but definitely wasn't worth paying for parking and standing in line for.
author: Carol B.

description:
Just ate at Swan's for the 1st time in YEARS.  It was one of those rare occasions when there was no line out front & a seat at the counter when I was walking by.

Nothing's changed much except for the prices.  $15 for 1/2 doz oysters and $22 for 1/2 a cracked crab?  Yikes!!!!  However, a bowl of chowder and a glass of beer ONLY cost $5 each.  Add some bread & butter for $1 and that about as cheap a meal that you can get now at Swan's.

The beer was cold, the sourdough bread was fresh but the chowder didn't have many clams visible in it and the chowder was not rich or creamy.  So, despite the popularity e/ the tourists & TV show celebs, I don't think I'll be eating at Swan's again for many more years.

The only thing I do keep coming back for is their horseradish which beats the pants off of store bought but even the price for a small jar (4 oz, I think) has escalated to $3.50 from $1 but, even so, it's still worth the price.
author: Martin C.

description:
As an engineer, I always do a mini IRR on all things I partake in life. I know, such a nerd.

Swan Oyster Depot's IRR is out-of-the-park, you'd-be-stupid-if-you-didn't. Sure, there's a wait. Chill out and come prepared. For a single such as myself, I snuck in after just 45 minutes on a still-bumping-at-2-pm Friday afternoon. Not too shabby, but I still should've brought beverages as one clever gentleman thought to.

The seafood is amongst the freshest I've had beyond catching it myself. The oysters were Bluepoint (nah, I'll pass), Miyagi (oh, yeah!), and Kumamoto (hell yes!). The servers, while not uber-attentive, are into recommendations. Ask what's in today or seasonal. I ended up with fresh-off-the-boat raw sardines tossed in thier 'Italian' sashimi (i.e. olive oil, lemon, capers). All of the sashimi options are off-the-menu. 

It's quinticessential San Francisco at its best and most authentic.
author: Kaylin B.

description:
Tourist trap!! Run away!

...which is what I want to tell people so that the line here would get shorter.
Since I don't really know of locals who wait in the line to eat here, I thought that this must be like any of the other tourist-trap seafood joints by Fishermans Wharf. I was SO wrong. Their seafood is amazingly fresh and tasty. Their clam chowder, with the thin soupy broth that I prefer, is probably one of the best chowders I've ever had. Their smoked salmon was definitely the best I've had in my life -- perfectly smoky and perfectly salty, with a very fresh, meaty texture. Their crab salad was piled with tons of fresh crab. Okay, I'm a big fan of uni but I didn't like that one as much --- as Tiffany C. mentioned, it has a slight floral taste to it, which turned me off. The texture of it felt a little strangely dry, too.. but maybe that's how uber-fresh uni is supposed to taste?

Anyway, when I have some time to kill in the middle of the day and don't mind a wait, I'll definitely come back here to satisfy my seafood cravings!
author: Kazu O.

description: Been here many times over the last 10 years.  They don't just surive and stay in business without good reasons ...   Depends on the day, the time, sometime you just hate the line, other time, walk in just fine.  Simple reason to come, clam chowder, raw bar and a few pints.   There are time I notice the cream started to break down instead of silky smooth white (see my uploaded pix) but then the flavor of clam in the soup just beat everyone else.  There are many oyster bars out there with good oysters but this place is special.
author: CAScuba Y.

description:
SUPER FRESH.  This is any seafood lover's dream spot.  There's no fancy decor or other frills to detract from the main attraction - the food and also the wonderful staff.

Our order: a dozen oysters, clam chowder bowl, half-cracked crab, crab fat, uni (sea urchin), and a pint of Anchor Steam.  Everything was delicious and we loved the half-cracked crab so much that I had to make a second order.  

I'd eat here every week if I didn't live in another country.  Swan lives up to all the hype and then that.  The chowder was perfect with the sour dough bread that gets served.  The sour dough bread is also amazing when dipped into the crab fat.  The half-cracked crab was definitely the highlight.  Nothing but pure undulated sweetness and freshness of crab meat bite after bite.

Yes - the line is long, but in my opinion, the meal is worth the wait.  For those in a rush, go for take out and either bring it home or bring it to a nearby park or bench!
author: Jade C.

description:
Swans has had me hooked since my first time in 1999 while out here for ZAP and being a local now I really love it being able to get the best seafood in the Bay. 
Cheers Deano
author: Dean W.

description:
Zero stars.  Would be "negative" if Yelp allowed it.

Went here for lunch one day.  I told my then co-worker that we were going to SF, & she insisted that we come here to eat.  She raved about SOD & I had always wanted to try it since I heard so much about it.  BIG MISTAKE.  The guy who waited on me was condescending.  He pretended to be polite but was as fake as a 3-dollar bill.  I didn't walk out as I had waited in line so long & we were starving by that time.  

The wait time between ordering & receiving ALREADY-MADE chowder was unacceptable.  I got clam chowder & that was very watery.  It was like eating cloudy white water with a few potatoes & clams in it.  A roll came with my water - oops, I mean soup.  It was so hard that I literally couldn't eat it.  I couldn't even tear it apart.  If I had thrown it at someone & hit them on the head, they would've been seriously injured or died from the trauma.  My husband did not like his food either.  

I've had my share of clam chowder & this was the absolute WORST I've ever had, hands down.  I've had canned chowder that was way better, & I didn't have to put up with an attitude either.  

Save your time & money & go somewhere else.  There are plenty of options in SF that actually have edible food!
author: T. Y.

description:
I finally got to come here after years of wanting to!  The hours aren't that great and it can be really busy, but I had a week off Thanksgiving week, so I gave it a try.  

Okay, I was really impressed the food here. The oyster we're really, really fresh and tasty.  For being in the middle of polk street, I find the oysters here to be fresher than those at Waterbar.  We had a mixed dozen and they were all delicious.  Also had the Smoked salmon.  This was quality fish here.  Although it was smoked, you could tell it was a quality fish!  I was a little let down by the clam chowder.  I don't mind clam chowder being of lower viscosity, but it just didn't feel rich enough.  The flavor fresh clams is definitely there, but I can't say it was the best I've had, or even top 5, it just didn't stand out. 

Bottom line:  This place is pretty amazing and the people here know there seafood and how to prepare it.  You also get a show in fish preparation as they are a fully functional fish/seafood stand.  It gets crowded and the prices are kinda expensive, but it's a great find on polk street.
author: Veasna H.

description:
I've been coming here for years. Stuffing myself with oysters, crabs, sea urchin and other bottom feeders. When I come here I forget about my problems, I forget about work and forget about the hour and a half long wait I usually pull. 
So people need to stop bitching about this wait cause it's worth it. The staff is just the friendliest group of people and the food will have you wanting to come back.
Swan oyster depot. Heaven on earth.
author: Kelly T.

description:
Biggest concern: They lack proper hand washing! Ewww. 

As I waited in the long line for an hour, I had the opportunity to watch the servers prepare food with their bare hands and handling cash without washing their hands. They did everything from scooping up shrimp, wiping tables, shaking hands, and handling cash (they don't take credit cards). I hesitated and fought myself from wanting to leave because I so wanted to try this place out and I did wait a whole hour. The server was nice, and greeted us promptly. We ordered the combination salad, which was so expensive for a freakin salad! They ran out of crab so substituted it with smoked salmon instead. The salad was good, but nothing I would wait an hour for. The clam chowder was pretty good, but was on the salty and runnier side. The oysters  were really fresh and good as well. The place just lacked cleanliness and everything just seemed dirty to me. All the condiments were shared and did not look appetizing at all. I'm glad I got to try this iconic place, but the germaphobe I am will stop me from coming back.
author: Tay T.

description: I can't believe I physically stood in line for 2-3 hours for this. NEVER AGAIN. The food was soooooo mediocre. I mean not bad... but it's no different than other SF seafood restaurants out there. Like.... all they do is shuck oysters for you. How's that any different from other restaurants? It's not like they only sell special oysters topped with crack. Geez...
author: Betty T.

description:
I've been dying to try this place.  I mean it's a SF institution, AND I LOVE seafood.  However the line here is ridiculous so I had to go on a day off.  The question really is if the food lives up to the hype and is worth the wait?!?  I mean state bird is worth the wait, but T-pumps? hell no.

After waiting nearly an hour to get in, we ordered the sea urchin, crab salad, clam chowder, and smoked salmon.  The clam chowder is so good, I think I'm addicted.  The smoked salmon isn't something I usually order but was amazing.  The uni had a somewhat floral taste that I wasn't used to.  For the crab salad they really pile on the crab!  Definitely worth the wait, although getting food to go is probably also a good idea!
author: Tiffany C.

description:
We actually got lucky because we happened to walk up right when they were giving out the "last one" sign! 
If you're starving don't come here. Not because you won't get full from the food but because there's about an hour to 2 hour wait (that's with about 10 people in like in front of you) 
The food was super fresh like it just came straight from the ocean. I had the clam chowder it was very tasty although it wasn't very chowdery, more soupy and watery than the normal chowder but still very good! They forgot one of our items that we ordered :( the crab cocktail.. But we were getting too full and tired to wait so we said we'd pass. I'm not an oyster fan but I did try one... Still don't like it haha but my husband said its the freshest he's had. Overall good food, super dirty/fisherman feel to it lol .. If you like that. It was enjoyable :)
author: Briana V.

description:
Hands down, best seafood in San Francisco! 

If you want quality seafood at a reasonable price then this is the place! My favorites are the combo seafood salad with the Louie sauce and of course the chowder! (You also can't go wrong with a bed of oysters). 

I've been coming here since preschool and nothing has changed except for the fact I can now see above the counter. 

I can't wait to take my kids here one day.
author: Shannon R.

description: It's perfect. That's all you need to know. Embrace the atmosphere and have a great time enjoying the freshest seafood in SF.
author: Katenryan B.

description: This place was AMAZING!!! We waited in line for about an hour and a half. We arrived about 1030ish. BUT it was well worth the wait. My friend and I shared a plate of oysters. I had the combination salad plate... BUT next time I will just get the crab, it was so delicious. My friend ordered crab and our server showed us how to crack and eat them correctly. I highly recommend this place! I will definitely go back next time I visit San Francisco!
author: Nicole Z.

description: Came on Friday for lunch. We only had to wait in line for about 30 minutes. This place in tiny, loud and crammed. There were people next to us standing at the counter eating which made the limited space even tighter. Everyone was very nice and the service was fast. Not the cleanest place by far which did bother me a bit since I am a neat freak when it comes to food service. Neither of us got sick which was a bonus. Didn't see much hand washing between handling money and food. No one seemed to be wearing gloves. We had oysters, clam chowder, and crab. The oysters were very good, clean and fresh. The whole place is overpriced. Probably wouldn't come back, just a little too loud and dingy for my tastes. I am not opposed to eating at a counter but when I have no room to even move my arm and can't get my stool even close to the counter and drop $100 on food I expect a little more.
author: Erin K.

description: OMG... inspired by Anthony Bourdain to try out this restaurant while in San Fran. Definitely lived up to his praise. Got there 15 min before opening. Saw them unloading from the truck and prepping the fresh seafood. They put it out on display in the front window. We were excited for the fresh sea urchin served in the shell, but there was none for that day. Despite the setback we ordered clam chowder, oysters, crab and scallops. I highly recommend the crab back served in the crab shell. Soooo creamy and mild in flavor. It made up for my disappointment. Oysters were a winner too. AND the service fantastic. Each customer had their own server gentlemen that was attentive. Some were young, some middle aged. They would serve one dish at a time and always refilled your drinks. A great dining seafood experience.
author: Vee D. H.

description:
IF you're ever in SF, you should try this place for its AMAZINGG SEAFOOD.

The line for this place is RIDICULOUS. you'll see it, you can't miss it. It wraps around the street like damn..  you'll be thinking doesn't SF have any other seafood places? but of course, this place just takes the cake though. The wait is about 2 hours on average because the restaurant is really small, and it can only hold a few customers, which is why their service is pretty great! I love how you can converse with them as they're prepping your food, it has that great family run business feel! 

Food:

1. Crab Salad: OMG favorite salad in the world. The portion is pretty big so underestimate it for a salad. They give so much crab! The crab was fresh and soft, it was so good. AND the dressing, so creamy! This probably the one time where I would want to have salad for dinner.It was a little pricey but worth it in taste.

2. Oysters on the half shell: YES GET THIS. I really liked their oysters. Its fresh, slightly sweet, and tasted of the ocean. Put a little lemon and hot sauce in there and you have a seriously delicious oyster. They also have wine that goes with it. 

3. Clam Chowder: Their chowder was creamy! It was good, it had a lot of flavor and content but it was nothing too special for me, but definitely nice to have on a cold day.

4. Shrimp cocktail: It was good but nothing special for me. Get it if you want it, they do prepare it pretty well. 

I really love their hospitality and the atmosphere. It's super lively and just makes you feel like you're in a party! I just wish it wasn't so PRICEY ): but good seafood is never cheap.
author: Jennifer H.

description:
Timing is everything-- for a weekday lunch, we were lucky to grab three adjacent stools at the counter. Otherwise, prepare to wait and peer in from outside. The place feels like a hallway--basically just counter space and stools.

Clam chowder, oysters of the day, sashimi (italian style)-- all great choices. Definite repeats! 

Friendly guys, no frills, awesomely fresh selection of seafaring delights!

Be sure to stop by the ATM-- CASH ONLY!
author: Jenny H.

description:
Oh yeah buddy. Oysters, salmon, seafood. This place was visited by none other the man himself, Anthony Bourdain. And was he right, this place is awesome! I enjoy eating oysters and so I came here one afternoon with a friend and his mother. This place rocks. Fresh oysters straight out of the bay and was it yummy.

The price is a little meh, but what do you expect getting food this fresh? I ordered a cocktail as well as some oysters, in addition to some clam chowder. I really enjoyed my experience here, however it did seem a bit cramped. I'm not going to complain about that though, I would recommend you to come on a weekday instead of a weekend as I have heard the restaurant cutting the line when it comes close to closing time. 

Overall, this place is a have to go to kind of spot. Don't go to fisherman's wharf and deal with tourists and the okay food (I can't complain though because I'm from NC) and come here and have some delicious oysters. (they have salmon too if you're not into oysters!)
author: Bruce K.

description:
Got here an hour before this placed closed on a Saturday and was one of the last parties seated. I would recommend not coming in a large party as the place is small enough as it is and you get seated immediately whenever bar space opens up. We ordered two dozen of the mixed oysters. I can't remember which oysters they gave us but there were 3 types and all of them were fresh and delicious. They pair really well with lemon and tabasco sauce they give you.

I also ordered a bowl of the clam chowder. The chowder is a bit more watery than what I would've like, but it had great clam flavor . I prefer my chowders to be of the richer, creamier variety. All the servers were incredibly nice and I never felt pressured to leave quickly even with the constant line out the door.
author: Kevin N.

description:
What can you say.. it's probably a little bit of a tourist trap, but I found it to be almost worth the wait.

This establishment is cash only. The staff is very friendly, but they are aware of the line forming on the block.

My group waited almost 2 hours. This would have been longer if it weren't for three groups that decided they could not wait any longer. Some dbag with a guitar came mid-wait and played a bunch of tunes for the same section of the line. He left after an hour, because he realized he wasn't going to get any more tips then he was already given. 

Once inside you get to sit on a bar stool and the ordering starts almost immediately. They aren't going to wait around and let you settle knowing you are probably hangry from waiting, and the line is still out there. 

The calm chowder was really good, oysters were obviously really good. Seafood combination salad was also good. I was UBER disappointed because they did not have sea urchin. After seeing MANY MANY pictures of it on yelp I was so freaking excited. I felt a bit crushed :(

The seafood is great. I saw the had a high health rating over 95, but no one here uses gloves... Turned me off.. A LOT. I am slightly OCD, and I could NOT get over it. 

Honestly, I'd wait if you had the time. Would I come back? Maybe, if they had Sea Urchin. I'll call ahead to make sure.
author: Mina C.

description:
Swan has odd hours. From 10:30 am-5:30pm and there is almost always a lineup. From what I understand, this place is not just a restaurant, but sells fresh fish for take home, as well so the morning catch is fresh as can be. A fellow foodie in San Fran implored me to NOT go to Fisherman's Wharf, but to check this place out. I arrived around 4:30 and people were still waiting to get into this tiny little diner-esque spot. Decor is no frills wood paneled walls and a long bar with just a few tables all decorated with one bud in a tasteful vase.

Right before closing a seat opened up at the bar and I was beckoned over by a nice waiter in a white shucking smock who asked me if I wanted a drink. I ordered a Sauvignon Blanc and he whipped a bottle from an ice filled bus bin and took my order for the Clam Chowder, Shrimp Cocktail and 6 beautiful Oysters.

The Chowder arrived piping hot with tender clams and potatoes swimming in a creamy broth. There was a lot of flavour to be had here. My shrimp were plump and juicy, firm and fresh with a cocktail sauce that the waiter eagerly adjusted with some killer hot sauce for my palate from hell.

The oysters were fresh, sweet and tasted of the salt sea water. A little lemon and some fresh horseradish and I am a happy gal indeed. Just when I thought it couldn't get any better, the waiter wiggled the wine bottle in the air and raised his eye brows at me. I frowned, because I had to drive. He said "It's just a bit. On the house, and you take a nice walk before you drive!" I liked this guy and I loved Swan. This is one of the first places that I will revisit when I return to San Francisco.
author: Jenny N.

description:
If you want FRESH...this is the place to go. Wanted to experience what the hype was.

Went during a weekend, 04/11/2015, and found a great parking spot near the SWAN oyster depot. Stood in line for about an hour which was fairly a good wait.

PROS: Anything you order looks good and TASTE great. Tried the combo seafood salad and smoked salmon sandwich. it was SUPERB!!! Wanted to order more on their menu list,but it was CASH only - so limited in being able to try other things. (Fail on my part, should've known better )

CONS: Its a VERY small bar. Basically it's eat and go meal ... as everyone else is standing in line waiting for their turn, but "mean mugging" you to hurry up (lol). As soon as you sit down, best to know what you'll be ordering. There is no time to have a decent conversation with anyone.
This place can accommodate about 20 seats - but what felt really uncomfortable was sitting close to everyone (literally elbow to elbow). Sitting on the barstool was totally uneven, but that never stopped me from eating.

Love the old skool cash register...and it still works.

Keeping my options open on coming back again, but not anytime soon. Will be trying other seafood bars in San Francisco first.

Thank you for a great experience!
author: Mel L.

description: Crab Back, Crab Cocktail.. hold the sauce, Fresh Oysters, Clam Chowder, and hot sauce. DO IT. The food here is fresh and the service is fast. The freshness is amazing and let me just say, that crab back... made my night. The place is small so be prepared to wait unless you come during an off hour.
author: Marlene T.

description: Go for the experience. Set your expectations accordingly. Expect to pay more and wait more than desired.
author: Connie L.

description: Showed up here on Saturday at 4pm. There was a short line and I was informed they were no longer serving people. I'm not sure if this is a thing but I walked in the rain to get here and was turned away. I could see the delicious fresh seafood in the window but was not one of the lucky ones. I am disappointed and sad. But I am not deterred, I will eat oysters and crab today, somewhere, somehow, as Yelp as my witness.
author: Lori C.

description:
Crab Salad. That is the play.

You: "But I don't want a salad; I just want crab"

Seriously. Get the crab salad. It's just a ton of crab meat (more than the crab cocktail) on a bed of shredded lettuce. So... in other words... AWESOME. And get the Louie dressing on it--not exactly sure what it is, but it's creamy and delicious.

I also like to start my meal with a bowl of their "Boston" clam chowder. I put Boston in quotes because I used to live in the Boston area, and the clam chowder in that region is always, in my experience, called New England clam chowder. I only bring this difference up because the taste and consistency of Swan's "Boston" Clam Chowder is notably different from that of a classic bowl of New England clam chowder. Rather than describe those differences here, I'll just encourage you to keep an open mind and palate when you embark on your first bowl at Swan's and to resist the urge to compare it to your favorite New England clam chowder. Also, don't be afraid to dunk your bread in there.

It's a good time.
author: Lex C.

description:
In playing catch up with my reviews for some idiotic reason I left out Swan's. Which is a travesty in so many levels.  I'll keep it short because anyone who bad mouths the place should be completely ignored.  

It's simply the best place to get fresh seafood. Sure the line is long. Deal with it. If anything you'll cherish it more once you're inside.  It's seafood done simple and amazing. They do very little to the dishes they serve.  As they should because it would only take away from the freshness and natural flavor really really good seafood has. Just go. Stop reading. Hell you shouldn't even have gotten this far.  You should be in line playing Candy Crush and Instagraming pictures of the fish waiting for you in the window.
author: Joco F.

description: these people are so much fun and inviting. You can't hate something thats been around for generations. things i recommend to get! oysters! such great quality and sweet (all 4 different kinds). the po boy with louie sauce, MOUTH WATERING! the crab guts in the shell...forgot what its called but i wasn't too much of a fan. sashimi platter with olive oil and capers...wow! wish I tasted sashimi like this instead of always eating it with soy sauce. go early and it's worth getting a seat! oh wait, forgot...clam chowder has big chunks of clams and just so good!
author: Claire K.

description:
Saturday, following a recent show of Anthony Bourdain's 'Layover' featuring Swan Oyster Depot, 1 hour and 45 minutes wait (my friend and I caught up on everything under the sun during our wait, time well spent!) - and this time I had cash!

We had amaaaaaaazing seafood, and the wait was worth it!

* Crab cocktail (lovely, sweet, fresh and oh so tasty)
* Bowl of clam chowder (mmm, warm, comforting, nice consistency)
* Thin sliced scallops with olive oil, red onions and capers (fresh, raw, nicely flavored, yumm)
* Smoked salmon on sourdough (got a half order, perfect combination with the sourdough, smokey wonderful flavor)

Loved it, ooo, mmmm!!  And will definitely be back!!  :)
author: Maile N.

description: We tried crab back, oysters, crab cocktails and sicillian sashimi. Crab back was good, but the rest were not impressive at all. Crab cocktail was waste of money. The service was not good. It was good to try once, but I will never go back.
author: Ashley K.

description: My wife and I have been looking for a place where we could get fresh seafood for a fair price while enjoying our environment and we have found it! We had a short wait outside but it was well worth it as we watched everyone depart with a smile. Once seated we began to enjoy the interaction between the staff and customers and were quickly drawn into conversation ourselves. Once our meal arrived I saw the look of approval on my wife's face and knew that we were in the right place. Everything was fresh, tasty and properly proportioned and left us completely satisfied. We were afforded the opportunity to eat at our own pace and to enjoy our meal and were not rushed to leave or pay. Upon finishing our meal we peacefully handed off our seats to the next happy participants at Swan Oyster Depot knowing that we had to leave in order to come back.
author: Matthew K.

description:
I went because it was all the hype! its been written up a long and there is always a line. 

I would say yes the oysters were fresh and delicious. But $30/dozen is a little pricey in such a casual atmosphere. We did get to try a bite of the smoked salmon, which was amazing but I wasn't in the mood for a whole plate. 

The clam chowder was just okay, i wouldn't order it again, it was pretty bland. 

Overall it was good, but very expensive, and definitely not necessarily worth all the hype.
author: Lily C.

description:
Swan Oyster Depot should be made a San Francisco landmark because it (in my mind) pretty much has the best of everything that San Francisco should be known for.

People
San Franciscans, regardless of what neighborhood we're from, are proud, genuine, accommodating and sometimes kind people. All the employees I've seen at Swan Oyster Depot seemed to live up to this mantra very well: they were all extremely professional and proficient at their job; they would tell you straight up what's good and what's bad (in terms of the catch); and they accommodate based on your needs (need food to take out? no problem! a party of three but only two chairs? your friend can stand if he's cool with it). Even the customers (the regulars, as I have come to understand) here on my particular visit were very understanding: they would scoot down further in the narrow counter place so other can sit--one lady offered me her spot because she believed that soup should not be consumed standing up. Only in San Francisco.

Atmosphere
Swan Oyster Depot is smack-dab in the middle of Nob Hill, which due to the nature of the residents that inhabit the area, are one of the more pleasant and "cultured" parts of town, and by way of semantic inference, the least offensive part of town. I won't bore you by going into details about how Nob Hill was destroyed by the 1906 earthquake, and its resurgence to the heights of affluence that it has currently attained is a testament to the will and fighting spirit of the San Franciscan people, since I assume you probably know that already.

Clam Chowder
Every now and then, I like to blaspheme and proclaim that x has the best y that I've ever tasted  in z. I would like to invite anyone to try Swan Oyster Depot's clam chowder and tell me you've had a clammier, richer chowder. I will gladly pay top dollar to anyone who can indeed point me to the right direction.

Florid and pseudo-intellectual discussions aside, the Combination Salad is a culinary dream come true and a must-have. From what I've been told by others who have frequented this place before me, the ingredients that go on the salad changes every now and then, but I got a soiree of shrimp, prawn, smoked salmon, and another smoked fish that I cannot remember for the life of me. 

For those of you (like I've done myself) that are planning on ordering the Sea Urchin (or Uni, to you foodies) because you've seen millions of pictures of it floating around on your friends' instagram feeds, the type of Sea Urchin that they serve here is different from those typically plated in Japanese sushi restaurants, and has kind of a paint/chemical-like after taste. It's palatable, but probably very different from what you may or may not be expecting...
author: Scott S.

description:
So freaking great!!! The freshest seafood I have ever put in my mouth.

Swan Oyster Depot is like stepping back in time (it is 101 years old!!).  They are basically a restaurant with one long counter.  Simple.  Not fancy.  Most of the time there is a line to get in but the day I came my friend and I were able to walk in and grab 2 free seats (the only 2 seats in the place available).  You order from the menu that is up on the wall.  Ask about what was just brought in off the boats.  There is a window in the front packed with ice that has the fresh seafood on it.

I had the raw oysters and crab salad.  Of course I had an Anchor Steam beer on tap with that.  No excuse not to drink some with your seafood (unless you are not a drinker).  

Soooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooo great.  Ohmahgah.

I loved chatting with the people who were sitting at the stool next to me.  Great place to talk to other people since you are sitting so close by.  Note:  you get their home made sourdough bread when you arrive.  

Things To Know:  CASH ONLY (sneaky devils).  The cash register they use to ring up your food is from like, the 1930's.  This place has had a lot of the press over the years and in recent times.  It was recently featured in Anthony Bourdain's San Francisco edition of his Layover show and a few weeks ago was named as one of the top 20 restaurants in America by Bon Appetit magazine.
author: Heather F.

description:
If you see a line as long as this, you know they are onto something. An hour long wait was easily cut down in my mind as the owners of the shop started to hand everyone in line FREE BEER. I'm not talking samplers, but whole cups of beer with plenty of refills. I know this place strives off of customer loyalty, but man are they doing it right. The owners are friendly and have kept it a family business for decades and I can see why they are so popular.

Finally when we sit down, one of the younger sons of the place became our "personal chef" and helped us with our orders. The smoked salmon and capers was my favorite dish of the day. Normally I'm not a big fan of capers, but this dish was so perfect. The clam chowder here actually tastes like clams, instead of the regular thick white ones that just taste like cream. The dozen oysters were good, but they weren't that fulfilling. I seriously want to come back again just to try the half cracked crab (one of Anthony Bourdain's favorites) and the crab salad (sold out when we went). No cards accepted here, so remember... straight cash homie.
author: Jay R.

description:
AMAZING, FRESH, TASTY SEAFOOD!! Narrow and small, but this little place packs a punch to its menu.  The staff was on top of the service, friendly and def know their menu.  Lines form as early as noon.  So best to get there early to get seats.  

Dozen Variety of Oysters $28
Smoked Salmon $9-10
Prawn Cocktail $9-10

All the condiments are all out on the counter.. AMAZING FOOD.
author: Becky U.

description:
Your first and last stop for the freshest, most delicious seafood in San Francisco.  I've been a customer my entire life.  There are plenty of great reviews to read, so I will simply provide a few hints/helpful tips-

1) Cash Only
2) Most of my patronage is for purchasing fish/shellfish to consume at home.  In fact I have only eaten AT the restaurant counter a couple of times in my life. They will cut tuna, sole etc to your specifications...
3) When buying seafood to purchase to go, DO NOT WAIT IN THE LINE.  Walk to the front corner of the counter near the door, and someone will promptly take your order and help you out.  The line for the counter could be 20+ people deep, but its ok- this is the protocol here.

Well, thats about it.  Swan's is your solution if you crave fresh fish.  End of review.
author: Andy S.

description:
This place is amazing!  

Just like everyone else said the wait is really really long.  I waited close to two hours before being seated.  What makes this probably one of the worst waits ever is the fact that you have to stay in line as opposed to putting your name down and coming back in 30 or so minutes.

It's bar seating only and it can get pretty cramped in there.  But the staff is super friendly and when one of the guys noticed I didn't have a place to hang my coat or purse he found some space for my stuff on the side.

When you sit down you'll notice a variety of sauces on top that's more or less a free for all.  I saw Tobasco, horseradish, etc.

We had the infamous clam chowder.  I see how some people really like it and others don't.  I personally didn't.  I wouldn't even really consider it a chowder since chowders are usually a stew or thickened soup often made with cream or milk.  This is more of a clam broth.  It definitely has a strong clam taste to it but none of the heartiness that is usually associated with a chowder.  

Ordered a half dozen raw oysters.  They didn't have my favorite kumamoto but they did have some kind of mix kumamoto and something else and I still really liked it.  The oysters were super fresh and briny.  They give you the standard cocktail sauce.  They also give you this dual sauce tray where one bottle holds their own mignonette sauce while the other side has some kind of green thai chili and habanero sauce.  That sauce is freaking awesome and I ended up putting it on my salad.  I wish I could bottle that sauce and bring it home with me.

We also ordered the combination seafood salad.  I was worried at first because I don't like heavy mayo based dressing, and it seemed from everyone's review the dressing for the salad was some kind of remoulade.  But you can have the dressing on the side and a little bit of the dressing with the divine green chile sauce and it was just deliciousness for my tastebuds.  The salad is a pretty hefty portion and if I was a moderate eater I probably could have been satisfied with just the salad.

Next we got the combination sashimi sicilian style.  It was basically some tuna, salmon, and scallop sashimi drizzled with olive oil (it's actually more than a drizzle it's a generous hand with the olive oil) and topped with fresh cracked black pepper, diced red onions, and some capers.  This was something interesting to the tastebuds but I probably won't order it again the next time (and yes there will be a next time) I come to Swan Oyster Depot.

And for dessert we ordered another half dozen oysters.  I couldn't leave without having one last taste of briny smooth deliciousness.
author: Jennie K.

description: There are plenty of places in San Francisco to get oysters. I've been here once, waited for an hour. The food was good, the people working were rude. It wasn't worth the wait. If there is a line out the door, don't bother wasting your time. There are other places that are nicer, have better service, have more than 20 seats, and have the same prices.
author: Samantha S.

description:
Visited SF for my birthday and was recommended this place by a friend.

I had looked it up on Yelp before my trip and this made my absolute have to do list. 

Needless to say they didn't disappoint. I wanted to get here before they opened. I really wanted to try the Sea Urchin. But we got there probably closer to 11:30am and were seated by 12pm. 

It's really small and only bar seating available. But the service was wonderful and the food was even better. It's worth the wait if you love seafood as much as I do. I think I was an otter in another life, haha. 

LOVE THIS PLACE.
author: Tiff Z.

description: In my mind there are two top seafood raw oyster restaurants here in San Francisco that you must try... Swan is one of the two! Very cool, small 'old school' vibe. Little seating at a small countertop. It is all so cool and fun. The guys there are very friendly and knowledgeable. Amazing oysters, crab, you name it! I recommend them.
author: Kirk M.

description:
This would be a five star experience if only I didn't have to wait a few hours to get in. A couple mistakes made: 1) Never go on a weekend or in our case a holiday weekend (4th of July weekend) on the Friday before they will be closed for a week 2) If you don't want to wait, just order to-go! Locals know what's up. Tourists like me are just rookies.

Food - Worth the wait and very tasty
- Oysters - Had 3 different varieties and I didn't keep a note as to what types they were. One stood out completely that was creamy and flavorful and I believe they were from Nantucket?
- Raw Clams - Ordered this twice. They were the littlenecks. They were out of the cherry stones. These little necks were meaty, briny and so good.
- Smoked Salmon - Comes with a small shrimp salad. I would highly recommend this. Smoked in-house and served on toasted bread with capers & red onions. The salmon is nice & oily and the wood smoke comes through
- Sicilian sashimi - I know everyone raves about this but this was just okay to me. We had bluefin tuna and a couple different types of scallops topped with olive oil & capers. The olive oil takes away from the true flavor of the seafood you are eating but this is a bit different than anything you would normally find anywhere else.

Is this place worth it? For the food, absolutely! Would you wait greater than 2 hours just for a meal? Maybe. I'll tell you right now that the family that runs this place are top notch and even brought me out a free beer while I was waiting. Now that is what you call customer service! Damnit Bourdain! You gave away a local secret to the rest of the world and it's worth it!
author: Mike G.

description: OMG this place is good. I'd been meaning to go for two years and finally did when friends were in town from the east coast. I had every kind of west coast oyster (2 dozen in total) and I didn't want to leave. They're also extremely nice and helpful and will guide you on the path to oyster nirvana. The crab cocktail is also amazing. I want to go back every weekend now!
author: Lauren C.

description:
Two hour wait on Saturday but I did go at 11:30am.  Go early else bring snacks and drinks, or buy one from inside.

The bar seating was a different experience.  It was nice, they took their time explaining the different types of oysters and other offerings.  We went with a combination seafood salad, clam chowder, and the sashimi plate.   No oysters...I know - Swan Oyster Depot and no oysters?  We had just gone to Tomales Bay the prior weekend so were oystered out.  They source from the same place only difference would be the cocktail sauce.

The chowder came first.  Not are creamy as most but still carried good flavor.  You can taste and smell the freshness of the clam and whatever else was in there.  Served with bread, butter, hot sauce on the side, and some crackers.

The salad was next.  It was an generous portion of prawns, crab, and shrimp over a bed of shredded lettuce.  The dressing was on the side so you can adjust to your personal taste.  What really made the salad was how fresh the seafood tasted...coupled with a bit of their dressing.

The sashimi plate was not on the board but available.  It was freshly and meticulously sliced salmon, scallops, and tuna topped with olive oil and capers.  It was ok and I prefer the standard Japanese version for the salmon and tuna.  The scallops were better with the olive oil and capers.

Next time I am doing take out.  Really fresh seafood and friendly staff but not worth waiting again for 2 hours.  There are only 2-3 places in the world that I would wait for 2 hours for food every time.  

Like others said before - bring cash.  If you forget, there is a bank across the street and you have plenty of time to grab some cash while your friend waits in line.  Parking is street but not too bad even on weekends - a few blocks is good exercise.
author: Roy L.

description:
Taste: 5/5
Presentation: 5/5
Quality: 5/5

It doesn't get much fresher than Swan Oyster Depot. After renting a bike and struggling up the inclined streets of SF, I made it to the foodie destination. 

The clam chowder is in the style of New England but not heavy by any means. The consistency was runnier than expected, this is mainly due to the ratio of clam juice to cream. At $2.50 this flavorful chowda is more affordable than the $5 versions down by the wharf. The combination seafood cocktail ($12.95ish) was a delectable melange of shrimp, prawns, crab, oyster, and clam in a smooth cocktail sauce. 

Highly recommended!
author: Matt R.

description:
This was a complete waste of time & money.  Ever since I saw this place featured on Anthony Bourdain's show, I've always wanted to try it.  I first went on July 4th  and was so sad to find out that they were closed.  I had called the place in fear that this might happen but they didn't even have the decency to have a message to let patrons know about the closure.  So I finally found time another day to try this place out.  After an hour wait (1-2pm) standing in line, we were finally seated.  It's true, the person does touch money and that same hand grabs fresh seafood that goes right on your plate.   They don't use gloves.  Ok fine.  I guess these are characteristics of "hole in the wall" places.

About the food.  You pay a steep price for what you get.  Portions are small.  For 2 people to be comfortably full, you have to spend at least $150.  That sashimi platter was a joke.  They take ONE scallop and slice it into slivers.  It is drizzled with olive oil.  You lose so much of the natural fresh flavors.  This is a bad way to enjoy fresh seafood.  I was so disappointed to learn that the fresh uni that I was so looking forward to was unavailable.  After spending almost $100 bucks (no tip included yet and still not full), we decided that this was pretty ridiculous.  We ended up going next door to Nara sushi to fulfill our appetite. 

Don't waste your time (or money).  Sadly there is no hype.  So many other fantastic places to eat in this beautiful City.
author: Sandra L.

description:
I like the freshness of the seafood here, but can someone please explain to me why I just paid $32 for a tuna sashimi plate?  Especially when most of their other items are priced below thirty bucks?And it wasn't like there was lots and lots of tuna... The portion size was moderate.  

I've been coming here for years and never felt overcharged until today.  Also the price wasn't posted anywhere otherwise I would have noticed and probably ordered something else.
author: Jordan H.

description:
We finally tried this place after hearing so much hype. One time, we tried walking over once on an early evening, to find out the line had already been cut off. 

This time, we got there at 1:40 pm on Tuesday and there was not really a line thankfully. The 3 of us ordered a cup of the Clam Chowder, the Crab Cocktail, the Prawn Salad and I got a Half Dozen of Mixed Oysters. Our bill was $62! Crazy high. This is ludicrously expensive.  Yeah..it's seafood, but the same dishes are definitely cheaper at other joints.

A few nice remarks: This place is nice because its a family-run business with lots of old-timer regulars that have been going there for 30+ years. ((They must be very wealthy to afford coming here so often))

This place isn't so nice because it's just a cramped long counter, and it's difficult to go with more than 1 other patron and expect to sit together or even comfortably. We saw a group of 3, and 1 guy had to stand behind his friends. The stools are also all different heights which is ridiculous.

We were a group of 3 (I was with my boyfriend and his mom), and one of the employees asked us if we wanted to take a seat and have one of us stand. Really? I don't want to stand and eat seafood that costs a small fortune. For that price, I want to sit, thank you very much.

Also, the menu is extremely limited. I didn't want seafood slathered in cocktail sauce, nor did I want it on a plate of iceberg lettuce. Those seem to be the only 2 options. They also serve clam chowder; it was ok, but it didn't blow me away. 

I am remiss that I did not look at the pictures on Yelp or I would have asked about the seafood or scallop sashimi -- which actually looks really good. I didn't see much fish in the window that day. And I didn't like that there wasn't a specials board, or a sign that mentions to ask about what the specials are for the day. I did ask about what was recommended to order, but the guy just pointed to the menu on the wall -- that wasn't helpful at all since I clearly wasn't impressed with the very limited menu I had been looking at for quite awhile. 

Also, they charge you for bread and butter. Really? It was cold unsliced bread with rock hard pads of butter, and they didn't even ask us if we wanted it. I don't like to be charged for something that I didn't even ask for.  We didn't end up being charged because we ended up ordering the salad and it was included in that, but we were served the bread before we even ordered. 

This place is CASH Only, so definitely hit up the ATM before you go, and take out loads because you'll need it. 

In summary --- I just don't get the hype and I won't be returning anytime soon. It's definitely not worth a long wait, and the prices are too high. The portions aren't that big for items that cost nearly $20 either. Yeah..I know it's seafood, but still...
author: Rebecca G.

description:
We came hungry ready for some good raw seafood, between the 2 of us we had
a bowl of clam chowder - (3) probably the weakest of all dishes imho
half order of smoke salmon- (4.5) creamy, slightly smoke not too salty, wish we ordered a full order
one doz assorted oysters - (4) very fresh, excellent
half doz raw clams - (4.5) slightly salty savory crunchy goodness, loved it
Crab cocktail - (4) very fresh Genuineness crab meat, yummy
Sashime (4) we actually liked the olive oil / capers / red onion Sicilian style dressing  so the freshness of the fish really stood out
3 glasses of wine, bread and butter

The total bill came to $144 before tips somewhat  in line with what we expected. Swan is very smart in their business model, very little cooking involved at the premise; the freshness of the seafood speaks for itself and the friendly family oriented atmosphere added to it's attractiveness.

you can visit here to have deliciousness
author: Jenefer _.

description: True Old Time SF still lives here. Take your kids and young friends to show them. Worth the lines. Or come early and beat the lines.
author: Ruth S.

description:
I tried it once. Wasn't crazy about it.

I tried it twice. Still not a huge fan.

Maybe it's the huge line that you have to wait in to get in (Although my 2nd time I waited less than 15 minutes), maybe it's the outrageous prices they charge for half their menu, or maybe it's just that the service is a bit cold. Whatever it is, I just wasn't sold.

I will say that their oysters were delicious. At $30 for a mixed dozen, it was on par with other places. But $22 for a half cracked crab when it's crab season seems insane to me.

In the end I'm glad I went a 2nd time to give it another shot. At least we got to meet some nice people sitting next to us!
author: Kristen C.

description: Not at all what I expected from the reviews. The fish was fresh, but the service and presentation lacked appeal. They were also lacking uni the day I ate there, and that was my prime reason for going in the first place. The whole experience was uncomfortable and basically meh. They also need to learn to take credit cards like the rest of SF restaurants. A huge disappointment.
author: Steven H.

description:
DO NOT Eat at Swan Oyster Depot!
We waited in line for almost two hours for a meal that could at best be described as mediocre, some of which was truly repulsive.  The Staff doesn't follow even the most basic food safety procedures, handling cash, rags, raw and cooked food all with bare hands and no hand washing.  A trip through the filthy kitchen and cramped backroom to the one and only bathroom exposes the reason they wouldn't want to go into the back to wash as one feels dirtier after venturing through it.
The food is grossly overpriced and there is no sign to inform customers, credit cards are not accepted.
author: Clairee H.

description:
Waiting in line 30-45 minutes, worth it. Sitting elbow-to-elbow with strangers on uneven barstools, worth it. If you are serious about sea-food in the old fashion sense, then you should really try Swan Oyster Depot. Here's my recommendation:

* The lobster is $45 and worth every penny. 2 people should get a good 3 mouthfuls each. 
* Can't go wrong with a dozen mixed oysters - 2 people should be able to put down 2-3 of these easy.
* Getting a cup of New England clam chowder and a beer is the best way to start the meal.
* Suggest going 2 people, max of 3.
* Start with beer and finish with champagne.
* Cash only! Use the ATM across the street.

Expect your meal to run $120-200.
author: Grayson K.

description: If you love seafood, this is an essential stop. What an incredible experience. This place has been there forever cranking out the best seafood daily. We got there about half an hour before opening and snagged the last two seats of the first seating. The dude helping us out was an excellent food guide for our first visit, lots of fantastic recommendations. There isn't a bad item in this restaurant. The people, the atmosphere, and the food make this an absolutely essential SF stop
author: Cade W.

description:
This place has been entrenched in my SF bookmarks list for the longest time, so I can finally cross this off -- well, sort of. We arrived shortly before their opening hours of 10:30 am, only to see several people clustered by the front entrance. It turns out they were not going to do counter service and only takeout orders. 

A bit weird and confusing at the same, as a sign would've been helpful. The guys inside all seem flustered, running around with their heads cut off. They would pop their head out and abruptly ask "how can I help you?" in a I-don't-want-to-be-bothered-attitude. When I asked them why no counter service, they said they had several hundred orders for the holidays.

Anyhow, I figured since we were there, might as well order something to-go and eat it back at the hotel. I ordered the crab salad, which came with sourdough bread and a side of their louie dressing. The guy helping us simply used his bare hands to grab fistfuls of the crab by the front display window. Then, he took our cash.

*Thumbs up*
It's all about the crab. It was fresh, tender, sweet, juicy, succulent, and any other positive adjective you can throw out there. It doesn't compare to stuff that's in a can or previously frozen -- there are dudes that just crack the crab all day just to extract the meat. I love dungeness crab, and I always have to get my fix whenever in SF. The heaping whole chunks of the crab leg meat is the best part.

*Thumbs down*
The thinly shredded lettuce for the salad is your standard iceburg lettuce. It reminded me of grade school cafeteria lettuce. But it did give a contrasting crunch in texture versus the crab meat. The workers handle the food with their bare hands and take your grubby cash, so that made me cringe a little.
author: Dru C.

description:
Way overrated. A two hour wait to be seated. The oysters were delicious and the fish was fresh, but that's about it. Limited menu and no sides. The counter was dirty and the seating very tight and uncomfortable. My chair felt like it was about to break. The clam chowder was mediocre. They couldn't serve crab because of an algae bloom, but didn't let any of the customers lined up outside in the rain know. A customer who waited for two hours and 10 minutes for the crab sandwich couldn't find anything to eat on their limited menu.  They were also out of Kumamoto  oysters by 12:30 pm. Service  was subpar. The only thing our waiter said to us that wasn't along the lines of "What can I get you" was a short and simple "thank you" only after we tipped him. We had to go elsewhere to grab lunch after this waste of time.  Find another place to grab seafood. 
This place is all hype.
author: Gary F.

description:
I stopped in yesterday (Wednesday) afternoon for an afternoon snack. The place was busy but I was able to grab a stool as a group of four left. I ordered a combo cocktail, of shrimp and oysters, and a cup of chowder. Everything was good, but nothing was special. (I will admit that I'm not a big fan of oysters so maybe they were amazing and I just didn't realize it.)

I get that there's a lot of appeal to this place, and its history, but while I had an enjoyable and tasty round of food, there is nothing that is making me think this is a place I need to return to. For me - that's a 3: good food, but nothing to write home about.
author: David B.

description:
Phoned in my order and picked up what was a DELICIOUS meal.  Tons of people waiting on line but I jumped ahead because I ordered for pick up.  

Why doesn't everyone do that???
author: Chris B.

description:
Wow this place was absolutely amazing. It's been a week since I ate here and my boyfriend is  still dreaming about the delicious salmon plate and crab salad.

Be prepared for the long line, the wait sucks but you can get a beer while you stand in line and the food is divine. Honestly they should buy the place next door and expand!

Things to get:
Clam chowder, duh!
salmon plate, came on sliced bread with capers...drool!
crab salad with loui dressing, I mixed the dressing with horschradish... yummy!
author: Heather M.

description:
I've been looking forward to trying Swan Oyster Depot for a long time. In all fairness, the food here is probably a 3-star deal, but for the prices, service, and hygiene, I will definitely not be back to SOD or recommend it to anyone.

- Oysters ($15/half dozen): We actually got 13 oysters even though we ordered a dozen. The oysters are fresh and come on the half shell, and the Thai spice and picked onion sauce are a nice touch, but the oysters have a strange metallic/bitter flavor. Questionable.

- Clam Chowder ($5/bowl): This is probably one of the worst bowls of chowder I've had. It tastes like a combination of spoiled fish and milk, and has a very strange, flakey consistency.

- Sashimi Plate ($16): This is not on the (very, very haphazard and confusing) menu. We saw the couple next to us order it (they said they saw it on TV). The assortment of hamachi, tuna, salmon, squid, and one other type of fish came topped with capers and olive oil. This was very fresh and good, probably the best part of the food.

- Seafood Combination Cocktail ($13.50): This is supposed to come with shrimp, prawns, oysters, clams, and crab. We decided to order this over the combination salad, because the salad is basically charging you $12 for lettuce. The waiter brought us our cocktail glass and told us he left out the clams (because they were out) and the oysters (because we already had oysters) - NOT COOL. That is literally 2/5 of the cup; I would have appreciated some kind of advance notice or apologetic attitude.

You have to stand in a line to get in; we only ended up waiting about 30 minutes at 4PM on a Saturday (they stopped letting people line up 2 parties after us). The place is set up as one long bar where you can watch them prep most of the cold food. I'm not sure how this place passes the health inspection. The employees were handling money and one was cleaning his teeth with a napkin, and then serving RAW seafood to customers. Even if my food weren't raw, that sounds like a recipe for food poisoning (which we thankfully didn't get) or at least queasy feelings at the thought of germs swimming around in a bowl of chowder. There were a lot of other hygiene issues here; once you notice them, you cannot unsee.

People kept coming in the door and talking to the servers, who would then give them bags of seafood that they told dine-in customers they were out of; the kicker is that the servers never asked these people for payment either. This happened so frequently (4-5 times while we were eating), that other dine-in customers started to complain/ask what was up; one server simply said "They're my friends." So do your dine-in customers absorb the cost of this free food? We ended up paying $70+ for a meal that didn't leave us half full. The servers were also obnoxious and contributed to 70% of the noise level. They chatted up white customers, and literally ignored requests from the three groups of Asian customers (our party included).

If you want good seafood and oysters, go to Hog Island. Do not even consider SOD; it is not worth any kind of wait.
author: Jessica F.

description:
everything was so fresh - oyster, clams (i LOVE the clams much more than oysters), scallop... i was SO sad that they didn't have uni on Monday - WHY??? i'll just have to go back.

i didn't like the clam chowder cus it was too watery - but it was still not bad.

bears on tap and nice wines, services were excellent. i'd definitely go back again and again - and made sure not during the busy lunch hour - on a Monday afternoon around 3 we still waited for about 30 mins.  the store right next door is 'for lease', why not get extra space? 

and cash only? i guess they must make a lot of money!
author: Bonnie Y.

description: An hour and a half wait in line. Yup, it was totally worth  every second of it. We ordered a plate of crab meat, 6 oysters, which included 3 varieties. The staff is hard working to keep up with everyone's requests, quality of food is top notch. I can't wait to go back. Yes theirs lots of "hype" over this place but I can see why, what's better than FRESH delicious seafood?!?!?!? and cold beer?? Did I mention they have wine, champagne & beer? they do. =)
author: Ness S.

description: Great people and great service.  Everyone knows about this place so it is busy.  My advice is to come early on a weekday if possible.  If not and you have to be there on a weekend enjoy the wait, meet the people around you and know the reward is worth it.
author: Tim P.

description: Completely overprice and over hyped. Waited in line for to go food and the only reason your waiting is they have like 10 bar stools to sit at.  Clam chowder tastes exactly like the one I make with Campbell potato soup as the base sashimi mediocre.  Way overpriced and will not trust Yelp on this one ever again.  Totally disappointed with San Fran seafood, just blah nothing great. People who worked there were nice but they need to tell you where then take out line is but would not go back with no line
author: K C.

description: A simple classic San Francisco seafood joint. Arrive early unless you don't mind waiting a few hours to be seated (line started forming at 9:45ish).  The crab back and oysters were the main reason we came here, and both were amazing!  We also ordered a few other items that were IMHO just okay - clam chowder (watered down), Italian sashimi (needed some salt), and crab cocktail (good). But again, we came here specifically for crab backs and oysters which did not disappoint! The service was awesome, and the guys behind the counter gave off this old school vibe that made the dining experience very authentic. Definitely a must try if you're visiting San Francisco.
author: Jay S.

description:
We had to wait for 2.5 hours in the line to get in. It was a Saturday afternoon but most of the times you will have to wait. 

Food
3.5/5
I came here just to have the clam chowder. And that I liked. The chowder here doesn't have a thick consistency. But it tasted good. They serve it with sourdough bread and butter. 
The shrimp cocktail was not for me. I like my sea food nicely seasoned. Just the cooked shrimps with ketchup (you could add hot sauce, horseradish to it) did not go well with me. I thought it is a hyped place but that's my personal opinion. 

Service 5/5
The staff is really good though. Friendly and engaging. 

Ambiance
4.5/5
It's a bar style serving with stools and a long table. They prepare food right in front of you. 
The place has an old feel to it. Do check the old cash register with the numbers flipping on it. And the authentic cash register sound.
author: Akshay M.

description: One of my SF musts.  This place is a loving dive with great oysters and the best Crab Louie around. Get there early and bring cash, no cc cards accepted.
author: Bruce B.

description: I also wanted to comment on the wave of silly comments regarding Swan's clam chowder, which I consider to be the best in the city. It is not "watery." It is the way it should be. Clam chowder as we know it was ruined by Boudin when it introduced the bread bowl to the unwashed touristy masses in the 1980s. That stuff is fraudulent. You can't find better chowder in SF than at Swan's.
author: Yowz A.

description:
A fantastic hole-in-the-wall that has been open since 1912, serving super fresh seafood everyday from 10:30a to 5:30p. I got a taste of all it's specialties, leaving hugely satisfied: clam chowder, shrimp cocktail, mixed seafood salad with shrimps, prawns, smoked salmon, and crabs. Too bad they don't exist in New York City.

VERY reasonably priced.
author: Giacomo C.

description:
Even with only two types of oysters (e.g., Eastern, Olympia) that day, they both made my mouth water with or without the sauces (e.g., cocktail, creamy thousand island-like).  Try the sweet and juicy crab and the bowl of clam chowder with their sourdough bread.  I could eat here all day at the counter =D

if you don't want to wait in line, order take out.  The service is friendlier while seated, but it's tough for large groups to dine together on a counter.
author: Jenny L.

description: This a really small restaurant/retail seafood store. There is always a lot line to buy food or get seated to eat. Waiting time is 30 mins or more. I ordered smoke salmon and oysters. They were amazing and delicious!
author: Mila N.

description: Came here in a party of 3. Anymore and we would have waited all day for the limited stool seating. As it was, we waited 1.5 hours for the best seafood in town. The wait may have encouraged more spending than anticipated to justify the time invested but keep the shooters coming! I don't think I would ever come here again but it was a memorable one time experience, elbows buried in shell reminants while watching all the food preparation before our eyes.
author: Tina K.

description:
Truly the seafood here is as fresh as it gets and the place is run with friendly folks who have been dishing up seafood delights since 1912. 

2.5 stars

Swan Oyster depot is like a fish market and a diner coexisting in a long, narrow space.  Fresh fish, crab, squid are seen on display by the window. There aren't any tables here, only a marble counter and rickety stools to accommodate 15 or so people for eating in.

I needed to cross off oysters on the half shell which is #15 on my Big Eats SF list. Mom is a huge fan of seafood so we ordered a couple of dishes to share. $12 bought us half a dozen cleanly shucked oysters (yay, no bits of shell in there!) Drake's Bay, kumamoto and Sweetwater oysters are served with mignonette sauce. Delicious and definitely deserving to be on that list.

Their clam chowder is reminiscent of Hog Island's version: think thin soup with clams and potato. So if you're into the usual thick, coat the back of your spoon chowder, skip this.

The crab salad had generous portions of sweet crab claws but I don't get the $19 tag price since it only had iceberg lettuce and thousand island dressing on it. 

Forget your plastic at home, this place is cash only. The way they calculate your bill is done on a napkin, I haven't seen that in ages! 

The reason this isn't a glowing 5 star review is the fact that they handle EVERYTHING with bare hands, so please correct me if I'm wrong, but I didn't see any sink nearby for the employees to wash their hands. I know kitchen staff at other restaurants probably don't wear gloves when preparing my food, but the fact that I can see it right in front of me kinda grosses me out. (a year's worth of Microbiology classes can do that to you)

If you're curious, come for the experience. The people here will make you feel SO welcome, you'll feel like you live right around the corner.
author: Janice C.

description: The oyster was kinda pricey and very salty. Wish they could have at least clean the oysters before serving
author: Rainbow Y.

description:
I wanted to love this place but it's overpriced for what they offer. If you can get in without waiting for more than an hour to be seated it is definitely worth checking out. They have Stella Artois and Anchor Steam on tap. We had the mixed dozen oysters, half a crab and chowder. All of the dishes were solid.

The bottom line is it's way too much of a hassle and overpriced so I can only give Swans three stars. They can clearly charge whatever they like given the lines to get into this place but there have to be better options for seafood in San Francisco.
author: David T.

description:
I don't usually write reviews in this circumstance but I must.  Visiting from Boston and I had read that I must come try this place for excellent seafood.  Waited in line 1 hour before close and the gentleman came out and asked the group in front of me to hand a paper that read Last One to my group of 4.  we waited some more and then when it was our turn he came out took the paper from my hand and out loud in front of everyone in the doorway.  Who gave you this? you go this other party comes in but you can only get take out.  If we didn't give ya this so you you can't just accept it from another cusyomer!

I was appalled.  the four of us just stood there as the entire place stared at us.  in shock all we could do was give the paper back to him and walk away.  how unreal!  No better articulated what a complete a--h---!!!

Anyone who treats a customer this way on the way in the door is clearly unfit to run or serve people in any dining setting.

So we went down the street to Woodhouse Fish co. who were amazing in service and food.
author: Mario C.

description: One of my favorite spots! Highly recommended. You won't be disappointed, these are some of the best oysters I've ever had.
author: Maya B.

description:
I am a total loss of why there is a line out the door.
Late in the afternoon, I only had to wait about 10 min for a seat to open up.

The "famous" clam chowder was watery.
The oysters were good and I was able to get a decent sampler of 6, but it was no better than i can get at most places that shuck to order.

When you add in the inconveniece of paying for parking, waiting in line and then getting squeezed in like a sardine at the counter: this place loses all appea to me.

They obviosuly do killer business , so congrats to them!
author: Mike A.

description:
It was the first day of Indian Summer 2010, a Monday.  We parked and got in line at about 11:00 and were seated 45 mins later.  We were told by the guy ahead of us in line (a tourist from Rhode Island of all people) that the food is "really good" and that he literally got off the plane and went straight to Swan.

I have the same concerns about this place that Janice C. has.  It is DIRTY.  There were flies landing on the seafood at the front of the restaurant by the WINDOW and it was a hot, HOT, day.  I think it's going to need a little bit more than simply putting a tray of seafood on ice to keep that raw food fresh.  The tray wasn't even buried in the ice. 

One of the cooks/preparers had a bad cut on his finger and it was bleeding all over the place and he waited a while before he finally put a bandaid on it.  Seriously?  You're BLEEDING in front of your customers in a restaurant.  Go wrap that sh*t up.  I hoped to God he wasn't going to be the one shucking my oysters.

Nonetheless, we ordered 6 blue point oysters and 6 miyagis, and a combination salad (comes with bread and butter that otherwise costs $1).  The blue point oysters were the best part of the meal and all the oysters were cleanly shucked.  I loved, loved, loved the habanero migonette.  The crab in the combination salad wasn't very fresh and didn't have much flavor.  It was not worth $19.  The clam chowder seems to be popular, but it was way too hot for that.

Service was nice.. our server was not the one with the bloody finger.  Thank goodness.  On our way out, he handed us a postcard and a "swan sponge".  

Definitely overhyped.  I can get those blue points elsewhere.
author: Vivian H.

description:
This is a restauranteur's wildest dream.  Cash only business, loyal following, low maintenance decor, overpriced menu.  

The selection of seafood is fantastic, and you can't get much fresher.  But from a value perspective, I still think the food is overpriced after taking everything into consideration.  $26 for crab salad buys you a plate of lettuce with some crab meat on top of it.  Wow....
author: Jack L.

description: Moving away from SF, I miss Swan more than anything. It's often a long wait but the service is great and you never feel rushed once you sit down. If fresh crab with make-your-own cocktail sauce, some clam chowder, sourdough bread an anchor steam beer in a family owned historic San Francisco establishment is your kind of thing, then it doesn't get any better than this.
author: Drew T.

description:
As I am leaving SF at the end of my academic endeavors, I am embarking on: 

"A quest to eat all the things most people in other cities will ask me if I've eaten once they find out I lived in SF for 3 years." (TM)

Swan was top of the list since I saw Bourdain drown in crab fat on the layover, so I readied my seafood fairing companion for a round of oysters and mayhem on a wednesday afternoon. 

After a very modest wait, we were treated to fresh sourdough, 3 delicious oysters, and the best goddamn smoked salmon I've ever had. UNREAL. I need to remember to ask for some as a graduation present. 

Good fresh seafood, but I wasn't blown away by everything. It was also super pricey but I appreciate why. Definitely filled up on bread. 

Cash only.
author: Emily D.

description:
Family run oyster joint. Can you spot who's related?  I found 3. I'm guessing a father, son and uncle combo.

Got the Oyster platter ($28) to try them all. All freshly shucked right before your eyes if you look hard at the corner they do this.  Does smell quite seafoody in the restaurant and makes you feel a little bit like your in a fish market.  They've also got a great range of sauces to go with the oysters.

This place is by no means cheap. They also dont accept plastic. I'm sure the oldest cash register still being in use on the planet would tell you that though.
author: Angela Y.

description: Definitely not going back, ever. The place is filthy and the employees and servers handle the ready to eat food with their bare hands followed by handling money, followed by wiping the counters and prep areas with a kitchen towel and agains food without washing their hands. Ridiculous! You wait for 45 minutes to an hour to get seafood that is not exceptional at outrageous prices served in worn and chipped plates, sitting on uncomfortable chairs, to pay cash only, and feel crowded and hurried. Wines are ordinary served in tiny cheap glasses. Easily spend over $75 per person. Are you kidding me? I use to always trust Anthony Bourdain on his recommendations. Especially casual places where food is excellent even when served on paper plates. But this one, well, let's say that Bourdain really got it wrong. For less than that you could eat at Waterbar near Embarcadero and get amazing seafood, awesome service and excellent wines in a beautiful setting with views to the Bay Bridge. Still, the thing that bothers me the most is the filth and the lack of food handling safety. You have to wonder if the health inspectors have an interest in this restaurant and that is why they have not shut it down. Double ridiculous!!
author: Basilios K.

description:
The best oysters I've ever had! This place is worth the wait and cost. It's CASH ONLY. 
My party had oysters, raw calamari (highly recommended and tasty), clams (didn't like those), prawn cocktail (very fresh and worth ordering) and sauvignon blanc. The service was fantastic and all the guys were very friendly and accomodating. This is a must visit in the city. It's a very tiny place so the wait can be hours long. Make sure you go in at a non-peak time.
author: Amy M.

description:
Came here for the first time because I saw it on a tv show and thought my husband would like it. I was right he loved the place! He got all 6 types of oysters they offered for about 20$ and i got some shrimp in a cup (about 6 or 7) with cocktail sauce for about 11$.  They charge 5$ if you want melted butter with something. We both thought that there prices were a bit ridiculous but chalked it up to the fact that its in sf and its fresh seafood. The place was packed and cramped. There are no tables its just a counter with stools and almost no room to walk behind the people sitting down. We brought our son in his stroller and it was literally a miracle that we made it work. The staff was very friendly and accommodating, the atmosphere was nice and enjoyable for us. All in all we will be back for the oysters.

Definitely a place you should try at least once.
Would have given 1 more star if prices were more reasonable.
author: Cindy W.

description:
This place is my go to for fresh/fast seafood! It is quite a small spot though so if you are going to sit at the counter and eat lunch, definitely get there early or show up later around 1:30/2.

The boston clam chowder is just as good as on the east coast, thick and creamy, but still hearty. 
They have a fine selection of both east coast and west coast oysters.
But the thing to get is the Sashimi plate! You can get it italian style with olive oil and capers and onions. Delicious! The Mignonette is very acidic and yummy too - perfect for a briny oyster.
The smoked salmon is totally work every cent too, some of the best I've had in my life! Very straightforward flavor, no frills, wood smoked and simple with a good texture.

The real secret is this: Swan Oyster actually opens at 7 AM and they guys are there then. You can show up any time after then and order any of their delicious food to go! I know it's not the same experience as eating at the counter top, but they will pack you oyster crackers, lemons, and whatever sauces your heart desires at no extra cost! I surprised my boss down in San Jose with a quart of clam chowder and shucked oysters on ice once...he was so excited he couldn't speak!
author: Jennifer H.

description:
Two stars only because the staff made it fun. 

1. Clam chowder: one of the worst cups of chowder I've had. It was runny and the broth tasted weird. I'm used to the creamy New England style classic chowder and this isn't it. 

2. Crab salad: it was fine. But just fine. Nothing special. Very mediocre. 

3. The oysters were oysters and you can get them anywhere and not have to wait an hour in line for them. 

I wanted to love this place but it's overrated and resting on its laurels at this point. Also it's very expensive.
author: Damien F.

description:
Fresh seafood, fun atmosphere, friendly service.  Loooong wait.
