author: Nea A.

description: I've had lots of oysters from different places. This place is really fresh. My favorite was the komodo. The Miyagis have a fishy finish to them. The cherry stone is decent but not my fav. The prices is steep and you could easily spend $80 for two without eating much. It's good to try and check off the list. I'm not quite sure I would come back. This place is more for the experience than substance.
author: May C.

description: I've been here before, but forgot to write a review. The other day I drove by with some friends and glanced inside as I passed and saw hella empty seats! We pulled over and went inside and ordered three cups of clam chowder, a dozen oysters, an order of tuna, scallop, and salmon sashimi, an order of smoked trout and smoked salmon. The chowder was more on the soupy side than chowder, but everything was fresh as usual and everyone was satisfied. The smoked salmon with onions and capers is my fav and always a must. Order that!
author: Joe N.

description:
Just okay and not worth the wait. 

Had the line been not there or less than 15 minutes AND had the oysters been a notch up in taste, this would have been the best seafood I've had in the states. But those were just broken dreams. 

I can't really complain about the wait, but I can safely say that the oysters I had at Hog Island were a better bang for the buck. Here, nothing had that magical creaminess that I want in my oysters. However, there were some items at Swan that bested any other oyster joint; 1) the olive oil drenched sashimi and 2) the seafood cocktail.

http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/eI0DpD2Xx8hFlk7eAdFCqQ?select=oDA7ONJwSxUSPsdGOSpfvQ

I guess I could just go to any LA sushi spot and bring some quality olive oil and get the same effect, but I won't. Regardless of what I will or will not do, this was a great eat.

http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/eI0DpD2Xx8hFlk7eAdFCqQ?select=ytMbEoMT7s2LmHrWP00MDg

For the seafood cocktail, they let us pick exactly which creatures we wanted to be shredded into our cup. The thing that got me off the most about this one was the portions, HUGE! You get a fair amount of crab and other goodies for a good price. This is something that I would get again. 

But for a place that has oyster in their name, I was let down. I would only ever go back if I happened to be driving by and there was no line. Else, Hog Island will be my SF go-to spot for oysters.
author: Eli G.

description:
The wait can be discouraging, but don't fret; it isn't that bad at all and it's well worth it! I've actually come here on several occasions and I typically come a little before they open so the wait isn't too long. 

Their crab salad and cherry stone clams are a most! They have fresh oysters too, but their cherry stone clams are the best though--very fresh, great chewy texture, and excellent salty flavor. Their crab salad is made of very simple ingredients--shredded iceberg lettuce and lots of fresh crab meat--but it's incredibly tasty and refreshing. They typically use a lot of dressing, so I'll ask for either light dressing or for dressing on the side.

The staff is super friendly and casual and will whip you up anything you want. It's a tiny place with maybe 15 or so bar seats, so it's a very lively environment. Prices are reasonable, but do note parking is limited to street parking.
author: Lien T.

description: We are from Denver and tried this spot and it was amazing. There was a very long wait since there is about 15 seats inside but well worth it. We had the combination salad with tons of fresh seafood and homemade dressing that they make in front of you. The oysters were also some of the best I've ever had. The atmosphere is veryyy casual and the service is very friendly and welcoming. Don't expect much as far as ambiance. It's basically a hole in the wall.
author: Michelle N.

description:
This is a landmark.  If you are starving skip this joint because there will most certainly be a line.  The place is a small room with a counter and stools lined up next to it.  You order, you eat, and you go.  Don't expect to loiter.

That said, WOW, you will get fresh, delicious sea food. 

If you are a tourist you have to come here, it is a place were mostly local go and we flock to it.
author: claudia w.

description:
This no frills restaurant is small and only has bar seating so make sure to get here early.    If you're not careful ordering everything starts adding up really fast but everything was good.  

Recommended:
crab back: (the head of the crab and all the gooey stuff) was only $4 which I thought was a pretty good deal.  
Smoked salmon
Dozen oysters

Decent:
Clam Chowder: not the best but not the worse I've had.
author: Kenneth H.

description: I'd been trying to get here for a long time and I was not disappointed.  We showed up a little early to beat the crowds and we were able to get in right away!  The crab back was buttery and delicious and the Sicilian sashimi was amazing.  All of the guys behind the counter were amazing!  They were kind, funny, and really made you feel comfortable.  I can't wait to go back!
author: Brandon M.

description:
Been to New Orleans? Been to San Francisco? If you have and love these two cities as much as I do this place is a must visit. As close to Acme Oyster House in NOLA as one can hope for.

Fresh seafood and super friendly staff will draw you back to this tourist-less area of The City over and over and.... The oysters are about as alive as can be and the smoked salmon plate was worth every penny of the $19 spent. Funky old historic space has the regulars lining up daily. We arrived shortly after 11:00 am (weekday) and copped the last 2 bar stools (no tables). By the time we left at 12:30 the local office workers were in the queue for the best lunch in the area. Lucky bastards.

Lunch here with an Anchor Steam is the quintessential SF experience you need to add (replace?) to your Fisherman's Wharf visit.
author: Dan H.

description:
It's soooooooo good! My two must haves are the oysters on a half shell and the clam chowder. The clam chowder isn't very thick, but it is chock full of clams and potato goodness. The oysters are so fresh they taste like the ocean. I usually get a variety of whatever they have in stock (today it was blue points, miyagis, and kumamotos).

On my most recent trip I also had the shrimp and prawn cocktail. It was as tasty as everything else.

I would give Swan five stars, except that the wait was way longer than I remember it (and a couple that seemed to be regulars who sat next to me also mentioned the wait being the longest ever). Although in fairness, there did seem to be a disproportionate number of tourists in the mix. So maybe avoiding the seafood hot spot during the holidays would be a good plan.
author: Dani D.

description: Best sashimi I ever ate.  Don't fool yourself, order the largest plate of it they will make you.  The place is a culinary landmark and for good reason, super happy, friendly staff serve up raw seafood of all sorts plus salads, crab and shrimp cocktail.  Wine was also good.  Atmosphere for those who like it old school and authentic is as good as it gets.  If there were ten stars I'd give it ten.
author: Kathleen J.

description:
2 hour wait. 4 hours paid on a meter= $8. At the end of our adventure was unbelievable fresh seafood. The oysters, we had the sampler and cannot tell you which one is which, were just delicate and wonderful. The crab cocktail was so fresh, so tasty, so so so so good. The clam chowder was extremely flavorful really really great! The guys behind the counter were very helpful in picking out some food items for us. 

Two downsides- the place is teeny tiny. Only seats at the bar and about 15 at a time. Hence, the two hour wait. And the bar stools arent that comfy to sit at. But those two still do not ruin the experience. 

We did the crab back, as seen on the Bourdain show "The Layover" and we were pleasantly surprised as to the flavor. It was buttery, seafoodie, and yet meaty. Cannot explain...you just gotta try it. 

Horseradish is a must condiment. I really enjoyed it with just about everything. I mixed some into the cocktail sauce. 

Will be back. Have to be back. I am now hooked on oysters!
author: Michelle I.

description:
Super fresh, sweet oysters here. They even have "sashimi" plates. There's a reason that they don't showcase this on their menu though. It's not very well done. 

The best things you can get here raw are oysters and raw scallops. So sweet and fresh. Really unbelievably delicious. An oyster shot pairs incredibly well with the clam chowder, too. 

Sit your whiny butt down when you're playing hooky from work at 3 o'clock in the afternoon, SF native BSer. Why on earth would you think to come here on a busy day? Tsk tsk. 

I love how it's kind of rough here. Hey you want some bread? Hey what would you like to drink? What can I start you with?--all this from different people. I like it. I like it a lot.


About them using their hands to prepare food--well, no duh. Pls don't complain about this again anywhere ever. It's people like YOU that force sushi chefs to mold nigiri with rubber gloves. UGH.
author: Margaret S.

description: Can't wait to see all my friends !! We've been coming here for 3 yrs now and have become good friends with the folks behind the bar! Trust them for they know what they do
author: Nicole P.

description:
We got to Swan Oyster Depot at about 2:30. There was a line and we waited for about 35-40 minutes. The long wait was definitely worth it. We had the crab back which is crab fat and crab innards served with sourdough bread and butter. It was delicious! Next we ordered smoked salmon. The smoked salmon was the best we ever had! It was buttery with amazing flavor! Finally, we finished with a crab cocktail. This was the best seafood place we have been to. We would definitely recommend this place to seafood lovers visiting San Francisco.

Note: The restaurant accepts only cash.
author: Abraham K.

description:
Get here early or be prepared to wait. The seafood here is delicious! Plus the folks who work here are very nice and courteous.

Clam Chowder: I've never had a chowder like this before. It has more seafood flavor than your typical chowder which tends to be more creamy. Thus this chowder is thinner in consistency but it's that flavor that makes it unique. Throw in some oyster crackers too.

Shrimp Salad: Sweet shrimp on a bed of lettuce that's quite easy to quickly gobble up.

Mixed Dozen of Oysters: Your waiter will explain the types and where they are from before you get to swallow all of them. My favs were the blue points + kumamotos but all are sooo good. Tabasco, horseradish, cocktail sauce, mignonette and lemon wedges are all available to top your oysters.
author: Maya S.

description: Came here on a tuesday afternoon around 3pm and still had about an hour wait, but that was expected given the size and Bourdain praise. The staff treat you like you're a member of the family and their no bs attitude made for a few great laughs. Having grown up in New England the seafood offerings were not anything extraordinary and everything was overpriced (even by SF standards). Yes, fresh seafood is inherently expensive, but after spending nearly $100 on what amounted to an afternoon snack I'm not planning on running back the next time I'm in town.
author: Matt D.

description:
Came here the day after Christmas around lunchtime on a recommendation from my friend who used to live in SF. We were hoping that most people would be back at work and not on vacation like we were, but we couldn't have been more wrong. The line was already at least 50 people long and because the place is so small (seats about 20 bar style) and the gentlemen that work there are pretty laid back, it took us a painful three hours to finally sit.

The line started at the Nail Salon, and trust me I was seriously considering having my boyfriend hold our place in line while I got a mani-pedi. Instead I grabbed him a cinnamon roll and me some coffee at the doughnut shop just up the street (sadly they don't offer gluten free doughnuts..wahhh!) . If you get there and the line is that long, I HIGHLY recommend having a little snack while you wait or you will be famished by the time you get seated.

Doing my best not to faint from lack of nourishment and only a mom & daughter duo away from sitting, I was pleasantly surprised when one of the waiters offered to pour me a glass of wine while we waited just a tad longer. I chose the Sauvignon Blanc. Expecting something cheap from a screw top bottle, I was psyched to receive a delicious glass Honig from good 'ol home-sweet-home, Napa Valley! I was a happy lady.

We finally sat and the place was, well...messy. Like a joint run by a bunch of dudes, which is exactly what it is. It was a little cluttered, stuff just seemed all over the place, far from glamorous. Coming from Napa, we don't have a ton of "hole in the wall" type places so it took at least one more glass of Honig to ease into it. 

Although the surroundings were a little out of order, the service was IMPECCABLE, the gentleman we got as our server was super easy going, kept my wine glass full and even offered me Udi's gluten free bread to nosh on when I let him know I had a gluten allergy/celiac disease. I was literally floored. Especially because I was fricken starving!!!

We ordered:
Half Dozen Oysters (sorry cannot remember the names) - They were.. good. Not great. We enjoyed some of the best oysters of our lives at Barrell House Tavern the night before in Sausalito. I wouldn't go here for the oysters, but if you're in the mood, go for it.

Prawn Cocktail - Deee-fricken-lish! So fresh and perfectly pink! Their homemade cocktail sauce was what really made the dish. Hands down, once of the best I've ever tried and gluten free.

Clam Chowder (cup) - The bf got this one, as our server said there are "traces" of wheat in the soup. It was legitimately a cup, small. And had a more brothy texture than most are used to. He said it was delicious and lapped it up with his crusty (and gluteny) bread.

Crab Salad - I had originally asked for the Half Crab, but our server suggested the salad so that we didn't have to deal with the shells, I opted in and was VERY pleased with the decision. The salad was a plate full of very fresh and crunchy lettuce and loadssss of seriously fresh crab. Their homemade Louie dressing was ridiculously yummy, so creamy and also gluten free!! I asked for some drawn butter on the side (which he candidly heated up on the coffee warmer) and it really hit the spot. I seriously think I could eat this salad EVERY day, with extra butter of course ;)

San Francisco Sashimi (aka Italian Sashimi) - NOT LISTED ON MENU. I saw this creation on yelp and had to try it. Though it was not on the menu, the waiter knew exactly what I meant and made it picture perfect to what I had seen in photos. It is raw tuna, raw salmon and raw scallops drizzled with olive oil, salt, pep & capers. Seriously fresh and delicious! 

I had a total of three glasses of wine (and I deserved every ounce after that line!) and the bf had a Stella, our bill came to $110. Pricey, but that's what you pay to get seriously fresh seafood in a renowned location in San Francisco!

The question of the day: "Was the crazy wait and price worth it?" 
HELL YES, it was worth it! I would wait all over again in a heartbeat.
author: Crystal H.

description:
WOW- 1.5 hour wait, must be good right? RIGHT!

Because of the limited seating up in this joint, you'll have to wait a considerable amount of time before getting started on your food. With a party of 5, there is a good chance you won't be seated together but that day, everything worked out and a party of 3 and 2 left (and they were right next to each other). Man, having all of their fresh seafood displayed in the window is simply torture!

Between three HUNGRY guys, we shared a combination cocktail (oyster, shrimp, crab, clam) with their amazing cocktail sauce. Someone commented there was probably crack in it. We also got a medly of oysters (one of the waiters joked, please do not ask how many oysters in a dozen like a previous customer). The oysters were good but still doesn't top my best oyster eating experience.

Really, what blindsided me about this place is the crab salad. Sounds simple, it's made up of 3 measly ingredients: bed of cabbage, dungeness crab (loads of it) and a secret sauce that looks like In-N-Out's house sauce but not. WOW. Every bite gave me that tingle in the sides of my cheek from being absolutely tasty. 

Service is chaotic here, but in a good way. Everyone there looks like they are having fun and making sure their customers are too. 

I think what I would do next time is to just to go my crab salad and continue my food trek through SF. 

Remember to bring cash, they only accept cash!
author: James L.

description:
I can believe the claim that this is the freshest seafood in town. It's a unique experience to sit on one of just a dozen barstools and eat fresh seafood while watching it being prepped behind the counter right in front of you. But I personally wasn't a big fan of the brusque, no-nonsense service and would have been less happy if I had waited several hours in the typical weekend line. 

The crab cocktail (better deal than crab on salad) and clam chowder were excellent. The raw scallops with capers and olive oil were fine, but I wish we had spent those $$ (cash only too!) on more crab!
author: Amy X.

description:
Came here on a Saturday, waited for a good an hour and a half to be seated.

Customer service was the best, all of them seemed very friendly and nice; we were going to order one whole lobster, but they were sold out. So we ordered some oysters and clams; it was my very first time trying the raw big clams and OMG they were super fresh juicy and sweet! The oysters were great too but now I prefer to have the raw clams instead.

Two stars off because they don't wash their hands before putting their hands into the seafood that placed in the front, they put their fingers into the food and put them into customer's place, then wiped their hands with their shirts or a towel that has been sitting on the table for so long, can't imagine how much dirt's the towel has! That's why we didn't order the seafood salad, don't want to get stomach ache. 

I won't come back here for this long line again, maybe ordering to-go or if there isn't a long line.
author: Sammy C.

description:
Swan Oyster Depot, there are so many reasons to love you! You just grab me by the heart and yank. This place has been open forever, just look at all the documented history in the form of pictures on their walls. No, seriously. They've been serving up seafoodgasms since 1912. Yes, that's over a century! This place just embodies and screams San Francisco. It's basically raw bar heaven. 

I love casual spots where you sit on a stool and they serve you up spectacular eats like it's no big deal. It's not the most comfortable seating and having such long limbs doesn't exactly help when you're trying not to elbow duel your neighbors but I'll do a lot of things for great oysters. These guys take their seafood seriously and I'm always happy to reap/eat the benefits. From the moment you walk in, your eyes widen at the glistening creatures of the sea laid out in such an enticing manner. All their offerings are fresh, simple, and delicious. A true religious experience. 

When I come here, I eat until I'm at capacity. It would probably a first and last date if I came here with a guy and he witnessed my transformation from well behaved broad to ravenous beast. That's why I come here with my pal who's nicknamed "The Garbage Disposal" so I can order everything I want with no judgment. So far, I've never tried anything I didn't like. Calamari salad, the famous clam chowder, Dungeness crab legs, combination seafood cocktail, crab fat, and of course, oysters! All bomb. Even the damn sourdough bread is good, it's super crusty with a soft crumb. 

Sure, the wait can be long but don't you dare miss out on this. To be real, I'm probably going to go to sleep tonight dreaming about a crab salad with Louie dressing and as many oysters as I can stuff down my gullet, washed down with a cold Stella.
author: Ruby G.

description:
Amazing. Worth the wait. We showed up 30 minutes after they opened over the holidays. Waited in line for 40 minutes, but enjoyed an Anchor Steam which helped pass the time. Heads up, it's cash only but that's cool because whole you're waiting you can use the Chase ATM across the street. 

Keep an eye out for open seats because the staff won't usher you in, it's super casual. Everyone was so friendly and attentive. We told them it was our first time and they went out of their way to make us feel comfortable, showing us the ropes. The family staff was incredible. 

We ordered a little bit of everything, but the standout was the Blue Point oysters. Crab was amazing- we ordered a cocktail without the cocktail sauce, highly recommended.

Tip/secret: if you know what you want (which is the crab salad) skip the line and stand at the entrance, tell them your order to go and you'll be out of there in under 10 minutes.
author: Shayne S.

description: This place is a top notch seafood joint. The owners are brothers and are both extremely welcoming and friendly. We ordered the clam chowder. It was some of the best I've ever had. We also had the seafood sashimi which was the freshest, tastiest fish I've ever had. The venue is a little small and cramped and the only seating is at the counter. You have to wait in line until people leave before you can sit down. The whole experience is worth it if you are looking for great seafood.
author: Mike S.

description: There was long line to wait! But the seafood is ok. The clam is sooo good . But I don't like the crab salad.
author: Hui L.

description:
If you a lucky enough to snag one of the twenty or so bar stools you absolutely won't forget it. A half dozen to full dozen different oysters flown in daily. Yes they are that fresh, but they have to order them that way, they have been known to sell out certain kinds. Shrimp and crab cocktails are very popular, but if your going to Swan for their clam chowder your out of your mind. Simply put SF has some of th best chowder around and honestly Swan doesn't make the best, it's good, but not great. It's not called Swan chowder company so stick with what they've been known for the past 100 years "Oysters" 

The chefs are great, Eager and honestly they are more fish mongers than the usual chef's you actually get a chance to meet at most restaurants. Not the prep cooks, sous chefs or line cooks. I'm talking about the executives, the head chef, the one's who make the menu is who I'm comparing them to. My usual fish monger gets food just as fresh, but not so much on the variety of oysters and slightly bigger fresh uni. 

Come early and come hungry. I promise you'll leave satisfied. Don't linger, the city has so much more to offer than Swan, the other reason I say that is because there are 100 other people waiting outside by the time you finished reading this. Take pictures, you might not remember how good this place is, but you sure will remember.
author: Walter M.

description:
Yes we waited 45 minutes at 3pm on a Friday, but we've been talking about going here for at least 4 years. My husband saw the line and started with "we can come back some other time...." So impatient, but I tell him "we are here lets just wait". 

So was it worth the wait? Absolutely! The guys behind the counter are cheery when you sit down (not like they've been doing this all day) they get your drinks going and some nice crunchy crusted bread to start. They are chatty and seem to love carving up the fish and designing beautiful plates of food. I went for a crab salad which to some may seem a bit plain, but the chunks of crab are so fresh. I was a happy camper. My husband had first a bowl of chowder (should have tried it, looked creamy but light not super heavy) Then he ordered the Italian Sashimi, a mixture of thinly sliced scallop, salmon, and hamachi drizzled with olive oil, chopped red onions, capers and some cracked pepper. A work of art. My husband actually works with two of the guys working cousin. So of course this got them telling us stories, and as you sit at the long bar you end up chatting with customers next to you. It's old school and only accepts cash (remember that stuff? So bring a good amount so you can have a lot)
It's definitely an institution and I can't wait to go back. Next time we have to try one of those fatty crabs that you dip your bread in....oooooh ahhhhhh. 
Oh yeah my husband was glad "I" made him wait.
author: Susan D.

description:
Another great review to add to this place. I arrived at 10:20 am on a sunny Saturday and waited almost 40 minutes to get a seat for one. I got a small sashimi plate, 6 oysters, and the crab fat.

Sashimi was amazing! My favorite dish. Totally worth it. The crab fat was a little disappointing. I think it really needs to be warm. $7 for essentially scrap crab is a little pricey. Oysters were very fresh, though there was a little shell piece in 2 of them.

This place just oozes old fashioned charm. Was totally worth the wait time and the $37 before tip.
author: S S.

description: Everything is sooo fresh. Great business that has stayed within the family. Good old fashion set up right on the counter with the workers. Had a fix for oysters and they were but bountiful in everything and more. Just keep in mind of the line and have your cash ready.
author: Esthefanie G.

description: Very fresh seafood ! I waited 2 hours and 10 mins to eat at one of the maybe 14 bar stools but it was worth it as everything was yummy ! They only take cash or check so bring at least $ 75 per person so u can try whatever looks good to you ! They sell what they have and when they run out you have to pick something else Last if you don't want to wait you can get it to go at the counter and that is a fast way to eat there
author: Lynette O.

description:
What a great experience. We did wait in line for lunch for an hour and a half. It was worth it. 

We had the dozen oysters mixed, crab fat, sea urchin, and two beers for less than $50. Everything was so fresh and delicious. Well worth the wait!
author: Danielle L.

description: This is not my favorite place in SF. I saw it on Anthony Bourdain and thought YES!! The seafood was fresh and the service was funny. A lot of F bombs. Beyond that it was EXTREMELY over priced even for SF. In very poor condition, literally the stools are ducked taped together!! It could use a professional cleaning. Oh, if you go be sure to bring a lot of cash. They don't except credit cards even at their high price point!!
author: Natalie G.

description: Unbelievable!! Freshest seafood and oysters ever, and the best clam chowder I have ever had. Not too thick, and rich clams flavor. Get there early, always a line out the door, bar seating only.
author: S. S.

description: Freshest seafood I've had in San Francisco yet. Clam chowder, crab fat, combo seafood salad, crab cocktail, dozen oysters, and that great bread. Everything was awesome. Service was good and wait wasn't too long. Definitely will be back again. Go eat here!
author: Hyuk L.

description:
"Here's your maiden voyage", as my server so poignantly articulated while presenting me with a cold, half-shelled mollusk.  

Swan Oyster Depot fed me my first official oyster--unless you count that one time at a Vegas buffet, which clearly this experience verified was a bad, unhealthy oyster... Anyway, as I was saying, the server was a real champ for allowing my boo-ski and I to dabble in what the Swan Oyster Depot had to offer.  After reveling at the fresh, clean taste and excellent texture of the taster, we ordered a half-dozen of Miyagi, a bowl of clam chowder, and a shrimp cocktail.  

In terms of taste, the Miyagi oyster was so fresh that its slight saltiness made anything beyond a squeeze of lemon sudden sacrilege.  The chowder was good, and the shrimp cocktail was everything you would expect from perfectly cooked shrimp.  The prices, though, are hefty, with an average price of $2/oyster sold by the .5 & single dozen.  But, from my Yelp navigation, the costs aren't too bad compared to others, everything just adds up quick.

As it's just a counter-lined restaurant with everyone waiting to catch a seat, SOD can be easily packed.  But the atmosphere is relaxed, and the service is genuine--though we were kind of ignored, maybe we look too young?  The Depot is also CASH ONLY, with the servers tallying up your order via collective memory.  

This spot is a real gem.. no wonder Anthony Bourdain (yeah, I think he's a badass) frequented this restaurant daily but chose not to feature it on his show... some secrets are best kept unsaid!
author: Diane N.

description:
It just doesnt get any better for fresh seafood than this place.

The wait is the only thing that keeps me from coming here 2-3 times a week.

The great food is complimented by the detailed explanations of the freshest selections.

I had a variety of sashimi including the tuna, salmon , and yellowtail. and authentic perfect clam chowder.

Having to wait an extended period is the only thing keeping me from giving 5 stars.
author: Brown B.

description:
Essence of letting the food speak for itself. If seafood is your game, then you definitely want to play at Swan Oyster Bay Co. You MUST get the oyster sampler and the sashimi plate (not listed just ask). 

Get there early! But if you do have to wait don't be discouraged by the wait, because the meal awaiting will change any notion of what you think fresh seafood is. Plus if you are waiting just go to the front and ask for a cup of beer in which they will happily serve you what's on tap in a red cup! 

Skip fisherman's wharf and head straight to one of San Francisco's finest.
author: Robby B.

description: They have really fresh seafood! I was so surprised that I ended up loving the oysters...I normally hate raw oysters due to having tried only bad oysters. I also had the crab fat and mixed sashimi, which was good as well. The only problem I had was that the workers do not wear gloves when handling the food. Other than that, the food was splendid.
author: Monique L.

description:
3 stars? Really? I know, I know. Let me put in the disclaimer first.

DISCLAIMER: I only had the clam chowder soup here. So, take my review how you may.

I live probably 5 minutes away from Swan's (max.) and pass by it frequently. I definitely promise to make another return to have the oysters. My friend and I waited in the 2 hour line to get a counter table but none of us were feeling oysters. By the time we got to that conclusion though, we were not getting out of the line. It's a pride thing at that point. Anyways, the waiter looked at us with pity when we only ordered the soup as if to silently scoff at our uninformed choice. "Didn't these girls pick up on our restaurant name?" he probably thought. 

The soup was average so Mr. Waiter's thoughts were correct. We should've tried the oysters. Everyone else seemed to be super happy and the seafood is undoubtedly fresh. This place is also on Food Network's best eats in SF so it must be good, right?
author: Salma R.

description:
After always seeing a line out the door at Swan Oyster Depot, I finally visited them last week for lunch.  We planned ahead and got there at 10:20am and was able to walk right in.  However, after we sat down there was a line out the door so we got lucky. 

We ordered the clam chowder, dozen of oysters, and the sashimi plate. Food was just okay.  I wish the raw fish was served cold because the fish was warm.  Also, the servers don't wear gloves while handling the food/raw fish and handling the money.  It really grossed me out and the man serving us had bruised finger nails that we're all black.  I wish they would wear gloves while serving and handling the food.

Also, I didn't like how the food in the front window was not covered.  Flys were all over the food and it was disgusting. A health inspector would have a hay day while inspecting this place.

After my visit to Swan Oyster Depot, I was left with a bad case of food poisoning.  Food was not the greatest.  I've had better clam chowder elsewhere. Service wasn't the greatest either.  The man who served us was not that friendly and left in the middle of our lunch.  Their "decorations" on their shelves looked like "dusty junk" that has been sitting there for years. And the food was kind of expensive.  I wouldn't go back there again especially if there was a long line out the door.  And I certainly don't want to pay $80 for food positioning again. :(
author: Gigi M.

description: This place is amazing. We only waited maybe 30-45 minutes to be seated & it was so worth it. My family & I drove 6 hours because we saw this place on delicious destinations & it was so worth it. The men at the counter are so welcoming also. I will definitely be back. I 100% recommend this place.
author: Ann S.

description:
Lets start by saying this is really a locals spot.  Note to self don't wear LA Dodgers apparel to locals spot in SF. 

We decided we were on a foodie trip and we ordered from 3 local spots very close to each other. 

We got 2 dozen combination oysters, clam chowder, smoked salmon and smoked tuna.  All of it was delicious and we really did have a great feast. Packed nice and neatly to eat at the park on a rare sunny San Francisco day. 

I want to go back and try more items.  Also this place is tiny and the line gets long.  Service is slow though and I believe its because they aren't rushing anyone out the door.  So are the way of these older, established, sticking to their tradition, and ways, kind of places.  

Overall I would go back, I would go in disguise, or at  least not looking like Hyujin Ryu while eating in a place where the people serving and eating are Giants fans.
author: Jon G.

description:
I'm not one of those customers who are anal and had a bad day with this restaurant. 
Waited 2 hours for 5 clam chowder bowls and a dozen oysters on a Monday afternoon around 11:30am.  

Only sits about 15 people. 

To order to go you have to flag one of them down, like at a bar in a club. The guy took forever to get that order in and it wasn't worth the wait. 
The clam chowder didn't have shit in it, and we had five different bowls. Just soup. 

I'm all about helping good review places, but the guys who run this joint won't care if you complain cuz no matter what, they will always have business coming in.
author: Alyssa B.

description: OK wow... lived in the city 23 years just around the corner from Swan Oyster Depot. I had picked up their delicious shrimp for a few parties before but never sat at the bar. Decided to bite the bullet today (Tuesday) and finally go - in between jobs so that gave me more flexibility than normal. Arrived at 10am bc I wanted to make sure to get a seat at their 10:30am opening. I was probably number 6 in line and took a seat towards the end of the bar. Just to the left of the higher seats close to the kitchen. I have had the luck of enjoying such great seafood in SF and have to say the Sicilian sashimi still totally blew me away. I started with a "lady" portion but soon ordered another. I had to shut my eyes the fish was so fresh (halibut, salmon, maguro, yellowtail,) and the scallops tasted so sweet and divine.  Also enjoyed the clam chowder. Since I was alone I could enjoy the banter of the manly men working behind the counter. Definitely the type of guys you wish you were hanging with outside of work. One was a very cute marine who gave all his shirts away to charity and  now sees all the homeless wearing them around (overheard.) He was kind enough to notice me juggling my purse and stored it behind the counter. I have to say Tom was the highlight. He made me feel like I was in his home and prepared the stunning sashimi dishes himself. He was lovely. The only sad part was having to leave. Good news is I'll be back with friends and family as soon as possible. Swan Oyster is one of the few institutions that has held on to the old and beautiful vibe of San Francisco... and with great food. Very rare and quite a feat.
author: Win S.

description: Great service. Try to arrive early and miss the lunch rush. Bring home some Salmon smoked in house...it was soooo good. they have decent portions and fresh shellfish. I cant attest for much else since I go for shrimp, oysters and Smoked salmon.
author: J. G.

description:
Got there at 11am, on a Saturday morning. Waited 2 hours to get in. The Door Face's West. Gets direct noon sun. This day happened to be a Hot Day. Making it a trying 2 hours. Actually, hoping for Fog to cover the sun. We made it though. At the door, I was greeted by one of the owners and asked us how long we were waiting. We broke the sad news to him He promptly asked if we wanted something to drink,,,Soda, Water...a Cold Beer. We took the Stella Beer. We Still waited another 10 minutes or so till we finally got our seats. There he promptly took our half glasses of beer and topped them off. No questions asked. He made us feel at home. Told us about the Specials of the day and took our order. In between waiting, he came by and chatted with us. Very Friendly. Almost felt like family.

We ended up having the Oysters from Northern California and Canada. Totally to die for. The Crab Combo seafood salad, Very Fresh. Iceberg lettuce with seafood sprinkled on top, served with oil & vinegar or a home made thousand island dressing. Pretty Simple. Stella Beer to wash down.

Pros:

- Cool friendly atmosphere.
- Tasty and fairly priced fresh seafood, crab and of course, oysters.
- Family owned and ran for years.

Cons:

- I'm not sure that it was worth the wait. Almost 2 hours on a Saturday.
- Cash Only.
author: J G.

description:
You can find really fresh seafood here. That is what makes this place great. In general, they do very little to the food. We had chowder, crab salad, beer and oysters. Everything was spot on. The big chunks of fresh crab meat was great. The horseradish and sauce combo on the oysters were delicious. 

We showed up on a Friday at 10 AM and we got in when they opened (10:20ish) We were in and out quick. It was very fun, but probably not worth the wait unless you have nothing else to do.
author: Ryan M.

description: Swan's is as good as it gets. Stand in line, belly up to the counter, order and eat. One can't find seafood of a higher quality, always fresh and delicious. Great Louie dressing, great cocktail sauce and great bread accompany the excellent crab and oysters. The servers are kind and attentive. This on-hands dedication to the best food and service is the reason Swan's superb reputation remains untarnished by swiftly changing culinary trends.
author: Jane K.

description: This place is everything I heard & expected it to be. This staff is full of rock stars! They're fun, funny & extra helpful worldly dudes with a super laid back approach. The seafood is all so fresh & delicious. This place is everything you would want your small business to be. I love these guys
author: LaDarian D.

description: My wife and I decided  to wait in the usual line due to some previous information about this place. So a few days ago we waited in line until we witnessed the following: The food is located in the front window ( unrefrigerated by the way), and the prep cook approaches. He looked as if he just climbed out of a dumpster. His apron was embedded with a yellowish-green slime and he began preparing a lunch for some unsuspecting sap with his bare hands. ( Thats right after he wiped his face and nose with his bare hands mind you). No gloves. This is right in front of the customer who is getting ready to pay $ 30.00 for a case of food poisoning. I'd give the place a zero if I could. My wife and I left. Good luck taking your chances. Just watch to see for yourself how your lunch will be prepared.
author: Joseph K.

description:
Oysters are so fresh here.  I could eat a dozen to my self.  
Smoked salmon: could do without, still doesn't compare to russ and daughters in nyc
Fresh uni: seasonal and so amazing!  They serve it to you out of the prickly shell and the tentacles are still moving when its in front of you.  All it needed was a splash of lemon
I'm a big fan of their clam chowder.  Perfect blend of creamy and broth.  Can't beat the service here either.  Love the mom and pop feel of the place
author: vivian p.

description:
Sort of a pain in the -ahem- to get a seat in this SF institution, particularly after the hoi polloi discovered the place, but perhaps that just adds to the charm of the situation.  

Super fresh seafood, super salty staff.  They do shuck a mean oyster, and the chowder's light enough that you don't regret ordering a bowl.

Requires some advance planning, shoes you don't mind standing in, and a thick skin so you don't mind all the people staring at the back of your neck as they're waiting in line for your seat while you slurp.
author: Audrey L.

description: Ok, ok seriously, this place is the home of the best Clam Chowder I have ever eaten.  We stood in line for freaking forever, about 45 minutes, before we couldn't stand it any longer.  It was leave or get food to go.  The guys who run this place are funny and friendly and just plain nice.  We picked up a couple of quarts of Clam Chowder and it tasted like the freshest seafood chowder ever.  The line was crazy and wasn't moving even a little, so at least you have the option of picking up food to go.  We couldn't wait to eat and once we got our chowder, we sat at the bus stop eating till all the chowder was gone.
author: Lyssa D.

description:
After eating at the Swan Oyster Depot (Swan), the only thing that came to my mind was I should have gone to the other oyster place. 

Upon getting my rental from SFO (btw longest fucking lines ever at an airport rental car location), my wife and I went straight to the Swan. Due to San Francisco as a whole having shitty parking and the Swan being no exception, we were lucky enough to find meter parking across the street in front of the Walgreens. 

On a side note, I'd like to take the time here to thank the employees at Walgreens because all the parking meters along Polk Street are coin-only and the employees at Walgreens were really cool about me getting change without having to buy any obligatory merchandise. Seriously thanks, for making change for me on two separate runs. That's right, you heard me I had to make change twice. I think a quarter only bought me 6 fucking minutes. So yea, when you get change, ask for $5 worth of quarters. 

What seemed like an hour line (there were only 12 people ahead of us) ended up being nearly 1 hour and 40 minutes because this place is fucking tiny. Whether it was battling the frigid outdoor wind gusts, the glare of the angry Metro PCS worker at the adjoining store next door because the line cuts across their business, or the fucking homeless people smoking and begging for money, we persevered with the hopes of having the best oyster experience in our lives. I mean Yelp said this place was 4.5 stars after all. 

Well when we finally got in and were seated, we instantly realized why the line took so long. The turnaround here is insanely slow and their system of taking orders is ridiculous. Some Yelpers commented on this place being old-fashioned and rustic. Okay, I'll give it that since the restaurant and the workers are old. But for fucks sake, I don't want to grow old here waiting for my food. Let's just say, repeating our order to the same worker three times was really frustrating. Moreover, having to tell the worker what we ordered when we were getting the bill was equally annoying. The only positive about the bad service was the complementary pint of Anchor Steam for their constant fuck ups. 

Anyways, due to the recommendations of other Yelpers, we ordered the combination salad, an extra order of crab cocktail, a cup of watery clam chowder, and of course Kumamoto and Miyagi oysters. The crab here is really good and you don't need to get your hands dirty because the crabs are cracked and shelled for you by the little Chinese ladies in the back and all you get is the meat. The clam chowder is really clammy and should be called clam soup because it's not as thick as traditional chowder. The oysters were awesome, but then again, how can you fuck up an oyster when all you have to do is shuck them. 

After eating our meal, which took 20 minutes, actually 30 minutes since it took us another 10 minutes to flag the worker for the bill, I really felt underwhelmed. 2 hours and 10 minutes for an experience that was sub-par is just not 4.5 star worthy. Sigh... The following day when I went to the Ferry Building I saw a rival oyster restaurant where you don't need to wait over an hour just to eat oysters that are probably caught by the same fucking fishermen. 

To sum it up, I really don't know what the hype about this place is about. The next time I want fresh oysters I'm either driving up to Tomales Bay or going to the Ferry Building.
author: Richard K.

description:
I have to preface this review by saying that we ate here early in the morning.  So, I'm not sure if my stomach was ready.

What we had:

- Clam Chowder - I would probably not order this again.  It tasted almost water down and lack very little substance.  I was expecting a chowder chalk full of clams, but this was not the case.

-Seafood cocktail - This I enjoy.  A bit on the pricey side, but it had a good amount of shrimp and crab.  The seafood was fresh and sweet, just the way that it should be.

-Oysters - Also, very fresh and full of flavor.

It is a very small shop, so I would not suggest coming here with a big group of people.  Overall, a good experience.
author: Phat T.

description:
Always the sucker for dining places with history and character, and being an irrepressible fan of seafood, Swan Oyster Depot was a must-stop for me in SF.  As it worked out, I headed over there for an early weekday meal, so the long counter that's probably usually bustling was empty.  That's it on the seating for Swan Oyster, a place that's been in business for nearly a century, and changing hands only once, is family run for over 50 years.  The decor is workaday, with a comfortable, broken-in feel.  A real highlight eating here is the staff; knowledgeable about the seafood, friendly but in a genuine, not trained, sort of way, and incredibly entertaining to listen to as they banter among themselves.

After securing a local Anchor Steam, I started off with a mixed platter of a dozen oysters, fresh and delicious on a bed of ice with accompaniments.  Then onward to their famous Boston clam chowder, a style I'm unfamiliar with.  The soup was very thin in consistency but lots of clams and flavor; jury is out for me, I think I still prefer a thicker texture.  Ended with a combination seafood cocktail, another winner, fresh seafood that can stand on its own.

This is a place to have an awesome, casual, seafood dining experience.  The seafood quality is excellent, although not uniquely so.  But this sort of atmosphere can't be manufactured and for that, it is well worth experiencing and going back for.
author: Valery C.

description:
Highlights: 
- Fresh seafood displayed right in the front of the shop, so you can see what you are about to indulge in. 
- Things that will make you visit here worthwhile, oysters and salmon.

Improvements:
- Skip the clam chowder. It just didn't taste like the smooth creamy chowder that I have grown to love. 

Tip: Go early so that you can be in the first wave for seats and not have to wait too long.
author: Tracy T.

description:
Wow, it feels like walking into a local seafood joint in Seattle. Love the atmosphere and the general feel of the place, very homey and pleasant. 

Clam chowder is really good! I generally don't really like clam chowder and here's why: places usually put too much corn starch to thicken the soup or too much cream to make it creamy, or skimp on the seafood. This place did everything BUT that. It was homemade, you can taste the clams, it wasn't too heavy so eating a whole bowl was no problem. The clam chowder is the only thing they serve hot/cook there, everything else is raw. 

Oyster assortment: half dozen, comes out to about 13 dollars. It was great tasting all the different kinds and my favorite is the Alaskan oyster. They are smaller in size but very fat and fresh. 

Only drawback is the wait and limited seating. It fits about 15-20ish people at the bar at one time, so if you come during a busy time, expect a long wait.
author: Amy L.

description: We didn't realize this place closes so early, even on weekdays. We grabbed a to-go order of the crab salad and bowl of clam chowder. While everything was fresh, it failed to impress. The crab was sweet and plentiful but you get what you pay for. The clam chowder on the other hand was watery and I felt like there were instances where there was sand in my mouth. Perhaps there was too much hype around this place. We had several friends that would spend their weekend afternoons waiting in line to eat here. I'm not sure I would do that. I really wanted to like this place since we moved close by, but it's not likely that we will make a return.
author: Tiffany L.

description:
This place has been OVERHYPED to say the least.

The oysters are good, but how hard is it to get fresh oysters? Forget about anything on the menu that requires any preparation. While sitting on the counter that fits 20 people max, I had the chance to observe the hectic scrambling on the other side. Everyone behind the counter were loud and friendly, talking to the customers, talking to each other, talking to themselves... there was not much order to anything that went on. 

The clam chowder was more like a clam broth than a chowder. The flavor was good, but there weren't much clam or anything else in it. The mixed seafood cocktail had good portions of a variety of sea creatures. I was tempted to to get the sashimi with olive oil, but as I ordered with the guy behind the counter, he started to use an old rag to wipe down the cutting board which had 10 different plates placed on them and covered with remanents of different seafood scraps. Luckily I was able to stop him from making the order, which felt like the best decision I made all day.
author: Lisa Q.

description:
line is long, prices are high, but boy is that mixed seafood salad somehow actually a $20 portion of food. It doesn't seem like it'll be that much food when you get it but finishing it is a challenge and it's not just filler, it's really a ton of seafood.

The chowder is pretty solid too, I'd get a cup of that as well. I mean you already waited in line for an hour, you might as well spend an extra two bucks. I must say though, the raw bar stuff is too rich for my blood and i feel like when I can afford it I'll be too lazy to wait in line again.
author: Misha T.

description:
I'm neither an expert or fan of oysters, but I wanted to try this place anyway, given its popularity.  

Since these are supposedly the best oysters in the city, I was hoping this place would convert me to an oyster lover.  Sadly, no life changing experience here.  I got the mixed dozen, and while they were in fact good, I can still give or take them.  

The crab back, on the other hand...  Bread dipped into the crab back "soup" was delicious!  What's crab back? Don't ask, just eat it. It's wonderful. 

I also got the half crab.  The crab legs were nicely sweet, and they pretty much crack the shells open for you. And after waiting in line for two hours, it was nice to be able to just eat!  No fussing with those futile plier gadgets!  And the service is super quick once you finally sit down.  They place beer and food in front of you so fast that the pain from waiting in line melts away....
author: Riz W.

description: How much do I love Swan? Enough to make this a must-do each time I'm in SF. I'm a huge fan of the oysters, clam chowder (no-nonsense and hearty) and crab salad, but it's always a treat to go with whatever is fresh for the day. Waiting in line is never a hassle when you are choked full of anticipation for what is to come - I recommend grabbing a coffee and getting there early! I also love the banter that happens at the bar - both with the staff and amongst patrons. There's just such a bustling, happy vibe running through the place!
author: Eugenie Y.

description: Amazing. The oysters from Humboldt were delicious and the bread although looking slightly burnt is actually full of flavor
author: Henry C.

description:
On our last San Francisco trip, being seafood lovers (specifically of the oyster variety) we researched local "insider" destinations for these treasures of the seas.

We discovered SOD, which had not only been featured on Anthony Bourdain's "Layover", but also named as one of the "most important restaurants in America" by Bon Appetit.  In fact, this unassuming nonpareil of seafood delicacies ranging from Kumamoto oysters to Salmon caught in British Columbia was the pinnacle of our San Francisco getaway.  Having been here for a century, still family owned and operated, it is a "must try" on anyone's list of foodie destinations.

We waited in line for 30 min on a Tuesday afternoon (approx. 12:30).  From reading the other reviews, it was evident that we were extremely lucky with our short wait time.  But I want to stress again and again that it is worth the wait!!!

We found our seats at the end of the long seafood bar, and began our seafood adventure with a bottle of Honig winery's Sauvignon blanc, a sweet honeyed Napa Valley vintage which pairs beautifully with seafood.

We relished a mixed dozen of oysters for only $28 - Miyagis from the Pacific NW, small and sweet Kumamotos, and Blue Points from Massachusetts.  The oysters were incredibly clean, meat separated easily from the shell and was phenomenal with their homemade horseradish and cocktail sauce.

The Ahi tuna and Salmon that we savored had been caught yesterday in BC and the Scallops came from the Bay of Fundi in Nova Scotia.  This sashimi platter was served with olive oil, capers, onions, and lemon and was the freshest sashimi we had ever tasted.

Along with our numerous meals, fresh baked San Fran style bread was served with that lovely sourdough taste.

The smoked salmon from BC was outstanding and came recommended by Jimmy and Eric - outstanding resources, fun conversation, and extremely knowledgable gentleman working here at SOD.

And the cracked crab....there is a reason why more than a thousand Yelpers as well as the employees here recommend it: buttery, fresh, succulently juicy. Having had crab up and down California coasts and locally and seasonally this is by far the most exquisite!  A divine grand finale for our seafood sojourn.

$140 for the lot, and worth every dollar spent.
author: Jacqueline M.

description: Love this place but the wait/line sucks.  Fresh on all the menu, maybe to be fair I'll go 4 stars but really 3 is about it because of the hassle.
author: Brian K.

description:
If you come around here at peak lunch time, be prepared to wait.  My brother and I waited here for a good hour, and there was no place to sit down while you were waiting. This place is loved by all locals and tourists alike so timing is very important.

Ordered the combination salad filled with shrimps and crab. Super fresh, succulent, and tasty with the mayo drenched over the seafood. 

We also ordered 8 oysters and split it among the two of us. The server was explaining where all the oysters came from.  I honestly don't remember, and I don't care because they all tasted good!. 

REMEMBER TO BRING CASH. This place is a bit overrated and bit pricey for the amount they give you. I honestly had better oysters elsewhere, but if this is your first time at SF, visit here for that SF experience.
author: Noel K.

description:
Walked in just in time for the first seating at 10:30. You need to be 15 minutes early to guarantee a spot but I got lucky. The line filtered in and I followed.
Bar seating on stools all the way down. You can listen as the servers tell others the specials and get an idea of what you want. There's also a large menu board on the wall.
I tried the combo cocktail with crab, shrimp, mussels, oyster and cocktail sauce, as well as a cup of their chowder and a medium "sushi" plate. The sushi which was really sashimi was great, I added a little squeeze of lemon to go with the capers and shallot. The chowder was fresh and the cocktail bowl was as you'd expect. Cash only.
author: Dan W.

description:
While the sea food is decent, I didn't think it lived up to all the hype.  Nor was it worth the hour long wait for a table.  I'm sure this place was a gem back in the day, but now it's just filled with tourists eating thin chowder at a dirty, crowded bar.  

Glad I can check it off the list, but there are too many fantastic raw bars around town to settle for this when I need my next oyster fix.  

BTW, if you're particular about cleanliness, try not to watch the guys prep your meal with the same unwashed hands that just handled a wad of cash before reaching into a bucket of wet rags to wipe down the counter...
author: Diana C.

description: We got to the restaurant at around 10:20 (10 mins before opening time) and luckily had to only wait for 5 mins to get a table. The place is small and has only about 10-12 spots and being in a small group (2 to 3 people) will reduce the wait time by a lot. The clam chowder, seafood cocktail and oysters were pretty good. The crab back was disappointing; it had a very sandy texture. I don't think this place is worth waiting in line for hours.
author: Supriya S.

description: Food is pretty good, everything I had tasted fresh. Friendly service. A bit in the pricey side even by SF standards, I was by myself, had a couple of beers with my meal and my bill was $61 not including the tip.
author: Colin P.

description: Most of the seafood is shelled and on ice. Had the crab and prawn salad and it was ok. The dressing is very heavy. There are only a handful of seats at the counter so the wait can get long. I was only able to order to-go, but I would come back to give this place another try.
author: Diane Z.

description:
WE LOVED OUR MEAL AT SWAN OYSTER DEPOT.

We came straight from the airport from Chicago, and were so pleased with the beautiful weather and the SHORT wait at Swan!  We went between 10am and 11am and probably waited around 25-30 minutes.  The stools are uncomfortable and it's not a cheap meal, but MAN is the food amazing and FRESH.

We ate:  
-sourdough and butter (real good bread)
-clam chowder (A++++, even my fiance who doesn't like creamy stuff loved it)
-a dozen mixed oysters (obviously amazing, and shucked a few feet away from us to order)
-a combination salad with louis sauce (very good)

The bill was not cheap, but it was well worth the wait and the dollars.  Glad we got there when we did--the wait after us was LONG.  It's an institution, and well worth it.
author: Kate W.

description:
I gotta admit, this place had me at the bathroom. Although everything is prepared in front of you, you break the fourth wall a little more by having to walk through their kitchen to use the bathroom. The back kitchen smells like fresh sea food. Nothin' fishy about it. I know it's silly, but I fell in love before I even sat down.

Had the mixed dozen oysters. All fresh, all delicious. So good, I didn't really want to top them with too much, just a little horseradish and lemon, but they also have cocktail sauce. 

The clam chowder here had me make a conscious decision to not lick the bowl clean. 

I want to come back to try every other goddamn thing they have here.

DIDN'T WAIT IN LINE because I came here on Tuesday afternoon around 4:30pm. Come around closing :) They'll still sit ya even if it's after 5.
author: Brian S.

description:
Pros
-beer and wine to the last group before the cut off for the line.
- Clam chowder (not your original clam chowder soup; more soupy )
- pawn and crab cocktail 
- mixed oyster ( it's really fresh, but I encounter some sand)
- live sea urchin, the shell was still moving!

Cons
- REALLY long line ( I took 2hr an a half)
- parking can be a pain (street parking)
- not good for groups (my advice 2-3 people)
- they only have bar seating.
- they make their food without gloves 
(If you don't mind them using their hand to make your salad)
author: Vivian S.

description: There's something to be said for a place that serves what they have THAT DAY because it's freshly delivered based on what's available. line out the door waited over an hour for oysters but man! If you're around this place, stop and wait...if you think you don't like oysters stop and try them again. The sauces they serve with them the and the fresh, shucked in front of your face delicious oysters are definitely worth the wait and price. CASH ONLY.
author: Justin And Leah P.

description:
Heard a lot about this place...an iconic landmark in San Francisco.  The wait was not too crazy as I went on Monday @ noon so it was only a 15-20 minute wait.  With booth Seating of 15-20, it limits the amount of turnover; however, service was not compromised.  

The gentleman was helpful but you can def tell they are more open to advising "women."  Anyways, I was taken back by pricing a little but finally realized it's the norm in SF.  Figured that the city is so close to waters, seafood would be reasonably priced but it's just as pricey as NY.  

Two of us shared the seafood combo a la "louie style ("thousand island esque)," Half a cracked crab, mix oysters, and "crab fat."  The oysters and half cracked crab were fresh.
Two girls next to us ordered the crab fat and I asked if it was good and they said yes if you like uni.  I ordered it...super fresh and buttery but adding a hint of salt would have made a world of difference.  As for the seafood combo, it was def the best item I had during the visit.  Besides the seafood being fresh, the louie dressing was surprisingly lite and refreshing.  

Overall, it was good but like many other reviews states, it is a bit overrated.  My opinion is based on the fact most of their menu items require no cooking.  This place epitomizes California cuisine...let fresh ingredients speak for itself.
author: Ricky C.

description:
Get one their salads and an Anchor Steam. Their sourdough bread is awesome and the crew is always friendly.

The wait can be miserable because you can smell all the deliciousness wafting out the door as you stand in line on the sidewalk. 

Once you're in; however, they don't rush you in typical turn and burn fashion. The crew seems to love what they do and although it is a little on the pricy side, you get a solid amount of seafood for what you pay for. 

This isn't your 5 shrimp "bucket o shrimp" kind of place. They load it up and everything I've had is fresh and amazing. 

A staple to any visit to San Francisco, one of the places I truly miss not living in the city anymore. 

Auf
author: Dave K.

description:
Preface: This is going to be a negative review but it is honest and justified, in my opinion. I am not the 'sue-Mcdonalds-over-spilled-coffee' type person. I am reasonable and will say bad things only when necessary--please keep this in mind.

I had a horrid experience at this unclean hellhole. Please, do yourself a favor, and realize that the wait is not worth it, and it's mostly just tourists here that are perpetuating their business and unjustified inflated prices.

I came on a Tuesday, at 10:20AM, 10 minutes before this joint was set to open. There was already a line of about 12 people (4 of them being some annoying kids who you know will be noisy). Alright, whatever. They actually started to let people in at 10:35AM--way to be punctual (you'd think they can get it right after so many years). Everyone sat down on wobbly bar stools and was served--that is, except us. While everyone around us were being served by cheerful smiles and greetings, we sat with blank stares wondering when someone would acknowledge our presence. Was it a racial issue? Maybe. Was it poor management? Perhaps. Is it because our server is senile and only makes like $20 an hour after working so many years? I mean, wrist dysfunction and customer service can take a toll on you. Maybe I'm being selfish and not considering what hardships our server went through. Then again, that's the nature of customer service though--customer first, and we definitely felt last. We literally were being ignored by about every service worker for about 15 minutes as we did nothing. Some would give us slight glances but quickly remove eye contact because they didn't want to feel any responsibility--talk about the bystander effect. We felt extremely marginalized and I already pictured myself writing this review and giving no tip. When you feel this way, where everyone around you is already eating and being merry while you're sitting looking stupid, then that's a red flag for a zero tip and a 1-star Yelp review. When you feel you have to beg for service like a second class citizen in the Civil Rights era, you're in the wrong place and should do something about it, be it a passive-aggressive Yelp review or leaving a penny (because who wants to make a scene?). I wish I had half a penny. How could we enjoy our food when the service is extremely poor?

The clam chowder? Too thin and tasteless.
Oh, when this came out, he gave us no spoons. We waited about 3 minutes to see if he would notice--nope, we had to ask. Furthermore, when our rude server put utensils in front of us, he threw it down on the bacteria cultured counters instead of setting it nicely on a napkin. Again, feeling marginalized.

The oysters? Pretty good, honestly--get the mixed dozen. But you don't need to come here in a 1-hour line for good oysters.

The smoked salmon open faced sandwich? Nothing special. It looked good, but when we compared it to how he prepared it for some other customers, ours looked nasty. How appalling.

When the Asian lady from the back came to put more ice in some bins up front, she definitely used her dirty hands on the ice. This is the same ice that your glass cups sit in and where you put your mouth. Who knows how many rats are singing in the back.

Lastly, the big slab of smoked salmon where the servers were cutting from was just sitting out in the open in a room at STP (standard temperature and pressure). In other words, it wasn't on ice so I wonder how many bacteria colonies were forming. It should be some sort of chilled surface.

In summary, this place is a POS and no native from SF who has any sense should come here when there's so many other better places that won't charge you ridiculous prices for sub-fresh seafood. It's all tourists in the line and it should stay that way so they don't come to the places that are actually worthwhile.

Please, save your money and your soul, don't let them play you for a belittled sucker.
author: Marlon T.

description: Stepped right up to the bar and sat with my wife. Ordered a Stella and waited about 2 minutes for a crab cocktail, a dozen oysters and San Francisco sourdough bread with butter. Expertly executed and reasonable priced. Definitely a place to visit again and again and again..,
author: Fernando L.

description:
Some of the freshest seafood in town. Every time I visit San Francisco, I make it a point to stop by here. They have never failed me and have always delivered. There isn't a single item on their menu that is anything less than expected. 

The one thing I wish they had more of is a bigger beer selection, although anchor steam goes great any day.
author: Andrew L.

description: Let me first say that this place usually has a line of people that goes at least 15 depot - just for a seat. We decided to go just after 12 on a Thursday and were able to grab seats just before the rush. The guys serving the food were great and really friendly while the fish and seafood were incredibly fresh. We had the oyster combo dish which was served with lemon and fresh cocktail sauce. It was so good. Had the shrimp salad that was to die for and we ordered a dish that was off the menu but saw a patron had it at a previous visit. It was heavenly, fresh scallops that were sliced thin over capers, peppers and olive oil. This is a must visit spot when in San Fran!
author: Chrissie W.

description: Had a $30 mixed dozen of Vibrio parahaemolyticus Oysters. So disppointing getting food poisoning after waiting 2hrs and over-tipping. 3 days of misery.
author: Tom L.

description: The world class reputation is inarguably justified. The crab fat, oysters, whole Dungeness crab, and Uni are all off-the-charts spectacular!
author: Jay Y.

description:
The five stars is based on overall dining experience.

Fresh seafood, great atmosphere, casual yet helpful staff!! One of the best eating experience I've had, despite the 1.5 hour wait...

The food was delightful. Everything was so fresh. They don't cook anything, but they make everything from scratch, even the smoked salmon.

The only concern I have is that they seem to be operating outside of the California health code laws... Maybe the law in SF is different from that of LA? But aren't these 'State' laws?... They don't even have their health code ratings on display...mhm.

But totally worth it!!
author: Brandon S.

description:
Grossly overrated seafood counter  / shop.  After waiting in line for 45 minutes, the boyfriend, sister and I took a seat at the counter.   We ordered a bowl of clam chowder, a smoked salmon platter which came with a shrimp side salad, and half a dozen raw oysters.  The clam chowder was decent, needing more clams, and done proper Boston style thickened with potatoes.  Smoked salmon platter was also okay but nothing to write home about.  Oysters were fresh but you can get similar levels of freshness at other places around the city for the same price.
For the prices, portions were small.  I would expect to see their prices at fine dining establishments in the area.  Service was average -- I did like that it was not rushed.

smoked salmon platter -- go two blocks North down Polk to The Bagelry and get their lox bagel sandwich for $7

This place has been overhyped by the tourist guidebooks.
author: Catherine A.

description:
Overrated. 

I came here knowing there would be a long line and assuming this was the holy grail of seafood in the Bay area. Faaaar far off. 

So there are two lines. One to sit, and one for takeout. You'd have no idea two exist unless you stepped out of line to ask about the takeout line. This is when I realized there was no organization here.

None of the guys behind the counter grabbing the fish etc... used gloves. I noticed this was the norm in the mission district, where at least their aprons weren't splattered in filth. That WAS NOT the case here. Their aprons were raunchy and looked as if they were working in a meat shop. Just disgusting.

Then the food. I paid 20 bucks for shrimp,  salmon peices and over lettuce. There was no seasoning and nothing awesome about it. I was so confused.

Skip the disappointment at all costs.
author: Russell B.

description:
I've passed by this place so many times and never wanted to wait in line. I gave in for once. Yes, it's good but the wait totally kills it. We waited for about 45 minutes only to be inside eating for about 20 minutes.

While the oysters are good, you can get these anywhere. You can buy Kumamoto's for $1 elsewhere so there really isn't a point of waiting in line for oysters.

The combination salad was pretty legit. Fresh crab (juicy meat) and shrimp. If you really want to try this, just skip the line and order it to go. I heard they package everything pretty nicely for to go orders.

Pricing is up there. $20 for a half crab? Damn! Bill was $45 for the combo salad, 6 oysters and a beer.

No plans on coming back anytime soon and if I do, to go orders or under 15 minute waits only. Otherwise, forget it.
author: Ken N.

description: Authentic seafood in SF? YES! The hardest part is chosing what to order. Sea urchin, oysters of all kinds, crab cocktail, and smoked fish are my favorites...
author: Darren H.

description:
3rd time here. I came here Monday morning about 15 min before opening and there was hardly a queue. Stark difference from 2 weeks back when I came 45 min before opening and managed to squeeze into the first seating.

A dozen of combination oysters ($30) - 3x 4 varieties. I only remember the Miyagi and the Kumamotos. Really fresh. Have always gotten a dozen every time I come. They change up the variety depending on what they have.

Sashimi platter ($28) - First time I got this. Combination of raw scallop, salmon and tuna dressed generously with olive oil, capers and pepper. My favorite has to be the scallop. Super sweet and fresh. While the fish was really fresh, I still prefer my raw fish plain and without the dressing (i.e. japanese sashimi style). 

Seafood combination cocktail ($12) - I really like this. It was a combination of small prawns, crab meat, big prawn, raw clam and topped off with an oyster. 

I also sampled the crab butter. I ultimately did not get a portion of it because I would have preferred it richer with more intense crab roe flavor. Pretty good nonetheless. 

Still a 5 stars overall. The seafood cocktail and oysters were so fresh and delicious. Other things I may consider trying in the future include the sea urchin (they open it up for you on the spot!) 

I would still wait in line in the future, though my preference would be to go in the morning before it opens so that the wait wouldn't be so long since I have ever waited 2 hours in the afternoon and in the rain (first time i went there). This place isn't the cheapest, but worth it. Also remember to bring cash as they don't accept payment by card!
author: Olivia P.

description:
Crap...his place has gotten too famous because of some tv shows ......we use toncme In and sit down and enjoy a plate or two of oysters. We did today, but we're lucking since after we arrived there was a line of about 20 people waiting to get in.....
Huh, well I should just enjoy the place like I remember it from my days growing up here.
We had two dozen oysters, a smoked samoan plate and a crab cocktail plus 3 glasses of wine for only a hundred and twenty bucks.....what a deal...
It was still worth it and we didn't have to wait.....
I wouldn't stand in line for the place, but the food is fresh but nothing special.....
author: Matt G.

description:
Get the oysters!

Sure, they have wonderful scallop sashimi, and the uni is wonderful, when they have it, but the oysters are really what they are about.

Be prepared for a long wait.
author: Cary G.

description:
If you're expecting an upscale or trendy lunch spot, this is *not* the place to grab lunch. If, however, you're looking for a charming, classic spot with super fresh seafood, you're probably heading in the right direction! My boyfriend suggested Swan Oyster Depot for lunch while we were in the area and the line out the door just confirmed his recommendation. 

The space is small, so be prepared to wait a bit for a spot to clear up. With the two of us it wasn't much of an issue, but I would imagine it would be a different (read: impossible!) situation with a larger group! The food was fresh and the service was incredibly friendly. We split an order of oysters and I opted for the clam chowder while he got the combination salad. The clam chowder was perf -- not overly rich and creamy, just clean and delish. Our half dozen oysters included 2 of each variety and we loved them all! The only downside is that it IS a bit expensive for a lunch stop. Lunch was around $45 for the two of us and I only had a bowl of soup! That being said, it's still a great spot and definitely a San Franciscan experience for any tourists! :)
author: Shannon E.

description:
Unfortunately, my review is only going to be of the food that my fiancee and I were able to take out. We showed up on an early Friday afternoon, and there was a huge line (people who had been there before said it was 2 hours long) - and I didn't have anywhere near the change (nor the patience) to keep feeding the meter for that long. That said, you can order takeout, which is a lot quicker and will quench your appetite sooner.

We grabbed an order of smoked salmon and some clam chowder and chowed down in the car before heading out. I know there's a bunch of clam chowder out here, but I prefer the creamier, thicker versions that come out of Boston and the Northeast to the Left Coast version. That said, despite the thinner soupiness, the flavor was still good, and the broth had a lot more of the clam flavor coming through. The smoked salmon was heaven - not sure there's really much more to add to it, but wow is it awesome. They just load you up with some slices of some of the juiciest strips of salmon, loaded with that smokiness, along with a good amount of bread and some butter. Put a little butter on the bread, grab a piece of salmon, and partake. The fresh stuff is so much better than buying it in a packet at the store...enough said.

I'd love to come back sometime and maybe sit down, but I don't know if I can endure that kind of wait. There's always takeout, though, and for that, I will definitely visit again when I'm back in town.
author: Asuka N.

description:
Super fresh seafood. Love the atmosphere. Sit up on the counter and be ready to gorge on the best seafood! Their clam chowder is great, then I just get an array of oysters and shrimp cocktail. Their cocktail sauce and mignonette are amazing!  Most items come with hearty bread and butter, which is a nice base for all the protein you're eating. 

Don't come with a crowd - best with just a buddy or two so you can split.  

Ca$h only - there is a chase ATM across the street.
author: Karen S.

description:
It was my last day in the lovely city of SF. I had 3 hours before I leave for my flight and needed spend those 3 hours smartly... meaning, what must I eat and how best can I do it? 

Swan Oyster has been on my list for the longest. Reading the reviews, I knew there was going to be a line. Since I didn't have any time to waste, it was my first spot to hit. Oysters for breakfast? No lie, I had my reservations, but YOLO right?

According to Yelp, Swan opens at 10:30am. I got there at 10am and there was already a line. No fret, it gave me time to plan my next stop. Plus, in front of me the "residents of SF" (aka the original hipsters), were chatting about some movie production and sang some songs. Also helped that they were equipped with beer, paper bags, and had enough to share with little o' me. Beer at 10am on the streets on SF? Yep, YOLO. #brownbaggingitdontcare

When they finally opened (11am), we filed in, taking in the seats along the bar. Very quickly, the men behind the counter took orders and fulfilled. Though they didn't have sea urchin that day, I was very happy with my selection - 3 miyagi oysters, 3 kumamoto oysters, and 1 cup of their famous chowder. The oysters were sweet, briny, and fresh. The chowder had little cream, which is what I prefer, and each scoop was filled with clams. So yummy! Didn't have the room to order their cracked crab or the seafood salad, but maybe next time when I return with more people.
