Guys with the beer: if you happen to read this... thanks again and hope you enjoyed your first round on me. :)
author: Lily C.

description:
4 stars for the 2 dozens oysters I inhaled and 3 stars for the other food

Came here for an early birthday meal this year. I was in between jobs so got to Swan Oyster Depot at 10:30am. Found free parking across the street and no line! Yay! 

I ordered - 1 dozen oysters, small bubbly and raw scallops.
They were clean, fresh and perfect.

Convinced hubby to get the crab salad but found it too heavy and creamy.
The clam chowder was runny and didn't really taste any clams.

Since we had a late lunch reservation elsewhere didn't want to ruin my appetite.
So went back to my oysters and ordered a dozen more and said happy birthday to myself 

Was good to check this off my sf bucket list given I have looked at the lines and driven away for many years. If I came back it would be for the nostalgia and the oysters given there is no line and I am not going to pt Reyes over the weekend
author: Cookie M.

description: Despite the lines to get in, a trip to Swan Oyster Depot is always worth it.  Nothing better than some chowder and a Crab Louie salad.  A must for anyone living in or visiting San Francisco.
author: Nick W.

description:
After seeing this place featured on Anthony Bourdain's The Layover a week before my trip, I KNEW I had to add it to my list of places to stop and try. Knowing full well that there would be a line, my boyfriend, best friend and I made it the first stop of the day at 10am on a Saturday morning. We waited about 20 minutes, so it wasn't too bad. We maybe just had to wait a few more minutes before we could get a seat of 3 together at the end of the counter. 

The menu on the wall is a little overwhelming for the first visit, but I knew I wanted oysters! We ordered a dozen oysters to share between myself and my  boyfriend. He also got the half cracked crab, and I ordered a crab salad to share. My best friend had a half dozen oysters and some new england clam chowder. 

Everything was delicious but a little on the pricier side for what it was. Overall, however, the service was great, the guys working behind the counter are all so friendly and nice! I enjoyed my experience there and would recommend people to try it at least once :)
author: Jenny C.

description: I like their oysters and scallops. Simple yet tasty - Fine yet unpretentious. Taking it home is easier than waiting in line. Lines cue up approx. 30+ minutes before opening. I enjoy taking home their salmon skin-on; you can sear it, broth it in spicy miso-soup, or fry it with just a little sea salt. I think waiting in line to sit inside is a great experience to do with friends and family if you have the time or the day off. It's cozy and intimate - friendly atmosphere.
author: Janno L.

description:
Well I have to disagree  I think the clam chowder was very fresh and authentic.  I also had half a dungeness crab, also delicious.  

It's a very small place, maybe 15 chairs.   The bar stool chairs are abominable, couldn't be more uncomfortable.

Part of the charm is this place is run by an idiosyncratic group of guys, who seemingly have been together a long time.  A lot of the customers are well known to them.

I don't know how the food could be fresher, you see it cracked open right in front of you.  Also, I loved their sauces.

It is expensive, but it's also unique.
author: Rosie H.

description: This place is on the higher price side. But I am in love with the shrimp. My boyfriend and I came here to get take out as the line to eat in was sOOO LONG. Never come on a weekend morning / afternoon for brunch. The line is CRAZY! But the boss is SOO SWEET! We were short on cash and he just let us slide with a few bucks. My boyfriend promised he would come back and pay him back, but the man is so kind! We got scallop, shrimp, crab, clam chowder, and oysters. The oysters were mediocore for what is supposed to be known as a famous oyster place. But i definitely think that the crab and shrimp were the best I've ever had. ABSOLUTELY LOVE THE SEAFOOD HERE!! The scallop was okay. Be care with the oysters when you open then at home and get it to go! Cause there's plenty of water and you may spill all over ourself like I did! But try the clam chowder. A bit watery but definitely great with the shrimp and crab!
author: Amy Y.

description:
Such an annoying wait, over 90 minutes, everyone please stay away from this place!

Best seafood store in town. It's now my go-to place to buy seafood. 

I tasted real, fresh shrimp, that's not been treated with chemicals.
author: Yuchi C.

description: This place is SOOOOO classic San Francisco from the fresh from the bay seafood to the salty old men who work behind the counter.  It's quick, it's crowded, it's simple and straight forward market fresh seafood - briny oysters, firm shellfish, great accompaniments.  The chowder was a little lacking as it was much thinner than the classic white chowder that SF is famous for but the sourdough bread is great!
author: Angela W.

description:
It's good. It's cash only. I don't understand why there is always a line. 

I had the clam chowder which had a lot of flavor and the mix platter of oysters. The kumamoto oyster was definitely my favorite. If you're looking for some good seafood that has a long line out the door, come here. But I honestly think you can get good oysters and seafood elsewhere that doesn't have a long wait and accepts credit card.

Would I be back? Only when I have the strongest craving for oysters.
author: Ryan L.

description: While we've had oysters from Drake's Bay, which you'll find here, what they didn't note is that you have to get here 2 hours before closing or you're SOL.  Arrive early or drive up toward Point Reyes.  We were turned away well before closing.  We were excited, but won't be back here.  Hog's Island it is!
author: Mishka B.

description: Bar style seating, with only maybe 20 seats. You have to stand outside and wait for other patrons to leave. Very pricey but also some of the best oysters I've ever eaten. Friendly, non-elitest service. Again, I'll reiterate, pricey.
author: Brad M.

description:
Do locals come here, or are all the great reviews from tourists who have never had fresh seafood before? A friend, who sometimes has questionable taste in restaurants, dragged me here the other day after he couldn't stop raving about how great the oysters were.

Anyway, yes, the seafood is fresh. But I can get seafood that's cheaper and just as good at several other places where I don't have to sit crammed between people at a narrow bar on an uncomfortable stool after waiting in line for an hour.
author: D E.

description:
Came back today for the combo salad and crab is out of season. I wish I'd known this before waiting for 15 minutes (which for Swan's is a relatively short wait). 

I musta been confused because I had a whole dungeness crab from Craw Station about two days ago! So I was disappointed, but the food was good, the staff and other customers were friendly. I showed up at 11:30 am so the wait was minimal. 

Remember: Cash only!
author: Thalia F.

description: Yeah, it's a cool spot. Great atmosphere and, probably like a gazillion other people, I saw this on this on Anthony Bourdain's show and that's the reason I came. Am I glad I came? Yes. Would I come back? No. Food was good but not great. Atmosphere and vibe is the best part but in my opinion, $40 for lunch was high.
author: T H.

description: Old school, love how one person gets your drinks, makes the food for you and gives you the bill. Good beer and fresh seafood.
author: P B.

description: Must visit. One of those handful of San Francisco legendary joints where it lives up to its hype all food is super fresh no frozen shrimp all prepared right in front of you.  Everything is tasty as hell. You are sitting cheek to jowl and there is always a line so eat chit-chat and leave so those poor tourists who have traveled thosands of miles, can get their eat on. Its seafood and you will be hungry in a few hours and you will wish you had more of the stuff so get something to go.
author: SF T.

description: Good and fresh seafood. Somewhat overrated and more of a tourist trap. Great service once you're in there.
author: Fahmid K.

description: Came here around 3pm and waited in line for 20 min, not bad for a place that seats about 20 people. Ordered crab salad and and a dozen oysters. Food was good, I just give them 4 stars because they don't use gloves when handling your food. They only take cash and if you didn't bring enough, there's an ATM across the street.
author: Christina B.

description:
I haven't had the oysters here!

I don't even LIKE oysters!

So what the hell? What am I even doing reviewing this place? Can't I read? The word "oyster" in the name of the restaurant!

Am I some kind of MORON? Some kind of UNCULTURED SWINE?!?

The answer, of course, is yes.

But I do like seafood, and I've had the clam chowder and lox here. Both times the seafood was good and fresh. Nothing that struck my uncultured palate as particularly extraordinary, but definitely good. 4 stars territory.

And the people behind the counter are fantastic. The vibe of this place is simply the best. Very friendly. Totally feels like a homey family establishment, even despite the line always going out the door.

Whether it's worth the wait is another question. The line is *very* long. And it never ever ever goes away. Never. Even on like a Tuesday afternoon, when you think people would be at work or something. Even then! A line. Bah.
author: Greg P.

description: Visited Swan Oyster Depot with my brother visiting from Seattle a couple weeks back. After a 1.5 hour wait on a Friday afternoon, we were seated at the end of the long bar where everyone is served. Lots of white wine, good seafood, and making friends with our dining neighbors followed. The seafood was nice and fresh. We had plenty of fresh oysters, combo salad with Louie dressing (yum!), sashimi combo (a must try), and crab fat with bread. Their wine pours are heavy - I'm talking full glass pour of wine. Big plus after a long wait in line. Our dining neighbors were super friendly and even shared some of their whole lobster with us. Made for a pleasant Friday lunch!
author: Michelle E.

description:
I went there for lunch on a weekday, got there about 11:30 AM and I had to wait about 25 minutes in line before I got seated.  

My initial impression was not so stellar.  touristy people lined up in a tiny seafood place.  The service was friendly but somewhat slow.  To my surprise, oysters were great, and the combination seafood salad was quite good.  

Overall I liked this place despite not so stellar first impression.  Did I LOVE the place? no.  Would I go again?  hmmm, probably not.  

The wait in line and the prices which seems quite inflated can't quite justify a second visit for me personally.  I think there will always be big fans of places like this.  I personally want to go buy my own oysters and shuck them myself for less than 1/2 the price.
author: Alex S.

description: Service was ok, wait was an hour they were out of crab so I got a prawn salad Louie dressing is awesome......if I come to try the crab salad I will order to go.  I won't discourage anyone from standing in line but you can have the same food at home w/o anyone waiting for you to finish.   FYI THEY CLOSE AT 530pm and will NOT seat you after 445pm!!! CASH ONLY!!
author: Cheryl B.

description:
Amazing.  Must have the Sicilian Sashimi.  

The line gets long and it only seats about 24 but it's well worth he wait.
author: Chris O.

description: Best place to be for seafood coma. Freshest oysters, clams and sea urchins. Definitely worth the wait!
author: Debbie H.

description:
I've been coming to Swans for over 20 years, and, I do probably not for the same reasons most other people do.
You see, I grew up in San Francisco, went to school there and have a long time connection to the City.
Everyone who works in Swans is the same way. They grew up there, know the same people, have similar stories and stayed there. I didn't. I moved to San Diego. Places like this keep me connected to San Francisco almost as a resident.
Of course the food is always excellent, the clam chowder, the shrimp salad, the dungeness crab all are delicious...and don't forget the oysters. I always ask to have a variety of 12 oysters, and it's never questioned.
I'll always come back here, and not because of what anyone else says about the place, or what the reviews are, just because, to me, it's what's still real about San Francisco.
author: John G.

description:
Let me start off by saying Brian (the young seafood preparer) has great hospitality skills, keep em he definitely fits in with the rest of the crew and crowd.

Toured the city for some of its spots to play catch up on my food adventure bucket list with Le GF.

This time we got to check out the cramped alley-esque space of Swan. I could estimate not including the crew you can fit maybe 15 people max (20 if nobody's claustrophobic). Bathroom is way in the back, make sure you don't make a wrong turn otherwise you'll become apart of their walk-in freezer.

We sat at the very end and got the following items:

Clam Chowder Bowl (serving for 1, we shared: http://instagram.com/p/Yi9UcEnhwf/)
Mixed Dozen + 1 Bluepoint courtesy of Brian : http://instagram.com/p/Yi-ErxHhxf/)
"Best Smoked Salmon in The World"- phrased coined by folks of this place: (http://instagram.com/p/Yi__nnHh0w/)

The Chowder is straight forward. If the oysters are good then the clams have to be bomb. I prefer the stuff next to the Wharf but if you're in the neighborhood this will hit the spot and its the same price point just not as carb heavy.

Mixed Dozen of Oysters (I'll review outline each one individually):
My preferred palate from first to last is: Bluepoint, Kumomoto, Drake's (local) and Miyagi.

The size and ease of consumption of the bluepoint is music to my ears. Makes me want to get a diving certificate and acquire several pounds of that myself. The Miyagi and Kumomoto were also decent but tasting the Kumomoto's brine was a bit unpleasant for me (perhaps I was usually under the influence or had an overdose of mignonette sauce at sushi restaurants that masked the damn thing). Miyagi and Drake's weren't too bad however the Drake's may be to small of a portion to appreciate the tasting for some folks who want to get more bang for their buck.

Smoke Salmon, without the capers and red onion excess. Excellent, think of your highest standard of Spanish Iberico Jamon and turn it into a thinly smoke slices of seafood bliss. If you're into capers and red onions and the whole Jewish thing then bring some cream cheese and go H.A.M. on it.

Overall, I believe I spent almost $60.00 with tax and tip. Definitely worth the trip and the parking hassles of SF. Besides elbow room the fact they only accept cash is a bit of a damper. Considering I had to hustle my rear end to the nearest ATM which was a slight inconvenience. 

4.5 is my rating for now, no wonder Bourdain liked this spot. At least there's one place we can agree on.
author: Ryan M.

description: Love this place. Always fresh and always tasty. Despite the reviews I've never had a problem getting a table. I always have the shrimp salad and clam chowder. I must get more adventurous because it all looks so good.
author: Bernard O.

description:
I love the old school vibe of this place. It's so simple and unique at the same time. I've worked down at a seafood restaurant at Fisherman's Wharf for the past three years and it's safe to say that Swan Oyster Depot trumps all. 

There's nothing frozen at this place. Only fresh, local seafood. Can't beat that. And with the start of crab season in the city (now), the Dungeness crab was AMAZING! Great flavor chilled on its own or lovely with the Louie dressing. 

I would come here every week if I could afford it--and if the line wasn't such a pain. Other than that, it was a one-of-a-kind dining experience I enjoyed very much. No frills here. Just normal guys slinging quality seafood. So all you snobby SF foodies who can't handle the real deal, please look elsewhere for your Michelin Star restaurant.
author: Monique G.

description:
An amazing seafood restaurant! Went on a Friday afternoon, and although there was a line, it is well worth the wait. 

The actual restaurant was very small, but the service was amazing and very clean. The restaurant consists of one single bar-like seating. 

The service was friendly, efficient and knowledgeable with the menu. 

Cup of Boston Clam Chowder ($2.75) was our appetizer. Much thinner soup that i expected (more used to a thick clam chowder), but delicious in it's own right. pieces of potato and seafood were abundant in the soup. Went amazing with the fresh sour-dough bread. 

Combination Seafood Cocktail ($9.95) was our first dish, a little bit of everything. Crab, shrimp, prawn, clam, lobster and oyster. Extremely fresh and delicious

Mixed Dozen Oysters ($26) are fantastic! We had blue point, miyagi and kumamoto all served on a bed of ice. the server was very nice in explaining which oyster was which. Each type had it's own distinct flavour, texture and taste; amazing to be able to try such wide variety in one sitting. 

Overall amazing place. Don't be put off by the wait and line ups, the service and freshness of food is well worth the wait.
author: Jason L.

description:
YUM!!! Freshest oysters I've had in the city. 

Service was SUPERB. We were the smart and lucky ones that arrived around 4pm on a Wednesday and there was no wait. Ordered a glass of wine and he gave us a half for my non-drinking friend just to cheers with! I feel like we were celebrities!!! After that we had the best mixed dozen oysters ever! Try the pink vinaigrette stuff, it's legit! We also ordered a combo salad and it was mouth watering good. 

bottom line, I'LL BE BACK
author: Emily T.

description: Well, we waited for years to got to Swan as we were put off by the long lines. But we finally went at the urging of a friend and were not disappointed! Worth the one hour wait on a Monday at 11:00 a.m. ! Our orders of clam chowder (so fresh, best in SF!), crab cocktail, smoked trout, mixed sashimi, smoked salmon and sliced scallops were so delicious! The side order of sourdough bread and butter added the touch, as did an ice cold Anchor Steam. The wait staff was so friendly and helpful, and the retro atmosphere and simplicity were a real plus. Items were pricey but worth it. We'll be back soon!
author: Michael B.

description:
Ehhh, 
 Apparently the "Crab Shortage" is a common issue here.  The portions are small, expensive and just nothing special.  I also waited 45mn for my meal and sat elbow to elbow.  I would recommend the WARF over this place.
author: Justin F.

description:
A tad embarrassed to say I've only been once, and it took me over 2 years to get here....and I live around the corner! The horror.  This is one of those must-try SF spots. 

Anyways, my one and only visit was a good one! I opted for the coveted seafood salad. Everything was so fresh, I felt like I was at sea when I ate this.  They don't skimp you on the portions, so go hungry. The service was quick and friendly, I walk by a few times a day and you can't not notice the hard work going on. 

Recommendation: if you can, get takeout unless you want to wait in line all afternoon. I'll definitely be back!
author: Brianna M.

description: Everyone was friendly and bread was good. I had the prawn salad and clam chowder. The prawns sat atop a few shreds of iceberg lettuce. Two of them were deveined and the rest were not but ok. The clam clam chowder was "broken" the cream was separated. Not flavorful at all. The smoked salmon looked good but I was out of money after my $24 dollar salad. Very overpriced for the casual atmosphere and less than "no frills" salad. one of the employees was pouring bleach all over the floor right while we were eating. Never be back.
author: M L.

description:
Awesome seafood place!! We ordered the seafood salad (prawns and crab only. You can get it with shrimp and other seafood items as well) and a dozen of the local oysters (4-blue point, 4-kumamoto, and 4-miyagi). They're very generous with the amount of seafood that comes on your salad, and can be quite filling. Who knew a salad could be filling! The oysters are eh, but are fresh. They're also kind of pricey. The combo seafood salad was $21 and the dozen mixed local oysters was $30. 

All the guys there are super friendly and are quick to clean up and get you seated and served. 

There's always a line out the door (because they can only seat like 20 people at a time. It's a bar-type seating), and they stop serving at 5:30 so they'll stop allowing people to stand in line after a certain point. We stood in line for almost 2 hours and our starting point was the furniture right next door if that tells you anything! We'll definitely come back, but will order to go next time instead. They get you in and out pretty quickly and package everything nice and tight.
author: Alice L.

description: I came very early on a Monday morning...so early I had time to run into the thrift store half a block down until the place opened.  When I made it back I was the 6th customer seated at the bar.  Started off with the mixed oysters and boy were they fresh.  Kumamoto's were again my favorite.  Also ordered the cup of chowder....or should I say broth.  I thought it was not bad.  Then ordered the sashimi plate with salmon and scallops.  Scallops were bland but salmon was super fresh.  Also got the smoked salmon plate and the crab and prawn cocktail.   The prawns were the best part of the cocktail.  I'll probably be dreaming about the smoked salmon later tonight.  All in all, this meal wasn't cheap...but so worth it.  Servers were all super friendly the day I came.  If you're in town, its a must visit.
author: Jeremy T.

description:
Looooove this place.  Love it!  There's a magic about it.  Same stools for the last 60 years, same cracked white tile counter, same dusty memorabilia on the wall in front of you.  Same four Italian brothers (and their kids) running it, who took it over from their dad.  I regard Swan as quintessential old San Francisco.

My dad took me here when I was a kid and I've taken my kids.  I always have the prawn cocktail.
author: Thomas H.

description: I think this is the place to start in San Francisco unbelievably fresh fish. Service is way over-the-top. We only had to stand in line about 25 minutes since we hit it right after the first lunch shift.  Matt sure knows how to plan  a trip.
author: Glenn K.

description:
There are a number of places that I have resisted reviewing for a long time.  Like Swan Oyster needs even MORE publicity or good reviews.  Frankly, it's gotten SO HARD to get in here, and the line out the door so long, I don't go as frequently as I used to.

The seafood salad is always copious, fresh, and delicious.  Same with the oysters.  Along with the SF sourdough bread, downing a fresh, draught Anchor Steam beer while shoulder-to-shoulder with locals and overseas tourists is a quintessential San Francisco experience.  I think that the only time to go without a wait is 9am or earlier on  a weekday.  You are a SUCKER if you wait in those long Saturday lunch lines.
author: Dave N.

description:
AWESOME PLACE!

Alright, so the place has a pretty long wait. Its only has a few chairs available. But I tell you it is well worth it. Everything is fresh and well prepared. I had a bit of everything; oysters, shrimp, crab, smoked salmon, and the beer. The food and service was great. All the staff is friendly and quick to help. I recommend coming in around breakfast time to avoid much of the wait.
author: Michelle L.

description:
Featured on the 7x7 Big Eats. http://www.7x7.com/big-eat-2012-photos#/74

It is easy to see why it was and why there is a long line out the door for this place. The oysters here are fresh and delicious with my favorite being the Blue Point.

I would love to give this place 5 stars, but the cleanliness of it refrains me from doing so. There are juices/other liquids on the counter where you are served. They do not seem to practice very sanitary manners, but oh well. The oysters are bomb!
author: Ava S.

description: It's small and they only take cash. However if u beat the line and get a seat it's absolutely amazing! The seafood is so fresh and tasty. The vinaigrette with crab fat is amazing onto of the crab fat. The clam chowder is better than anything I have ever had and it's different than most chowders but seriously has the best clam flavor. It's not good for groups but it's worth every minute of your time and $.
author: Michael D.

description:
Been coming here for the last 2 years (ever since I moved to SF). When I want to treat myself, I make the 1.1 mile walk to Swan Oyster Depot for a nice meal.  

Note: you'll only like this place if you enjoy fresh seafood and plan to wait inline for awhile. 

I usually write off about 3-4 hours, including the walk from my apartment, and I usually get 4 things: always the fish carpaccio/sashimi with capers and olive oil, maybe a clam chowder, always the crab cocktail and then I see what else is fresh.  Then, I order to take out, usually salmon. 

Yes, I wish I didn't have to wait in line so long, but the nice thing about it is that you usually meet cool people, and you end up having these cool conversations. By the time you get to the bar, you're sharing food or wine. 

The more I get to know other places in town, especially the oyster and seafood places on the Embarcadero, the more I appreciate this place. Love it!
author: Sergio R.

description: We were lucky we got here just at the right time at 10:00 to line up. You're paying for the experience here, not so much the food. Great service and old school ambiance. Solid seafood but not solid value. Still glad that we did it.
author: Michael W.

description:
Very disappointed.  My friend and I had been looking forward to Swan for weeks prior to us going there the day before Christmas.  I know.  "Day before Christmas."  Maybe we should have had a plan B prepared, but we did not see anything on their website warning us that there would be *no counter service* on that particular day.  This was only noted by a sign outside the shop.  

Of course, we were looking forward to eating at the counter; after all, that is a major part of the Swan experience.  We would have settled for take-out.  Unfortunately, they didn't even offer that, or any real niceties.  When I asked if there was anything available to purchase, I was shocked to be responded to so curtly by one of the men, stating only that they were not selling anything and to try back after 2 p.m.  What a kind invitation, to come begging for scraps.  Sign me up!  

Perhaps on a normal day, we would have had the amazing experience everyone raves about: the friendly counter workers who love their job, the fresh seafood, a pint of Anchor Steam and elbow-rubbing with fellow seafood-lovers.  It was not to be the day before Christmas, and I'm pretty much turned off to the idea of ever going back there now after the way my friend and I were pretty much dismissed by the staff.  Sad to have missed out.
author: Christina G.

description: Way over rated and definitely not worth the wait out the door that stretched down the street. Clam chowder was watery clam juice, combination cocktail might have been better if it wasn't 3 bites and $15. Be warned too that they only take cash.  Head down to Fishermans Wharf for way better seafood (and atmosphere).
author: Becca L.

description:
This review is kind of hard to write for me.

I enjoyed the experience.

I enjoyed the service mostly. It took too long to acknowledge us, but once acknowledged, the server seemed like a nice enough guy although there were subsequent lapses in service. I got a hint that they have maybe let success allow them to forget the fundamentals.  I also noticed some other guests not getting adequate service, then getting a lot of service. There are some major inconsistencies going on in the service.

We ordered the chowder, the mixed oyster & clams, and a whole crab.

The chowder was the most watered down chowder I've had in years. There are some excellent chowders out there. This isn't one of them. It's ok, but it's not worthy of a hot spot like this is supposed to be and certainly not worth the prices they charge.

The server brought us the wrong oyster order. He brought us the mixed oysters not the 6 oysters & 6 clams we had ordered. He didn't even really apologize. I got the feeling - even though he seemed nice - that he was doing us a favor. Anyway, he brought the clams on a separate plate after we pointed out the mistake. Hey, the oysters and the clams were wonderful!  They were wonderful!

He never brought the crab and we cancelled that order. We observed that the other guests were enjoying their food. I watched them prepare sea urchin & that was a great experience. The people sitting next to me tried one & they were unwilling to comment on the taste, but I pressed the 3 of them for an opinion and finally they seemed to agree that it was *meh.* It was a culinary experience, but not a tasteful one, just an experience and that's cool - one should try things, but not all things are awesome.  The other people sitting next to us had the salmon & said they really enjoyed it.

Then we sat there for another 15 minutes waiting for the check. I finally had to get up hoping he'd get the message we were ready to leave. That didn't work, so I went to where he was and asked for the check. It was closing time, so they were cleaning up and doing other chores. I get that. I'm not trying to be too harsh.

Overall, the food was very good (except for the water-downed chowder).

They're way overpriced. I assume because they've received some notoriety.  They definitely have the tourist prices due to their 15 minutes of fame.

The service seemed to be hit & miss. Our experience on service was, overall, negative.

I felt ripped off like the tourist I was. I won't eat here again. The food's good, don't get me wrong (except the watered down chowder), but why would I pay twice the price?
author: Scott N.

description:
I am in my oyster phase and this place seems to have a lot of hype. So this past Saturday, we stood in line for an hour to get into this joint for my seafood fix. "Was it worth it?" you ask...I say ehhhhhh, I've had better.

Besides the long wait and the rocky bar stools, I would have to say their "right off the dock" and family style service was very endearing. A bit dirty for my taste but hey, it's like this if you were at a fresh fish market or a pier. Just don't wear white pants! 

We ordered a dozen combination oysters, which included my favorite Kumamoto oysters for $27, crab cocktail $20, bowl of clam chowder $5 and scallop Sicilian style $8 each. The oysters had tons of sand in it and for that price, I've had better at Water Grill and everywhere else for that matter. I mean it's fine when it's just a few of the dozen that's filled with sand but when it's 10 out of 12, come on. I have oysters at least once a week, so I know what I'm talking about here. As for the crab cocktail, they redeemed themselves with their special Louise dipping sauce. Clam chowder was super watery and you could see the separation of oil and cream. The best thing about this trip was the Sicilian style scallop. They took 1 large fresh scallop, thinly sliced into 4-6 pieces, drizzle with EVOO, capers and red onion bits (not on the menu btw).

Overall, I think I will come back on a weekday, by myself so I don't have to wait and order everything else on the menu. Oh and did I mention it's cash only?
author: Laurel T.

description:
There's nothing more satisfying than finally knocking off a place that's been bookmarked forever. With the limited lunchtime hours and the ridiculous line that forms on Saturdays, I haven't had a chance until now.

Wednesday afternoon. About 2pm. We get here and there's maybe a dozen people lined out the door in front of us, but it moves quickly. We're probably seated within 20 mins. The line actually grows quite a bit while we're waiting.

There's no tablecloth, no fancy menus here. Just a guy who serves you at the bar and a giant menu up on the wall. 

We start a cup of the clam chowder which is not as soupy as I've had elsewhere. But it's very rich and full of flavor. Possibly one of the best clam chowders I've ever had.

Next came the crab fat and requisite sourdough for dipping while we waited for our oysters and combination seafood salad. As a Korean, I've had "crab fat" mixed with rice and other spicy goodies plenty of times growing up. But at Swan Oyster, it was cold, and didn't have much flavor. Still tasty but could've been even better. The super spicy hot sauces they had on hand packed too much intensity and didn't really work with the flavors.

The oysters were extremely fresh (like everything else I had that day), and the salad was this huge, shareable mountain of crab and shrimp. By the time the uni arrived, I wanted to die of happiness from being full of delicious seafood.

Swan Oyster is the place locals go. And tourists. It's where you get real, legit seafood without the crowds at Fishermen's Wharf. Don't wait a decade like me, go check it out.
author: Cristofer P.

description:
I heard the Clam Chowder in this place was amazing and it wasn't, it was supposed to be Boston style and didn't have the orange Boston color or taste to it.

The Swan Oyster is good for fresh seafood but don't expect to eat anything fried in there.

The flys hanging around the counter didn't make my dining experience any better.  I kept wondering how long the flys were hanging out on the front window food trays before they were swatted away.

This place is cash only so bring lots of cash because this place is really expensive.

The guy sitting next to me ordered the fish, had 2 beers, and oysters.  His bill came up to 55$.  WHAT ???????
author: Charlie B.

description:
This place is amazing!  The seafood is so fresh.  Service is quick and friendly.  It's worth the wait.  And the wait is LONG, no matter what time or day you go.

I've had the chowder, oysters, combination cocktail (but without the cocktail sauce), and salmon.  It was so fresh and delicious.  

You can't go wrong when you order - it's all amazing.

FYI - cash only.
author: Jordana M.

description:
AMAZIIIIIIIIIIIIIIIIIIIING. 

Dining at Swan Oyster Depot is truly an experience. One that starts with a really, really long wait. My friend and I waited for 1hr45 before we got seated, but it was well worth it. 

We had 3 oysters and clams each to start and then both got the shrimp louies. The food was incredibly fresh and just scrumptious. The waiters were also incredibly personable, which made it all the more enjoyable. 

Yes, the wait is pretty darn long, but I'll probably end up going again, esp. since I know friends who still haven't been since they moved to the city. But! TIP ALERT: going alone or with just one other person is the best strategy as otherwise the wait is even longer.
author: Rowena L.

description:
Fresh seafood? ORLY?
Fresh oysters?! I'm listening...
Fresh scallops?! OMG!!
Fresh shrimp?!! OOMAAHGGGAAHHH!!!
Not so fresh line?! OOhhhh Noooeesssss!!!!

In any case still five stars, cause I probably went on the worse day possible, a Saturday of all days.  Very tiny place and I was thinking, "oh, we are the 12th in line, shouldn't be that bad."

*2 hours later*

"My f*ing jeebus bunions and corns have formed on my feet from standing soooo long!!!"

Some rich lady tried to cut to get in the to-go order behind some other people already in line for to-go. Denied. Period.  The people that work there won't even acknowledge you until it is your turn or you know them.

But the food was well worth it! I had the smoked salmon plate, tried a shashimi plate, a bit of my friends shrimp cocktail, and the clam chowder.  Not so impressed with the clam chowder as I like it thick and full of chunky clams and veggies. It was very watery but the bread soaked it up well.

Service was very attentive and efficient considering how busy it was. The bill for two came out to about $60.

Try going on a weekday, go early, or unless you have the free time to spend that much time waiting in line on a weekend, then I would still recommend this place. Chatting up with the people in front or behind of you in line definitely makes the wait a bit more bearable. 

Note to self: Bring an umbrella, sunscreen, suntan lotion, or camp chair if long wait.
author: Davis T.

description:
Ok so - I get the hype.  It's classic.  Bar-only seats, 5 old guys making everything to order every time, putting care into everything - and you get to see it all.  However, if you're not huge on oysters or raw fish in the first place - this probably isn't for you (and that's probably me...).

I also was a little uneasy seeing the cooks wipe sweat off their faces with their hands, then picking up tons of fish with their hands and putting it on my plate, just weirds me out. ha.

So all that said, the cocktail was good (but overpriced).  The line was insanely long (because it's just bar seats).  

And the best thing: the soup was freaking awesome.
author: Scott S.

description:
Sogood.  So fresh.  Such a treat.  The counter probably seats only about 12 or so, so .. get there off hours if you want to eat quick.  This place has a feel not unlike Russ & Daughters in Manhattan.  Both excellent seafood, both full of locals lined up since they know what's going on.  Tried the sampler plate of oysters, some chowder, a shrimp louie salad (mm, good dressing), and some smoked salmon.  Totally worth every penny.  

It's cash only, and a little spendy, but... these are the sorts of things that you get what you pay for!
author: Roger W.

description:
Brace yourself, there will be lines. No matter what time you go. 

I had the clam chowder, some seafood salad, and oysters. They were all alright, with the best of them being the oysters. 

The clam chowder: was a little watery for my taste, and the flavor was quite clammy. I know a lot of people think this is the best chowder in the city, but it just wasn't me :/

The Seafood Salad: It's shredded iceberg lettuce, a ton of baby shrimp, and other kinds of seafood. I think I got a big shrimp, prawn? Some smoked salmon, and some trout. Not my thing, I think I'd prefer a seafood cocktail.

The oysters: Very meaty, lots of flavor, and a lot of toppings to suit your taste. I had 3 different kinds, and I enjoyed everyone of them.

I spent around $30, but regardless, I'm glad I went to this SF staple.
author: Kevi L.

description: I haven't been here for years, but I this is an SF institution. The seafood is great, though the prices are a bit steep. Still, it is a bit of fun. Just be prepared to wait in line.
author: Richard S.

description:
This is a life changer. 

People talk about long lines here. Those people don't realize you have been waiting for your entire life in line to get in here! 

Staff treats you like family and you will never get faster service in your life.

I personally waited in line for 25 years to get into this place so the 1.5 hours spent outside was truly nothing.

There is no wrong choice here, but if you like crab then you owe it to yourself to get a crab cocktail (or two to be realistic). Next is the sashimi plate which will change your perception of that term and every sushi restaurant you have been to.

Combination salad will rock your world with the Louie sauce. I also had a crab back and a cup of the clam chowder which I cannot describe with words.  The crab back captured the essence of the ocean like nothing else I have ate.

Oh yeah since this place is called the oyster depot let us not forget to mention how succulent and fresh these oysters really are. Unsurpassed and unmatched. 

Eating here is truly an ethereal experience and talking about these items do no justice.

You can blindfold me and I will know the items from Swan whether it be the sashimi, crab cocktail, crab back, and the unforgettable Louie sauce.

Bought an ice chest just to take home smoked salmon and crab the next day before I drove off wishing I could take even more.
author: Narbeh D.

description:
If your life is anything like mine, it's probably pretty difficult for you to carve out several hours for anything - much less a meal in the middle of the day.  But if you search for quality and authenticity, and are willing to pay with your time and money to attain them even temporarily, you need to get yourself down to the line for the counter at Swan's ASAP.

Stepped down there for a miniature reunion of sorts with 2 college buddies, and we sprang for virtually everthing on the board: Oysters, Clams, Crab Salad, Smoked Salmon, Sicilian Sashimi, Chowder, bread, and plenty of Anchor Steam to wash it all down.  The fish might as well still be waving at you from your communal plate - it reminded me of those Coors commercials where the fridge opens to grizzled mountaineers pulling bottles from Rocky Mountain peaks - only in this case it was as though they were scooping oysters and Hamachi directly from the water.

Downsides: you're almost definitely gonna wait, particularly if you're foolhardy enough to try for more than 2 people.  The bill is also not for the faint of heart and you have to pay cash.  But they do let you drink beer in the line, and the meal will not be the slightest bit forgettable.  There's a reason these guys are so busy after so many years.
author: Andrew F.

description: Waited in line for an hour on a Thursday afternoon during Fleet Week but was worth the wait! Ordered the Dungeness crab cocktail, prawn cocktail and clam chowder. This place is a no fuss restaurant with fresh seafood and awesome service!
author: Jesse H.

description:
The weather ruined the experience. It's a small place w/ small bar counters to sit at and the door is always left open due to extremely long lines and it was very cold, even inside, when I went. Dress up well.

It doesn't help that their seafood are all served cold!

Prices are also fairly high. 

Half dozen oysters - $7.5, 2 kumamoto, 2 blue point, 2 miyagi. I'm not an oyster fan myself but I tried these anyways just to see what "good" oysters taste like. I couldn't stand the flavor. It had a lot of sea flavor. I spit out the kumamoto. Miyagi was the best. Blue point was just meh. My oyster loving friend said these oysters were very high quality, but if you already know you don't like oysters, don't bother trying

Half-cracked crab - It's just half a crab. The meat is very good. You can tell it's super fresh. I just wished it wasn't served cold. Would recommend.

Loui sauce - supposedly it's renowned, and my opinion is that it was pretty good and a delight to dip my crab into it.

Clam Chowder - nasty stuff that tastes like sea. There are also hardly any clams. Also lots of weird foamy bits that I have no idea what they are. Avoid at all cost.
author: Mark D.

description: Flew in from FL, checked into the hotel and took an Uber directly here in hopes of avoiding the crazy wait I read about on Yelp. I arrived around 2:25 pm and waited until 3pm for 2 seats. As soon as we sat down we placed our order. Fyi, all items available are in view of the 20-seater bar. I had the combination prawn and crab cocktail, with homemade cocktail sauce. I also had a cup of the clam chowder and sourdough bread to dip. Everything was seriously beyond my expectations. Being raised on the Gulf Coast of Florida, fresh seafood is a staple and very hard to match. From the flavor of the chowder to the sweet freshness of the crab and prawn, this place is legit! We were in and out in 20 minutes. Fyi, cash only, but there is a Chase Bank across the street.
author: Danielle S.

description:
This may be my favorite dining experience of all time. I've been there twice and each time was unforgettable.

Most recently I went with my boyfriend and best friend in September. We got there around 3 p.m. on a Thursday, and there were three seats left. Perfect.

All told, we split two bottles of wine, smoked salmon, oysters, prawn cocktail and clam chowder. Each item is the best I've ever had. 

The salmon was so flavorful and delicate, the oysters so fresh, the chowder warm and comforting. 

Add to that the impeccable service from the men behind the counter. They are so warm, friendly and dedicated to making sure all their customers are comfortable and happy. Each time I've been they offered to hold my friend's purse and my purse behind the counter because there's really no good place for them. It's those little details that make true customer service.

On top of all that, they gave us a free bottle of wine and did shots of tequila with us after close, also free. 

These men love their job, they love their product and they love their customers. And I love them right back.
author: Amanda M.

description:
My friend came to town asking for clam chowder and I was a bit helpless: I'd grown up visiting here and eating the stuff at the Wharf but since moving here had been shamed by all the locals not to eat there. 

In return, they tell you to go these centenarian standbys like Tadich Grill, Swan Oyster Depot, etc. but now I hear Anchor Inn on Castro is where it's at.

Anywho, we spotted Swan so I flipped a B, nabbed a parking spot and walk up and the guy tells us we can't come in because they just closed which is bizarre because it's 4 or 5pm on a Friday but apparently they close early folks so warning to you all on that front!

After some haggling we worked our way in and sat down and ordered a plate of oysters, clam chowder and a crab salad and some beers.

Half the fun of this is watching the old school professional fish mongers or shell chuckers or oyster artists or whatever you call them, communicate and fling fish at people a million miles an hour while at the same time, everyone seems a little buzzed, and are drinking beers like they're naked on the beach in Mexico. 

Anywho, the crab salad is knockout good, as far as cold crab goes, this is the best I've had (at the time, it was in-season), the oysters were stellar with good toppings but the clam chowder was a little thin and no bread bowl (boooo!). 

So, I wouldn't come here for the chowder (it just wan't my type) and it was so buttery, but like not in a good way, in a just like, holy crap, is this 50% butter? Ptew! Ptewey! And where the clams? When I get a chowda' at a hardcore fish place like this I'm dreaming of  some delciious clams in the broth but I am asking a lot, I know!

One sentence summary? If you have a fat wallet, this place is fun for the old-school beer and seafood, black-and-white-tile, fishmonger ambience!
author: Ryan S.

description:
"Meh. I've experienced better." This is exactly right. And I'm not trolling, believe me -- I'd like nothing better than an amazing seafood restaurant to praise and advertise. Especially one as famous as this one. I'm from Maryland -- where even babies eat steamed crabs -- and then lived in New England for 5 years -- where even babies eat clam chowder. Seafood is a part of me.

But the food's just not very good here. Take the clam chowder for example. It's a unique recipe, yes -- thin and oily, with hardly any clams. I've never had anything like it before... and I hope I never do again. It's no accident that they put giant bowls of oyster crackers in front of you: once you add the crackers, they become the best part of the soup.

Then there's the crab "salad," which I couldn't have been more excited about before I ordered it. For $24.50, I expected a lot of crab, and that's what I got. Unfortunately, it was maybe 60% leg/claw meat and only 40% "thigh" meat, which means it was 60% tough and rubbery. As for the vegetables that make it a "salad," it's only shredded iceberg lettuce. Shredded lettuce! The same lettuce you find in a Taco Bell soft taco.

So, to recap: for $30 total, I got a pile of unseasoned crab, some shredded lettuce, a drizzle of Louie sauce (aka light Russian dressing), and a bowl of watered-down clam chowder. All this would still probably be worth 3 stars but for the fact that there was a wait at 10:30 in the morning on a Wednesday to sit down for blunch.

2 stars, and utterly not worth the trouble. Go to Hog Island for better oysters and clam chowder and R&G Lounge for better crab.
author: Albert L.

description:
Fresh , delicious and all staffs are friendly. 
This place become tourist place so you need to prepare to wait in line for a while but it's worst it also prepare cash since they don't take any credit card!!
author: Katie E.

description:
wow cant believe i waited 2 hours (from 1 pm to 3 pm) for the seafood.

clam chowder: not as creamy as other places, still good though (but not too many clams found inside)
oysters: 30 for a dozen, guess its pretty cheap compared to the fine restaurants (yums)
prawn / crab cocktail: goooooood
scallop sashimi: very freshhhh so good with olive oil. 

but im not sure if its worth the wait, maybe i'll just grab the takeouts next time.
author: Miffy L.

description:
When you see a line, you know it's good. Then again, the place is really small with only a bar to sit at.

The workers are super friendly and you get your food pretty quickly. I shared a mixed seafood salad with my friend and it was amazing. Unfortunately, there was no crab that day, so we got smoked salmon which was still equally good.

The clam chowder was very good, and you can taste how fresh the clams were. Definitely go early. It gets busy.. early. Go!
author: Melissa N.

description:
I've never written a Yelp review before, even though I'm an avid food and restaurant lover. But I absolutely had to get online to share this. 

GO HERE. Just do it. 

No frills. Simply amazing seafood. We had the combination cocktail (all kinds of yummy ocean things with cocktail sauce), fresh raw oysters (and I do mean fresh), cracked crab (twice), smoked salmon (the best I've ever had) and chowder (OMG).  Worth the wait, worth every penny.

The family-run atmosphere is so laid back and friendly, and even though there's always a line out the door, no one is rushing you. We enjoyed some lovely wine (nice sleeper little white wine list) with our food and service was attentive though definitely not hurried, in the best way possible.

I'm going to have a hard time coming back to SFO and not making a trip here each time, regardless of where I'll be. I've been to loads of oyster and raw bars in many cities over the years, and this is by far one of my favorites yet. Thanks for the hospitality, Swan guys, and I'll most definitely be back!
author: Amber N.

description: Went there for lunch today. After waiting for 20 minutes outside in the cold, they seated me at a part of the counter that had no overhang (no place for my knees and forelegs). It was extremely uncomfortable and I could not enjoy my $28 shrimp salad, so I opted to take the rest to go. Sitting in my car to finish the salad, I found a dead fly among the greens. Needless to say, I will not be going back!
author: Judith F.

description:
Shh. Don't tell anyone about this cubby-hole sized seafood restaurant. The lines are already out the door...

This business has been in the "family" for years and when you come in, you can chat with one of the brothers serving you behind the counter. This is a no frills shop that has fed locals forever. Eat the classic Boston clam chowder and the fresh, fresh seafood and enjoy 'ole world SF.
author: Joanna T.

description:
Yup, get yourself in the queue for this place, and get ready to squeeze into whatever space you are allotted.  The wait is worth it. 

The food is fresh, the staff are all locals who have no pretense (huzaar, especially in this crazy-fast-growing-ever-more-trendy town).

It's simple, it's tasty, it's casual.
author: Kristina A.

description:
After the Anthony Bourdain shout-out the line is even more ridiculous than before.  The guys were saying people are now waiting 2 to 2.5 hours!!

This is what is beautiful about Swan's.  To keep the quality of service, they have to delay serving at the bar until 11... they open at 8:30.  

To avoid this, I would recommend going in the middle of the week and middle of the day if you can.  If not, then call in your order.  They don't always answer but if you do, it'll save time.  Otherwise you can still get take out, it'll be faster than 2 hours I promise.
author: Z C.

description: Freshest seafood around. You can skip the line for pick up. If you sit down... Make sure you get DARREN!!!!!!!!!
author: Kimberly D.

description: Never open when you want it to be, mainly because you always want it to be open. Fresh, delicious seafood with some bomb clam chowder. San Francisco at it's most SF.
author: Chris P.

description:
A friend and I stopped in to get some of their famous crab and oysters on the advice of Anthony Bourdain, who mentioned it on his Layover tv show about dining destinations. We were prepared to wait, but were surprised to find empty stools at the bar, so we sat down and started ordering. They have tables, too, but the bar is so much more fun and convivial. 

Upon entering, you can tell that this place is an "institution" and it has the worn seating and memorabilia usually associated with such places. The counter staff is warm, and they've all been there a while, judging by the friendly banter between themselves and the customers. 

I ordered a crab louis salad, and was served a heaping plate of crab on a bed of lettuce, and topped with some nice sauce. My companion had oysters, which she said were fresh and delicious, and also some crab. The place is pricey, but the seafood is so fresh that you just don't care; it was some of the nicest crab I've ever eaten. It was served with sourdough bread and pats of butter. 

They don't accept credit cards or checks, so bring cash. Would it be worth the wait? Probably. But I'm not one for waiting much. Had there been a long line, I would have skipped it.
author: Angela L.

description: The food was good but the sanitary conditions not so much. The guys behind the counter took money shook hands wiped off the counter and then without washing scooped up the cold seafood with their bare hands. Every where I have ever worked that's a health code violation.
author: Tress C.

description:
Here we are,about to spend 36 hours in the great city of San Francisco.  Right around the corner from our hotel is the famous Swan Oyster Depot.  My niece says "It's been on my to-do list for the longest time", so off we go and get into line.  This line - it literally took us 2 hours of patient standing to get into this place.  Our mouths were watering, our stomachs were empty.  Oh, how we were anticipating having some rich, buttery crab. 

And oh, were we disappointed!  My niece ordered the Octopus Salad.  "Sorry, we're out of octopus."  I ordered a cup of clam chowder and the half crab.  "Sorry, we're out of crab."  Now if I stand in line for 2 hours, I DO NOT want to settle for my 2nd or 3rd choice.  My husband - was in the same boat.  Crab was the name of the game for him as well.  Fortunately for him, he's equally capable of eating oysters, so he (and my niece) ordered the dozen oysters, with 3 or 4 different varieties.  I just can't do the cold, slimy food, so I ordered prawn salad.  

First, the waiter brought 2 cups of clam chowder, but I guess in the confusion over the lack of crab he didn't hear me order any soup.  No problem; it came out very promptly.  Then the 2 plates of oysters arrived, but no prawn salad.  He said:  "Did you order anything?"  and then he proceeded to make my prawn salad.  This consisted of a bed of shredded iceberg lettuce, and about 8 very large, delicious shrimp, with a side of Louie dressing.  Now, this was very good, but I was expecting - a salad.  You know, with tomatoes, and onions, and all kinds of good things.  I mean, this was $21, and while those shrimp were delicious - this was robbery.

Would we have waited if they had put out a sign in front that said "Sorry, no crab available today"?   No, we wouldn't. (The waiter said they hadn't had it for 2 days.) There were plenty of other very famous (and infamous) places in that neighborhood to eat, and we wouldn't have waited 2 hours in the cold.  So I understand why there was no sign outside.  But at the end of the meal, we laid out over $100 for a less than satisfying lunch.  We did enjoy the ambiance.  It's fun sitting at a counter, reading the old signs, watching the bustling activity and since we were near the door, we watched all the take-out happening, the directions given, etc.  It was great entertainment.  But still....I hate to be crabby, but man, we REALLY wanted crab.  Maybe the next time, San Francisco?  

And a little P.S. is due here:  Sunday, we did the seriously touristy San Francisco Fisherman's Wharf, and let me tell you - there was NO shortage of crab there!
author: Joan L.

description: A waste of time. Honestly you can do better.  I waited to be seated, only to wait  to be asked if we wanted drinks then waited to be asked for our order then waited for the order to come then had to wait to pay.  We had oysters that were cracked in front of us but not sure how long they sat there.  Then the clam chowder was split which means, it was probably old.  We had sashimi,  they didn't even have gloves on to prepare the food, so hygiene is questionable. The check was $63,  and even though we were seriously disappointed,  we still left a tip.  This place sucks!  Don't be fooled by the rating.  They act like their doing the consumer a favor by serving us.   These guys don't understand the meaning of customer service.
author: Annika F.

description: Another must-eat place when in San Francisco!  We had the clam chowder, oysters, and the combination cocktails!  Come early and avoid the long line!
author: Jun L.

description: I've been here several times and I won't come back again. I saw the server just use his bare hands to take cash from other people and then using these hands to prepare my food....Cash is one of the most dirtiest thing in the world, it has million of bacteria!!!! The food here is just so so to me, I came here because my gf wanted some fresh oysters. The wait is supper long and the price is ridiculous. 2 stars is for the so so service. They need to improve the hygiene condition in this place, so disgusting!!!!
author: Sei H.

description: The seafood is amazing! Had crab cocktail, crab, oysters, clams and clam chowder,  everything is just the best! Too bad we didn't get the chance to try their lobsters and uni~ I need to come back to this place again and start lining up early next time, hmmm
author: Kathy Z.

description: Came here after 2pm on a weekday and barely a wait!  Swan Oyster Depot is an SF institution, but it's not for the faint of heart.  The seafood is fresh but it isn't the cleanest place.  Our server was old school friendly, but my stomach churned a little when he grabbed our food with his bare hands then proceeds to handle cash without blinking.  What can I say, it is what it is.  Glad I got to try it at least, but for the price, you can easily get the equivalent quality of food at another SF restaurant but with a more comfortable and clean environment.
author: Jessie W.

description:
I really want to give them more stars, but can't.

We waited in line 45 mins, then got seats on the first round when they opened. There were literally 8 guys working behind the counter, and it took them over 25mins to even acknowledge us :(.  For 2 of us we had 6 oysters, a bowl of chowder, a smallish plate of sashimi, and 2 beers .... the bill was $58 before tip!!!! And the chowder was not very good, was really watery and tasted like a big bowl of clam juice. Ick! They should actually put some clams in it, might help a bit. Also, pretty lame for a seafood place to charge for bread!!! :/

The only good thing i can say is the oysters were actually quite good as well as the sashimi plate, but the amount of fish was far too skimpy for the price. Also, gotta love $4 draft beers :)

So, if you don't mind paying HIGH prices for small amounts of pretty good seafood, and don't care about being ignored, then this is your place! Personally, I think it is totally overhyped and will not be going back.
author: stacy a.

description:
The offerings at Swan Oyster Depot can best be encapsulated in one word: Fresh. Everything I tried tasted like was in the ocean merely hours before. I've never had clammier clam chowder. I ordered one to share to begin with, and had to order another to share because I just couldn't get enough. Between the smoked salmon, the oyster platter, the little necks, the shrimp salad, and all the little tastes I co-opted from others in our group, I was one happy camper. Swan Oyster is the place to take your seafood-loving friends. It just doesn't get fresher than this!

Oh yeah, bring tons of cash! It gets pricey, but it's totally worth it!
author: Angeline P.

description: There are not enough words to describe how good this place is. If you are in the area, it's a must try! The oysters and cocktails are so fresh! And the staff is super friendly! Loved everything about this little spot!
author: Jen B.

description:
I love this place!

Granted my boyfriend and I waited approx. 2 hours to get in here, but once in a while I'll test out when are the best times to go here so I don't have to wait that long...someone mentioned try when its raining haha

Anyway I love its feeling of a very traditional local fresh seafood place *cough* not touristy feel... I definitely wasn't expecting anything trendy but I loved the feeling of being in there and thinking wow, there is definitely history in this place.

I thought the servers were friendly and it looked like they loved their job and the people they are working with and I LOVED the fresh oysters and combination seafood salad.
My boyfriend loved the dressing that was made for the seafood salad, it was some olive oil vinaigrette with horse radish, salt, pepper and lemon type thing...haha

Overall love it, but I'll probably consider ordering the food to go and shucking my oysters at home. But definitely wouldn't mind coming here for breakfast every now and then =)
author: Michelle L.

description:
Mixed feelings about visiting Swan...love the old school atmosphere and the counter service aspects of eating shell fish.  

The quality of the oysters and clams were fresh and quite tasty, but to wait in line for 45 minutes just to eat oysters in a timeless spot that Anthony Bourdain said he loves, left me feeling  rather let down.
 
I guess that since I missed crab season, I didn't get the full TV show experience.  

I also feel that the price point to overall service and quality of food is too high.  

Oh well I can now say at cocktail parties that I've eaten at the famous Swan Oyster Depot.
author: Howeler G.

description: If you want a seafood breakfast in Nob Hill, Swan Oyster Depot is your go-to spot. My recommendations? Crab fat, sea urchin a shell and salmon on sourdough bread. Oh and throw in some shrimp cocktail
author: Vhalerie L.

description:
this place is absolutely amazing! the staff are super friendly and very helpful, it's a plus when they remember you by name :)

the sashimi plate w capers, olive oil, onions and lemon is to die for... so fresh! i could eat this every day. 

their clam chowder is great because it's not super thick like most places so i can actually eat a cup of it without feeling overly full. and they have fresh bread for dipping on the side. 

that with a nice cold beer is the perfect meal.

&& i started ordering seafood from them to just pick up and take home, it's amazing! they are very knowledgeable about their products and will make fabulous recommendations based on what you're going to make with the seafood.
author: danielle a.

description:
I lived in SF for the majority of my life, and sadly, I have never been to Swan's Oyster Depot until now!  Yes, with their crazy hours, it's hard to swing on by there on a weekday, and weekends are just out for me.

I was back in the city by the bay and had a free weekday afternoon all to myself.  Why not hit up Swan's Oyster Depot finally.  I had heard about the ridiculous lines going out the door, but I was up for the challenge.  

As I approached this small store right before 1 pm, there was no line in sight.  All the seats were taken at the counter and when they asked if I was dining in by myself, they said there was a seat opening up in just a second.  I realized I came just in time as the line starting forming right behind me.

As I waited for my seat to clear, I noticed the fresh seafood in the window display and the constant movement of all the workers behind the counter.  It was busy.  People were eating and talking.  Some were loitering, as I would call it.  I asked one of the workers what their most popular dish was and he said the Combo Seafood Salad, Clam Chowder, Combo Seafood Cocktail, etc.  

Finally squeezing into my counter seat, the worker saw me struggle with my purse and offered to put it behind the counter on the top shelf.    (How perfect!  I don't have to put it on the floor, have it occupy my lap while I'm enjoying my meal, or attempt to find room on the actual counter itself.)  He asked if he could get me something to drink and I stuck with water.  He also offered me bread too, which I so gladly accepted.  Since it was just me eating on my own, I opted for the Combo Seafood Salad for $15.75.  It's a chunk of change for lunch on your own though.  

I watched as lettuce was piled onto my plate, then crab meat, prawns, more crab meat and bay shrimp were added.  I choice Louie dressing for my salad, as you can have it with oil and vinegar if you choose.  When my salad was placed in front of me (check out the picture!), I could easily understand why this was a popular dish.  This was indeed a seafood salad, with the lettuce only being an accessory and more like a bed for the seafood to sit on.  The crab meat was fresh, and the prawns were cooked perfectly.  Plump and just yummy!

When it comes down to it, my salad was great!  It was filling, tasty, and just oh so fresh.  I saw them put together quite a few Combo Seafood Cocktails with prawns, crab meat, an oyster, and a bit of oyster water  to top it off.  It sure looked good and I wish I could have ordered one.

The staff are friendly and easy-going.  You can easily be a regular here or a newbie, and you'll be treated all the same.  And don't worry about dining here alone, you have a better chance to get seated quickly if you do.  And plus, you can observe all the other patrons dining here.    

When it comes down to it, I had a great time here and can agree that it's worth the five stars.  It might even be worth the wait too.  The seafood is fresh and tasty and I wish I could have ordered more.  (The cocktails, the clam chowder, oysters and clams on the half shell, etc.)  It's not a cheap eat for one thing though, and I wish I had more weekday afternoons to enjoy this place.
author: Teri C.

description:
I wanted to love this place after waiting in line for over an hour and a half. 

1. The clam chowder was not good. Watery and bland. I'm from Boston, so I know great chowder and sadly this missed the mark. 

2. The crab salad was good but not worth the long wait. 

Overall, the food I had was very mediocre seafood restaurant fare. 

The PLUS is the charm of this place and the awesome, friendly staff. It's a fun place to eat but don't expect to have your mind blown food-wise.
author: Dan F.

description:
Deeeeeliciousssssssssss and so worth the wait!!! 

See below awesome reviews (how can you beat the acrostic poem??)

Cash only!
author: Nancy K.

description: After seeing Swan Oyster Depot featured by Anthony Bourdain, I decided to make a trip there. I went early afternoon and there was quite a long line. The line is due to the fact that there is only one counter space for customers to sit. Thus, I waited a good 1.5 hours to get a seat. I ordered the clam chowder, half a dozen oysters, and the smoked salmon. All the seafood tastes fresh. There is a sashimi plate that they can specially make for you that is also quite delicious. Sure this place serves fresh seafood, but you can also get such a fare elsewhere and avoid the long lines.
author: Jennifer L.

description:
FOOD: 5 stars

STAFF: 5 stars
+  sooo friendly + funny

AMBIANCE: 4 stars
-  small, cramped
+  but charming

COST: 4 stars
+ reasonable, but can always be less, right?!

THINGS TO KNOW:
* cash only!
* prepare to wait in line (outside)
* don't bring large purses/bags
author: Tina F.

description:
It was a beautiful sunny weekend, just a tick past 11, and no traffic to be seen.  What better time to try Swan Oyster Depot?

Parking was surprisingly easy near Polk, although only for a 1 hour meter maximum.  Given the stories of the long wait, I was a bit worried about having to make multiple trips to the meter god, but the siren call of "the best seafood in SF" beckoned louder than those worries.

Already a line had formed and the small, cozy place was bustling with activity inside.  Multiple people arrived as we waited (~20 minutes) to pick up to-go orders and I have to admit I was a bit surprised about some of the tabs (over $100).  Still, with the sun glowing warmly, waiting in line was definitely a nice experience and one I'm surprised I had never experienced while I lived in the city (though I probably couldn't afford it then).  People drank beer as they waited and most chatted pleasantly with each other.  The couple in front of us had driven all the way from Santa Barbara and had been going to Swan most weekends since they were children.  All in all, good signs.

After the quicker than expected wait, we made it to the counter and proceeded to order the dishes most in line had recommended:

Clam chowder soup - brothy and strong, with no hint of milk that most are probably used to with other chowders.  The chowder was an excellent start before all the cold food and was notable for the minimal amount of potatoes.

Oyster - A variety of 4 types, all of the oysters were extremely fresh.  I was a bit surprised at how small one variety was, but I know next time to just order by saying "Give me one dozen of the biggest fellas."  Definitely as good as Hog Island; points for the abundant selection of sauces: red onion-vinegar, cocktail sauce and horseradish.  

Prawn Cocktail - For $8.50, it was essentially four cold prawns in a glass.  Reasonably fresh, but I was a bit disappointed given the high price and lack of preparation.  Unless I live in the boonies and don't have access to fresh seafood during the winter months, I can't imagine what's so special about this.  In fact, I can go to Safeway, pick up a 1 LB bag of prawns for $21 and make 10 of these cocktails.  

Combination salad - For $17.50, the salad consisted of lettuce sprinkled with a generous helping of crab, shrimp and prawns.  Dressing choices are oil & vinaigrette or the famous Louie sauce.  Pardon my ignorance, but isn't Louie sauce just Thousand Island Dressing?  It sure looks like it.  I'll admit the taste is slightly different, but I wasn't impressed.  Again, while the serving of seafood was generous, to me, it was just cold, cooked crab, shrimp, and prawns.  I'm positive I can get as fresh a selection at any local seafood shop or even Whole Foods and recreate my own "combination salad;" with higher quality lettuce to boot.

Overall, I was a bit disappointed.  Given the stellar reviews, I definitely expected more.  Perhaps I'm spoiled.  When I say fresh seafood, I mean rock cod that I just caught that morning or cooked prawns that I just bought live from the Marina Food Market.  Heck, I've even ate lobster sashimi where the lobster tentacles were still moving!  That's fresh!  Maybe in a location where people just eat microwaved dinners and canned goods, the food here would be amazing, but we live in the Bay Area!  Seafood is everywhere and live seafood is too.  I enjoyed the ambiance, loved chatting with the other customers, but thought the food (other than the oysters) was average fare.  Sorry.  

By the way, be sure to bring your wallet.  All that fresh seafood ain't cheap.  Our bill came to ~$65 and it's cash only, all the time...
author: Randy F.

description:
OMG, this place is amazing! While on a mini-vacation to San Francisco with my sister, we agreed that while there we had to dedicate a day to eating just seafood. We were researching different places on Yelp and the nearest to our hotel was Swan Oyster Depot. The reviews seem to be a hit or miss, so we continued to research, but seem to come back to Swan Oyster Depot. Yes, we read that the wait can be really long, but we wanted to know what the fuss was about. I mean, they have a long wait for a reason, right? Why would you wait in line for so long if the food isn`t good?

We woke up kind of early because we wanted to try to beat the rush. Luckily, there were some stools available by the time we got there. It was about 10 o`clock in the morning, and there were already people inside. The place is really small. Only enough room behind the counter for the guys to walk back and forth from one end of the bar to the other and only enough room at the bar for you to find a seat. There are only 18 stools in the place, no tables. If you happen to find a seat open, snag it as fast as you can because people are always coming in and out of the place. Not recommended for large parties.

We sat down, got some waters, and looked over their small menu, which is up on the wall. My sister also got a beer (yup, at 10 o`clock in the morning). The two things we really wanted to get were the dozen Mixed Oysters and the Combination Salad, which were highly talked about on Yelp. I can`t remember where all the oysters came from, but there was one from Washington that was really good. Briny, tons of oceanic flavor, with just a squeeze of lemon, and it`s the best bite you could ever put in your mouth. So fresh! The Combination Salad alone, is something that I would come back again and again. Shredded lettuce, fresh crab, prawns, baby shrimp, and a side of Louis Dressing. Sounds pretty plain, right? Trust me, simple done right is the best. The seafood is sweet, flavorful, and generous.

When you come here, be prepared to make a dent in your wallet. It may be expensive, but it`s fresh, high-quality seafood. Worth every penny. Make sure you bring cash. These guys do it old school.

While eating, it started to get a little busy. A lot of people came in to do take out, which seems like a good idea, especially since finding a seat can be a hardship.
author: Chris T.

description:
Two hour wait.

Despite the wait my experience here was well worth it. 

Crab Back:
How do you not eat this? We asians love this part the most and they sold it for 3 bucks each! What a steal.....

Crab Salad:
Lots of crab and lots of cabbage, it was delicious but a little on the pricey side.

Clam Chowder:
Not superrrrr creamy but savory.

Oysters:
To die for, raved, and revered.

Everything was great and delicious. Definitely would come back but the wait just soooo long...
author: Irvin C.

description:
We came here for the oyster and they did not disappoint! We got the local oyster for our 1st dozen - might have been the best oyster I've ever had. So fresh. Our next batch was a combination of the other types - not as great as the first, but still fresh and delicious. The homemade tartar sauce with the cocktail crabs was really good - although, I would not recommend getting the cocktail crabs. For $14 it's worth spending more and go for a whole crab and go to town. The clam chowder was good - not as thick as I would like it, but it has a nice seasoning. 

It's a small place - basically a bar with about 20 stools - so expect to wait in line.
author: Jennie L.

description:
Swan Oyster Depot rightly deserves its reputation as one of San Francisco's great institutions. If you have a few days in the city and are on a tight budget, brave the lines and come for what will be a memorable dining experience. 

For a pseudo-native Bostonian like myself, the Boston Clam Chowder was up to par. It preluded the rest of the food very well: tasty, but not too salty, clean-tasting, not rich, like what good seafood should be. Apart from the chowder, we ordered the oysters, scallops, and a sea urchin. 

The oysters really stood out, probably some of the best oysters I've ever had. 

The scallops were generously-sized and had great texture, though I wish they had a sweeter taste. 

My friend and I shared an entire sea urchin for $16, which yielded six melt-in-your-mouth pieces of ocean goodness. At a Japanese restaurant, you'd typically pay the same amount for two pieces of uni nigiri, which is how I think it ultimately measures up. I've had tasted better-quality seafood at premium Japanese restaurants elsewhere, but for what you end up paying, the value was incomparable.
author: Alastair S.

description:
I arrived around 1:30pm on a Friday afternoon and faced a one to two hour wait, but I was willing to wait in order to try some fresh (and delicious!) seafood. The hour passed surprisingly quickly, and luckily for my boyfriend and I, once we were in the doorway we were ushered to our seats within five minutes. As we were waiting we were able to gawk at the fresh seafood that was on display (on ice) in the window, all of which looked fantastic. 

I was eager to sit down at the counter seating (one of about 12-15 seats) and to put in our order for a late lunch. We started off with a bowl of the clam chowder and two Anchor Steam beers. The clam chowder was generously served with loads of clam throughout the soup. The chowder wasn't incredibly rich or thick, in fact I'd even venture to describe the liquid as somewhat thin. At first I was a little put off by this, but the liquid was flavorful and it made the focus of the soup on the claims. The bread and butter that they served as a side to the soup was fantastic. My only complaint is that the sourdough bread wasn't served warm, as the sourdough flavor was incredible and greatly complimented the soup. We generously sopped up the broth with the bread, which was a great combination.

After we polished off our soup, we decided to split the crab salad with the louie sauce. My oh my, this was absolutely incredible. The base of the salad was a simple iceburg/romaine mix that was topped with a heaping portion of fresh chilled crab with a side of louie sauce. The crab was sweet and succulent and stood out wonderfully on its own. The louie sauce kicked up the flavor of the salad immensely, and I found myself alternating bites of the salad with and without the sauce. I'd highly recommend this salad, but definitely to share so that you can try more of the menu (and also due to its large portion size).

The service was overall attentive and friendly, but it took us awhile to get the check which I found odd as there was still a large line outside. As many others have mentioned, this restaurant definitely isn't the most sanitary as they're constantly handling raw fish/vegetables/etc without washing their hands. I also ventured back to the restroom which was next to the filthy kitchen. I'm glad I witnessed this after eating, as it was pretty disgusting.
