Although, all that being said, I didn't get sick from these conditions, so I wouldn't worry too much about it.

If you're in San Francisco and looking for a unique seafood diner experience, definitely hit up Swan Oyster Depot.
author: Megan K.

description:
I have been trying to do as many things on the 2010 7x7 list as possible. I got out of work early and this was on the way home. I asked my friend to join me since his late sister LOVED this place. She was the first person to order everything on the menu! 

Arrived around 12.30pm and there was a party of two waiting by the door. We get behind them. A party of 4 leaves so we just walked up and grabbed the two stools. You seat yourself. All stools by the "bar." The feel was very back in the day. It was interesting. No fluff service. I like it!

We read the 7x7 list wrong and ordered the clams in the half shell instead of the oysters in the half shell. The clams were really fresh but I guess its not our cup of tea. It felt like I was chewing on flesh. 

We also ordered clam chowder because it was cold out. I got a cup while my friend got a bowl. Good thing I got the cup. It was very watered down! It was this clear broth with speaks of white stuff in it. =/

We were in and out pretty fast. The price here is way better than the price at hog island. I was expecting to spend more money.  I would definitely like to come back and get the oysters and also a salad since it seemed like a very popular option. 

The stools are pretty small so if you are a bit bigger then beware.

CASH ONLY!
author: Sarah C.

description: Long line but worth waiting. I got smoked salmon, oysters and salad here. Very nice crew, friendly and good seafood. I definitely will come back
author: Krystal V.

description:
Been wanting to try this place out for a while now. Seems overpriced. (and maybe not so sanitary.) I didn't see the men who were helping us wash their hands between any transactions.. 

the food itself was ok. not the best i'd ever had. Although we didnt try that much stuff. I had a dozen oysters.. (I feel like you can get same quality anywhere for same price or cheaper during a happy hour) seafood cocktail (he said it was good. seemed a little skimp) and the fresh uni....not only skimp, but flavor wasnt that fresh even though it was carved out of the actual shell. =/

maybe it just wasnt our day, but since I do live in the city, maybe Ill try them again someday.
author: Lisa N.

description: This place is the absolute best.  Nothing fancy, no white tablecloth service, but always a smile and delicious food.  Ask about what's not on the menu, and maybe you'll get lucky and get some tequila.
author: Alexander C.

description:
We try the mix dozen of oyster and believe me it superb, the best i had so far.
Mix seafood salad, it looks ok from picture, but the taste is also the best we had so far.
The wait was about 1hr 20minutes.
Me n my wife came in hungry and left full and happy, the cost of our meal was $65 and another $10 for tips, so total 75 bucks.
author: Hong L.

description:
The line was well worth it! We were given our drink orders in line and when we sat down, they filled them back up to the top. We ended up getting the oysters, shrimp cocktail and the Italian sashimi. 
The oysters were delicious. I suggest getting a mixed plate because it allows you to try different oysters from different places. 
The shrimp cocktail was very generous with the shrimp and cocktail sauce. Add some of the horseradish and it's a perfect kick!
Finally, the Italian sashimi is not on the menu but it's a must have. It's halibut, salmon, scallops and tuna sashimi with olive oil, capers and red onion. It's delicious!
We will definitely be going back
author: Stephanie C.

description:
I am in love with Swan Oyster. My friend was hosting an AirBB guest and wanted to give her a tour on her last day so I joined and we did Coit Towers, the Pink Ladies, Lombard St. (the crooked street), Haight Ashbury, and happened upon Swan Oyster with hardly any line!  So we got in line and prepared ot have lunch at this almost 100 year old Oyster/seafood old school counter spot. The proprieter an adorable one of two brothers and his son helped us, greeted almost everyone by name with their takeout orders and as we sat at the end of the bar, I definitely felt that sense of community. 

A young woman peeked in around the line to ask one of the owners if there are other locations and if they have a card, he looked at her deadpan like she was crazy and said no. I had to laugh, quietly. In my opinion nothing about Swan Oyster says chain, franchise or even business card. It's straight up old school, and Gangster good. All the seafood is fresh and seasonal, so what's available is about what's available, our international friend had 10 Oysters, sampling two of each of the days featured goods, I opted for some clam chowder, so delish! and M had Mixed Seafood Cocktail, which looked amaze. Not to mention the fresh sourdough w/ butter which I could live off. 

The guys working the counters are in pictures for decades, and it's crazy endearing. A true family business where the current brothers/owners inherited from their father and work with their sons. LOVE. We even got a story and some Swan Oyster sponges. Adorbs....Felt absolutely special. Tons of folks were also picking up fresh fist to take home too. The coolest fish market/seafood restaurant I've been to!

I love an old school joint with good food, real folk and great atmosphere. 

Will definitely be back. 

No credit cards, no websites, no other locales. Note it. xx
author: Vanessa L.

description:
It's a unique atmosphere and the oysters were pretty good, but I don't think I'd rush back.  

The lines are long, even during off-peak periods. 

They run out of items on the menu, which is not a great sign. 

The oysters were good and not too expensive, but the clam chowder was just OK.  The sourdough bread that came with it was THE BEST I've ever had. 

The service was a little chaotic as you don't know who serves you and it feels disorganized.   However, it is a friendly place.  What does trouble me is that perhaps because it's just a bar, the cleanliness is an issue.  I wiped off my area when I arrived--no one cleared the crumbs, leftover sauce on the table, etc.  And my water glass tasted like seawater, which makes me think that the server didn't wash their hands or handle my water appropriately.  I was very thankful not to get sick after leaving here. 

SOD is an institution but I'd only go when it's not busy and you get real attention and service.
author: Anon M.

description: Really great for take out. Line to sit is very long. Very small place. Freshest basic seafood around. No frills.  Get it to go and eat a picnic in nearby park. Plain shrimp is the best!
author: Elianna S.

description: Sorry, but this place is overrated! We wait in line, as expected, then when we finally get in and get seated we are ignored by the workers for about 15 minutes. We finally got someone's attention and ordered some oysters (none of which are even local!) and some chowder. The oysters were okay, but the chowder was watery and really just fishy and bad! Somehow, even though they had just opened, they were out of crab -- huh?? We got a plate of sashimi that was pretty good, but the overall experience was below average. The men that work there are way to busy to show any kind of customer service, so we will not be back. We can get way better food in this town AND served by someone who is friendly! :(
author: Ann H.

description: All the servers touched the food, money, dirty dishes and sashimi without ever washing their hands. Absolutely the dirtiest restaurent I have eaten in my life. The oyster plate was 30 and the "sashimi" consisting of smoked salmon, scallop  and yellow tail came to $70. Cash only.
author: Nicholas H.

description:
If you are an oyster lover, then this place is a must stop place on your foodie adventure!

We hit this place last week early....again, I stressed early! Like 11:30 AM. Why you ask? Because it is such a popular place, very small, maybe 20 to 25 seats in the whole joint and from lunch on a line will fom outside the door with people waiting for you to hurry up and get out so they can indulge in some of the freshest sea food around town.

We got there for an early lunch and got seated right away. With a half dozen or so guys working behind the lunch counter service is right on. Menu is on the wall behind the counter so look up, hurry up and order. Wife went for the crab Louie salad which this place is famous for. I went for a bowl of clam chowder and a half dozen blue point oysters which I shared with her, I could have ate the whole plate of oysters alone, they were so fresh and with the horseradish and cocktail sauce mixed together, they were awesome! Here crab Louie salad was delicious and turthfully it had more crab then greens and we are not talking about slivers of crab, but large chunks of fresh dungeness crab, it was to die for, their thousand island dressing is full of flavor and this salad is a must try for anyone craving a good salad.

Place is a bit pricey for being a dive, but so worth it. Also, they close at 5:30 PM so if your looking for a late dinner, this place wont be open. I suggest, try it for lunch, either early or have a late lunch here since it's a hit with the locals around the area as well.
author: Bruce M.

description:
I really wanted to like this place but left a bit disappointed.  I went on a Friday afternoon for lunch at 2:30 and waited in line for a spot at their long marbled bar until 3:15.  I heard the line moves quickly, but not quickly enough in my opinion... 

I ordered a cup of the New England clam chowder, crab cocktail and half a dozen oysters (3 different kinds of oysters).  The clam chowder tasted ok but the rue of the soup was broken so it did not look appetizing since the cream and the broth separated.  The crab cocktail was ok but it left me wanting more as I realize that I prefer to eat crab warm vs cold (they de-shell the crab meat for the cocktail as well as the crab salad early in the morning, so there is a vat of the crab meat sitting on ice).  The oysters were good and I believe to be the highlight of my meal.  You really can't go wrong with fresh oysters on the half shell.  They keep their sauces in jars on the counter and they have thai chili as one of their hot sauces.  Service here is spectacular though and they make you feel super welcomed.
author: Kai C.

description:
Fun place to eat. The place has a lot of charm and character -- feels almost like you're right at the pier. It's quite popular so expect a long line.

The oysters are of course great here. The smoked salmon is good and the smoked trout is only okay. The crab is quite good and the clam chowder is pretty typical. Everything tastes really fresh (the reason why they close so early is because the family has to be there already really early in the morning to get the seafood fresh).
author: Victor W.

description:
In a nutshell:

Food: 5 stars
Service: 5 stars
P/C (bang for the buck): 4 stars

As soon as I saw this place, I collapsed, died, and went to the fresh seafood lover's heaven.  My friend and I were so determined to go here on a Saturday early morning.  We actually called each other 3 times to make sure we woke up by 8am to get there.  Holy Schmokes, when we got there around 10am, there was a line already.  But seriously, I didn't mind it, I was just so happy and satisfied looking at the array of the most vivid and fresh looking seafood items.  Plus, I was all decked out and the server brought out a bottle of sauvignon blanc, so we were good.

The wait wasn't all but 20 minutes, and we sat ourselves down at the counter (I think that there are only about 14~16 stools along the bar, so I suggest getting here really early in the morning - so that you beat the crowd and enjoy the most fresh batches of whatever you choose to inhale.)

So this is what we had (2 of us):

2 dozens of 6 different varieties of oysters
1/2 dozen of 2 different varieties of clams
1 shrimp cocktail
1 crabmeat cocktail
1 Sicilian-style sashimi of ahi, yellowtail and scallops (not on the menu - but you HAVE to try this).
2 bowls of clam chowder
1 bottle of sauvignon blanc

Yes, we were pigs.  But hey, if you were us and just love seafood, this is just a mild beginning.  Everything was so well prepared, sweet, and fresh.  The service was down-to-earth and swift.  The guys really know their seafood and take pride in what they do.  

The damage - $135 for two of us.  Really, it was money well spent.  I got my oyster fix and walked out as happy as I could be.

In conclusion - I'll go back the minute I have any sort of cravings for seafood.
author: Mike P.

description:
I likes my seafood the way I likes my men - fresh off the boat!*

Swan's definitely fits the bill for this, serving up a raw, fresh, seafood orgy. The oysters are huge and tasty, and I love the different style toppings that come with it. Their seafood tastes like they just drive the ship by and unload it into the restaurant every morning.

Love the no frills approach to amazing seafood and the great service. You eat at a counter and chat up the guys working there. 

The only thing that I found underwhelming was the clam chowder. But who really wants soup when faced with a giant platter of oysters and seafood cocktail?

It's so great that I don't even mind the cash only part of it. So long as my date pays, anyway.

**Tip**
I once happened upon Swan's when there wasn't any line here. It was around 10:30AM on a Saturday, but sadly I had places to be. I've contemplated oysters for breakfast ever since.

*From Hotlandia
author: Selina K.

description:
Some of the best cracked dungeness crab I've ever had was from Swan Oyster Depot. 

They only take cash!

The line out he door is for people waiting to be seated.....you can skip to the front if you're just going to order something to go (take out). 

Check out the photos of everything we ate at the link to my food website:

http://eatsporkjew.com/restaurants/i-said-i-love-youhe-said-he-had-crabs/
author: Philip H.

description:
This is the best seafood place in town. They get fresh seafood every morning from the fish market and you never walk out of this place without saying: see you soon! It has been managed by the Sancimino brothers since 1946 and they'll be very straight forward and honest with you about the quality of their food. So prepare yourself to hear: I don't recommend it today, we have had better quality of this. 

You'l fall in love with everything. From the very light, but still delusions, clam chowder to the old fashion uncomfortable stools at the bar which makes this place one of the  best seafood restaurants that I have ever been to. 

Make sure you try at least one of these: 

- The clam chowder
- Sashimi dish
- Smoke salmon over rye
- Fresh oysters
- Seafood Salad
- Sea Urchin (I love this)
- The crab head soup. (You really have to be a seafood lover for this)
author: Siavash N.

description:
I went thursday with my boyfriend and my family for the first time.

We enjoyed it so much the athmosphere was great all the staff was prompt 
to help us and answer our questions with a smile by far this is the best seafood restaurant I ve been to , everything super fresh ,really yummy .

Their Oyster cocktail was amazing. I ve seen this place for a quite some time but always with a big line full of people So I was just waiting for the perfect time to go I am so happy i finally went this place is Superb, I highly recommend it to all of you.


Thank you to all the Chef and to staff .
author: Theresa B.

description: The line was incredibly long and the seating arrangements were very limited. I decided to go up to the front and ordered to-go. This was a great time saver and was worth it. I ordered the crab cocktail and clam chowder. And it has been awhile since I had crab this fresh. They break it apart right in front of you and the cocktail sauce they make tastes perfect with the crab. They provide you with a large amount of crab in the dish. The clam chowder, however, wasn't impressive. It is more of a broth than a chowder so that caught me by surprise. It also tasted really buttery and wasn't like the chowders that I usually enjoy.
author: Izzy L.

description:
Apparently there was a crab shortage during the time that I was visiting San Francisco, so I did not get a chance to taste the half-cracked crab that everyone is raving about. Definitely recommend calling ahead to see if it is available since I wrongly assumed that it would be. 

Instead I got the shrimp and prawn combination salad, and while it was extremely fresh and tasted great, I thought $20 was a pretty steep price tag considering the amount of time I spent waiting and the sheer discomfort of the seating arrangements (perching awkwardly on a stool being elbowed by your neighbors). I really enjoyed the crusty sourdough bread and butter it was served with though.
author: Rachel H.

description:
BEST EVERYTHING!

This counter and the men behind it are truly legit.  Such an awesome place with authentic energy and shellfish!!!  

Start off with some chowda, get a combo salad and a dozen oysters - top it off with sea urchin...INCREDIBLE!

Wish I lived upstairs, I'd eat here daily...not to mention the fishermen and staff are hilarious and a riot to be around :-)
author: Alex T.

description: The food was good, not great. The line was 90 minutes. But it is an institution and you have to do it once.
author: Tim L.

description:
Um DELICIOUS. 

fell in love with the food. 

This place reminded me of fresh seafood in boston and the love the workers had for the food - they all felt like they were a family of brothers.  

I arrived there just in time when they made the last three people behind me the last people they would serve.  There was quite a wait, but the server brought us free beers and were so kind and happy that we were waiting for them. 

The place is somewhere you do not want to go if you are looking for a nice family sit down in a quiet place in nice clothes.  You want to go here if you want delicious fresh seafood and are in a party smaller than 3 and you don't mind getting your hands and possibly clothes dirty.  

The seating is as if you are seated at a bar, but you are served right away.  All the servers are helpful helping you pick your choices.  I normally do not like clam chowder if it is more on the watery side than creamy, but this clam chowder was sooo well balanced and filled with flavor.  I also got fresh oysters that they served with some hot sauce that was sooo good. I noticed people got fresh sashimi or smoked salmon that looked so good, but I knew if I ordered more I would be spending more money than I had.  

The only thing is that they are CASH only so make sure you only order as much as you can actually pay.
author: Kristina L.

description: Worth the wait! Go early, like 11am and be patient. This is a super fresh seafood bar with tasty oysters, shrimp, crab and of course COLD beer! A definite must do for locals and travelers alike!
author: Brian S.

description: I have been coming here for 30 years. I think its toime for the boys to wrap it up. Even though they say theyre open until 5:30 they refused to serve me at 5 pm. I was heartbroken this mam who i thought was a friend was rude and belligerent OBvIOUSLY they are making too much $$ and dont care about their loyal customers.    .  DO NOT GO THERE.  RUDE
author: Mp H.

description:
If you've ever dined at Swan Oyster Depot you may have noticed the long line (obviously), the seating area in the form of a bar with room for only 25 at a time, and the fact that everything on the menu is served cold (with the exception of the clam chowder).

However, I'd really, really like to know if I'm the only one that noticed the following:

1. The nonuse of serving utensils. Everything is served with the employees bare hands, and I'm talking hands with no gloves on.

2. Servers handling money from paying customers and then serving everything including, crab cocktails and shrimp cocktails with their contaminated, bare hands. 

3. Servers going to throw out the trash only to come back behind the bar and continue serving food with their BARE hands without even washing them. 

4. Locals coming in to get to-go orders that take forever and ever to fulfill and making the area where you stand closest to the entrance uncomfortably crowded and impersonal. 

5. How bland and watery the clam chowder is. 

6. How the crab fat (one of the most celebrated dishes) is nothing more than cold water with pieces of useless crab particles. I can't even say it tastes bad because it honestly doesn't taste like anything. 

7. This one is something I may have only had the privilege of witnessing, but I think it deserves credit on this list nonetheless.  A woman sitting next to me asked for a shrimp cocktail. She ate a few shrimp with her BARE hands (that have been God knows where) and then asked the server if she could change it for the bigger shrimp cocktail. The server then took her shrimp cup, dumped it in the bin with the rest of the small shrimp, replaced it with larger shrimp and said, "It's okay, somebody's gonna eat it." I can't make this stuff up. 

Show of hands...anyone? Anyone? 

I'm all for mom and pop places, dives, getting down and dirty, and even applying the 5 second rule with a chip I drop on my own floor, but I'm also all for clean, sterile dining. Even if all the health code violations go on in the kitchen where I can't see them, it's fine by me as long as the food is worth it. But if  I can actually see the mishandling of food no matter how good it is or how trendy it is, I don't care for it. 

Dine at your own risk, folks.
author: Vanessa M.

description: Good food.  Spare me the attitude behind the bar.  I can get fish & seafood that is just as good at other restaurants in the same neighborhood and no lines & no attitude. I won't be going back.
author: The P.

description:
12 Oysters
2 Cups of clam chowder
2 Anchor Steams
1 Seafood Salad

Total with tip: $80. 

Arrived hungry, left hungry, with a lot less money. Definitely not going back. It was good, but the price tag just didn't make sense for what we got. Only reason we tried it was because Cordon Bleu was out on vacation. That would've been 8 different meals at Cordon Bleu, and we would have left extremely satisfied.
author: Los Angelin O.

description: Awesome East past oyster bar in the heart of SF!  Get there early so you don't have to wait in line for hours since they only have about 15 seats at the counter.  Family owned and operated, it's awesome!  The oysters and lobster are amazing.  Chowder is also good but not super thick.  Can't wait to go back!!
author: Erin D.

description:
Overall, this place was good, but not worth the wait or the hype.  I heard about the ridiculously long lines, so I went on a Tuesday at 11 AM.  Waited about 25 minutes and got seated.  So far, so good.  

I attempted to order the crab, but the dude behind the counter said they were all out.  So I attempted to order the octopus salad, again, they were all out.  Hmmm... I then asked for some clams, and again, they were out of clams for the day.  Keep in mind the menu isn't that big, so I was running out of options.  How can a spot that specializes in seafood not have these items?!? Isn't this like going to a tacqueria, ordering a burrito and having some dude tell you that they are out of tortilla for the day??

Anyways, on to what we did order.  The clam chowder was pretty good, but nothing to write home about.  The prawn cocktail was also pretty good.  The prawns were very fresh and the cocktail sauce was tasty, but nothing special and not something to write home about.  The oysters were very fresh, but again, I can get oysters of these quality almost anywhere in the city, so nothing to write home about.  We also had the smoked salmon. This was the highlight of the meal.  Perfectly smoked salmon! Very fresh! Thinnly sliced! I would litteraly write home about this dish, ya kno, if things like texting, emails, facebook, yelp, twitter, etc. didn't exist.
author: Grant L.

description:
I try to make Swan a must stop on every trip to San Francisco. As much for the characters behind the seafood bar as for the seafood itself. Suffice it to say that both are fresh and an absolute delight. 

Don't come expecting anything more than what it is. A small tiled bar with limited stools (20?) for seating and most times a line out the door that can be an hour plus depending. Once seated however, prepare yourself for some delicious and quite fresh seafood. Love the oysters in particular. Always a good east/west coast mix and so perfectly tasty with mignonette or cocktail sauce loaded with as much horseradish as you care to heap in (hint... go for a blow the top of your head off quantity). The combo Louie salad is nice as well with jumbo and bay shrimp and plenty of fresh, briny crab atop a bunch of shredded lettuce. Basic story is I've always been happy no matter what I've ordered. 

Finally... Price. It's not cheap by any stretch but paying for quality is always an ok thing in my book.
author: Tom C.

description:
It was everything the reviews suggested and more... The Stella flows like champagne and the guys that run the counter here are fantastic! We did wait the hour and 45 minutes to grab 4 seats (2 and 2). We had the Calamari salad (blanched calamari rings and mini octopi in a broth), the mixed dozen (Kumamoto's, Miyagi's and Blue Points, $28) and a bowl of clam chowder ($5). All mouth watering and UNDENIABLY fresh! Just for the freshness of the seafood alone, wait the two hours and pleasure your palate.

I couldn't stop calling it the Disneyland of Seafood. It is the happiest place on earth for seafood :)
author: Camille L.

description:
Alright, the wait was long. I'm not a stranger to waiting for food, but I got a little impatient... then I got in, and I ordered their seafood salad and clam chowder. After some time chit-chatting with the friendly guys behind the counter (and many tummy growls later), I received my food I was blown away by the quality and freshness of the food.  Their salad, although slightly pricey, is the perfect presentation of seafood salad! It had a light dressing that complemented the crab and shrimp VERY well, and it was so, so filling.  Although the clam chowder is a lot thinner than what I'm normally used to, it's probably the most flavorful and fresh chowder I will ever find. The clams were SO good--no fluff or fillers in this chowder, you can count on that.  Swan Oyster Depot sets the bar really high for clam chowda :)

The guys behind the counter were personable and warm. I loved my experience here and thought the awfully long wait was... definitely worth it.  I would definitely recommend this place to anyone visiting SF and I'd come back here every time I visit myself. I love Swan Oyster Depot!
author: Jenny O.

description:
Just fresh, clean, straight up seafood. Right off the boat and delish!
The customer serivce is excellent & loved the counter service. We'll def be back! 



**Get there early!
author: C L.

description: Delicious: the sashimi is amazing, the smoked salmon like butter, the oysters crisp. Would rate it higher if it were a cleaner place to eat.
author: Corey T.

description:
I've been trying to go to this place for months, but their hours are not very customer-friendly so I finally made it in today after several unsuccessful attempts. 

I was mostly excited to try the clam chowder, but I honestly wasn't impressed with it at all. It was curdled, had only potatoes and a tiny bit of clams, and wasn't anything spectacular. Some of the chowder houses on Fisherman's Wharf have much better chowder! 

We also had the combination seafood cocktail, and that was delicious with horseradish added. I loved the crusty, chewy bread with butter. Next time I'd like to try the smoked salmon plate with shrimp salad. I'd go again, and would take friends visiting the city since it's such a unique SF institution, but my expectations were a bit higher given all the hype.
author: Jen R.

description: Every time I'm in San Fransisco I try to eat here. I've probably dined at Swan 15 times, there is no place I would rather go for seafood and Oysters!!! The people make this place special and worth waiting for.
author: Neil L.

description:
Totally awesome SanFran experience!  I brought my 7 year old Daughter here on a Friday b/c we had an appointment in the area.  We arrived in line at 1 (bad timing) and waited an hour....but it was totally worth it!  Kevin was the main person who waited on us, and he made the most AMAZING dijon vinaigrette I have ever had!!!!

I didn't know the place was cash only, no big deal. They tell your where and ATM is and just trust you will be back....which of course you will otherwise bad karma!

They made my Daughter feel special and everything we ate was awesome!  Crab Louis, oysters, crab cocktail, and chowder!

GO!!!!
author: Jen S.

description:
Given all the reviews, I guess I thought Swan Oyster was supposed to be an amazing, near-religious experience. It wasn't at all, and it was really pricey. Huge disappointment.

We had: 6 oysters, 2 cups clam chowder, 1 combo seafood salad, 1 sashimi plate, 1 ice tea.  Total = $75 before tip.
I think we were actually overcharged $5-10 in retrospect though I don't think it was intentional - just that they are busy and there are a lot of folks behind the counter running around, so it's chaotic. Plus some of the prices are not listed like the sashimi plate - or maybe that thing was $30+ dollars, which would be a joke. Or possibly, we were charged for bowls, not cups, of the soup.

Anyway, the quality is fresh - sure. But they were out of crab and uni. I understand as it's somewhat seasonal or varies by day, but those were the 2 main things my friend wanted to try. Anyway, clam chowder was fine but not the best I've ever had by any means. Oysters were good. Seafood salad and sashimi plate were okay - slightly disappointing. 

It is far from the best seafood I've ever had. I've been to the Tsukiji markets in Japan and I guess that is my criteria for the ultimate. I wasn't expecting the ultimate at Swan Oyster, but I though it'd be pretty darn good. It fell short, waaaaaaaay short. And it was pricey. 

Other notes: the wait wasn't bad because we came on a weekday after lunch, so there were about 10 people ahead of us. Service was mediocre.
author: Veronica H.

description:
We had to queue for about twenty minutes (and apparently that is a short length of time) to get a table at the long bar but definitely worth it. 
This place has been here for nearly 100 years, and it was great to see that the warm and friendly people serving have been associated with the place for such a long time (there are pictures of the staff from their much younger years on the wall behind the counter). They also made a real effort to seat our party of six altogether along the bar which was much appreciated.
 
The crab and prawn with the homemade cocktail sauce was perfectly balanced in terms of sweet and tartness. We also tried the oysters (of which there were three different types). The homemade pink and green vinegarettes available added a special dimension to the taste of the incredibly fresh oysters. A great way to spend an afternoon.
author: Viet-Anh H.

description: I won't come back again.  It's my first time came here.  The hygience is one of the issue.  Another is the oysters.  A professional staff should know oyster quality.  I ordered a dozen oysters,  two of oysters were expired.  The clam chowder was like a salty water.  That's absolutely not a chowder.  That's a salty water with potatoes pieces,  no seafood and no taste.  I supposed to have my dinner here,  after starter.. we decided to leave.  Absolutely disappointed and not worth it to spend time in the queue. Thank god no line up today.
author: Gayi L.

description:
Waited 1.25 hours in line. I hate to admit it, but it was worth it. If I go back it'll be M-Th when there is no line. The seafood salads can be made with a nice dijon vinaigrette instead of the louie dressing which contains eggs,, so if you don't eat eggs, there are options and, honestly, both myself and my wife thought the vinaigrette was better.

Combo Salad - RIDICULOUS
Oysters - AWESOME
Combo Cocktail - AMAZEBALLS

Everything we had was top notch and VERYa good. The service was equally amazing. Super friendly staff, very knowledgeable. The place has been there for 100yrs+ and is staffed and run by family. A true gem. highest possible ratings.
author: Johnson M.

description: The people behind the counter are just ok. It appeared as no system to helping someone. The wait for my oysters weren't long and the Oysters tasted good. When using the bathroom  it was alarming that one of the kitchens was located in the same area, way too close. If you want that 1950's feel it's a must see and experience in the bay area.
author: Bob B.

description: Hands down a great place!   Definitely worth the wait, kids loved it too.  You don't get lots of counter service like Swans!
author: T R.

description: Oysters and clams were very good, but the chowder was just OK.  I think Anchor Pyster bar is better.
author: Joe B.

description: The food was great the service was top noch. In a world where service is dwindling we were treated like royalty. The brothers who still work there and serve like prose made the experience perfect. I have eaten seafood in a lot of places that serve fresh seafood. This is the absolute best I have ever had! The service aka the few gentleman that work here are amazing!
author: Rob N.

description:
Ah yes, my favorite place to get seafood when I'm in the city of San Francisco.

Simply put, you just can't go wrong with this place.  Awesome food, great staff, and a simple bar and stool setup.  Yes, the wait can get pretty long if you come during peak hours, and if you eat a lot, it can get a bit pricey.  But trust me, you'll enjoy every minute you're here.

Here's what I usually order:

-Cup of Chowder
-Combination Oysters on a Half Shell
-Crab Cocktail
-Combination Seafood Salad
-A Glass of Anchor

Make sure that once you're sitting down and eating to glance over at the line of hungry customers staring at you.  The food will taste that much more sweeter.
author: Ken L.

description: I guess they don't like customers to order food Togo. I was the only customer in the Togo line. Told the guy with glasses I wanted something Togo and he told me "one second" and then 25 minutes passed I was still waiting. told another guy I wanted something Togo. And  another 10 mins passed. You are right. Still nothing. 5 dine-in customers were seated when I was waiting. So I just left. 35 minutes well spent.
author: Jessie K.

description: not worth the time looking for parking.  oyster is just average if that.  over hyped and for a small place it wasn't very personal nor friendly.  expect more for the price and what they boast themselves about.  not recommending or going back again.
author: Ben L.

description:
Always wanted to try this place and finally braved to stand in line and wait.  We came here for my 39th birthday.  When we finally got in, we had a sample of their oysters, crab fat, sea urchin, and chowder.  It was all delicious, fresh, and wonderful!  I would definitely come back - but it really is just a place to go by yourself or with 1 other person.  I couldn't take my whole family here - we'd close the place down!

The staff is so friendly and the guys behind the counter act like good chums kidding around and teasing each other.  It seemed like a happy place to work with.  Once you got in - you forgot the whole wait time and enjoyed the food.  They don't rush you out either!
author: JJAMZ C.

description: They were outta sea urchin by the time we got in. =( Sourdough bread was so good dipped in crab guts. Their oyster recommendations were spot on. Stellar Bay Golds were deliciously buttery. Sashimi plate was small but so fresh and so good. Capers were just the right touch.
author: Lynn D.

description:
My boyfriend and I came here a few weeks ago and LOVED IT.

We came in about 1 hour before closing on a Thursday and didn't have to wait at all.

We ordered:
- Dozen Assorted Oysters ($20)
- 1 cup of Clam Chowder ($2.50)

We love oysters so we figured we had to give this place a try. On the recommendation of someone who worked there we ended up getting an assorted dozen oysters, 3 of each of the 4 oysters they have. It was amazing. The mignonette sauce for the oysters was great. The oysters tasted fresh. Our favorites were the  Miyagi and Kumamoto oysters. They were so plump and juicy it was delicious! We also got a cup of the clam chowder on the recommendation of yelpers and it was quite tasty. The clams in it were great.

Everything was delicious. We'll definitely be back if we get the chance.
author: Eifeh S.

description:
Was here last year, can't recall a lot of what we ordered.
Got here around 10AMish and waited about an hour and a half. 

Well worth the wait. My friends and I thought everything here was delicious!

Had the cherry stone, blue point oysters, and West coast little necks.

Best seafood combination salad I have ever had!

Boston clam chowder 


Tip: Very limited seating, so don't come with too many people.
author: Robert N.

description:
These guys know how to handle business. I had too much food to list but the chowder was pretty good, the seafood combination salad was incredible. They don't skimp on anything here. All of the smoked fish blew my mind. So much flavor. This is the type of place where I don't look at prices and just order away because it's worth every penny. 

Apparently I missed Anthony Bourdain by a couple of weeks... maybe next time.
author: Tyler B.

description:
Absolutely delicious - Generous amounts of crab in their crab salad, and the clam chowder was awesome.  Never thought I was a big fan of oysters until I came here.  Swan Oyster Depot left an amazing impression on me, and I'll definitely be coming back soon.

Extremely friendly staff, and a wonderful bustling atmosphere.  If you haven't already tried Swan, you should! Probably the cleanest, tastiest seafood I've ever had (except for that one time I was in Maryland on the Chesapeake).  I'd give this place 6 stars if I could
author: Albert T.

description:
Very good seafood! I recommend fresh oysters !
The raw clams were delicious as well .
author: Ming T.

description:
Nothing beats a fresh protein loaded breakfast at Swan Oyster Depot. Make sure to get here right when they open so you don't have to wait in line and watch people eat their delicious seafood.

This place is no frills. Sit down, order, eat at the bar counter. I finally made my way here one morning and luckily made it before the crowd. We started with some oysters on a half shell and clam chowder. Their chowder is on the soupy side in case you prefer thicker, chunky soups. The oysters were fresh and they provide you a variety of sauces to dress them (horseradish, cocktail, salsa, tabasco, lemon, etc.)

Next, we had the crab salad (YUM). To finish, the smoked salmon was just right. Usually I don't care for smoked salmon, but this one wasn't too salty and came with capers and red onions. 

If you are a seafood lover, definitely stop by here.
author: Stine H.

description:
Finally went to Swan last weekend- we've lived around the corner from it for over a year. Firstly, some of the tastiest, freshest seafood we've had in a long long time. However, the line is a hassle. We waited for 2.5hrs (what can I say, once you've waited in line for an hour, it's not worth giving up, plus I was promised smoked salmon ;) ). 

The nice thing is, despite the line, you are on Polk St, which has plenty to do. So instead of wasting 2+ hrs I got a 30 min. massage across the street and then my husband got a haircut. All in all, a pretty productive Saturday. 

Definitely worth it, and the prices are certainly reasonable. Go for the combo seafood salad, and the smoked salmon. Having lived in New England for several years, the clam chowder is skippable. Also, say to Kevin when you go, he's great and incredibly knowledgeable about their fish.
author: Nina W.

description: Don't get me wrong, the food is definitely fresh and decently good.. But it's really nothing spectacular or worth raving about. If you like fresh seafood, it's  certainly worth a try. But, I don't think it's worth waiting that long in line for or in any way life changing. If you're from the Midwest or somewhere without much fresh seafood then yes this will probably blow your socks off. As for the rest of us from San Francisco - stop by if you're in the neighborhood, but don't go out of your way and wait for it.
author: Lisa H.

description:
Finally got a chance to come here, and I'm happy I did. We sat right by the door which is the "undesirable" spot, but we thought it was pretty cool. Just seeing the customers coming in and out dropping hundreds of dollars on food to go was amazing. Everything was good and if I ever walk by on a day like that day when the line isn't down the street I will definitely be back. This is one of the places that makes me wish I lived in San Francisco.
Bring cash. Lots of it.
author: Roxanne R.

description:
I may or may not have got ripped off...

I had a dozen oysters, half order of smoked salmon, half order dungenous crab, 3 clams and a Stella.  This is all for myself, by the way.  My total was $68 not including tip!  I ended up giving them $80 and left.  But then again...$68, that's alot of jack for ONE.

Here are the pros:
- Service is good/excellent, they will take care of you (and your money).
- Seafood/shellfish is fresh and tasty.  Oysters and clams are shucked in front of you.

Cons:
- Expensive and not worth the money.
- DEFINITELY NOT worth the wait (I waited 1.5 hours)
- Cramped - the seating is only a bar, so maybe 14 people tops.
- Sort of dirty - the floors were wet, I had a backpack that I set on the floor at the end of the bar.  Then one employee spilled water from a bucket...which I'm assuming is from the ocean (equals stank) so I had to yank my bag up quickly.  Basically, there was no other place to put my backpack (other than wear it) which made my experience even more awkward.
- I didn't like the bill, basically it was handwritten (and unreadable) on a napkin and the guy just said "that's $68 bucks."  I was obviously puzzled but he never itemized it for me.  Yes, I SHOULD HAVE ASKED FOR IT TO BE ITEMIZED.
- Cash only, which will be a surprise if you don't bring enough!!  I almost didn't have enough cash on me.

I would have been OK spending around $60 bucks including tip for what I got.  But really what made me mad is the COST PLUS THE WAIT.  

That, my friends, is a formula for disaster.
author: Stephen T.

description:
Bring lots of quarters! You are going to need it for the meter parking in SF

It's only 11 and it's packed!

This place has a line out the door seriously. It's because the restaurant doesn't hold that many people. But this place is worth waiting in line for. 

I love the feel of this place, it feels so old school and its family owned and ran I believe. It's not commercial or franchised. It seems pretty authentic. 

They have fresh seafood from oysters to shrimp to crab! 

They will crack the crab for you! 

We had a dozen oysters and the clam chowder. Both were sooooo good! It's cheaper then going to HOG's island too! 

We saw a lot of people order the louie salad. And they are very generous with their seafood portion, not shady at all! 

They make their own horseradish and cocktail sauce I believe. 

We ordered a crab to go, and we are so glad we did! It was that good! 

I highly recommend the crab, oyster sample, and the clam chowder!
author: Yung H.

description:
WORTH THE WAIT NO MATTER HOW LONG THE LINE IS!!!  This is probably one of my favorite restaurants of all time because the seafood is unbeatable.  

I always start with blue point oysters, they are so refreshing.  The smoked salmon plate has the freshest, most perfectly smoked salmon I have ever had.  The crab salad is literally covered in crab, there is no part of the salad visible when it comes out, it is almost entirely dungeness crab.  I am not a fan of thousand island dressing, so they also offer a "crab fat vinaigrette" made using crab guts, mustard, red wine vinegar, seasoning and olive oil, made fresh table side, and it is perfect!
author: L. B.

description:
Wow....That's all i got...if you are a local, come in and order to-go since it would be much faster.

If you are visiting, the 2 hours wait is worth every min. The people are super friendly and make you feel like you are a part of the family.

Hands down top 3 places to eat in SF for me.

Thank you Swan Oyster Depot i am a lifer!!!
author: Vitaly S.

description:
We came here on a Monday around 2pm and the wait was about 25 mins. Didn't think it was too bad for a wait. The place is small, so if you come on the weekend, be prepared to wait at least 1 hour. 

Let's get to the service and food. Our waiter was awesome! He was very attentive to make sure that we got everything we ordered and checked to see if we needed anything more. 

Unluckily, they didn't have have CRAB! :( The guy said that they didn't have crab all week. The clam chowder tasted awesome, but it was a bit watery for me. The scallops were sweet and fresh. The oysters are $28 for a dozen and we got the chef's selection. They were all very good and fresh. 

It was definitely a place worth the time and hype. I enjoyed the experience!
author: Alisa M.

description: This simple  seafood bar is a legend.... You will never find something like this in town. Only this place :)) service is homie ..dishes are heaven.. Whatelse you ever wanted for ...... One of  this day... I wanna say you re the best + best seafood restaurant for me .. Cheers
author: Regina A.

description: Long wait. I love their calamari w balsamic and olive oil. Clam chowder was aight. Wish I tried the crab backs.
author: Karina H.

description:
Hands down the best place in town for fresh seafood!

Been here about 3 times and my favorite is the crab cocktail. They literally de-shell the crab in front of you. Large selection of oysters as well. Prawns are also highly recommended! 

Pretty much just a counter for customers, so be ready for long lines.
author: Philip K.

description: This is a tourist trap. Most people wait hours for one of the coveted seats inside this small shop. While there are plenty of seafood everyday, you can definitely get fresher seafood, at better price as well around the Bay Area. During our visit, there were plenty of sea urchins available. Unfortunately, uni here is not as consistent since some of them are not the nice yellow shade you typically find in Japanese sushi restaurant. So save your money and head somewhere else.
author: Y C.

description:
So overrated! Must be successful to hype, not because of the service, ambience, and most importantly, not the food! Ate there for the first time today after battling through Market Street crowds celebrating the SF Giants achievement of winning the World Series and standing in line in the drizzling rain outside the restaurant for about 40 minutes. Would have been able to get there sooner and maybe not have had to stand in line so long if the Giants hadn't won ;) jk

Anyway, the clam chowder was pathetic. Oily, thin and lacking in clam and potatoes. The sea urchin on the other hand was sublime. Not as flavorful as some other that I've had but with a really delicate creaminess that was luscious and meant to be savored. The whole Maine lobster at $45 was a complete rip-off. It was accompanied by a brownish lettuce salad with a pile of baby shrimp. The lobster itself is simply boiled and served with melted butter. It was smallish and flavorless.

Even though the oysters and the sashimi served to others looked delicious and seemed to be really enjoyed, I don't know if that was enough to warrant another trip to this place.

So I spent about $90. Worth it? No. Especially since everyone sits at a counter on rickety little stools with no foot rest. No potatoes. No nice veggies. No rolls. There is bread and butter for $1.00. Whee!

Two stars for the uni (urchin). Really good.
author: Reynolds L.

description: Very fresh seafood. Highly recommended. Try the oyster platter, crab cocktail, and crab salad.
author: Sharon B.

description:
I ordered the calamari salad. A pint for $24! 
It's ok nothing special kinda flavorless. I don't see what all the fuss is about for this place. Service is friendly.
author: Evette M.

description:
Swan Oyster Depot - I think you're the first restaurant I was willing to wait outside in a line for 90 minutes. Yes, NINETY minutes with all the tourists snapping away at your window display of fresh seafood.

I can't help it! I mean, your half cracked crab just about tumbled out of the shell for my awaiting mouth. Your Bay Point Oysters have restored my faith in finding good oysters on the west coast (I am still very partial to my Island Creeks). Your amazingly friendly service, to top it off with beer while waiting, this is THE place to get cold seafood in SF and I don't think I can add much more than what has already been said, so in consultant style, here are some key takeaways

- It is very busy. Don't go here in groups and be prepared for a long wait. Might want to avoid Saturdays
- There is takeout! Don't want to wait? Just order to go
- Their clam chowder is interesting - it's lighter than most clam chowders I've tasted, less cream, but for what it is, I think it's very good
- Most of the food is cold. If you're cold, warm up with some chowder
- There are plenty of sauces to compliment your seafood, including louie sauce, tabasco, cocktail, mayo, vinegar... but it was just so fresh. Taste your seafood for what it truly is
- It's not cheap! Be prepared to spend around $40 - $50 per person
author: Shang S.

description:
I love this place, is a perfect spot! I try to go as often as I can.
The sicilian sashimi is very good and the crab salad is excellent. Old-school cantina. They have a special member in the staff, Brian, he is lovely!

I give 4 stars because the line is always long, and it takes a lot of time to get in as the place is very tiny. You have to go knowing that you are willing to wait for a while, even if it is 11.00am. The best time to go is probably 4.00pm, which is not the best time for lunch.
author: Lucia C.

description: Was visiting the bay couple weeks ago decided to stop by because of all the goods things I heard. Ordered a dozen oysters the clam chowder sashimi and the half crab. All amazing. Only complaint wish they would have a sign that said cash only and the line obviously is horrible but I would say worth it if your in the area
author: Ali A.

description: This place is small and has a long wait so we went on a Tuesday at 3:45 and waited less than 15 minutes. We had the clam chowder with bread. Very good but I prefer mine thicker. We had the crab salad which was awesome. So much fresh crab! Then we shared 1.5 dozen of the mixed oysters. All were small, plump and from the west coast. The staff is very friendly and attentive. I am definitely going back so I can try some of the other menu items like the smoked trout and Italian scallops.
author: Erinn D.

description:
This place is the real deal. Even though we got extremely lucky and were able to walk right up and wait minutes for a seat, looking back I would have waiting 1+ hours.

The chowder was excellent. But the oysters and clams are out of this world.

We went for the mixed dozen plus half a dozen of the cherry stones. Brian, our awesome waiter, threw in 6 little necks for good measure.

Phenomenal. Some interesting sauces to try as well.

Everything else looked great as well, wish we had time (and room) to try it all.
author: Ryan H.

description:
Oh Swan, what else can I add?
Yes, you'll wait a long time at lunch. Last time I was there, we got in line at 12:30, and sat down at 2:30. But once you're "close enough" to the door, you can get yourself a beer from the bar. That certainly helps the wait.

The only thing I've had that I didn't love was the chowder. It was grainy, like the sauce had broken.

So now that the disappointing is out of the way --- crab salad, raw platter of their fresh catches of the day (scallops were my fave!), raw clams (i'd never had them before, but they are delish!) --- this is one of the meals I dream of. If I lived in the bay area, I'd be there as much as I could stand waiting for.
author: Allison L.

description:
Crab Season in San Francisco is an awesome event, especially if there's not a strike or big storm.  And we are so lucky to live in area where we have big, beautiful, and yummy crabs!

I work in Russian Hill and every year our school has holiday party the them is always  Crab Feast and it rocks.  But every year, I am biting my nails because of either the fishermen are on strike or a mother nature storm that is so huge it keeps the boats in harbor.  So I never know until the last minute will I have crab?

This year it was a strike that almost turned our Crab Feast into a Shrimp Feast-- not quite as festive. 

However,  someone suggested that I try Swan Oyster Depot on Polk--And I am so glad I did.  Though, they could not guarantee fresh crab,-- because of the strike,  they would do what they could to get me 50 crabs!  These folks at Swan ROCK!  They took care of the order and when the strike ended I ended up with FRESH CRAB.  Everyone at the party noticed that the crab was of better quality this year.  

Oh yeah Swan also hooked us up with sourdough bread and dipping sauces.  Those were brilliant. 

Thank you, Thank You Kevin for all your help.  I am Swan devotee from here on.  

If you handle the line, Swan is the place to go for sea food.

XXXOOO
author: Princess P.

description:
Love this place. 

Small joint. 

You're gonna wait for a seat. 

Clam chowder was fabulous. 

Great staff.
author: Josh H.

description:
What an amazing little place!

We waited in line for over an hour and a half but the wait was made easier by the beer. The place is just one long cold marble bar that seats maybe 14-16 people. 

Once it was our turn to sit down I felt like we were treated like family. Service was so personal and accommodating. Between five of us we had a bottle of wine, 15 oysters, two bowls of clam chowder, smoked salmon slices on sourdough, 2 scallop carpaccios, smoked salmon mousse and 2 cracked crab salads. Plus the beers we drank in line I think we plopped down around $200 for lunch but it was so glorious. I was high the rest of the day from the Omega-3s. That scallop carpaccio was pure nirvana. The oysters were cold and briny and perfect. 

Not the kind of place you'd go all the time but as a once in a while treat, especially if you're just a tourist in the area, I'd absolutely recommend it.
author: Jenn O.

description:
***READ THIS REVIEW if you want a down to earth opinion on this place.


All right, guys.

I'm ripping this place a new one. 

I do not doubt that the seafood is fresh--I honestly didn't have anything from here except a bowl of the clam chowder and the side of bread.

The bread was better than the chowder, to be cont'd...

My boyfriend and I were looking up seafood places since we were planning on spending the day in SF. Obviously, this place got STELLAR reviews, so we were SUPER excited to come. Even waited outside in line for about 45 minutes as people very, very slowly ate their food (it's a bar setup, so there's very, very limited seating for the amount of traffic they actually get).

As we got closer to getting inside the place though, we started to feel less and less comfortable.

1) One of the reviewers on here took photos of the menu. Let's just say the prices have gone up since then. The 'seafood salad' (a small plate of lettuce topped with a meager scoop of seafood) now averages around 20 bucks. 20. Really?! Even if it tastes like heaven, that is pretty damn steep for some shrimpies that aren't even properly cleaned! (Keep reading.) A couple sitting nearest the entrance got their bill: "That'll be $130, please!"

2) So this place is cash only, right? How would you feel if your food were scooped by the bare hands of the same people handling all of that cash from customers' transactions? Ya know, think E. Coli and other fun germs on currency? All that seafood displayed in the window? Not a single tong or utensil--these guys use their hands, wipe 'em down on their aprons afterward, and then top your salad. With the occasional grabbing of a pearing knife to clean out a prawn further for your seafood cocktail because its line of poopies / guts are still in there.


So we were like okay, screw that, let's just get some clam chowder and bread and go food hunting elsewhere. 

Clam chowder was runny as hell. All that fresh flavor you other reviewers raving about? Dude, they've got bottles of clam juice lined up right behind the soup canteen right there. Come on!!! It's not from the clams themselves. There were barely any clams in the soup, the potato chunks were tiny and uh... gosh, I prefer Chunky at this rate. 

Bread was wonderful. Big heal of one for just a buck. ;)


Moral of the story: STOP PERPETUATING THE MYTH and falling for the typical big city trap of "I'm a tourist, therefore ill-informed" or "I've made it in life, see me eat in this joint like it's nothing at all." Impress people elsewhere if you wanna throw cash down. Again, I'm sure the seafood is great, but there is no way that it can be justified by the horrendous prices given the hygiene of the place. San Francisco is full of hidden gems for seafood--this is not one of them.
author: Eda C.

description:
This joint is a bay area no duh.

the mixed seafood salad was an amazing lunch.  

and the oysters are fresh and delish.  

prepare to wait in a long but worthwhile line.
author: Jim P.

description:
OMG!!! This is defienelty the place to go. I was visiting San Francisco and read up that Swan Oyster Depot had very fresh seafood and was a must have. I suggest if you are visiting its a must to stop by and if your a local and haven't tried it....go there. Be warned however the only bad thing which is why it got a  4 was that the wait is very long, always a line we waited an hour. The seating is a bit uncomfortable but again the food makes it worth while. So let me get to the goods

The food.....absoulutely delicious I have never had fresher seafood, I went with my boyfriend and we had;

1. Oysters- they gave us the variety and they were all delicious
2. Seafood Combination Salad- all I can say is OMG! So Fresh! 
3. Smoked Salmon this is a must get it was sooo good it melted in my mouth like butter, so good in fact I took a 1/2 pound to-go

Those are a must get, the clam chowder is okay, its a little too brothy for my taste and my boyfriend said the shrimp cocktail was good but I didn't have it.

Another thing too the servers are great, very friendly and make you feel like your kicking back hanging out with friends while eating some good food and a nice cold beer. 

Also helpful hint, THEY ONLY TAKE CASH!
author: Natalie M.

description:
Fresh quality seafood, and good service.  There's a line out the door almost always, but if your looking for fresh seafood at a reasonable price, check it out!

If you go near open or close it's usually no wait or at the very least a short wait.  The line during lunch time hours is just brutal though.
author: Eric C.

description:
Mediocre food combined w abysmal service and a 60 minute line (min). You can get the oysters served here at any other decent restaurant in town. Apart from oysters and clams, the only dish w creative input is the combo seafood salad which comprises of bay shrimp, crab, large shrimp and lettuce (all avail at Whole Foods) dressed w red wine vinegar, olive oil, mustard, salt and pepper. The clam chowder is not even worth the calories. The sourdough is probably from Boudin. That is the extent of the menu... there is no cooked food.

This place would be tolerable if there was no line and all the staff retired to make way for ppl who actually want to work rather than do customers favors by serving them.
Anything short of that and it's simply nothing more than a tourist trap.
author: Sebastian C.

description:
Undoubtedly one of the smallest establishments in Nob Hill, Swan Oyster Depot is larger than life and arguably, the best seafood restaurant in San Francisco. For locals, this is an institution that epitomizes the best of San Francisco. For tourists, it's a required visit as part of one's itinerary. 



"THE UGLY DUCKLING"

Originally called Cable Oyster Depot, Swan was founded by the Lausten brothers, Danish immigrants whose business came to a halt following the 1906 earthquake that crippled San Francisco. Despite enduring personal devastation, they rode a horse drawn wagon to Golden Gate Park replete with provisions and a sign that read, "Free flour and water from Swan Oyster Depot. Remember us." The Lausten's rebuilt the store across the street and re-opened it as Swan Oyster Depot in 1912. The name and icon of a swan is a symbol of good fortune and transformation in Denmark. No story better illustrates this than Danish author Hans Christian Anderson's "The Ugly Duckling." In 1946, the Lausten brothers sold their business to Sal Sancimino and today, his family continues the tradition of serving the best seafood.  Although Swan Oyster Depot has seen transformation, both within and outside of its walls, the good fortune has never run dry.



"HEY GUYS, WHAT ARE YOU GETTING?" - My order included.

SMOKED SALMON PLATE- thin slices of smoked salmon with fresh cracked black pepper, finely chopped red onion, and capers on 1/4 inch thick rye. The salmon pops with smoky flavor, hitting your nose before you take a bite in a very good way. Utterly amazing and nothing quite like it: 5/5.
COMBINATION SALAD- shrimp, succulent prawns, crab on a bed of thin sliced Iceberg lettuce. Add a couple teaspoons of their in-house Louie dressing and you have a fantastic dish: 4/5.
BOSTON-STYLE CLAM CHOWDER- slightly creamy with small bits of crab and potato. A cup is sufficient if one is looking to enjoy several menu items: 4/5.



"GLAD TO SEE YOU AGAIN!" -The charm of the Sancimino family.

The Sancimino family's passion for top notch seafood is rivaled only by their captivating charm, traits accentuated by the intimacy of the establishment itself. Brandon, our server, moved about and joshed with the proprietors and patrons alike. Unconventional is the norm here: everything but the clam chowder is handled by a bare hand and dine-in orders are never written down. Getting in and out of the premises is a tight squeeze. The chatter and archaic wall phone ringing periodically requires one to raise their voice a little. However, once you sit down and grab your first order and pint, the noise transforms into a melodic soundtrack and nothing but the present company and food matter. 


"HOW LONG YOU BEEN WAITING?" -Lessons learned from my visit.

-Finding parking in Nob Hill is challenging. Take the MUNI, grab a cab, or walk. Keep in mind that it's an uphill climb if walking from Chinatown or Union Square.

-To avoid a long wait, come before noon. In my most recent visit, arriving at 2 pm on a Saturday, we waited 2.5 hours.

-Do not come with a party of 5 or more. The place only seats 18 people. 

-Take-out/pick up orders have a separate line, left side of the entrance when facing the store. If there is no line, that means you're first in line. For orders called in advance, remember whom you spoke to because they may have placed your order in the fridge pending your arrival. You don't want to have them making double orders, do you?

-Their homemade Louie sauce goes well with the seafood salads. The red cocktail sauce is best with oysters. Tabasco hot sauce is also available.

-As the day progresses, the store will slowly run out of seafood. Do not come too late in the day.

-Anchor Steam and Stella Artois are on tap. White wine is also served.
author: Tom R.

description: What an awesome experience!!  The one hour wait was completely worth it!  We were greeted with a cold Stella Artois before seating. The Crudo was to die for. The oysters and champagne were out of this world and the combination salad was very generous.  THANK YOU!!!
author: Bonnie C.

description: I had the Clam Chowder and Combination Cocktail. It was all just ok, customer service was on point but this experience wasn't worth lining up 30 minutes for. Coming from NZ I think I've been spoilt with seafood so I didn't really appreciate what the fuss was all about.
author: Sarah C.

description: I can't say enough good things about this place! Hands down the BEST oysters I have ever had! Their accompaniments were to die for and prices were reasonable. They are CASH ONLY, so ensure you have enough before you go. Can't wait to be back in San Fran to visit again and bring friends!
author: Alicia C.

description: Super long line up but well worth it.  I will lineup again next time for their super fresh oysters.  Staff are friendly and happy.  Highly recommended.
author: Hoi Y.

description: The uni on a half shell is killer. Not my favorite clam chowder but hey.
author: Ilona O.

description: This place is a classic! I turned my husband on to raw oysters here a few years back. It's a small, family owned, and unique experience. Be prepared to wait on the street for one of only a few bar seats. The raw oysters are amazing with their mignette. The fresh crab and on the spot shrimp salad are great choices too. Cash only!
author: Cassie S.

description:
Wonderful place for shellfish lovers who don't need much done to their food.  Most of the stuff just gets shucked/cracked/sliced and served right up.  All is done in front of the small counter which seats like 10 people.  

I prefer the seafood cocktails over the seafood salads.  I don't know how much of the total price those lettuce account for, but I found that I wasn't interested in even a bite of it.  Also, not exactly a fan of the tiny bland shrimps that come in the combination salad/cocktails.  That's all the bad things I could say though.  The oysters, crabs, prawns, fresh scallops, and clam chowder are all delicious.  The best I have to say are the fresh shucked clams--super juicy, super plump--and the crab backs, which are rich and savory and one of my absolute favorite things to eat.  I put down three of those on my last visit and felt like I could die a happy man.

Wait sucks.  I only want to go on like weekday afternoon now after a torturous 90 minutes wait on Saturday.  Line's not long but it just doesn't really move.  

I am forever wondering why there aren't more places like this.
author: Kozmo C.

description:
We came on a Saturday at 10:20am, supposedly before the opening time but had to wait for "2nd seating" due to others lining up earlier.  The place is small --- truly counter style.  I think there are about 14 seats available.  
We had the dozen mixed oysters on half shell, Sicilian sashimi (tuna, salmon, halibut, yellowtail, and scallop), and the clam chowder.  Oysters were very fresh, and tasted great with the various condiment sauces the store made.  The sashimi was good.  The fish was fresh, but it was similar (but not better) than Japanese style sashimi, just with olive oil, capers and chopped onions.  The clam chowder was a pass for us... It was fishy and wasn't as creamy --- definitely more homemade, but not as tasty as other clam chowders we've had.
I think the biggest gripe I had was the value for the food.  For the three things we ordered, totaled about $65 before tip.  The place is cash only.  I think you can get better oyster deals elsewhere in SF for cheaper.  
Overall, enjoyed most of the food but thought it was a bit pricey for what we got.
author: Carissa T.

description:
We went there after we checked out from Westin. Early enough we could sit. Only bar sits available, I think.  It's like one service person per one customer! Not much of sits. Our service person was real nice. I even have a photo of him! We had chowder which was the best. Ilsa had tiny shrimp in cocktail glass. She didn't want to share with us! It was that good. No other typical smells we used to when we had tiny cooked shrimps. 
When we ordered oysters and clams, our guy went to far end of the place and worked for our order! Those were great. We had mixed oysters including kumamoto and miyagi.. Crab was also delish.
We ordered salmon with caper, onion on rye to go. 
I definitely would like to go there again. 
The morning atmosphere of the Swan was great.
author: Jean Y.

description: Just go. Don't second guess, don't overthink. Just go, and discover the real taste of fish.
author: Kristyn W.

description: Came on a Wednesday afternoon thinking I'd avoid the long line to finally try this place. The wait still took 45 minutes. Once seated I ordered the crab salad, to which I was notified that they didn't offer it because it wasn't in season. My response was, "you should post that on your menu that is visible outside" to which the server's reply was, "we don't do that," of course they don't, it is a tourist trap. The oysters I ordered were quality, but this place isn't worth the buzz. Good oysters can be found several places at much lower prices. I wouldn't recommend anyone wasting their time with this over-priced trap.
author: Anthony S.

description:
Herb Caen might be spinning in his grave to know that it's taken 29 years for this San Franciscan to finally make it to Swan Oyster Depot (SOD). 

And now that I've finally tried this SF institution, I find myself wondering, "Swan Oyster Depot, where have you been all my life?!".... just a measly 7 miles away...(smacks self in head)

I knew the meal was going to be perfection when Lael A. and I caught the last 2 spots at the bar without a wait.

WOW. JUST WOW. HOLY EFF. WOW. OMG. MMMMM. ---- some combination of those words were spoken in between every bite of food. 

I started off with a cup of clam chowder ($2.75). It did not have the thick, creamy consistency I'm used to with other clam chowders and the proportion of clam meat-to-broth was a bit sparse for my taste, but the broth was really, really good. Intensely infused with briny, seafood goodness and laced with butter, SOD's clam chowder was the perfect start to the meal. 

Next, we tried a dozen mixed oysters ($26). I was excited that SOD had some of my favorites available: Miyagi, Kumamoto, and Blue Point. The Kumamato is a GIANT among oyster-lovers, which is ironic because it is quite small. SOD's Kumamotos were perfection: petite and bursting with sweetness. The Miyagis had a bit more meat on them and were crisp with only a mild brininess. The Blue Points were fresh, crisp, and firm, with a sweet aftertaste that was 2nd to the Kumamotos. With a dab of home made horseradish, cocktail sauce, and a squeeze of lemon, the oysters were OUTSTANDING. 

Then, we had the Combination salad ($20), which was basically a large plateful of shredded lettuce topped with a generous portion of bay shrimps, 4-5 large prawns, and 6-8 sweet crab morsels. Definitely a filling entree to split between 2 people. A delicious side of home made thousand island dressing accompanied the salad. A bit of sweet seafood + crisp lettuce + sharp horseradish + sweet thousand island dressing all atop a piece of bread = scrumptious makeshift open faced sandwich. 

The ambiance of SOD only adds to the experience: sitting at the counter, watching all the servers bustle by, friendly banter with the servers, faded pictures on the wall, and a wait for it... a gold crucifix shining bright in the middle of the wall. Nothing says "old school SF" like fresh seafood + Jesus. 

A ~$60 lunch for 2 people, but WELL WORTH IT. 

There's seafood. There's seafood in San Francisco. And then there's Swan Oyster Depot. Try it for yourself if you can stand the wait. (Damn you, Anthony Bourdain!)

Note: If you're jonesing for the SF seafood experience, but can't make SOD's line or hours, make a reservation at Hyde Street Seafood House. Their oysters, seafood salad, and lobster bisque are on par with SOD, but in a more formal, traditional atmosphere.
author: Monelle A.

description:
Believe the hype...this spot is the real deal. You will most likely have to wait in line, but it is worth it. I will simply add what I typically order because I can't find it anywhere else:

Cup of clam chowder
Crab cocktail
Italian sashimi
Dozen mixed oysters
Dozen mixed clams
Smoked salmon
Anchor Steam (consistently throughout)
...get the urchin or sardines if they are available...thank me later

Be sure to say "waddap" to Guy or Darren if they are working!

D
author: Drew C.

description:
Love the atmosphere.  The walls are covered in old photographs and coastal decor.  The small and narrow space only provides enough room for counter seating.   You're pretty much elbow to elbow with others at the counter, so you'll probably make some friendly conversation with fellow patrons.  Due to the small space, there is always a line.  It's worth it when you're craving some fresh seafood though!

Aside from the fresh seafood, be sure to try the clam chowder.  It's one of my two favorites in the city.  I always get the cup size and regret it. GET THE BOWL!
author: Dina H.

description:
A must try on a visit to San Francisco. A bit touristy, and there's only enough seating for 1-2 people if your're going there. 

But the crab and oysters are fantastic!
author: Winny F.

description:
I knew one thing when I arrived to San Fran for a whirlwind visit, and that was good food would fill my days and craving tummy.

Fortunately, Yelp delivered to me Swan Oyster Depot. Sure, we had to wait but on a week day early afternoon we were only 30-45 minutes from the bar. My boyfriend was amused by my salivation and lip smacking as I gawked at seafood salads, cocktails and the like prepared for other lucky patrons inside.

Once we saddled up to the bar, I had no idea what to order and asked our super helpful server Darren what to do when you want it all?

His sage advice? Take it slow, how about you start with some oysters.

Which was our plan exactly. We started with six oysters (kumamoto, miyagi, blue points) and clams. So fresh, I wanted more. But no - there were other crustaceans to be had. 

From there it was on to a mammoth prawn cocktail. Good lord these prawns are behemoths. 

Do yourself a favor and dive in to the sauces provided counter-side. The house made horseradish packs a wallop that keeps you coming back, onion vinegar is great but the real gem was in a tiny dish swimming with amazing spiciness and favor - a habanero, other pepper, garlic, cilantro and vinegar number.

The half cracked Dungeness Crab rocked it. Sweet, succulent, buttery goodness within every shell. Only surprise was the cool temperature the crab was served. Good, but I thought it'd be warm. In fact, nothing is served warm wave the clam chowder. I was *thisclose* to ordering a second when I again took Darren's advice and slowed down to take it all in. All of these tidbits of heaven fill you up, even if you don't think so at first check. 

I wavered between a sashimi plate of super fresh catch, but we were having sushi later that night so I decided this would be overkill. We settled on a bowl of the clam chowder. As most have mentioned, the soup is a thinner consistency that I'm used to but it was perfect. The milky flavorful broth found all of the crevasses needed filling in my tummy. Remember that habanero/pepper/cilantro sauce I mentioned before? Toss some of that in to your chowder. It'll change the entire flavor profile.

I should also mention the crab head. Also served cold which is a bit, well different, but just as good. Sopping up the fat and eggs with the crusty sourdough is all of it. 

At the end of what must have been an hour, I had to kindly ask that they remove what remained of the wreckage else I wouldn't have been able to rise from my stool.

But I'll be back...

Amazing service, great personalities and fantastic food. The quintessential recipe for success.
author: Amanda E.

description: Been in the Bay Area for 6 days and this is the best food I've eaten so far.  I did take out and they had it ready when I got there and it's a good thing I did because there was a long line of people waiting to get in.  I initially wanted chowder and asked for other recommendations, the staff person suggested crab salad.  It was AMAZING!!
author: Jodie C.

description:
I won't give this hole 1 star, but damn...I am pretty near close.  Service was friendly and overly excited, but the place needs to be cleaned from top to bottom, including the training of hand washing for all the employees.  Beware of the walk to the bathroom too.

After waiting 2 hours in the rain, we sat down and had chowder...that was it.  I had been watching all the guys behind the counter shake hands with randoms, handle cash (cash only BTW), clean up dirty dishes, use the cleaning rags, and then dig those same hands into the fresh crab, shrimp, lettuce, and even the oyster crackers.  YUCK!!!!  I didn't want to leave after waiting so long, but we lost our appetite before we even sat down.  Chowder was okay but the bf isn't feeling good now.  We ended up going to Miller's Deli after wards and chowed down on some pastrami sandwiches in a cleaner and warmer environment.  

It's not the worth the wait or hype.
author: Ayrn H.

description:
Had the best experience here (except for the time it took to get a seat)
Every piece of seafood was exceptionally fresh. The Crab cocktail was terrific, the flavor was amazing. i ordered a dozen oysters and to my surprise you actually get 6 different types of oysters all very good. 
dip your crab in Louie's sauce
author: Carlos M.

description: A tiny, uncomfortable hole in the wall with stool seating and tourist trap prices. Not a place for relaxed dining. The poorly lighted place also needs a good cleaning. Parking in the grimy, congested area is impossible.
author: Pam J.

description:
Awesome little place on Polk Street that feels a bit like a slice of East Coast.  We went when they opened at 10:30, but the line got kind of intense after, and since it's a small place with just one row of seats at the bar, the line probably moves pretty slowly.

Love the combination seafood salad, although next time I'll probably get just the crab, because that was to die for. The shrimp was also very tasty, but I thought the prawns were just okay. The chowder was also perfect for a cold day. It's not as ridiculously creamy as the clam chowder you think of when you think New England, but I kind of like that better.

I will definitely come back for some oysters in the near, near future!
author: jon y.

description:
Straight up fresh and tasty, and I was a fan of these dudes, they were nice.  I knew it got crazy busy and theres limited seating so I went right when they opened with my friend who lives in SF.
I was going to go alone since my friend is vegan, but she said she'd still come since all I wanted to do in SF was come here and visit the Zodiac murder spot in Presidio.
