The types of oysters they carry rotate, but I imagine that all the oysters they have are awesome quality.

The oysters also come with an optional mignonette sauce.  I recommend putting very little, or none at all.  It's a little invasively strong in the vinegar department.  Some people also like to put some lemon on their oysters.  I, personally, like eating these oysters clean and unadulterated.

I also got the Seafood Salad and Boston Clam Chowder.  Both the salad and the chowder were a little too watered down for my tastes.  The seafood that sat on the flavorless bed of lettuce was darn good though.  The chowder also has little clam gems, but overall, the chowder is a bit flavorless and uneventful.

All in all, this place has awesome seafood, and I can imagine becoming a regular if I lived in the area.  When I can, I'll be sure to swim my way over to the beautifully delicious swan song that emanates from Swan Oyster Depot's oysters.

GET:  Oyster Sampler
author: Michael K.

description:
Would I wait an hour to eat here? Sure, if I had been stuck in the desert for a while and wanted to slowly torture myself  by watching other people eat fresh seafood while waiting an hour in line.

Don't get me wrong, the seafood here is darn good.  I highly recommend phoning in your order and taking your food to go. If you want to full on experience, this place is pretty low key and has a nice diner feel.

Crab- Nom!
Oysters- Amazing!
Clam Chowder- good clam broth. It's simple so don't expect tons of veggies and ingredients
Shrimp- Nothing to write home about.
author: Nadiyah S.

description:
To be fair, I grew up around a beach and cheap, fresh seafood, so maybe I'm biased, but I just don't get this place.

There are other places in the city you can get expensive, fresh oysters (some of which even have happy hours) which don't require an hour wait in line. The oysters were good, as you'd expect, but considering the price and line I can't give this place more than three stars. I'd really give it two, but the decor is sweet and the people working there are fun. 

Also, I seriously don't understand the raving about the clam chowder. It's pretty standard, if a bit on the watery side.
author: Bill H.

description: Hole in the wall spot with super fresh oysters and seafood. Went to the oyster depot about 11am before the lunch rush and the place was full. I ordered couple dozen oysters and the smoked salmon. The oysters were so fresh, clean and smooth. The smoked salmon melted in your mouth, with a little bit of capers and chopped onion. The staff was super friendly. Worth the wait, and CASH ONLY.
author: Ron G.

description: Swan Oyster Depot has been the BEST spot for Crab/Shrimp salad in all of San Francisco.  There is seafood for every bite of salad greens to the last morsel.  Well worth the price.  The secret to success is to go early and get it to-go!
author: Elizabeth G.

description:
We came at the least advantageous time in the week. Saturday afternoon at 12:30. It took the two of us just over two hours to be seated. Painful, but I guess that's how it is at Swan.

After we were seated we were essentially ignored for about 15 minutes while sitting in front of the previous party's dirty dishes. In a restaurant with only ~20 seats that just seems silly and unprofessional. No one was being unfriendly or discourteous, they just weren't paying attention. If you're attractive and a girl (I'm neither) you will get served quickly and receive free drinks! Yay!

Crab salad, smoked salmon, smoked trout, clam chowder, bread, and oysters were all absolute top notch. Some of the best cold seafood I've had throughout the world. I can still give this place a solid four starts despite the inconvenience and somewhat poor service because the food is just so damn good.

I would go back for sure, but maybe get in earlier so I don't have to deal with
author: Fletcher R.

description:
This is a MUST TRY place if you love seafood, esp oysters. And they have the BEST clam chowder here. I think they use crab broth to make it, but I've never had anything like it before. My sis and I shared a dozen oysters on the halfshell, a clam chowder with an order of their bread&butter, and the crab cocktail. Everything was so good so fresh. I'll come every time I'm back in SF.

Also: street metered parking only
author: Aileen M.

description: The freshest Uni, crab back, clam chowder, sourdough, oysters on the half shell and chili lime sauce..having it all thrown at you at once and getting it for under $60 ..yeah ...five damn stars
author: Jerry G.

description:
Today the stars aligned and a serious traffic accident had Polk street closed for a few blocks around Swans.  I parked, arrived with no line and a seat available. I enjoyed a mixed dozen oysters, smoked salmon and a crab cocktail and an Anchor Steam to wash it down.
Swans is Old San Francisco. They do it that way cause that's the way they have always done it.  It's crowded, uncomfortable and parking is sketchy. It's worth whatever it takes to go there.
author: Richard L. D.

description:
While there is a line out the door at lunch creating a 30 minute wait, a friend visiting from out of town wanted to try this place - so I did.  

Before I sat down, I was a bit skeptical -- the counter seating is limited, and overall cleanliness of the place a bit in question.

However, my experience turned out to be very positive.  The chowder is perhaps the best I have ever had.  All the seafood is very fresh and very tasty.  

Prices are not low, but the seafood is rich and goes a long way.  

Also, excellent sauces, including real powerful horseradish - recommended.
author: Bruce M.

description: Awful service wife found a hair in her entree! Never again. Tip: Wear hair nets or hire ppl with little to no hair .
author: Zafir M.

description:
We were wandering around Polk and saw a line. So, what are tourists going to do? Jump in line! Glad we did. They had amazing crab. SO FRESH! and I loved their clam chowder. It had the perfect clam juice/cream consistency. Not too thick. Not too thin. Juuuust right. 

I may have to move to SF because I love all the food.
author: Kat R.

description:
I was hoping that this place would be all that it was hyped up to be. Everytime I drove past it, there would be a very long line outside. The look of the place intrigued me. It's basically a long narrow room with a bar and 12-15 stools and the food they served was sitting on ice near the front window. The atmosphere of this place made me feel like I was at the fish counter at a supermarket. 

We waited in line for 35 minutes. When we made it inside, we sat down at the next available stool. It was cramped and I was rubbing elbows with a strange man sitting to my right. So I thought...maybe the food is that good that the atmosphere wouldn't matter. I was disappointed. 

We had a bowl of Boston Clam Chowder and a dozen oysters. 4 different kinds: Blue Point, Miyagi, Kumamoto, Olympia. Btw...Kumamoto oysters are the best. They're really small, but they pack lots of flavor. The clam chowder was really fresh. The oysters were good, but I feel that I can get them anywhere else without having to wait in a line outside and without having to sit in a cramped, cold room.  In the end, The bill came out to $29. Their seafood cocktails come out in small cup and were $13-$19 each, so I didn't feel like it was worth the price. 

This place is good for freshness. You can watch the guys crack crabs and shuck oysters in front of you, but that's the only factor that I find worth the visit. Once is enough, I don't think I'll be coming back.
author: Lynn V.

description:
As I write this I'm still giddy from the euphoria of having just eaten at Swan's. Mind you, this came along with a 1.5-hour wait (relatively quick, I was told) --Swan's is a narrow alley of 20 seats by the counter, though you can just skip the line and do take-out. But then you'll be missing half the fun: the interesting patrons, the frequent cheers of "Go Giants" from staff to customers and vice versa, the live shucking and deshelling of all the fresh, fresh seafood. 

I came by myself but never felt alone. Throughout my wait I had the companionship of a lovely, chatty couple from New Jersey, and during my lunch I spoke to Fred, who's a regular of the restaurant (he even let me try a bit of his crab cocktail which spurred me to order my own). I even saw the staffers bantering with the other customers, so I doubt you'll ever feel lonely there.

Now onto the food, which is mindblowingly good. I actually came for the clam chowder, which while decent, pales in comparison to its raw bar. In a way, I'm glad I came alone, so no one could judge this 5"1 girl for eating half her body weight in seafood. I started off with a bowl of clam chowder for $5(skippable), and an octopus calamari cocktail ($9 - not bad). But then I ordered the half-dozen mixed oysters ($14) and my oh my. It was like I was transported to heaven: the Blue Points were GREAT, as was another East Coast oyster... The salty, briny taste of the Washington ones wasn't my favorite but even then, I loved the texture. I was so tempted to order more oysters until Fred let me try some of his crab cocktail... And then I was sold. 

The cocktails are small (I think it's just enough for one person) but you'll have the most value for money getting the crab cocktail ($14.95). It comes with a dipping sauce (I added Tobasco and lemon to mine to make it more zesty) but the crab meat is succulent and juicy on its own, not in the least bit dry. The flesh is thick and generous and by the time I was done, I was STUFFED.

Of course the boyfriend couldn't miss out on this solo adventure completely, so I bought him a combination cocktail ($12) which comes with some crab, oysters, octopus, a bit of everything really... The staff who helped me was super knowledgeable and friendly which makes this place accessible for seafood newbies and aficionados alike. Well worth the wait! :)
author: Rachel A.

description:
Best clam chowder in San Francisco. Hot, delicious and clammy (in a good way). 

AND they have cherrystone clams aka quahogs on the half-shell. That is some New England-y goodness right there if you are pining for Narragansett Bay and environs. 

Went today at 1:30pm and there was no waiting, so don't be scared away by the fear of lines.
author: Gwynnie P.

description:
Seafood Heaven!!!!!

WORTH THE WAIT- Since it's 12 person bar counter seating only, you'll normally find a line outside the door.
FRESH- when you're waiting in line, you get to drool over all the fresh seafood the strategically place at the window front. 
FOOD- MUST and i do say MUST get the Combination Seafood Salad.  It's comprised of a bed of lettuce topped with large chunks of crab meat, heavy amounts of shrimp, and gigantic prawns with the Louie dressing on the side.

Clam Chowder was subpar.
Oysters- the batch we got was average.  But the vinegar concoction they had to accompany it was supurb!

Warning:
The sink & prep stations are all open for all to see. The server had broken a glass as he was cleaning our area.  He then decided to pick up the glass chards with his bare hands.  Watching him like a hawk,  I couldn't believe what happened next...or i should say what DIDN'T happen next...He went over to cut us some sourdough bread and brings it over to us WITHOUT WASHING HIS HANDS!!!!  I don't know about you all, but the only thing I want in my bread is butter, not pieces of glass.  Needless to say, we asked another server for bread and explained what we had just witnessed, once our server was confronted, he got defensive and said "of course, I washed my hands"...LIES!!
author: Elaine L.

description:
Ate here for the first time on Sat June 9th, 2012.  Went at 11am, waited in line for 40 minutes.  This was the freshest seafood meal I've ever eaten.  A unique, old-school family owned and operated business that has kept the same winning formula for generations.  Only 15 or so seats in the place, so you wait.  You overlook the wait and the neighborhood after you have the first spoon of the chowder.

Just trust the guys behind the counter.  A must if you have time -- great meal.
author: Andrew M.

description: The seafood is worth the 3 hour wait.  But not the price.  How on earth did I spend almost $100 on a lunch (for only myself) sitting at a counter? Cash only!
author: R K.

description: Quite possibly one of the greatest Oyster houses in San Francisco. Great prices and a historic gritty atmosphere turns a meal into a complete dining experience..
author: Joe p.

description: It's touristy restaurant, for sure, but it's also really good. I had the combination cocktail, which is admittedly small but had all the best tasting pieces of seafood. I also had a half dozen oysters which were amazing. Anyone with  a bigger appetite may need more food but I left satisfied. I'm still smiling thinking of my meal.
author: Amber T.

description: I don't know what all the fuss was about concerning this place.   Long wait outside in anticipation of a great lunch.  Not worth the wait or price.  The combination salad is nothing more than two handfuls if chopped lettuce with previously frozen shrimp and crab meat on top for 21 buck.  I mean "come on man"  Dennys does a better job.  Takes forever to get service and waiters leave for long periods.   I had to stand up and call across the room just to pay my bill.
author: Glenn S.

description:
A shop owner near hear recommend going there.The
first guy was OK, the second old one forgott what I had ordered, and the third guy took me  sixty bucks for about forty bucks without giving any change nor saying"thank you". Is that the way to do every time here?
author: kibou t.

description:
Outstanding seafood! Expect a a long line... don't get impatient, because it's absolutely worth the wait. 

Get a glass of Sauvion Blanc, a cup of clam chowder, a whole lotta oysters, and the the whole crab (they crack it for you). 

Family run, friendly and delicious!
author: Julie O.

description: Waited an hour to get in. It was well worth the wait! For anyone with gluten free needs bring your own cocktail sauce. Otherwise they even supplied us with gf bread! Very warm and accommodating servers! We had the oysters, clams, squid salad and smoked salmon. Everything was incredible and fresh.  Would def wait to go again!
author: Christina H.

description:
Ahhh-mazing!!! My husband and I stopped here on a Monday afternoon, based on all the reviews we'd heard and read about this place, we had to check it out for ourselves. And yes, be prepared to wait! We waited about one hour and forty-five minutes, but since we were visiting from Chicago we were in no rush and it was well worth the wait! We tried a little bit of everything, including oysters, the combination salad which included shrimp and -they didn't have crab that day so they substituted a little trout and salmon instead, salmon on rye, and the combination cocktail. Everything was delish! We found the Chowder to be the only thing we didn't particular like, I've had better on the east coast, but it was the only thing that was just mediocre.

Such a cool place, the guys working were great and very friendly. A definite must visit when you have time for awesome seafood!!
author: Caroline F.

description:
What do I remember....
long lines, 
uncomfortable seats
very LIMITED seating 
great service
freshest oysters everrr (i personally this it is one of the best i've had)
not-so-awesome boston clam chowder (where are the clams and why is it so oily??)
great sourdough bread 
super tasty half cracked crab

and $60 more broke.....
author: Jang David K.

description:
OK, since Bourdain was here on "The Layover", Swan has been even busier than before. 

Tip: They don't open until 10:00 now, because they couldn't get their prep work completed due to the suggestions to "get here when they open" (it used to be 8:30). 

So, yeah - they open at 10:00 now. 

8:30's a little early for raw seafood anyways..

We arrived at 11:00 on a Wednesday and were the only people waiting (only 5 minutes or so). The staff is extremely friendly, they treated us like family. The regulars are friendly also, you can see how the staff takes care of their customers both old & new.

Don't be afraid to order the crab back. Dip your bread in it, or mix it will some olive oil, pepper and dijon mustard and use it to dress your seafood salad.

Outstanding on every level!

I can't say anything else that hasn't been said before..Just, go!!
author: H P.

description:
It seems like every time I give a homeless guy change, it comes back to haunt me.  One time the guy followed me for two blocks asking for more and progressing to cursing (had my daughter with me).  Another time the guy said "Thanks, write me a check turtleneck."  Now whenever I wear a turtleneck my friends bring this up.

Today I was craving a Diet Coke so I swung though McD's drive through.  They always have someone standing there asking for change as you pull out, so today I was a sucker.

Then as I enjoyed my DC in the beautiful weather by the bay, I was chatting with Jen K and she brought up Swan's for lunch.  Great idea.  As I got close there was a great parking spot on Polk about a block from Swan's.  Unfortunately I only had $1.10 - enough for 50 minutes.  And the local vendors wouldn't make change.  I'd have to hurry.

Goodness, the line was short and the triple in front of me let me go when a single seat opened up. So I got in quickly.

As it always is at Swan's, my lunch was good (cup of chowder, bread, half dozen oysters, and a Stella). I wish I was hungrier, the Crab salad there is great.  In and out in no time.  I even had time to stop at Spencer & Daniels for some wine buys on the way back to my car.

And when I got to my car, the delivery truck for the florist that wouldn't give me change was double parked by my car.  Oh well.

Lunch was good and the place is great.

Thanks Jen, I owe you one.  Next time you are in town, I'll take you here.
author: Jeff H.

description:
Love this place. The line is long. Also it's not one of those places where you put your name in and you come back in an hour. You have to actually stand there in line until you get a seat, which is sort of a drag. It actually went faster than expected, but next time I'll just grab something to go. Plus when you get to the front of the line, someone asked me if I would like something to drink while I was waiting. I gladly said "Yes" and he brought me out a cold Anchor Steam. Sweet.

The food is fantastic. Simple. Clean. Classic. Everything we got was great. We ordered some oysters, which were unreal good. We then got some clam chowder, which is a less creamy version than I am used to, but still good. And then we split a combination seafood salad with crab and shrimp I believe. Total for all this was $57. Not bad!
author: Jamie Q.

description:
This is by far my favorite restaurant in my neighborhood and possibly the City. It is a San Francisco institution that is worth the wait.

Start off with some of their amazing clam chowder, followed by some oysters and a salad. One of the gems that I believe is not on the menu is their Sicilian Sashimi--fresh fish and scallop sashimi topped with fresh pepper, capers and extra virgin olive oil...AMAZING.

Be sure to ask for a pint of Anchor Steam while in line.

Great food, great ambiance, excellent place.
author: Steven W.

description: Went there on the advice of a friend. Thank you, Lorrie!! It was amazing. We had a sampler of oysters, cup of clam chowder and a combo salad. I'm pretty sure we had just about everything on the menu. Everything was delicious. The atmosphere was perfect, small and quaint. Very well worth the wait. Can't wait to eat here again!!
author: Kim E.

description: I looooove oysters and apart from heading out to Tomales Bay, this is the place to get em! If you go during off hours i.e. around 11 am, there's usually less of a wait but regardless- its definitely worth it!
author: Titus C.

description:
Best oysters ever. I know I am prone to hyperbole, but these really were the best oysters ever. 
I like to stop in here every month for an impromptu dozen oysters if I dont see a big line. I may have to make that a weekly habit...did I mention the best oysters ever?
author: Nilu r.

description:
I've been spoiled. I recently was taken to the Grand Central Oyster Bar in New York City and had Amaaazzzing Oysters in December last year.  Today I went to Swan's for the 6th time and had so-so bland oysters and clam chowder which tasted on par with canned Campell's soup, only a little more watered down.  I don't seem to recall Swan's being less than stellar before I went to the Grand Central Oyster Bar. Are they slipping?

The only saving grace is that they treat you fabulously and have great hearts. Oh, and they have gluten free bread if you talk to the right person.  They save it for one of their special customers.
author: Colette T.

description: We happened to see a line formed outside Swan Oyster Depot's door around lunchtime and decided to join in. Nothing but raves from us. This is a cool seafood shop with a long lunch counter where locals and tourists alike belly up for some of the city's freshest seafood. Highlights include Dungeness crab and raw oysters served with a sauce just spicy enough to really bring out their sweetness without overwhelming them. Try the shrimp cocktail, too. No reservations - as customers vacate seats, more customers are welcomed in. You can get seafood to go here as well. Champagne, wine and beer on tap are all options. Cash only.
author: Jack And Barbra D.

description:
We were fortunate to encounter no line and only 4 other people seated at the counter. But this was at 10:40am on a Thursday morning. By 11:00am, a line of people was already formed at the door, looking on with hungry, impatient eyes. The service was brisk and to-the-point; the veteran seafood guy who took care of our order didn't fawn over us with kid gloves on, but he was courteous and friendly in a gruff, sort of way, like a grandpa who looks out for you but doesn't say too much. He saw that it was our first time there and was informative and didn't make us feel rushed.

The clams and oysters were divine and arguably the freshest I've ever tasted. I slurped them straight from the shell unabashedly. The combination seafood salad was a thing of beauty, piled high with crab and shrimp. I wasn't a fan of the clam chowder; it was too brothy, and I prefer it thicker. We left about $30 poorer per person, on the not-very-full side but stuffed with tasty memories.

I'm not a fan of the crowded, shoulder-to-shoulder counter seating. A guy seated himself next to my sister and overflowed into her personal space (and at 100 lbs, she was already taking less than her fair share). He wasn't particularly large, and the person on his other side wasn't crowding him. My sister felt so uncomfortable that she just stood up to eat.  

For parents of little ones, like myself: This place isn't suitable for young children, as there is absolutely no room for strollers or high chairs, and it is impossible to hold a child on your lap while you sit on these stools.  

I'll definitely be back again some day, although I will do everything I can to avoid having to wait in line. (I hate waiting, and I hate waiting even more when I have to feed a parking meter.) Oysters for breakfast, anyone?
author: Andrea W.

description: We waited in line for 30 minutes on a Saturday at lunchtime, which honestly isn't that bad for how tiny the place is. It was really a neat experience. I love restaurants where you sit at the bar and watch them prepare everything. The atmosphere was top notch- lived-in, cozy, and has the original tile from when they opened. I went with two people and it was a right squeeze at the bar, but that was part of the charm. We shared a clam chowder, a calamari salad, and a dozen raw oysters. The food was incredibly fresh, if a bit expensive. I loved the service. Everyone was relaxed and happy. We in no way felt rushed. Charming. I would give it 5 stars if it weren't for the slightly steep price.
author: Kat R.

description:
Great fresh seafood and unbeatable prices.. 

I'm torn because while I liked the seafood here, I didn't really like the grimy "fish market by the docks" quality of the restaurant itself. Maybe it's just me, because my girlfriend thought was incredibly unique and fun. 

Great oysters, clams, chowder, bread, scallops, and smoked salmon.

This is your place if you're on a budget ($50 for 2 people vs. $100 at Hog Island). 

Come early as they close at 5:30pm!
author: Jon R.

description: The service here is friendly, but it's not a very nice place to eat. Very cramped. I only tried the sea urchin and I hated it. Wish I had tried the oysters though, based on all the reviews.
author: Sim H.

description:
5 stars for the food: creamy clam chowder, fresh-as-can-be oysters on the half shell and the best crab cocktail I've ever had.

Minus one star for the 75 minute wait and the cursory service.
author: B. Y.

description:
We rocked up to two seats at the counter with nary a wait this afternoon. Just as we began tucking into our bowls of New England clam chowder the line began to form at the door. We were quite chuffed at our impeccable timing. After the soup, we shared a half dozen oysters (which here gets you 7 instead of 6) and a prawn cocktail. 

The men who work behind the counter are just the friendliest lot. They shuck your oysters, judiciously refill your iced tea, and seem to authentically love their work. All in all it makes for an absolutely lovely dining experience.

I can't wait to go back!
author: Miriam W.

description: Crab and prawn cocktails were great. Crab back poured over crab cocktail was divine! Chowder terrific. Would have given 5 stars, but they gave me a real runaround when I tried to order the secret oyster stew. Acted like they didn't know what it was and Tommy (owner) was standing right there. When I said I saw Tommy make it on a cooking show, they said which show, still playing dumb. So, I told them and they said, Oh yes, that chowder. That was a huge mistake, because now everyone wants it. I guess you have to be prettier and younger than I to get them to make it for you. The seafood was sensational, but I really waited over an hour in line to get that stew!
author: Harriet E.

description:
I would give this place 50 stars if I could. I understand that it might not always get 5 stars because of the wait but the experience makes up for it. We went on a Wednesday afternoon for lunch. We waited about 15 mins. which was fine with me because we were aware that there would probably be a wait.

 Anyway, as soon as we sat down (and there are only about 15-20 stools along the bar to sit in which I think makes for a more intimate lunch!) we were approached by an older gentleman who obviously wanted us to have the best possible lunch we could! He brought us water, beer, and bread immediately. We both started with the double combo of the seafood salads, etc. The crab salad was highly recommended and thankfully we ordered that first because unfortunately they ran out for the rest of the week! We then got a mixed plate of oysters (which were bomb!) and then finished with a sashimi plate that was to die for! Best seafood I've had in a long time.

Aside from the lunch itself, the service was phenomenal. The guys know there's a line around the building (in some cases, mostly weekends we've heard) but their focus is on the people seated right in front of them. They don't rush you to finish your meal and each guy serves you-there's no "well, I'm not your server so I can't help you!" There's obviously local San Franciscan's that visit on the regular and there's definitely a sense of family and long-time friendship evident here. They genuinely want you to enjoy your experience (local or tourist) and we certainly did. We will definitely be back!
author: Liesl G.

description:
Love, love, love this place. 

I always make it a point to stop here whenever I'm in SF. 

Staff is friendly and nice, food quality is always top notch. They even serve you beer while you wait! 

I always get Clam Chowder, crab salad (more like crab meat on a bed of lettuce), and their oysters and clams. Delicious! 

The only downside is CASH ONLY. So make sure you load up on the greens before you come. 

Also, they're not open on sundays, and there's ALWAYS a line, so be prepared for the wait.
author: Kathy C.

description:
Honestly, I thought it was just over-hyped.  I was pleasantly surprised though to see how absolutely delicious and fresh tasting Swan Oyster Depot was.  The GF and myself recently found ourselves in the neighborhood, and the line was only moderate, so we decided wtf let's try it.  
Upon entering, the service was excellent.  Actually, we were offered beers/drinks while in the entranceway waiting for our seats to be ready.  Perfect. 
The menu itself is relatively simple, and is posted in front of the bar.  This changes verbally depending on what they have fresh at the time, so please ask your server what they recommend.  We did this, told him at the minimum we wanted crab and some scallop sashimi, but wanted to try everything he thought was good at the time.  
The result: we feasted on EVeRYTHING!
scallop, salmon and halibut italian sashimi
crab as a mixed seafood cocktail
smoked trout and salmon
clam chowder
crab back/body/fat
shrimp also at some point.

I am doing the list put together and brought out in sequence a great injustice to our server and the seafood, this is only a partial list and isn't even close to describing the delightful, mouth-watering experience we had

Must try, and then return.
author: Rob B.

description:
Rated 3.875/3.8....

You want to get seated? You better get here like its a Black Friday Sale.  Seating is limited so get you butt up or you will be forced to wait on line for a while.  Remember that the restaurant is near an area with coin only metered parking...

Here's the scoop!  Bourdain came here!  That's the reason why I wanted to try this place.  Ordered almost the same things that were seen on from the Layover but, was a little disappointed from the show's dishes however; the experience was reasonable.

Crab Fat (for dipping with bread):  The crab fat was cold and didn't really taste like anything.  Just a cold seafood tasting liquid with bread.  

Sea Urchin (uni): Totally different from what you may enjoy at a sushi restaurant.  Had a very bitter after-taste.  This may be b/c it was that fresh?  Or not so fresh?
(it was definitely an experience to try it but, mentally ruined my love for uni).  Not recommended unless you want to say you tried it.

Seafood Salad (Ordered the crab salad): Decent amounts of crab meat and was pretty good with the sauce they offer. (recommended)

Clam Chowder: Sorry West Coast, I  believe you've just been had b/c East Coast chowder rocks it... (Was ok yet prefer the ole Massachusetts/NY chowder)

Dozen mixed oysters:  It is called the oyster Depot for a reason.  (highly Recommended)

Overall:  OId fashion diner atmosphere with friendly service.  Enjoy a beer with your oysters/seafood salads.  Remember, its cash only and the price was reasonable with all that food I ate.
author: Jeong K.

description:
1. Only open for lunch/early dinner (close at 5:30P.M.)
2. Have to wait in line for people to finish but it is so worth the wait.
3. Very small, only seats 20-25 people.
4. The line moves pretty quickly if you go around 2-3P.M.
5. Some of the freshest and tastiest seafood I've had.

Love this place. It exhibits so much character. Family owned and worked for multiple generations. They seem to love what they do, they always have a smile on their face. Standing in line isn't that bad, once you get up near the front, you can drink an Anchor Steam or glass of wine while you wait for people to finish. The shrimp and crab are the freshest I've ever tasted. The clam chowder is New England style, just the way I like it. Dip some of their great bread in it and it's just heaven. Their oysters are also delish. I like to get the variety platter. It's a San Francisco gem! I think they only take cash, but there is an ATM across the street.
author: Kate N.

description:
Oysters
Crab roe with bread for dipping
More Oysters
Crab salad
and Beers

That is what I had, and it was very good.

The bad? Well I'm not sure if it was the food here or the maple bacon latte from Pirate Cat Cafe or maybe the combination of both that caused me to sit on the toilet for days.

I'll come back someday, but for some odd reason Ive lost the desire to want to eat oysters ever since...
author: phillip w.

description:
Key search words:  Whole squid.

I wanted to make mom's stuffed squid recipe, in which tentacles make a prominent appearance, but my usual Chinatown fish places failed to produce intact squid.  A foodie friend of mine suggested Swan Oyster Depot, but I resisted...surely the price per pound would be prohibitive.  I've seen those lines down the block every weekend!  Out of desperation I called anyhow, and when they said $5 per pound, I said "SOLD!".  They had 4 pounds all wrapped up for me by the time I got there.  The squids were nice and pretty and perfectly fresh.  Reserving one star until I actually eat there.

Free cooking tip:  After cleaning, a pound yields 10-11 squid.
author: Valeria R.

description: Oysters and smoked salmon - highly recommend.
author: Elizabeth L.

description: Cool place with history. The oysters and raw salmon, 4-5 stars. The chowder was blah...too runny, all potatos, no clams at all. My biggest complain though, is the workers handling the cash, then grabbing/serving shrimp, fish etc with their bare hands. Kinda nasty.
author: Farshi M.

description: The clam chowder is a disgrace. I'm shocked how watery and clam-less the soup is. What a waste. It tasted like milk water butter. No seafood in it. Maybe the other stuff might be good, but this was awful. Ouch.
author: Miro C.

description: Such a great place little place with an old-school vibe. We waited about 45 minutes on a Thursday afternoon, but it was worth every second. We sat down and ordered 2 cups of chowder right off the bat. It was a little thinner than I like, but at $2.75 for a cup, you can't beat it. Add the $1 bread basket for mopping up the extra chowder, and the crab back that you should order next. I've never had crab back, and I enjoyed it, and my boyfriend absolutely loved it. It was a delicious little addition to our meal. After finishing our Anchor Steams, my boyfriend ordered the Swan Special which is a Bud Light and a shrimp cocktail for $13. Great deal and delicous cocktail. The true star of the show was the Italian Sashimi plate. We got the medium and it included scallops, halibut, hamachi, salmon and tuna covered in a lemon-olive oil drizzle with capers. Holy crackers, I think I died and went to heaven. The seafood melts in your mouth and the sauce just enhances, enhances, enhances. The guys working the counter are all super-efficient and nice. They serve you quickly and make sure you are always happy and fed.
author: Krista D.

description:
I've been wanting to go here and I finally did a couple weeks ago.  Went on a Saturday afternoon around 3:30.  There was a line of about 20 people, but we ended up waiting in line for an hour.  The place only has seats for about 14 people.  You basically sit on bar stools which pretty much looked like the original (based off a photo) from when the place opened many many years ago.  The staff was very friendly.  Their menu is noted on chalkboards on the walls.  Ladies, there's nowhere to put your purse so just give it to the staff and they'll put it on the shelf or next to the register for you.

I mainly came for the fresh oysters.  They offered beer on tap, but I had sparkling wine.  We ordered a dozen and a half of various oysters, mixed seafood cocktail, and crab cocktail.  I loved how they had various sauces and toppings....tabasco, ponzu, various Mexican chili sauce, Siracha, capers, soy sauce, red vinaigrette with onions, tartar sauce, cocktail sauce, etc.  It was worth the wait and it definitely satisfied my fresh seafood craving!
author: Erica S.

description: We went there for lunch and waited in line for 40 min. But the experience were meh. We ordered clam chowder, dozen oyster, and combination salad. The clam chowder was watered down and grainy (broken), with just little bits of clam and potato. Salad was basically seafood on a bed of iceberg lettuce, granted the dressing was good. The oyster was very good but we could have gone elsewhere and get the same quality oyster. Granted the food came out really fast but everything was way overpriced. We also have upset stomach afterwards. :(
author: Tiffany L.

description:
The most refreshing experience you will have dining in SF. This is an old school, authentic place with solid old values. They treat everyone like family. The people behind the counter ARE family, and it has been around forever. It's a landmark!

Anthony Bourdain didn't rave about this place for no reason.

It want you want fresh seafood, then look no further!
author: Kyle W.

description: This the place to go if you want fresh oysters and clams.  The only thing I dont like about this place is the wait, but I guess if if you appreciate freshness then waiting shouldnt be a problem.  My advice is to try going in the afternoon atleast the crowd dies down a little.  The staff is laid back and friendly. :-)
author: Joseph G.

description:
To begin I would like to thank Anthony Bourdain and Swan Oyster Depot. If it were not for Sir Anthony I may not have heard of Swan unless I was lucky enough to have a local or seafoodie inform me about this place. 

Given I took Mr. Bourdains advice, I went closer to the end of their hours around 4 and didn't have to wait to sit. Thank god though, I got there when I did because they were beginning to run out of everything. That is a good sign. 

To start I indulged in a cup of their chowder. Unfortunately, I have to say it was a bit too watery for my standards. Beyond that, it had a decent helping of seafood awaiting inside not masked by too many potatoes like most chowders can. 

After that, I salvaged someones Crab skull they chose not to have accompany the legs they ordered. For just about 7 dollars, I sopped up and spread all that medula obla crabba on some nice crusty sourdough. I highly recommend, if you want to try something different. 

Given I was by myself, I only finished my day off with a Anchor Stream draft and a tray of 6 Blue Bay Oysters on the half shell. Pardon my language but D-Fuckinglicious. So fresh, so perfect, and so local. Those Oysters saved my visit. I had originally planned on just getting chowder and some crab brain. If I had, my review may not have been so in depth and positive. 

The staff feel like that uncle that taught you how to throw a football and drink whiskey the right way. Straight up and out of the bottle to stay warm near the bay. I can't wait to go back and get a bit more acquainted with these fellas. 

Great place.
author: Spencer C.

description: Love the freshness and the variety of seafood! Ranging from oysters, lobsters to just fish! The eng clam chowder and the seafood salad are musts! If you got some extra $, get a dozen oysters!
author: Kitty L.

description:
Any place that serves you alcohol while you are outside waiting in line is pretty fantastic in my eyes. When you have an ice cold stella in your hand you tend to forget how long you have been standing in line, but enough about the waiting let talk about the food. 

There was not a single item that i didnt like. Smoked Salmon... amazing. Clam Chowder.... superb. The oysters looked smelled and tasted fantastic. Unfortunately since i am newly and sadly allergic to shellfish i was unable to taste the crab and shrimp. however my fellow patrons provided me with a good idea of how great they were based on the amount of mmmmmmmmmmmmmms and ahhhhhs that i heard. oh and the fact that they kept saying "its too bad you cant try this. sucks for you"... come from a loving family =)

Another thing to note is the service. The staff at Swan is great. You can tell by their witty rapport that the are a close like family bunch. The interactions with each other are actually very comical... its kinda like dinner and show.
author: Lillian B.

description: only 18 stools to sit at the counter so expect to stand in line on the sidewalk. Worth every painful minute of waiting. This hole in the wall is a must visit if you are a seafood lover.
author: Martin Y.

description:
Craved oysters, thought hmm, swan's or hog's?  Since i'm not a hipster and i didn't want to pay $15 for parking for an hour of oysters, i decided on swans.

Midweek, got there little after 12.  Place was full but there was only a couple of people in front of me.  Got seated within 10 minutes so my harblz didn't freeze.  Interesting for an oyster place, they have the prices on the wall for everything BUT oysters.  Bit annoying but whatever.  Everything looks fresh, everybody is having fun, the atmosphere is quite electric.

A jolly rotund man that kinda looks like Norm from cheers is my server.  Jolly to everyone but when he's taking my order, it's like he was talking to an IRS agent.  Um, I'm just here for oysters.  I ask what the selection of beer is and it looked like he was getting audited.

I order corona, a cup of clam chowder, 6 blue point, and 6 miyagis.  The corona was smooth, but had a hint of urine.  The clam chowder, wasn't.  Not sure if it's punishment for getting a cup but there was maybe 4 slivers of clam, and the broth was more buttery than chowdery.  It wasn't even creamy white for  the love of gavin.  Also, one would think, being in SF, they would get some proper sourdough bread.  It was just meh. 

The oysters, on the other hand, were truly food for gods.  Both types were remarkably fresh as others have stated.  Blue points were meaty and the miyagi's were salty with bite.

I'm sure all the other items on the menu are just as refreshing as the oysters but my rating is based on what I had.  Oyster depot, you didn't make me leapo, 3 stars.
author: Dirk M.

description:
shit service, shit quality 'oysters' (and its CALLED swan OYSTER), shit hygiene. 
really do not understand why there is even a line and why its not closed down already
author: T N.

description:
This is one of my favorite restaurants. There are a few downsides to this place. It's tiny; the line to get in takes forever; it isn't cheap; and it's cramped and uncomfortable. Despite these shortcomings Swan is still one of my favorite restaurants. I love the staff. I love the bread; I love the Louis dressing. Their seafood salad is old-school; simply a plate of iceberg lettuce, heaped with crab, shrimp, and prawns topped with the best Louis dressing I've ever had.

I have found it's best to come here for breakfast or a very early lunch to avoid the long line. If you don't want to eat seafood and drink wine for breakfast then that leaves more space for me to get in.
author: Noah S.

description:
Famous oysters says 7x7 100 Places to Eat in SF, therefore I HAD TO TRY IT!

Split everything with a friend so neither of us ended up deathly full. :P

Clam Chowder (Bowl). YUM. I liked how it had pieces of clams in it rather than the whole clam including the shell like they do at Hog Island, but I thought it was definitely way more watery than the one at Hog Island since I find that to be more creamy. It was good though since it had a nice share of potatoes in it, and I love me some potatoes. I also liked how it wasn't overly salty. 

Blue Point Oysters. YUM!!! I love oysters! They were definitely bigger than the Kumamoto oysters I had at Hog Island, but less sweet. These were still good nonetheless and I feel like I got slightly more bang for my buck because these were larger. They tasted great with the yummy sauces they gave us. 

Can't for the life of me remember what the sauce was but it tasted as if it was made of vinegar and pepper. I liked this best with my oysters. 

Cocktail Sauce. It was alright but I definitely liked the vinegar sauce better since I could better taste my oyster with it. 

Bread and Butter. Came with the salad. I think it was sourdough, it was alright, since I don't really like sourdough, it wasn't anything special. We didn't even finish all of it because we were too full.

Shrimp Louie Salad. Cocktail shrimps served on a bed of iceberg lettuce with Louie Salad Dressing on the side. It was pretty good, the shrimps were really fresh and tasted great with the dressing and lettuce. I also appreciated how clean the shrimp were AKA no nasty shrimp intestines, I hate seeing that knowing I'm eating it since I find it disgusting. 

Louie Dressing. YUMS. Like Thousand Island but creamier. 

Service was great. I loved how it was a more neighborly and friendly place even though it's become THE place for tourists and 7x7 readers to come to. It's still got it's hole-in-the-wall charm. Do note that you may have to wait for seating unless you come by yourself. Me and my friend had to wait half an hour for seats together. I think I may have to try the Kumamotos and their off the menu sashimi next time! 

P.S. Their old school cash register is SUPER COOL!
author: Constance C.

description:
I've never had oysters before.  I was always wary from trying since the words people used in association with oysters has always been 'slimy' 'slurp' and 'fishy'.  Really, do those words sound appetizing to anyone?

My friend on the other hand do enjoy a good helping of oysters, and since he is visiting what else to eat in SF but seafood? Swan Oyster Depot here we come.  

The wait on a Saturday afternoon around 4pm with Santa Con  2010 Santas and elves mulling around was about 45 minutes.  While waiting on line, we got an order of new England clam chowder to jump start our Swan oyster depot experience. 

To give one some perspective.  My favorite new England clam chowder is Campbell's.  Yep, the ones you buy from the shelves of a Safeway supermarket.  I've been to Rhode Island and Boston and tried their local famous new England clam chowder joints, yet my favorite is still Campbell's.  

Back to Swan Oyster's new England clam chowder.  I would not categorize it as a chowder at all.   It is more like a clam soup.  The consistency reminded me of miso soup with too much miso.  I didn't see lots of seafood in that chowder as well.  And its a bit too salty for my taste.  

We finally sat.  My friend did the ordering.  But the waiters were all very friendly and helpful.  The atmosphere at Swan Oysters was just really relaxing and fun.  

We had 3 varieties of oysters and cherry stone clams.  half dozen cherry stone was $9.25.  I remembered blue points were $2 a piece, the other 2 kind were probably around $1.85.  Don't recall exactly, but our bill came out to be $28.25 for 6 clams and 10 oysters)

My first time trying oysters and it was a wonderful experience both with the food and the restaurant.

While we are enjoying our oysters, 2 girls dressed in the sexy Santa suit stopped by and started caroling asking for oysters.

Well, the guys at SOD requested that they give a little to get any free oysters.  The girls lifted their shirt and flashed - sorry guys, with bras on :) .  For their effort, they got 2 free oysters.  

HAHAHAHAHAHA, this made our SOD experience even more special and fun!  No one at the joint was offended, everyone was enjoying this exchange with good humor and laughs. 

I'd definitely go back to SOD again!
author: Jessica C.

description:
The fact that you don't really know the prices of the off the menu oysters is a little scary. The bill may scare you in fact. I think of this place as an roughened up, Americanized omakase. 

I got there around 3 pm on a Saturday afternoon. Of course, there was a line, but it wasn't too bad. The wait was about half an hour. We managed to score some of the seats all the way at the end, towards the back of the restaurant. The restaurant is basically one long counter, and a bunch of seafood chefs behind it. The guys remind me of tough, big Brooklyn guys. Anyways, the omakase begins with a chef asking about what we like, what we want. It was a funny interaction, it was kind of like, sure you can get that, why wouldn't you be able to? 

We requested salty, briny oysters, a mixed platter of oysters, some scallops, and smoked salmon on french bread with no frills. The bill came out to be about $50/person including tax and tip. They don't write down what you got, this is all the honor system.

The oysters were fresh. They also had a huge selection of oysters that are not on the menu, so you should definitely describe what you want and they can fix that up for you. I didn't like that there were a lot of random shell pieces in the oysters, but hey, they were damn good. A favorite of mine was the shigoku - I was told it was a mixed breed between 2 different oysters and it is a new oyster breed. It was a small, but very deep oyster. It was a little sweet, a little salty, but definitely full-bodied. Amazing. 

I heard they also have sea urchin sometimes. I hope to try this next time I come back.
author: Stacy T.

description: Yes, Anthony Bourdain brought me here but the food has guaranteed that I'll be back. We headed out here on a weekday morning.  Arrived roughly after 10:30am and there were already about 20 people in line. The wait was about 30 minutes but well worth it. Fresh oysters are a no brainer but another stand out dish were the scallops with olive oil, onions and capers. Deeeelish! I also enjoyed the clam chowder even though it was a bit grainier than what I'm used to.  Service was quick and friendly. Definitely look forward to coming back the next time I'm in SF!
author: Mymy L.

description:
CLAM CHOWDER ($5.75 for small bowl)
+ great clam taste
+ bits of tender clams...not tough
- too thin
- too salty...salt was main flavor...no balance of flavors...
- needs more substance
- cream separated so see dots of cream...not homogeneous
- the price (expensive for what it is)

OYSTERS (kumamoto, miyagi, blue points)
+ fresh
+ very fatty oysters especially kumamoto
+ variety of sauces (mignonette, horse radish, cocktail sauce)
+ ice cold platter
+ clean oysters - not bits of shell on it
- $2 per oyster

SERVICE
+ nice guys
+ lots of people working there
+ they seemed to enjoy their job
+ feels like new york or new jersey style service...rough yet friendly and family style
- gave us bread asap without telling us it costs money
- was rude to a rude customer who wanted to eat there after their "last call" note was given

DECOR
+ fun as it has a very old feel
+ has some history
+ i am a sucker for countertops
- too many tourists vs locals

BOTTOM LINE
- It was too expensive for the quality of food
- not the best clam chowder, not even close
- fresh stuff but way overpriced....i overheard $55 a pound for the crab meat
- it is now a tourist trap and for the simple preparation, i would not come back...neither would i feel like i had a horrible time had i have to come again...
- not a recommendation nor praise for Swan Oyster Depot...just okay in my book...
- i prefer Woodhouse for clam chowder and oysters if u are to pay this price...
- without the decor, I would not have enjoyed it as much...
author: Simon L.

description:
They literally close the doors at 530pm, even if you've been standing in line, so get there early peeps!

We got there at 330pm on a Saturday afternoon, and were finally seated at 445pm.  I was thinking, "This place better be damn worth it!"  Nice thing is, while waiting in line, you meet cool people.  Tangent tip - meet your neighbors while waiting in line - it'll definitely speed up the time! :)  Also, there was a homeless man walking up and down the street singing the same song over & over that added to the amusement.

 Place seems to be owned a by a family of big white men.  They were all super nice and friendly & had alot of personality.  That was nice.  

Crab Salad:  $23
Dozen Oysters:  Approx $26
Beer:  $4 

My husband and I got shared crab salad, dozen mixed oysters, and 2 beers, and walked out a $59 bill, plus tip, totalling $70.  That's abit on the high end for me personally.  

But the oysters were SUPER FRESH and delicious!  Crab salad has HUGE chunks of fresh crabs.  

-1 for overprice.  I would give it -1 for long wait in line, but I won't penalize for that, it's Yelp's fault for bringing all that business :).  

Otherwise, great place and I'd definitely go back next time if I $$ to splurge.
author: Nancy M.

description:
Oysters were SO GOOD AND SO FRESH!!! I got half a dozen of the assortment of oysters so basically got six different kind of oysters. All of them tasted so fresh and yummy!
The service was really great as well. It is a family owned business and you can tell, they serve everyone promptly and with kindness. The claim chowder is the best I've ever had. 
Would definitely come back again.
author: T L.

description:
This place opens early in the morning and closes at 5pm. Every time Matt passes by this place, people wait in line to check the freshest seafood captured everyday by the brothers running the establishment.  

Matt landed to this historical seafood bar for a quick snack. The selections were limited, because he got here kind of late as they were about to close for the night. The soup special on Friday was the Boston Clam-Chowder in a large bowl. The $4.75 bowl of chowda contained the freshest clams and other ingredients caught that morning. Since Matt got there at the wrong time, as expected the soup was a bit too salty and diluted. Even with the stale $.75 sourdough bread didn't improve the taste. 

Matt's first ever visit to the Swan Oyster Depot will be his last, at least for a while.
author: Matt G.

description: One of my top 10 meals ever. The clam chowder is the best you'll ever have, and you just have to try the smoked salmon plate. Simply one of a kind. Bear the wait to get in, you'll be happy you did.
author: Eddie M.

description: OH BOY! Waited in line for 20 minutes but WELLL WORTH THE WAIT! The oysters here was as fresh as any restaurant on the pier, if not better. The service was entertaining and friendly. We had a dozen oyster and a bowl of clam chowder, our meal was delicious. Would def try again and recommend to any friend.
author: Dennis H.

description: As far as raw bars go, this place is the tops.  I have lived in the area since 1998 and always put off going because of the wait.  However, hour long wait on Saturday at lunchtime was worth it!  The place smells amazing when you walk in.  The old school vibe is so great.  We shared some clam chowder, a mixed dozen oysters and some bread.  The clam chowder is outstanding.  Heavy on clam flavor, not thick with flour.  The oysters (six kinds) were absolutely top notch.  The bread was perfect local sourdough: thick crust on the outside and soft crumb on the inside.  Pints of beer on tap are $4 all the time.  That is like happy hour pricing everywhere else.  The staff is outstanding.  I cannot think of anything that would have improved our visit.  We loved it.
author: Amber B.

description:
Soooo gooood. 

Got an assortment of oysters and figured out the kumamotos were my favorite. But the combination salad with louie's dressing oh my gosh so good! The seafood tasted fresh and thinking about it just makes me crave it. Definitely worth the money.

I was full from half a salad and 6 oysters but I had to try their clam chowder that I hear so much about. It was definitely a lot more thinner than what I'm used to but it was very flavorful with chunks of clam. 

One of the other things I loved about this place is the people working there. They were very nice and knowledgeable about their seafood. Just seeing them make the salads they are so careful in assembling the salads.

The only thing I can think that can be a con is the wait but it's definitely worth it! yummm!
author: Katie M.

description:
Hubs and I originally scheduled Swan Oyster Depot later in the day in our day of absolute gluttony.  After our first stop to Hooker's Sweet Treats (ok, I guess second stop, if you count coffee at farm:table), we decided it made more sense time-wise and location-wise to go to Swan Oyster Depot.  This was purely for my enjoyment because hubs doesn't eat oysters.  At first, I hesitated because it was only 10:15am and honestly, I would be embarrassed if I was their first customer... the pig that eats oysters in the morning.  I decided to own up to it and just go.  We got there at 10:30am and the place was packed!  We took the last two seats at the bar and soon thereafter, a line started forming outside of the place.  They gave us bread which was super soft and chewy- the best kind of them all!  I ordered a dozen of the mixed oysters, crab cocktail, 6 mixed clams on a half shell and hubs ordered a cup of clam chowder.  The oysters were so cold, fresh and delicious.  Some sweet, some briny.  HEAVEN!  The clams were a little weird for me because they were so meaty and raw.  The only other time I had clams on a half shell, they were tiny.  The crab cocktail was also very fresh and soooo good!  I love that they do all the cracking for you and you can just enjoy the meat.  YUM.  The clam chowder was also very good.  Not as thick and creamy as your typical clam chowder but it was oh so flavorful!  Right before we were finished, I noticed that someone had ordered sea urchin (my FAVE).  I ordered it and they said it was the last one!  Boo.

The place is very casual with a bunch of manly men working behind the counter.  They didn't hesitate to refer to us as "that Asian couple" to each other out loud.  They're very straight forward but also very friendly and informative about their menu at the same time.  

Wish we had one of these in Orange County.  I would be there every weekend.
author: Lanna K.

description: The owners, all family are a fun lot to watch as they hustle behind the counter, moving back and forth like clockwork to dole out the simple good tasting food of the san fransisco ocean.  a dozen oysters, smoked salmon, fresh bread, a crab cocktail and a few beers sent our hungry palates swooning.  our neighbors had the Sea Urchin cracked right in front of us and cleaned very carefully.  and then the little neck clams...  i had never seen them so pink in color. crispy and of the ocean.  a real treat... thanks guys...  steve and ellen
author: Steve S.

description:
Swan Oyster Depot is a revelation, and you know it from the moment you walk in the door.  Because I'm a very judgmental person I have a habit of immediately loving or being disappointed by restaurants, this was true love and remained so to the finish.  I have another habit of wanting to pre or post date experiences I'm having, like when I take the BART from the airport I think to myself, "This is what living the future must be like", or when I pay with exact change, I imagine it's the 1930's and I had to scrounge it out of my coffee can from under the creaky floorboard in the pantry.  Judgmental people are usually highly dramatic as well.

As you can imagine Swan makes this all too easy for me, because it really is from another era.  From the old marble counters, to the old refrigeration system, to the "watcha like dollface" service style from the guys behind the counter and the array of classic seafood condiments, it truly is a blast from the past.  Part of this historical accuracy knocks them down one star; the half hazard and dubious sanitation of shared bowls of oyster crackers, and some of the fish flopping out onto the counter from behind its glass partition was a little worrisome, but no matter, people were heartier back then, no?  I'll just assume that imaginative time travel protects you from communicable disease.

I was here on a Monday, when it was still crowded, but nothing like some of the Saturday lines I've seen waiting.  It's hard to know if anything is worth the lines I've seen coming out of this place, but if your life depends on a fresh, varied menu of seafood items prepared in the super classic manner, then that line is but a drop in the bucket of time.  Since my love of seafood is not life threatening, I'll stick to the off hours.
author: Kathryn M.

description:
THE WORST PLACE. I don't understand the point of this place where I'm POSITIVE you can find other places for the same kind of seafood in the city. 
First, the wait is ridiculous, line is so long out of the door, we waited so long that all the girls in the group had to use the bathroom in Walgreens across the street.
Second, NO ONE WAS WEARING GLOVES!!!! they make food and everything else in their bare hands!!! Passing money and changes, cleaning tables, no one prolly even washes hands after the bathroom breaks cuz the place is so damn packed n busy!!! 
Third, the people work there were so rude and impatient, and they tried to start a fight w the guys in our group!!!! Which I thought it was completely out of the line, we were out of the town tourist, and simply wanted to see what this place was about, and we didn't expect the wait to be SO LONG, so one of the guys in our group went up and asked if the food was ready, the guy who was making the food literally turn the knife around and tried to pass it to my friend hinting " please, you do my job for me." we were all in such a shock, and didn't know what he was trying to do!!!! Then the people in line started yelling at us, like we did something wrong, and told us to leave!!!!! 
It was the worst experience I have ever had in a food service place where customer service should be important. I guess the place is so hyped up, they don't need more ppl to come.
Fourth, the place is so small, and there is no tables, it's a bar kind of setting prolly fits around 15 ppl, and the floor is wet. Imagine a fish mkt indoor.
I don't recommend this place at all...as I'm sure there are plenty other places which has nice environment with good food, and also are managed by the good people do exist in San Fran :)
author: Ming H.

description:
My favorite place in s.f. don't miss it
and off hours are the best
love the louie! love the soup, love the salmon.
funny i've never even had an oyster there
author: johnathon c.

description: The wait was crazy long when my dad and I decided to give this spot a try and we started to wonder if it was worth it. Oh boy were we glad we waited! The food was amazing and super fresh. That wasn't even the best part though, the guys working behind the bar treating us like family. They were so attentive and gave great suggestions, they even gave us samples of the food and thru in a couple of drinks on the house. Only regret is that we didn't try the crab fat that everyone was eating. This place might be small but it made a huge impression on us. Next time we're in SF we'll gladly wait in the long line for this!
author: Cailyn S.

description: We stumbled across Swan's by accident, noticing a line if people up the street. After waiting half an hour for a seat in this little hole in the wall we were totally wowed. The smoked salmon was sliced off the fish in front of us and is so fresh that it melts in your mouth. The service was A-mazing and the atmosphere was also great. Slightly expensive but given the freshness of the seafood this is understandable.
author: Kirsty L.

description:
After reading reviews on this place, I decided to give it a try on my last visit to SF back in November. I have to thank my fellow yelpers once again for helping me find this spot! It was so good and the price was pretty darn reasonable. 

We started out our meal with their boston clam chowder. It's not your typical clam chowder but still pretty tasty. Then came the stars of the meal...kumamoto and blue point oysters. My god...these oysters were so fresh and oh so good! Probably one of the best oysters I've had. I think we ordered like 2 dozen and a 1/2 between the two of us. Lastly we had the seafood salad with their louis dressing. The salad was delish and the seafood that came with it was super fresh. I loved it!

Total cost for our meal and two glasses of beer was about 70 bucks..great deal for yummy oysters and fresh seafood. I will definitely come back the next time I'm back in SF.
author: anna n.

description: The first few times I went here was before the popularity explosion due to some TV publicity.  Though there is a longer wait now and it is really most prudent to arrive before they open I still find myself here every time I am in SF.  All of the standard menu items are a good choice but I find its always a good idea to see what additional oysters, crudo, or other stuff they have as well.  They get some things with the season so you may be able to get something special every now and then.  Its great to see that the fame hasn't affected the atmosphere or the quality of their offerings.  I won't dock them a star, but I do have to express disappointment with the more recent hours which no longer allow me to have sparking wine and oysters at 7am... That was really a great way to start the day in SF a few years back :).
author: Harvey G.

description:
I can not understand the yelp rating on this place. I'm from the state of Maine, thus I've eaten at a lot of seafood spots.  This place SUCKS. One of the owner sons(1 OF 6) was rude to his employees in front of us at the end of the bar. That made the atmosphere a stiff and cheap. 
As for the food, EXPENSIVE for the amount and quality. Sorry but 3 dollars for  each oyster is no bargain. 19.00 bucks for 1/2 pound of smoked salmon is not a good buy. Waiting 45 mins for average food at high price is bad. Also everything is cash and added up on a napkin.....I have never seen this...WOW.....avoiding the tax man.
author: john w.

description:
*FYI: Don't come here if you're in a rush*

Had just landed in SF from LAX and was famished.
There was a long a line, as usual but we were very entertained because we had come during Santa-con and there were plenty of drunken Santas, elves, and reindeer cheering and singing to keep me pre-occupied while waiting outside in the cold.  The beer also helped.
The clam chowder was delicious.  Its not as thick and chunky as I prefer but it definitely hit the spot after waiting outside for an hour.
The oysters was fresh and delicious.  We got a sampler of the 3 types they had and all were fresh with varying taste and size.  Always fun to try a variety and see which one you like.  But for me its like wine, I know what I like but can never remember the names.. :(  They also give you a bunch of different dipping sauces to try so ask for them if they forget
The prawn cocktail was really good, better than the shrimp and tasted fresher too.  The smoked salmon with capers and onions was great, looking at them cut into a huge slab of salmon made my mouth water.
The staff was the best part of the experience, they were very friendly and accommodating--our group of 4 got split up and later we were able to reunite and sit next to each other, yay!
Overall it was a fun place to dine, sitting at the bar and talking with the staff, hearing the story from the owner about his dad and his kids to me is so much better than sitting at some dimmed restaurant with a snooty server.
author: Jennifer L.

description: Great oysters.  Been coming here for over 9 years and 99% of the times it delivers.
author: Jim J.

description:
This is the first oyster bar I've been to...and wow.  Amazing.  I wonder why I don't do this more often, especially since I'm addicted to sushi.  

Food.  Order the oysters.  They're really fresh.  My friend and I shared a dozen oysters and a bowl of clam chowder and a order of prawn cocktail and crab salad.  The oysters were amazing, but I think the prawns out of the three was the best.  They were big, juicy, and oh-so meaty.  I had to cut mine into pieces because it was so big!!  Do NOT order the clam chowder.  It's thin and runny.  It's a great flavor, but not creamy at all.  In fact, there was absolutely no cream. It tasted like water with chucks of clam.  If that's how you like clam chowder go ahead, but I prefer my nice, thick, and hearty. 

The service was decent.  I mean, our server was nice, but he didn't care, if you know what I mean.  He did offer to put my bag behind the counter so I didn't have to put it on the floor. However, I was a bit worry about him handling our food because I did not see him wash his hands once. =/  Maybe I'm just being OCD? 

Our bill was about $65 + tip
author: Debbie T.

description: Maybe it was just an off day but..this place bristles with complete arrogance or maybe ignorance. I have been coming here for years. Warning do not try the UNI.. The one i had tasted of rancid piss and the guy claims that it was really good. Now  i have been eating uni since i was a wee boy being  that its part of our diet growing up. We used to pick em off the rocks in the beaches. Anyway they did not even try to say hey you know what youre right. It was just  tough. Minus 2 stars this time. I do not mind waiting in line for an hour but wow.Completely arrogant  but i just hope it is just ignorance.
author: Jorydude r.

description:
First, I live for a good New England chowder.  That is one of my favorite foods.  Everywhere I can find it, I try it.  I am a San Francisco resident and so that is one of my treats for myself: finding great chowders in San Francisco and everywhere I travel.

On a scale of 1 to 10 (on San Francisco standards), I would rank the clam chowder a 3.  I've had a few worse chowders in San Francisco: maybe two that I can think of.  The chowder reminded me of when I was a kid and I use to make Campbell's New England Clam Chowder where you add milk to the stuff that comes out of the can: it was watery.  For San Francisco standards, I can think of so many places in San Francisco with much better chowder that I'm not even going to start listing the massive list here.  Boudin's is even better and that in opinion is the lowest standard for chowder that I will eat.

As for the shrimp salad, it didn't look that impressive for the price.   I'm not an oyster person. 

For seating, everyone sits at a packed counter that was completely uncomfortable: there are no tables.  Think of commuting on a packed subway train (BART) at rush hour where everyone is so packed together that you just can't wait to get off the train; that is what it felt like to sit at the counter and eat my bowl of chowder.

I would not visit this place again for any reason, there are just way too many better places to eat in San Francisco, and way too many better chowders.

As for the Yelp review about eating the dungeness crab brains (the visitor from Texas).  That yellowish stuff is the crab's liver and it can be potentially harmful for you.  I would not recommend eating the crab butter (which is the polite name for that stuff).  You might want to google it before you eat it again.
author: Rob E.

description: All the fresh clams in the window were dead -- slightly open.  i can't imagine a worse advertisement.  I didn't go in.
author: Diane L.

description:
worst service I have had in the world. waited for about 2 hours to get a sit inside and  
The food is normal. considering the price, I think the food is bad. 
It seems that the staff in the bar have no pride of their reputation. look like just feeding their  customers such pigs. except the guy with glasses, the staff look down Asians. Maybe it is a part of their service which is differentiated from the others.
author: Glenn L.

description:
I've been meaning to go to Swan for many years now but for one reason or another I've always missed the opportunity while visiting San Francisco. I'm glad we finally found the time to swing by this past trip so now I can check it off my bucket list.

Got there a little after noon and there was a healthy line starting to form outside the door. The wait wasn't too bad, about 25 minutes or so before we made it to our seats. The fellas helping us out were real decent guys, straight-shooters that handled their business. You could sense the history of the place, the walls were adorned with old photos, knick-knacks, various oddities and sports memorabilia. I really liked the vibe.

We ordered the clam chowder, six types of oysters, clams on the half shell and the combination seafood salad. The oysters were a delight, especially the four varieties of wild Miyagis we sampled. No frills food but incredibly fresh and satisfying. Please do try the habanero mignonette with your oysters and clams, I couldn't get enough of the stuff and I've never seen anything like it anywhere else.

It was a fantastic lunch, a cornucopia of the sea and we enjoyed every last bit. The bill came out to about $30 a person with tip and considering the amount of food we had it was well worth it. Forget the Golden Gate, Swan Oyster Depot is the real San Francisco landmark.
author: Lu T.

description:
I love oysters so much especially fresh ones (5 stars)!!! Oh man, the line can be super long, but worth it!!! The customer service here was excellent because while you are waiting in line, the server would ask if any drinks are needed, etc. Again the combination oysters were super fresh, I love the kumamoto the most! I tried the claim chowder, even though it was watery.. it was still full of flavor (3.5 stars). However, it can use less potatoes.

Oh, I enjoyed the white Honig wine. BTW, you can also take the food to go if the line gets too long.
author: Nhung T.

description: Wow, the seafood here is the absolute freshest I've ever had. This place made me felt like we were just on a fishing boat catching all the seafood out at sea. LOVE the oysters and LOVE that seafood combo salad. The workers were an absolute delight. The wait can be a pain since this place is so small.
author: Marilyn W.

description:
every minute waiting in line and every dollar spent was worth it! 

must haves: 

clam chowder
oysters, of course! 
calamari salad
crab cocktail

customer service was amazing! i put this on top of my list as the friendliest restaurant ever!
author: katee l.

description: Waited for an hour but totally worth it. We had the sashimi, calamari cocktail, combination seafood salad, clam chowder and smoked salmon. All of them tasted really fresh and delicious. I wish we could have had the sea urchin but they did not have it. My two favorites were the sashimi and the smoked salmon.
author: Ekin G.

description:
Barbara & I ate a mid-week lunch here. The line was out the door at Noon. I've walked past this place 500 times without giving it a thought beyond..."This place is a hole-in-the-wall, it looks old, dirty, and funky. Everybody waiting on-line looks like a tourist". Barbara ate here many years ago and insisted that I try lunch with her. 

I'm going to admit that the crab louie was good. A bit too old school recipe for me, but the quality is high. Had a bowl of chowder - Thought that it was too watery, I guess they do not use potato to thicken the broth. They didn't thicken it with any clams either.  The sourdough bread was okay, not the best  - Lombardi's brand?  I drank bottled beer.  Barbara loved her seafood salad and sides. 

I'm put-off by all the junk on the shelves above the food prep counter. Looks like there are 4 years worth of newspapers dropping dust on my food.  The fixtures, counters, & seats look like they haven't been cleaned in 50 years. Too gritty for me. 

Yes the servers all all wonderfully friendly and clever. Good food served in a dive. I ain't going back.
author: Tom S.

description:
Amazing oysters and friendly folk.

I stopped in here at 9:30 on a Saturday morning, had no problem getting a seat.  The staff (about 10 large dudes) were quite friendly in walking me and my date through the menu.  We both received bowls of deliciously meaty clam chowder ($2.50), and 12 oysters (six steak-sized Blue Points, and another six from up and down the coast).  Every five minutes one of the guys behind the counter asked us if we were doing okay; we felt very well taken care of.

We were in and out in forty minutes with bellies full of oysters and clams.  I highly, highly recommend this place if you can get a seat.
author: Bill H.

description: Good, fresh, affordable.  I had sea urchin, cut open and served in the shell.  Beer is cold and the bread and seafood cocktail is awesome.  Very old school, cash only.
author: Hector R.

description:
While it's common to say that you left your heart in San Francisco, they overlook that they also left their appetite and their seafood craving in San Francisco. 

Oh, who am I kidding, I crave that stuff right now. I don't think there's a better place to eat all sorts of seafood than this place. You want good customer service? Come here! 

There's a couple of places you want to establish a good relationship with the purveyor of whatever it is. Your barber shop is one place, a butcher shop, your sushi chef and a Swan Oyster depot guy. These guys will treat you right when it comes to shellfish, they sure are selfish. 

There's typically a line. It's worth the wait and once inside you'll see that it's a pretty tight space between you, the counter and the person getting your crab ready.. and you have to get the crab here. Their sourced fairly locally and there's nothing better than food that was breathing just a short time before it hit your plate. 

And while there's many places to get good oysters in S.F., I don't think you could beat the setting that this place provides. It's just your average joe on the other side readying your food. The moment they hand you that plate of ice with a lot of little oysters laying on top of it.. that's a magic moment right there. 

Pull one of them back and let it slide and you'll be in heaven. You don't even have to put anything on it. Just let them fly one by one and the taste. some it taste so delicious. Wash that sucker down with a cold one and you got yourself a meal fit for a king.. or queen. I don't know, this is S.F. after all. Not sure what's the correct P.C here. 

Then the crab. Oh my, the Dungeness crab is the staple here and they do it right. Giving you that shell with the juices just flowing in it. That is amazing to eat. 

Shrimp cocktails were pretty good, I guess I could go either way with them. I did really enjoy the clam chowder here. That was a treat. Who said you have to be from New England to make a really good clam chowder? Well, from the accents I wouldn't be surprised if a couple of these folks working were East coast transplants. But at least they were easy going and friendly. No wonder they wanted to get away from that. 

You'll be mopping the juices of all your food with the sourdough bread and craving more soon after. Yes, I truly left my heart in S.F... just on the stool I was sitting at Swan Oyster Depot.
author: Javier J.

description: Top notch all around! Came here during the Polk Street Blues Festival a few weeks ago and amazingly, only had to wait in line for about 30 minutes. I've heard that folks have had to wait for up to 1 hour + to get a seat at the counter! The guys here are awesome-- friendly and terrific service! They even hooked us up with beer while we waited in line for a seat. Oysters were amazing and so was the shrimp cocktail! I'll definitely be back!
author: Angelina B.
