First of all, I am not comfortable when I see the staff scooped out the cooked crabs or shrimps with hands for seafood cocktail.  A bit of a hygiene issue for me.

The wait was about 40 min to 1 hr on Saturday, it is just a bit long.  Partly, I think the service is not that fast.  Our waiter is friendly, but they are really taking their time. Good for the people who have sat down, not the line.

Now, the choice, having lived in Boston for years, fresh oysters and clams of different varieties are available in many restaurants, so I don't think this place is any special.  But, I would admit this so far the second place I found to serve fresh clams, also cherry stones.  

Now, when add the price, I don't think there are any cheaper than restaurants.  For e.g., $10 for half dozen clams is usually the price in upscale restaurant at Boston.  As for the oysters, on average is $2+ each, almost typical restaurant price.  We tried the platter, got a lot of miyagi, new Zealand etc.... Think 9 out of 12 from different locations, only 3 Kumamoto, a little bit disappointed as we always like kumatoto and blue point oysters, another type, not included.   So, inquire the mixed types before ordering.

We also tried the smoked salmons, which I thought was the highlight.  Seafood cocktail is good too but the thought of them hand picking those cooked seafood just made it less enjoyable.  

Overall, we might try again if we happen to be around and no line, otherwise .... And, we spent $85 for 2, not cheap....
author: Bell C.

description:
Long ago during my past life, I used to work next door from Swan Depot at See's Candies. Ever since then I've seen lines after lines of people waiting to try their famous sea foods. Fast forward eleven years later, I finally came around to  seeing what all the hype is about. Outcome? part awe and part disappointment. So I came early like 10am- no lines thank god.

1 star - assorted choices of oysters (bay point, miyagi, and kumamoto)
1 star - awesome customer service and friendly vibes (the guys always came around to ask if we need anything and offer us tips on what to eat)
1 star -  clam chowder was delicious with lots of clams

minus 1 for the half shell crab. Nothing special..really. No special flavoring and I can get the same crab elsewhere for cheaper than 17.95 WITH the crab shell and not just the legs only.

minus 1 star was not taking cash and not giving us a total of how much everything cost but that's ok because asian people can calculate in their heads I guess (i kid)

Overall, I would go back just for the fresh oysters IF I was in the neighborhood.
author: Kelly C.

description:
Wednesday a little after 11:00 am.  Scored the last 3 seats in the house.  Looked over our backs 3 minutes later, a line was already forming...

My mom (visiting from Tokyo) got the combination salad, me and my friend (also visiting from Tokyo) each got a cup of chowder, the combination cocktail, and a beer.  I got mine with only crab and prawns because I don't really like clams, oysters, or the little shrimp.  I'm a pretty picky eater, especially with seafood.

When my friends combination cocktail came, the oyster that was on top fell off onto the table.  We both looked at each other, and I flagged the guy helping us over.  I pointed at the oyster, and he said, "Oh!!!" and proceeded to pick up the oyster from the table with his bare hands and plopped it right back on top as if it was the most natural thing to do in the world...

ONLY at Swan's do germophobes forget that germs actually exist.

As for us, we couldn't stop laughing.  Then continued eating our food as if nothing strange had just happened.

I live a couple blocks from this place, so I'll hop in when I'm walking by and there's no line and I'm lucky enough to have nowhere else to go.  My perfect meal here is the cup of chowder, crab and prawn cocktail, and beer.  I've had the combination salad a couple of times, but it's usually too much for me, and I'm not the biggest fan of the dressing.  The bread they serve there is really yummy and goes so well with the clam chowder.  The prawns are plump and juicy, and the crab, which they are very generous with, is really sweet and tasty.  I can understand why people would say the clam chowder is too watery, but I personally like it like that; more broth to dip my yummy bread in.  

This is the kind of place, especially after reading all the rave reviews about the oysters, that makes me wish I was a little more adventurous with my seafood...
author: Jennifer H.

description: This small seafood market located in Nob Hill is killer! The fresh seafood was displayed over ice in the front window. We ordered the famous crab salad, Boston clam chowder, and the combination raw oyster platter.  All were very tasty and delicious, and it was worth the wait. Make sure you bring cash because they don't accept credit cards.  The service as excellent, and the food was better! We will definitely go back the next time we visit San Francisco.
author: Cecillia N.

description: I have never stood in line for 2 hours for food EVER.  But it was not unpleasant at all!  Even with a long line, slither in and ask one of the guys behind counter for a beer. They will happily pour you a beer in a plastic cup and tell you  to "pay when you eat, pay later."  Once you sit down just enjoy. The guys (all related to each other) will happily give you great service. For a place with only about 30 bar stools, it's amazing that nobody rushes you at all.  They chat, joke and ask you questions about where you're from. The food was AMAZING.  Chowder, blue points, crab Louis salad.  The best.
author: Mur B.

description: Not only were the oysters amazing (every single one of them), but the service and ambiance were wonderful as well!
author: Dee G.

description: Finally made it back  to Swan Oyster depot. Waited in line for over an hour. Chatted with some really nice people in line, then heard someone say you can do take out. So to avoid the other hour we decided on takeout. Clam chowder super watery yuck! I was embarrassed because those lovely people in line I told how great the chowder was. And now I was so so wrong. What were they thinking serving that stuff? It had a foul tastes and super thin. Did they run out and toss together a batch on the fly? The crab cocktail was good, love their horseradish, and the bread was really good, but let's thank Boudins for that. Next time in town I'll go somewhere else.
author: Emmy M.

description:
The sea lives here.

While the wait can be daunting, there is no doubt, that this charming SF spot is enduring for a reason.

Every visit reminds me of why I love seafood, and at Swan's it's delivered in the most natural way, allowing you to truly taste the years of cultivated taste.

Recently, I came by with my mother, and while the wait was a good hour, once we were seated, we quickly let the legs rest and jumped into their clam chowder. It's a bit different here, not as thick as other places, more on the watery side, but the delicate flavors of the sea are crammed into each spoonful.

I highly recommend the Combination Salad, which is a cold bed of lettuce topped with chunks of crab meat, heavy amounts of shrimp, and finished with gigantic prawns. I ask for the dressing on the side, so I can truly enjoy the pieces on the salad.

The dressing is phenomenal though. Curb that diet, because this delightful thousand island dressing will make you earn it on the treadmill.

Obviously, if you're here, you must try the Oysters. We ordered a dozen blue point, and they will disappear faster than the line outside. You have your choice of horseradish, cocktail sauce and their home made dressing. All of which will only add to your love of your dozen.

Swans is a tiny venue, with only 12 stools, but what truly makes this place unique are the servers. We had the pleasure of having Michael work with us, and he was top notch. Warm, funny, and allowed us to maneuver through our meal with ease.

Michael embodies why Swan's has been around so long. Fantastic service, that has SF values at it's core. Seafood straight from the sea, and served with unabashed straightforwardness.

This is a SF must, and while at some point in the line you may think of ejecting and satisfying your hunger somewhere else, stay put, and get ready to enter into seafood radiance.
author: Mike K.

description: Great food. Heard it was worth the 90 minute wait and it was.  Jimmy was interesting and funny.  Had a few of most everything and it was all great!  The cold Stella when we got to the front of the line was perfect!
author: Scott B.

description:
Be prepared to wait in line for this place....but it's so worth the wait!!  It's very small (probably 15 seats max) and only has bar seating.  The seafood is so fresh and we tried:

1) shrimp cocktail and beer special
2) combo salad
3) smoked salmon (A MUST HAVE) - tasted like butter, if thats even possible

I probably shouldn't be telling you this since it means the more people who know about this the longer I have to wait in line, but I'll share...just this once.
author: ellainne v.

description:
When you're 1000+ Yelps into San Francisco life, it's always nice to find a place that makes you feel like you're discovering the city's charm for the first time.  And Swan's is one of those places--whoever said it was a "tourist trap" or "over-hyped" obviously got stuck in line too long (we had no problem at 11:00 on a weekday).  So come in, hang your coat on the wall, grab a stool at the counter, and prepare to receive the sea's bounty.

Now normally I don't find oysters to be worth the sticker shock, but fortunately I was going on the company's dime so I was able to just focus on deciding what deliciousness I wanted to sample.  Even then, as a relative novice I found the disjointed menu on the wall a bit overwhelming.  Fortunately, the guys who work the bar are consummate masters of dishing out sage (and friendly) advice.  In the end I got to try 2 kinds of oyster (dipped in horseradish, vinegar, and cocktail sauce), a cup of clam chowder, and a plate of smoked trout and salmon with bread and butter.  My colleagues swear allegiance to the hefty crab salad, but I demurred this time as the local crab season hadn't started yet.
author: Wes M.

description:
Nice oysters. About 8 dollars for half a dozen and there are four kinds of oysters. It came with horse radish and cocktail sauce which when mixed with lemon juice is delicious.

I liked the prawn cocktail for 8.50 which came with cocktail sauce too. It was slightly overly salty though. They must have put too much salt into the water they used to boil the shrimp. I got maybe seven prawns in a small cocktail glass which was plenty for me.

We also had the mixed seafood salad for 15.75. It had small shrimp, prawns, crab meat, and lettuce with louie dressing on the side. It was a nice combination.

Everything was tasty and fresh but seating was very uncomfortable-- the stools were cutting into my thighs. I think getting this food to go would be nicer. 

Service was friendly. It wasn't cheap but it was a good value for what it was. Call ahead of time for a to go order and leave the wait and uncomfortable stools for the others.
author: Lorissa W.

description:
My love of raw oysters can be firmly indulged in this small depot.  

This is a true leftover of a bygone era.  Old working class bar where you seat yourself and order from the menu on the wall.  It's not that difficult as your choices are limited to seafood, seafood, and more seafood.  And most of it is served straight up so there's no fancy French phrases to read through and try to make sense of.

I love love love the clam chowder soup here.  You can tell it's home made and not all thickened up with flour or corn starch.  It's runny and oh so clam-my.  Even if you don't like it runny you have to admit the flavor is superb.  Not like most other places where it just tastes like stock with potatoes and thickener and some small chunks of clam thrown in.

And oysters.  You can get a sampler of different oysters to slurp up with your choice of sauces (though I prefer mine with a dash of lemon and nothing else).

I didn't find it difficult to get seated here.  Try to come before noon on a weekday.  Weekends are packed.  I always see people lining up to go and think how lucky I am to work in the city where I could go every single day if I wanted to!

Very jealous of the regulars here who get called by name and greeted by all the staff.  I wannabe a regular!

Bike Parking: designated bike racks across the street on Polk St.
author: Jean K.

description:
4 stars for quality fresh seafood. 
2 stars for old old decor and seating--- heck, its tradition.
Its all about the fresh sea food appetizers.
Kumamoto's are a Fav: sweet , slighly briny and succulent. Get a pint of your fav. brew. Only open for lunch. 
customer service: eh...kinda slow.
author: Bert K.

description: I came here with one other person during an odd hour on a Saturday...something like 3 PM. Our wait was still incredibly long as the line moves slow. Very friendly service, delicious seafood, and after a 2 hour wait in the rain...still worth it. I think that many of the other reviews for Swan Oyster Depot have already covered how wonderful this place is!
author: Vienna L.

description: 45 min wait and then we had to leave. Would've been another hour. Cooks were taking their time without any hustle so this place must take their customers for granted. Not worth it - went to a competitor near by and it was great!
author: Chris L.

description: I was excited to try this place after a coworker recommended it and forwarded a glowing review from Bon Appetit magazine. Went for lunch with the Mr. and happened to come on a weekday with no long line up. We each had a bowl of chowder and split a dozen oysters. The chowder base had a spotty, broken appearance, like it had separated. It tasted fine but didn't have too much in the way of clam and potato pieces. The oysters were fresh but poorly shucked - we both found ourselves biting on shards of shell more than once. That was most disappointing, considering that's something they do a lot and what people come for. Others around us were eating some shrimp salads that didn't look all that appetizing with the iceberg lettuce, mini salad shrimp, and creamy dressing. For our meal and 2 beers, it was about 50 bucks. I don't think we'll be back.
author: Lala K.

description: It's a little mom and pop restaurant run by a family of just the guys. Great prices, the oysters are super fresh, and the clam chowder was great.
author: Anthony A.

description:
If it were possible, I'd give this place zero stars.  

The clam chowder was horrible. Read through some of the lesser-ratings, and a pattern emerges - the clam chowder is watery, greasy, contains almost no clam and no potato and thus no flavor. Come on San Francisco - this cannot the chowder to represent our city. 

The seafood was fresh. But that's not so special in our fair city. Here, they drowned everything in thousand island dressing and cocktail sauce - boring!  

The atmosphere is unique - old-fashioned diner style. But with the long line and counter sitting, it didn't make for a pleasant dining experience. 

There are so many other great seafood options in the City. Skip this one.
author: Lyna F.

description:
best local ambience experience in all of San Francisco...never disappoint always satisfy and lord the clam chowder! the Oysters! the Stella on tap! the oyster crackers! the horseradish! the mignonette! I wish I could bring myself to order anything but these delicious favorites of mine but I think they're the best in the world so maybe some day I will find the strength to order something else...or starve myself and go in and eat it all!
The staff is the best at what they do! Go try some!
author: Chris D.

description: Get here early. I went on a Friday morning. I was there at 10:30 in the morning and already there was a line. We got a dozen oysters, smoked salmon, clam chowder and the crab back. I am not the biggest fan of raw oysters but now that I have tried these I do like them. Each of the ones I tried had a different taste and the radish was spicy but oh so good. The clam chowder I didn't care for. A little too clammy in taste and too watery. I like my clam chowder a little thicker. Smoked salmon was good and I didn't try the crab back but my friends loved it.
author: Christy P.

description: Always wanted to check this place for a long time. Finally got here to SF,arrive by 5:00 their was a line already. Waited for bout 45m,but it was worth it. If you guys love seafood this is a must try. The staff are very nice and they know product and the oysters r excellent.
author: Noel Q.

description:
There is probably a debate between which oyster place is better in SF, Swan or Hog's.  I think the oysters are about the same, but I like the chowder a little bit more at Hog's.  

But the really great thing about Swan's, and the reason that I come back here every time that I am in SF, is that they open at 8am.  And since I usually have a list of restaurants that I want visit each time I come to SF, I can always come to Swan's for a great breakfast of oysters and a cup of clam chowder.   So I highly recommended coming here for breakfast if you are only going to be up for a weekend.
author: Patrck C.

description:
the first thing that meets you when you find this place is the insanely long queue. The place accepts only up to 20 people each seating. BUT DO NOT LEAVE. It is worth every minute of the wait!!!

we had the blue point oysters and combination seafood salad. It was pure bliss eating it. The seafood was EXTREMELY fresh and bursting with so much flavour!
author: Ding Fang C.

description: Best seafood in the city!  My family and I have been coming here for years.  We are never disappointed.  The wait is well worth it.  We generally get the combination salad with a cold Anchor Steam.
author: Ted J.

description: Fresh oysters. Their shrimp cocktail is different but good. The seafood salad is good and they give actually give a lot of seafood on it! The seafood salad is a must.
author: Holly C.

description:
Arrived at about 11:30am on a Saturday and did not have to wait at all.  Even got street parking with a broken meter!

Yes, this place is not super clean, the counter could definitely use an upgrade but it would take away from the "fisherman's boat" type of ambience.  However, look beyond that and look at the food.

Started off with two Stella's on tap at $4 a glass, then a dozen oyster variety platter, bread and butter, two crab heads, then a crab salad and a combination salad and topped off lunch with another crab head.

The salads had heaps of seafood so it was good.  Where else can you get seafood w/o peeling a thing?  The crab was fresh and I pretty much passed on the lettuce.  Total out the door for 2 was around $80 for lunch.  Yes, pricey but seafood is not cheap.
author: Benny M.

description:
This has got to be the best fresh seafood/chowder place I've ever been to.  I came here once as a teenager but didn't remember it.  I re-discovered it from Yelp and came here again.  

We actually came here twice within a 3 day time space.  Over the 2 visits, we ordered Prawn Cocktail, Crab Cocktail, Clam Cocktail, Oyster Platter, Clam Chowder and Sourdough Bread.

Everything was very good, although I could have done without the clam cocktail (very fishy tasting).  Im not normally a big oyster fan, but they were very good here, especially with the garnish sauces.

The best thing here is the clam chowder.  Many people complain that it's too watery/soupy and not thick like they're used to having it.  I knew this going in and the chowder DEFINITELY makes up in flavor what it lacks in thickness.  You really can taste the clams in the chowder.  Dipping the fresh sourdough in the chowder is one of the best things you will ever eat in your life.
author: Sushi X.

description:
Can't find a better seafood joint in the city.  Although not a big space to sit down and have a leisurely meal, the place still seats 15 people for a quick seafood fix.  

I've been dying to come here, but their hours has put a lot of limitation on me.  Plus, Saturdays crowd is a little intimidating and I'm rarely patient enough to wait through it all.  I've tried the clam chowder, oysters, smoked trout and a taste of their ahi.  So fresh, highly recommend you to give this place a shot.

Another plus is the family owned business; all the employees are very pleasant and enjoy working there.  Oh and my FAVORITE part of this place, their window display.  Love the way they layout the food.
author: Laura H.

description:
I pass by this place all the time and wonder what the heck is this line for? I will never wait that long for seafood. ok i lied i will.

Heads up...if you want fancy this is not the place to be. 

Always have a long wait but  you just have to pick the right time to go. I don't really mind waiting because they will give you a glass of wine while you wait by the door. Seating's are limited to around 10 people or so at a time. Staffs are super friendly and quick. 

Scallop sashimi, Italian style is soooo refreshing! It's not on the menu but ask for it! Must try the cherry clams, clams and different kinds of oysters. They are sooo fresh. 

I love their business card and if you want to know why...ask for one!
author: Amy L.

description: Tiny little place. Went around lunch and there was a line out the door. The line moves pretty quick and is worth it! We sat at the bar and all of the fish surrounding me looked beautiful and fresh fresh fresh! The place has an old world feel and the service is basic. The oysters and shrimp cocktail I ordered were delicious and very flavorful. Next time I go I really want to take home some of the beautiful scallops I noticed in the front window as I walked out. This is a special little place with a lot of charm. Great place to bring a visitor. If you order a lot of things the bill can get pricey quick, other wise the place is a star in my book!
author: Chelsey G.

description:
I've never waited in line so long for anything in my life.  Really.  1.5 hours I think.  With my parents.

But it was worth it!  It's just an experience you have to do.  Quintessential old SF.

Find out when the lines are not so long and go.

I complemented the smoked salmon and they gave me a plate of it.  That's the kind of gruff, honest, cool, personal service they have.  I like that.

The food is perfect.
author: Nate P.

description: Coming from Colorado, good sea food is nonexistent, so when in San Francisco, I only expect the best.  Swan Oyster Depot is simply amazing and delicious. Bourdain turned me onto the place, so I had to try it. The oysters are amazing, shrimp and crab cocktails to die for, and last but not least, order the crab fat! It's not on the menu, but in my opinion the best dish I had while visiting. If you are adventurous and like trying new things, order the crab fat, trust me. The staff was wonderful and fun. Being a first time customer and recent college graduate, they took care of me (cheers). Now for everyone complaining about the line, shut up. I stood in line for 45 minutes (which in my opinion is not bad at all). Most people will wait this to eat at a crappy chain, so if you prefer that, then have fun at the fisherman's wharf, otherwise the wait is well worth it.
author: Ryan S.

description:
So my Fiancé and I ventured to San Jose for a weekend for a wedding and decided to travel to San Fran for some seafood. 

I'm so glad we decided to avoid the tourist stomping grounds for a local gem. The wait was 40min, but it was kind of fun. Everyone waiting in anticipation for the goodness inside, eavesdropping on the conversations of what to order and swan depot veterans speak of how often they go really made it a tad bit more exciting (Especially seeing the fresh goodness that was sitting at the window).

Once inside you see the menu on the wall, beer on tap, fresh sea goodies and a long counter for people to sit and a group of guys who know how to shuck an oyster and open a crab like champs. Once a spot is available, toss your coats and purses on the hook on the wall behind the counter and order your grub. 

Everything we got was fantastic, good sourdough bread, Combination Salad, Smoked salmon that came with a mini shrimp salad, crab head/back (its free just ask for one or two and add some of their house habanero salsa/sauce, lemon and vinegar and dip away with bread.. YUM!), clam chowder and 6 blue oysters and 6 clams. IT WAS ALL AWESOME AND FRESH.  

Add what I listed with 2 beers, and the total for everything was $80. Not bad for two people with hangovers and who couldn't drink more. I was stuffed and happy! 

Kudos to the staff for making it a great experience. They were all helpful, and they made everything feel so laid back. I felt like I was having a beer and lunch with a bunch of friends. Honestly, you end up sitting close to people you don't know, so if they make it feel relaxed and fun you end up making temporary counter friends. 

The only warnings I can think of is 1- If you like thick clam chowder, this is not the chowder for you BUT it is yummy and 2- Make sure you are ready with the cash to pay. No plastic, all natural here. 

So check it out, it's worth the wait and you will enjoy it!
author: Erisa C.

description:
I'm not a counter guy, but there is 1 place I eat at the counter. Now that list has grown to 2 places. So, be prepaired to sit at a counter with uncomfortable chairs at Swan Oyster Depot.

The service was some of the best I have received from this fine city.....

Oysters = had a dozen & they where very good. Not watery at all 
smoked salmon on sourdough = very tasty. No fishy taste. 
sashimi platter = fresh & an absolute must. 
Smoked trout = was very moist for being smoked fish. 
crab salad = was delicious. 
calamari salad = maybe not next time. (they where out of Squid)
author: A. B.

description:
On a typical afternoon in sunny San Francisco,  you'll find a peculiarly long line, flowing out the front door of a cubby-sized restaurant in Nob Hill. Tormenting passer by-ers with a tantalizing display of mouthwatering buckets of fresh, vibrantly-colored seafood - I was left defenseless to this seafood lover's utopia. Yes, even after having brunch, a tall cup of coffee, and indulging in a mid-day dessert from a few blocks down the street - I still stopped in my tracks. I should have kept treading up the hill, walking off my satiation -  but there's always a bit of room left for fresh oysters and clam chowder for any seafood lover, right? It was nearing lunch time, so I made my excuse and sneaked in line for a quick bite. Don't judge! I mean, you really can't call yourself a real seafood lover, and not enjoy the freshest of seafood, sent straight from the Wharf by the San Francisco Bay.  And with fresh scallops, maine lobster, smoked salmon, clams on a half shell, and three different kinds of oysters on display - it was more of an automatic attraction, than an actual decision I had to make. I had to stop by.

After hanging your coat on the wall behind you, sit down and rest your arms on a gorgeous slab of solid white marble that's been at Swan's for over 100 years. Serving fresh seafood that's as simple, and wonderfully timeless as that white marble top is only one of the many reasons to love this place. Here, you'll always have a front row view of how each dish is prepared - another comforting example of the confidence they have in the freshness of their food.

The only menu they have is the one on the wall, and even that changes from day to day - depending on what is in season. Whether it's crab, oysters, and (sometimes) even sea urchin - there's always something wonderful to enjoy at Swan's. Their baked sourdough bread was perfect for dipping in their creamy clam chowder soup, and as I waited for the rest of my food - I got to enjoy watching servers shuck fresh oysters, throw together colorful seafood salads, and carve delicate slices of smoked salmon while enjoying a glass of chilled chardonnay. Sure, it's still a bar without a TV - but with the front row entertainment, I couldn't have cared less.

The shrimp cocktail, and oysters were so fresh and delicious by themselves, that tartar and cocktail sauce became unnecessary. This was easily my favorite part of the entire meal, and I ate each little piece of shrimp, one by one like it was buttered popcorn at a movie theatre. It's like tasting a slice of margherita pizza in Napoli - you'll find it remade in several other corners of the world, but you'll never find it as fresh and as perfect as you would at it's original home. And providing the freshest of seafood, and serving it clean, and absolutely untouched to let its' original flavors shine through is why Swan's Oyster Depot is such a popular favorite among seafood lovers. Polk street is full of delicious little eateries, and foodie favorites - but be sure to make a quick visit to this little seafood bar. This is the way fresh seafood should be enjoyed, and a great experience for vacationers who may not have the opportunity to taste such fresh seafood back in their hometown.

Click Here for the Full Review: http://thehungrymuse.com/2011/03/20/the-hungry-muse/a-fresh-off-the-boat-feast/
author: Jennie T.

description:
Swan Oyster Depot has the best smoked salmon I have had in San Francisco.  Served with shrimp salad and sourdough bread on the side, along with a little plate of chopped onions and capers, its a real classic.  I also like the clam chowder here, the dungeness crab, and of course, the oysters! 

If you come in the middle of the day you will be fighting with tourists and locals for a seat--the space inside is actually the opposite of "a storehouse or warehouse" (Webster's definition of a "depot").  Instead of a Home Depot-like cavernous space, you get a counter with about 15 seats in a row.  The perpetual fight for a seat keeps this place from 5 stars.  The service is good though, as long as you remember to flag down one of the guys behind the counter if you aren't approached first.

I like this place for a smoked salmon breakfast, when you get here early enough, crowds are not an issue.
author: Aaron S.

description: Yes the line is long. Yes the prices are a little high. But the vibe of this place is unique and priceless. Old time San Francisco Bay Area seafood bar. The food was as fresh as if it just came from the boat, and watching them with the fish carts outside it likely did!  Worth the wait for your first time. Sometimes you can get lucky and catch them when they're not so busy. I've never had luck ordering takeout but it's not deterred me from coming back!  Great little gem!!
author: Jamil S.

description:
Though I've been going to Swan since I was a toddler, I will never tire of the top notch seafood and cheery familial service. 

The clam chowder is amazing, served up with Boudin sourdough bread if you wish. The freshest oysters are from all over, with a dribble of lemon juice and horseradish, or minionette, yum yum. A dozen of those delicious sliders make my entire day more pleasurable. 

When our local crab is in season, be prepared for the best you've ever had! The crabs from up north on the Pacific Coast are scrumptious too. A glass of Anchor Steam beer or muscadet is a perfect pairing for anything you might like to eat.

A line for counter-only seating forms Monday through Saturday by around 10:30 a.m. so get there early, or prepare to chat with people from all over while you wait for a seat at the counter. I usually go to Swan alone and rarely have to wait, no matter what time of day.

Lots of folks drop by to pick up seafood to prepare at home, and Swan delivers in most parts of the City.

Swan is undoubtedly one of the best, authentic San Francisco eateries.
author: Steep R.

description:
Scrumptious food indeed! 

Anything from clam chowder to wide variety of oysters (combination plate is the best for novice), and a must have "combination salad"-a generous portion of lobster, crab and other fish is added to the salad with house sauce. Your mouth will begin to water just looking at them preparing it. 

On the weekend, the wait could be up to an hour, but believe me, all the torture will be forgotten as soon as u have a first bait at Swan's.

Oh yes, and don't forget to order their local amber ale!
author: Alex N.

description: Overrated and overpriced. I understand that I'm paying for fresh seafood (yes, it was fresh) and partly for the decor/charm/history (yes, it was charming). The seafood salad was tasty, but c'mon - some pieces of crab and shrimps on top of regular lettuce with some louie dressing for almost $25? Additionally, I had heard so many good things about the chowder - the flavor was fine, but it seemed watered down, and there were only 2 measly pieces of potato/clams floating around. Unacceptable, especially with a 2 hour wait in line. I'd rather spend my money at Sotto Mare in the North End for some great seafood.
author: Connie L.

description:
Love this place, the oysters are so fresh and tasty, and the atmosphere is very unique
Worth the waiting time, it's a must try if you love fresh oysters!
author: Veronica M.

description:
I used to wonder why this place always have such a long line...I mean, you really can't tell from the outside what draw people in.  Then I decided to find out first hand w/ a friend...waited in line like others (luckily, we got there early so the wait was very minimal) and sat along the counter (20 total?).  Ok, cold beer is in order and it was a good deal...then it was the seafood salad w/ loads of shrimp and crab, yum!  Oysters...man, I love oysters...and these were fresh!  Clam chowder - clams in every spoonful and it's the perfect texture, not too watery or thick...YUMMMM!  

The guys (brothers and cousins?) are fantastic!  Fun and personal, you know they are having a good time and they let you join in on the fun!  We had a great time and look forward to the next visit.
author: Gloria H.

description:
This place is simply classic.  Simple and Very Fresh seafood.  If you're a tourist...skip Fisherman's Wharf and come straight here for some classic seafood.  

Crab, Shrimp, Oysters, Chowder...etc, etc.  Family run, you'll see three generations side by side working and offering good old fashioned service.  They are all pretty friendly and you can see they take great pride in the food they're serving.  Be prepared to wait but once you get a seat there's no need to rush, grab some wine or a beer...order a dish, enjoy, relax, finish...then peruse the menu once again and order another little dish.
author: Rafael s.

description:
Wait....

This is a DAMN Fine Oyster BAR!  -especially if Agent Dale Cooper visited Swan Oyster Depot.
author: Allison B.

description: This place is very overrated I've been here a couple of times, having both the crab and prawn louis salad, oysters, clam chowder and although it's fresh and good the prices, uncomfortable seating, waiting and hygiene is something to be desired. The workers touch the counter rags, money and grab the food without washing hands or using gloves.
author: N A.

description:
The freshest seafood in the City hands down.

I used to go here and they had a chowder and pint of beer combo, it was awesome but they dont serve it anymore.

They do still serve the best damn shrimp/crab louie salad around.  Try the chowder and the smoked salmon, awesome.

Great staff too.

SF institution.

GO early to avoid the line.
author: Richard N.

description:
There comes a time when a Yelper really can't say anything else because it's all been said.

FIVE STARS and if I could give more I WOULD!

If it's your first time, try the clam chowder (but don't expect it to be creamy and $6 like Boudin's) and their combination seafood cocktail because you'll get a little taste of everything. 

Next time I go back, I'm simply going to get a platter of the blue point oysters... I've never tasted any seafood so fresh and delicious in my life.

Love it...
author: Lynn C.

description:
The place is small, and everyone is seated next to each other at a bar. There's no public restroom, and it's cash only. It's a little hole in the wall type of place, and they still use this old cash register that looks like it's been there since they opened the place.
But all of this just adds to the fabulousness that is the Swan Oyster Depot. The food is SUPER fresh, oysters and clams on the half shell, crab, shrimp, and seafood salads, crab, shrimp and clam cocktails and delicious clam chowder. 
Wanna get great value? Go to the Swan Oyster Depot!
In addition, the BEST most fabulous service ever. These guys are so nice and friendly!
author: Marisa O.

description: Perfect for a swan song or an every day meal.  I would like this to be the place I have my last meal on earth.  Everything at Swan's appeals to me, from the slightly sullen but funny service to the wonderfully fresh, heaped helpings of crab-salad to the very thin but oh, so delicious clam chowder.  Two things to keep in mind when you visit:  they only have a tiny counter and no tables so there is almost always a wait to get in and they only take cash.  Outstanding oysters,  crustaceous crab, luscious lobster and smokin' smoked salmon! The seats at the counter are rickety and a little uncomfortable but the seafood is so delectable that you'll forget that soon.  If you haven't been lucky enough to eat at Swan's, gather up your cash and hurry on over for a first class meal!
author: Warwick M.

description:
Fresh seafood? What's not to like?

I live in the 'hood and made it in for the first time recently, after a month of ill-fated attempts at doing so. 

Let me preface my account of the food by stating that I typically prefer breakfast to be the first meal of the day. You know, eggs, pancakes, granola, cereal. Not seafood. That's ok though, Swan made me forget all that.

My girlfriend and I walk in at 8:15 on a Saturday morning. There are always lines out the door, so we figured this would be a perfect time to beat the crowd. This proved to be correct, as we were the first ones there.

The menu is super simple - chowder, seafood salads, cocktails, oysters and whatever else they catch and haul in that day. We went for the chowder, the crab salad, and oysters. Oysters to begin with, oysters again after we finished the rest of our food. The chowder was tasty - and actually had nicely sized chunks of clam in it. It wasn't too salty either. The crab salad was your ordinary salad with lump crab sitting atop. Delicious. I could taste the ocean on that one. The oysters - kumamoto, hama hama - were also very fresh and tasted great with a squeeze of lemon or horseradish sauce. 

All in all, this place met and exceeded all of my expectations. If you're expecting sophisticated entrées, fancy decór, or fast food prices, then I'd recommend taking your money elsewhere. If on the other hand, you love fresh fruit from the sea and don't mind paying for it, then this place has your name written all over it.
author: Zach F.

description:
Since my friend is from Vegas where they only get frozen oysters (meaning they taste like ice when you eat them raw), I wanted her to try what "fresh raw oysters" were like.  I took her to Swan's.

It took us half an hour of waiting in line to get seated.  However, once we were seated, the service was friendly, fast, and enjoyable.  We had ordered a cup of clam chowder and a oyster sampler platter that was devoured fast and enjoyed immensely.

I'm definitely coming again for more oysters!
author: Anna V.

description: My experience here began with an almost two hour wait in line outside the restaurant before I actually got to eat.  Even still, the wait was over and when we entered the restaurant, the staff was courteous and outgoing.  I loved the vibe of that hole-in-the-wall restaurant where the staff is not afraid to interact with everyone in the restaurant.  We got the crab salad and the clam chowder.  Probably the best clam chowder I've ever had!  It's not overly creamy and it's filled with spoonfuls of clam meat.  It was delicious and satisfied my clam chowder craving for the day.  The crab salad was so fresh and tasty, yet such a simple concept.  Overall, the experience in the restaurant was fast and memorable.  I don't know if I would ever revisit with a line that long, but worth trying on some off hours of the day.
author: Debbie C.

description:
This place has awesome oysters and delicious clams, and even better their staff is GREAT.  

The seafood was fresh, the clam chowder was yummy, and the combo seafood salad was seriously amazing!!!  

I really enjoyed this place because of the friendliness of the staff, freshness of the seafood, and deliciousness of the food.  They have a descent selection of oysters and the prices are super reasonable.

Definitely go early though because the line starts to form at approximately 12 noon.
author: Red J.

description:
I've been a FAN of this place for the last 13 years. 
We last went on a weekday to start of my husbands birthday. We had everything you can imagine. 

The OYSTER SAMPLER PLATTER consist of Blue Point, Miyagi (my fav), & Kumamoto oysters. Which can be eaten alone or with their mignonette sauce. This is heaven. It goes great with beer...yes, beer at 11AM in the morning.

The SHRIMP COCKTAIL is oh so good. You can taste the ocean in your mouth and you just can't stop. You can ask for a side of freshly grated horseradish on the side if you want to add some heat on it. 

The CRAB SALAD is great and fresh. The juicy morsel of chunky crab meat is succulent and the best part is you don't have to pick it off the shell which can get a little annoying when you are supper hungry. 

Leave some room for some of their homemade CLAM CHOWDER you wont regret it. 

TIPS: Get here early! Once they are out of the fresh seafood they will close the doors. The place is a narrow tiny little bar located in lower nob hill. You can find street parking easily or park at the Holiday Inn just a block away. It's hard to miss the place when you can see a stretch of hungry folks waiting to get in. 

Ask for their business card. It's printed on a paper thin sponge that can easily be hydrated with a little water and can be used as a regular sponge at home. Pretty nifty!
author: Rhodora E.

description:
I'm very torn about not giving this place 5 stars. But I can't just assign a rating willy-nilly, and I can't help but compare this place to my first love: Hog Island at the Ferry Building. It is a difficult comparison though, due to the fact that the only thing these places have in common is that they serve excellent seafood and they are both located in San Francisco. But where they are located is very different and the feel is very very different. 

There is bar seating only and not much of it compared to the crowd it draws. Having passed by this place before, I've seen the line that goes out the door, so it was daunting to actually decide when to go. Multiple attempts to schedule visits to Swan with friends ultimately fell through. Finally, this morning (Saturday) when I woke up at the crack of noon, I decided to suck it up and brave the line alone as I'm temporarily living within a few blocks of Swan. I got there around 12:30 and was very pleasantly surprised when the line only barely stretched out the door. There was a trio and a couple ahead of me with beers in hand because they take drink orders for people waiting in line. Having never been there before and not knowing what to do, I asked the couple ahead of me what the deal with the line was, whether I needed to put my name down or anything like that. They said you just get in line, though people ordering to-go could bypass the line. They also told me that if it was just me, there were probably a few stray available seats. I walked in to take a look and indeed immediately found a seat. So basically, my wait was less than 5 minutes. 

The seating was cozy but not too bad. There was no place to put my purse except my lap, but I just don't really like to put it on the floor. It took a little while to put in my drink order (Anchor Steam, of course! The other choices are Bud and Stella), but once I got a server, everything was good. It's a little chaotic behind the bar just because its not like each server is assigned to a certain spot; it's just a matter of whose eye you catch. The menu is on the wall, so thank goodness I brought my glasses. 

Having skimmed the other yelp reviews, I determined to get a bowl of the clam chowder and a half dozen oysters. Man, oysters really are an expensive habit, but so worth it. $13 for a half dozen. Now, I'm not at all a person who ever orders off menu, so I just go off of what I see. The menu had an option for half dozen (Blue Point?) oysters, or there was a mixed option for the dozen. When I ordered, however, the server very helpfully suggested that I could get the half dozen mixed as well. So, I was glad to be able to try 3 different kinds of oysters. I can't quite remember the names of the oysters, just where they were from. The Maine oysters, I didn't like too much as they were too big. Despite my love for oysters, there is still a part of me super-squicked out about the idea of consuming these things raw. The local ones were okay, but the Washington ones were by far the best. I don't think they were the Kunamoto, as I don't think that's what he said. But I appreciated that he took the time to tell me which ones were which and about the mignonettes. He asked if I wanted cocktail sauce, which I rejected, because I hate cocktail sauce and I think eating oysters  is a wasted experience if you dump cocktail sauce on there. 

I didn't like the clam chowder as much as some of the other reviewers. I like thicker chowders (and I think I also prefer them with bacon...). It was still pretty good, but I think I'll try something else next time. But for $5, definitely one of the cheaper options at Swan. 

I like that bread and butter is not complimentary. Well, it may as well be since it is only a dollar. But I don't really like bread anyway-- it usually goes generally untouched by me unless I'm starving, so I'm always feeling guilty about the wasted bread. However, when the server asked me if I wanted bread, I was caught off guard and so overwhelmed by the place that I just agreed. But paying for the bread, even just one dollar, gives me more incentive to eat it, and I used it to sop up the chowder, which made the meal a little heartier. 

You also have to ask for water. I actually really like the restaurants that do that because it saves water. I personally do tend to drink the water, but have seen so many people not even touch theirs. 

I really like their simple bare bones operation, the fantastic service, and the excellent seafood. I think I'll go for one of the seafood salads or the crab next time. And if I've saved up for the month, the lobster. Though I'll probably bring a friend for the lobster. My only trepidation about going again is that my timing will not always be so great. Once I left today, around 1:30, the line was out the door.
author: Jia min C.

description:
The first thing you notice when you come here is the line going down the block. There is only one bar to sit at so its not a fast moving line either but it's well worth the wait.

As soon as you get past the the threshold of the the restaurant you are given the chance to order a drink while you finish your wait. The staff there is great. Always very friendly and helpful. 

We got clam chowder which might be the best I've ever had. We also had smoked salmon, oysters, and the combination salad. Everything was amazing. If you are in San Francisco you have to do yourself a favor and stop by. The wait is long, but that's because its a great place to eat.
author: Frank J.

description:
Swan is my kind of birdie, especially when it tastes like raw oyster.  I've been here many times over the years, and I still enjoy it just as much as I did the first time.  The oysters are always good, and when they're local and in season, they're wonderful.  The key is to ask whoever's attending to you which ones are the freshest and most local.  And also, remember that any month with an "r" in it means oyster season.  If you like crabs, they also have good crab.  I'd get the seafood cocktail, and just ask for extra crab if you wish.  Stay away from the seafood salad, unless you dig iceberg lettuce.

I enjoy everything about this place-the cramped space, the wiry benches, the lunch counter setup, the junk on the walls, the helter skelter vibe, the seafoody smell, the hat hooks behind the counter, all of it.  It's very San Francisco in my opinion, and great for snapshots, which I've taken many.

There's always seems to be a line at Swan, especially at mealtime.  I've never had to wait, however, even on saturdays.  All you do is plan to have an early brunch and arrive between 10 and 11am.  They open at 8am, so you can even have breakfast there, thouth that's a bit early for an Anchor.  

If you get to know any of the people who work there, they many even hand you a special treat!
author: Roland C.

description: The freshest Seafood Depot gents behind the counter at Swans in San Francisco have a good time while they douse deliciously unhealthy amounts if homemade 1000 Island dressing on top my long sought-after plate of fresh prawns, lobster and shrimp salad. Don't mind the chopped iceberg, but do request the personalized portion of in-front-of-you made dijon vinaigrette. The 30 minute wait was greatly rewarded by the nicest, happiest, and most content hunk of bread, pats of butter, and a glass of chilled white to accompany the freshest seafood salad devoured in Forever! Grateful that I stayed through the wait and the crazy lady-patron who's back pains aren't her only problem, I was fed and able to still catch my 2:30 flight! Charmed & fed am I. A toast to the bartender at Murphy's Pub in the Financial District, who's draw was their painted façade advertising fish and chips. Mama wanted fish. Bartender was an honest lady. Mama got het fish quickly and handsomly at Swans!!
author: Gina P.

description: The smoked salmon is so silky and delicious. With rye bread it's low cal and full of flavor. I noticed flowers on the counter and a cleaner ambiance today. Still, the money and fish handling should not coexist. That's my only gripe.
author: Kelly K.

description: Absolutely love this place!!! The atmosphere is very casual. Depending on the time of day you go, you could be waiting in line for quite some time, but no worries, they staff will offer you a beer while you wait. Once you sit down, the only question will be is how much stuff you can afford to get haha. The oysters are amazing!!!! The Italian style scallop sashimi is also awesome. The smoked salmon is great. Basically everything I have had there has been so so good, I just want to keep trying more stuff. Still on my list is the combination seafood cocktail and the seafood salad. Im sure I will be amazed at both once I try them. This is my go to spot in the city.
author: Kathrine A.

description: I love it here, but hadn't been back in years. We decided to take a chance on a Wednesday afternoon and as luck would have it, they was a big smelly smoking tar truck outside, and only 3 people in line! Ha! We were seated in less then 10 minutes. I'm sure that will never happen again! Everything was delicous as usual. The crab salad, the oysters, fresh horseradish.
author: Lisa K.

description: Always a long line, be prepared to wait. The hours are pretty shitty (I think they're 9-5). BUT you can get better oysters anywhere in the city. Incredible every time. The crab is bomb, too, their cocktail sauce kills the game.
author: Brit F.

description:
They filleted a bunch of the fattiest pieces from an extremely high quality piece of salmon, and served it to me on bread, with oyster crackers, capers, and onions nearby. Sure, it wasn't anything fancy. But it was all I wanted, and the taste stayed in my mouth for hours after that.

I also like their "New England friendliness" - they're not immediately the most warm people ever and they love to joke around, but they will do whatever they can to make sure you have the best experience.

And a free sponge!
author: Mark A.

description:
What is the point of Yelping your trip to San Francisco where everything has 400+ reviews? Why, to make a list of course! 

The people behind the counter were amazing. They were all super friendly and very out going. Plus, it's fun to see them pouring all of the liquids and cups of ice at their feet. They must have some amazing non-slip mats back there. 

The food was tasty.  Everything tastes fresh.  The oysters had great flavor. I'm not a big fan of their cocktail sauce though. That was the only thing I thought was lacking in flavor. 

This is a really cool place to go if you want to introduce someone to the world of raw oysters. For a decent price you can sample three types and they are more than happy to explain the differences to you. 

It's a great experience, especially if you're a tourist.
author: Jenna C.

description:
I ate here with my boyfriend when he drove me home from LA, and I must say the Blue point oysters and clam chowder are to die for.  Our first experience was soooo amazing that we made it a point to go here every time we go to SF to visit my parents.  

The MUST eat: 

Blue point oysters (at least a dozen for myself)
Clam chowder and their local bakery bought bread
Cherry clams 

The "OK" eat: 

seafood salads 
all the other oysters

seating is very limited so go early or late in the afternoon, just not at lunch time, but there is always a wait regardless.
author: JY L.

description:
seats are limited with lines out the door for at least 30 minutes.  i though i was waiting for a ride at the amusement park!!

try the oysters, chowder, and the crab!  DELICIOUS
author: Munsok S.

description:
Fresh! Nice Presentation! Delicious!! 

I've gone here a few times (take out) and have never been disappointed. If you have a seafood craving, here is the place to go. The wait... expect to WAIT. This is a popular seafood spot with bar seating, so you have to wait for a seat. I've never dined in, but if you order in advance you can bypass the line and pick up your order. The team there is also really friendly. 

Do yourself a favor and try it out - you wont regret it! 

-Dee
author: Dianne I.

description: Wow everything at this small hole in the wall is everything everyone has promised and more! Let me tell you that we waited 21/2 hours to get a seating at this small place and it was worth it!. There was not one thing we didn't like and we ordered pretty much the whole menu. The only thing that I was disappointed at was the fact that they didn't have a couple of things on the menu that I really wanted to try. Maybe next time. But you probably need to go on another day that is not the weekend or prime lunch time because you will wait for a LONG time!
author: Cynthia Y.

description: So good, the freshest seafood I've had in years.  Scallop sashimi was especially remarkable.  Well worth the 2-hour wait on a Saturday afternoon!
author: Soma C.

description: Worst Service Ever. I was so excited about this place because of all the great reviews, but honestly, there are a hell of a lot of places to eat in SF and this place is just not worth it. I called ahead to get takeout and was put on hold for 22 minutes. I thought maybe I'd been forgotten so I hung up on called back, only to hear the phone ringing for 10 more minutes. Finally someone answered and very rudely stated that they didn't have the time for takeout, why don't I just come in? Why in god's name do they say they do takeout if they're just "too busy"?! And why didn't the first guy tell me this so I didn't waste half an hour screwing around on the phone with them? What a waste.
author: Amy S.

description:
First time visit today.

EXCELLENT service first of all. Happy and cheerful atmosphere, Has a family / neighborhood kinda vibe.

Had the combination seafood salad, prawn cocktail and a cup of clam chowder with my girlfriend.

Everything was fresh and tasty. I have a new favorite seafood spot and will be going back again soon to try the smoked salmon.

good eatin and good people

love this place !
author: Mario W.

description:
Read about this place in the Smithsonian Magazine, so me and my friend decided to go here. That day the foodie god must has been smiling on us.... I got parking literally across the street just like that and when we went to the place, lo and behold... no waiting!(thx. Giants parade!) I heard the line can be long at times but it just like the place is waiting for us! My friend went for the chowder which is delicious, but I went straight for the big mama... the oyster sampler! I had Oyster Rockefeller at the Four Seasons New York but the sampler at Swan's just blew my mind! No pretension, just total authentic heaven in your mouth..... Even the place is very authentic, classic fishmonger place, classic cash register, and food prepared fresh. I got interested with the crab on the counter so I ordered half crab and oh my god.... the sweetest, juiciest, fresh crab I ever tasted!!!!
Definitely will go back there!
author: Charles S.

description:
DON'T BELIEVE THE HYPE!!!
I've been waiting quite some time now to check this place out and to be honest, I left Swan Oyster Depot feeling unsatisfied and very disappointed.  Maybe it's because I had such high expectations for this place, but I really can't see why everyone loves this place so much.  
Between my wife and I, we shared a dozen oysters, half a crab, and a couple drinks.  I don't mind splurging on a good meal, but what we were served clearly did not warrant the almost $60 tab (tip included). 

Good:
- the Louie sauce was very tasty
-bread was good
-oysters were ok
-friendly staff

Bad:
-Way too expensive for what you actually get
-Crab was very small and not as juicy as I had expected at this price point
-not so sanitary conditions.  The same staff that serves your food can be seen handling money and wiping down the counter with a damp cloth with no washing of hands taking place. 

The quality wasn't terrible, but I give this place 2 stars for value.  Very little bang for your buck here.
author: Eroc V.

description:
I was visiting San Fran with a buddy.  We were staying at the Holiday Inn on Van Ness and Pine and looking for somewhere near the hotel to eat.  We walked down Polk to see what was around.  We almost stopped at an Indian restaurant but decided to keep walking just in case something really sparked our interests.  We then almost stopped at a sushi spot, but noticed some of the action next door coming from The Swan Oyster Depot.  We looked inside from the door and saw that almost every seat in the counter style restaurant was taken.  The visible demand sold us.  

We walked in and found two seats at the counter where we were immediately greeted by the friendly group of guys working the fresh fish.  Its a family operated business and you definitely get family hospitality.  The food was great.  We ordered a combination salad, crab cocktails, chowder, and a mixed plate of oysters.  Everything was delicious.  The seafood was all as fresh as possible.  A local sitting next to us said, "this is where the fishermen come to eat."  I really enjoyed this place and will definitely go back next time I'm in town.

It wasn't cheap, but it was worth every penny.
The place is small and is not the best for big groups.
author: Hugo G.

description: Used to frequent here, before Anthony Bourdain existed! Came back years later, the price definitely jacked up!!!!!! 2 orders of salmon crostinis, smoked trout, a cup of clam chowder, 2 kumamotos, 2 miyagis came up to $89.90.... I think it's insane. You can buy Scottish salmon and make crostini at home. For oysters, you can go to Waterbar at ferry building for happy hour price $1 per oysters and they are amazingly fresh! I would not come back here. Tourists can spend their money here but not for locals :-) For crab go to the famous CRUSTACEANS, it's 5 mins walking from Swan. You can get 2 a## dungeness crabs for $80 ish. Tourists take a note of it.
author: Clemencia S.

description:
Their seafood was definitely gooood and fresh.  The staff was friendly... this joint is family owned, father, daugher, son... all work there.

But I was just disturbed by the cleanliness... or lack thereof.  They display their seafood near the front and you can see that they grab the seafood in handfuls (nice portions) but  they wear no gloves.  There is water and stuff everywhere on their counter and they don't really wipe down the counter you eat on either.  

Their homemade horseradish (which is very good), lemons, oyster chips, are out on the counter and meant to be shared.  But I wondered if there were double-dippers seated before me?  The bowl of lemons had fresh and already squeazed quarters....

But I must say, even with that... I sat there and ate all my crab salad and oysters!  And it was yummy.
author: Grace S.

description:
The food here is wonderful. They had 6 different kinds of oysters when I came here and I was able to try all of them.  3/6 were freaking delicious.  SO sweet. but the rest were just okay.

I also had the crab salad with louise sauce.  Yumm. it was a cold day though, and that dish is better served on a nice hot summer day.

I also tried their scallops served in Japanese and Sicilian styles.  Japanese ones, not so fond of, the sicillian had olive oil, capers, salt pepper and diced red onions.  Loved it.  It brought out the sweetness of the scallops.

The clam chowder was delicious.  It was really original and in a good way.  I do like the ones from scoma's better because that one has it's own style, but for traditional style clam chowder i think this was one of the best.

ohh I shared with my bf...lol...i ddint' eat all that by myself.
author: Zu W.

description:
You will be sure to get the freshest, highest quality seafood here.  It is a winner for their quality and customer service.  You feel like your part of a fisherman's family when you go in, that you don't even notice- you even feel okay with- the cramped quarters and somewhat deteriorating interior.  It feels like home.  The long line is worth the wait, and you will feel like you had a very satisfying meal no matter what you order.

Be aware, the prices are steep for many dishes.  I recommend the well-priced clam chowder if you don't want to break the bank.  However if you want to spend a little extra, you will get a special meal that is some of the freshest, most authentic you can find.

I got the sense that the people that worked there really like to be there, and really love preparing fresh seafood.  And a tip- bring some fish home, the prices and quality are outstanding.

Perhaps it was because I scrunched up to the folks next to me, but I even stuck up a 'lil conversation with the locals that attend here.  He said 'I'm starstruck!' 'What?', I said, and thought.  He said 'The guy sitting two seats down from me is a totally famous show-pop performer- you don't recognize him?', he said nervously.  Whatever floats your boat.  Swan floats mine.

Place needs remodeling/makeover, so not a perfect rating.
author: Marc M.

description:
Any place that most of the patrons are fishermen themselves is a place to get your craving on for seafood.  Oysters are delicious and very fresh, crab is divine and the meat sweet, and the clam chowder is very good.

Staff is sweet and quick... this place is a must when in San Francisco
author: Michelle S.

description: Alright - so this place is legendary.  If you like "local color", wise guy fish slingers, sitting on stools, and great seafood this is the place for you.  Bring a lot of cash (there is an ATM across the street at CVS), try to get there around 4-5pm (lines are short to nil), and order EVERYTHING.  You will be happy you did.
author: Michael S.

description: Food is great, experience is even better. These guys were SO friendly and treated everybody so well. It was our first time (as I'm sure it is for many patrons). You might expect them to be sick of the same questions, etc, but it was the exact opposite - they were patient, happy to offer suggestions and genuinely seemed to love hosting new guests. Great quality, fresh product, delicious flavor.
author: Adam D.

description:
Great seafood! Fresh! 
excellent service! Friendly people!
Had a great time, will come back again!

Long wait worth it!!!!!!!
author: Olga A.

description: This place is a tiny little blink-and-you'll-miss-it type of place. It's kind of like a diner in that everyone sits at the bar, so I can see how it gets crowded but I loved it. We got the Eastern Oyster cocktail and the crab salad. Both were delicious! It's a little bit expensive but everything is really fresh and the place has been around since 1912, so 100 years! It's a must if you live here, and the staff is really friendly. :)
author: Montana O.

description:
whew, i was sure hoping that the hour long wait would be worth it...in the cold, and in the rain, and after 2 trips to the Chase ATM across the street...on my birthday.

...and it was.

with counter only seating and a good amount of wait staff, you kind of get your own personal seafood barista at swan oyster depot.  if you're looking for fancy seafood, this isn't really the place to get it, but if you're looking for insanely fresh and simple seafood then i can't imagine it getting better than swan oyster depot.  

my hungry girlfriend and i each had a clam chowder that converted me from a thick creamy chowder loving guy to one that now prefers less thick but more flavor.  we then shared a crab cocktail (different and better value than the crab salad) and a bay shrimp cocktail, both of which were sweet and fresh (can't stress fresh enough here).  we also topped it off with a dozen kumamoto oysters that were shucked right in front of us by our barista.  

all in all, they have inconvenient hours, a tiny and somewhat cramped seating area and are cash only, but you quickly forget all of that once you start eating.
author: Jeff N.

description:
I love this place! The seafood is so fresh, and the clam chowder is to DIE for. 

Be warned, it will get crowded, and I was lucky to have been able to go there before the huge crowd rush. 
I was with a friend, and ordered oysters to share and a bowl of clam chowder. The oysters are as good as they can get, and the clam chowder is amazing. Usually, you get more chowder taste than clam, but here, with one spoonful, you taste the clam. It's amazing.

Amazing service, very friendly and fun workers!
author: Bianca W.

description:
As I was waiting in line for lunch here, a guy passed by on the sidewalk and said to us, 'This is the first time in five years I haven't seen a line here!!'  Needless to say, the line wasn't too long when I went there for the first time.

It's old school, and I would describe it as unrefined (fine with me) and tiny. As I sat down at the counter, one of the many men behind the counter asked me if I wanted him to put my purse up on the shelf to give me more room-  uh, yes please.

It's fun to watch the workers because almost every single one is related, and they all have the same profile!  Now, for the food.  

The clam chowder was really good-- it didn't have lots of cream or any bacon so I could really taste the delicious clams.  I had the crab Louie salad which had loads of crab atop some shredded lettuce and just the perfect amount of Louie dressing!

It's not inexpensive to have a salad almost entirely of crab meat, but I'd have to say it's worth it-- although, I would have loved a hard boiled egg on my plate to go with.

They 'don't take plastic', so have your billfold full, and go enjoy a delicious lunch.
author: Karen W.

description:
Best seafood in town, and they don't even have to cook it!  

We always walk past the line of people out onto Polk waiting patiently for a seat at the counter.  We got there at 11 AM on a Saturday, sat down right away and were greeted by each of the 10 or so men working the place.  So friendly!

We had clam chowder, combination seafood salads, oysters and beer.  Best breakfast ever.  The seafood is incredibly fresh and it shows in the taste.  You will not be disappointed with Swan Oyster Depot.  It's pricey, but considering the quality and taste, absolutely well worth the cash.

(Cash/check only!)
author: Shannon V.

description: I've been dying to try this place.. but there's always a long line! Luckily, there wasn't a long line today at the time I went! The guys working here are so awesome- super kind and funny! I had a cup chowder, blue oysters, calamari and anchor steam. They were fresh and delicious! I am definitely coming back and bringing friends!
author: C J.

description: Hours are 1030-530pm. No tables inside, only stools across a bar. Hence, the long line out the door. Very casual place.  The people who work there are pleasant and get you what you need.  After you sit down, they offer you sourdough bread and takes you order.  He then walks over to the seafood case and prepares your order fresh.  The seafood is very fresh but I was disappointed with the clam chowder.  It was a watery broth, lacked in flavor, and there weren't many clams in there.  Not sure if it was because we came just before closing or what.  Waited standing in line about 50 min before we got seated.
author: Sandy G.

description: A San Francisco institution plain and simple. Funky, fresh, amazing. Prepare to wait in line....no frills, and it's not cheap. Well worth it.
author: Jebidiah P.

description: I don't get the hype surrounding this place.  The seafood is fresh - sure.  The oysters were good.  The crab was fresh but boring.  Anchor Steam on tap - yum.  Friendly staff in an old style setting.  Way too expensive for what you get though.
author: John O.

description: If you enjoy fresh seafood and a friendly staff, then I highly recommend this place!
author: Andrew B.

description:
Solid seafood, but prices are a little steep and it's a little too "touristy must-do" for me.  Seating is VERY limited- basically a dozen seats at a "bar" makes up the whole restaurant.  

I came at 10:30 so I didn't have to wait, but if I did like some of the tourist chumps (who waited an hour or more!), I woulda been pissed!

Clam chowder- buttery and delicious but didnt' really have that much clam meat in it and was kind of runny.  It would have been better slightly thicker.
Oysters- had a dozen mixed oysters with cocktail sauce and horseradish.  Solid.
Half cracked crab- pretty small crab (esp compared to the ones they were advertising in the window) and for $20, you could have gone down to the crab stands at Fisherman's wharf and gotten a whole crab.
Crab salad- not very much crab meat on a bed of yucky lettuce with thousand island dressing.  Bleh.

The bowl of oyster crackers that they have out makes me very nervous because I saw some nasty guy in overalls next to me basically reach his hand in there, put some on his oyster, and then reach back in there with his oyster-shell-dirt-laden-fingers.  I read somewhere that the 'peanut bowls' are bars harbor a TON of bacteria from people reaching their nasty ass hands in there.  Surely this oyster cracker bowl would give the peanut bowl a run for its money.

Cash only, bring at LEAST $70 if you want to be full and have a beer (for two).

My advice:  Go to Hog Island Oyster at the Ferry building, sit in the back and enjoy people watching with a beautiful view of the bridge.
author: Maxine S.

description:
I don't know why all these people are raving about the clam chowder, it was the worst clam chowder I've ever had. There were almost no clams/potatoes/anything with texture, and my cup of "soup" was about 1/4 gross floaty oil.

The oysters I saw being served to other people looked good, which is why I am being lenient with my 3 stars, but if you like thick, chunky, tasty, clammy clam chowder, DO NOT go here. If you like buckets of oily, salty cream with one hacked up clam hiding in it, head on down to Swan's.
author: Keighley M.

description:
San Francisco is known to have some of the best food in the country. Everything and anything can be found in the city, but what really sets them apart is their selection of quality seafood. In a city so well known for seafood, I would figure it to be impossible to find the best Clam Chowder, but my theory proved to be wrong as soon as I walked into Swan's Oyster Depot. This spot can be found on Polk street, and you have to be careful when you drive by because the restaurant is so small, you will probably drive right past it. What's probably easier is to look for the long line of people heading into a hole in the wall, because that's precisely what you are looking for. 

Now, I consider myself somewhat of a chowder connoisseur, so I was very excited to check this place out. I tried to go here once before, but the wait was one and a half hours and I couldn't wait because I had to be somewhere later that afternoon. Back to the chowder at hand...my friends and I arrived to the place at 11:45am on a Monday, and much to our surprise, there was NO line! We walked right in and there were three remaining seats, the perfect amount for our party. This place is small, there are no tables, only a counter that seats about 15 people which can explain the usual line down the street. Since we had a day full of culinary adventures, we had to save room so each of us ordered a clam chowder in a bowl and a combination seafood cocktail. 

The chowder.....

I have had a lot of chowder in my life and I must say, Swan's has some of the best I have EVER had. It is not thick, but more of a creamy soup consistency. There are plenty of ingredients found in your typical chowder like potatoes and of course clams. But it's the soup that really sets it apart. It just tasted amazing. I knew something was up when it was served because you can see a light layer of oil on the top (you can see it in the picture above if you click on the thumbnail). Oh, before I forget...get the side of sourdough bread, it's perfect for dipping in the soup. 

On to the combination seafood cocktail...

Each order of combination cocktail came with an oyster on top, some shrimps and a bunch of crab, all topped with their cocktail sauce. On the counter was a big bowl of horseradish sauce to add to your liking, but I decided to try it first without. It tasted pretty good, but once I added the horseradish sauce...WOW, this dish was GREAT. The horseradish has some serious kick, so be careful if you don't like too much heat. 

All in all, this place is wonderful. The chowder is exceptional and from the looks of it, so is everything else on the menu. It's not a hidden gem as a lot of people in the city know about it, so be prepared to go early or wait awhile. Just a note, on our way out, there was a line of 15 people waiting to get in, so we were lucky with not having to wait.

more reviews can be found on www.thekitchenfloor.com
author: Koji I.

description:
food: 5/5
service: 4/5 
atmosphere/decor: 3/5

Came here on a weekday and wait only only 20 mins because we beat the lunch time rush. The place is very small, only about 20 seats on a long bar. Do not come here with a party more than 3, you will either have to wait a long time or not be seated together. It's a nice homey place. I would say this is probably one of the freshest seafood places I have been to. And the best uni (sea urchin) I've tasted, they crack open the sea urchin before they give it to you so it is literally right out of the shell. Oysters are also very good. For a small meal of 2 cups clam chowder, 6 oysters,and 1 uni  the total came out to $50 (including tax/tip) between two people. Be warned that I I dont eat too much, so you may spend more. The table next to me spent $80. I think for most people, you will be spending $30-40 per person to be really full. I think the experience is worth it because the seafood is definitely fresh. However, I will not be coming back often.

Service is hit or miss. The main server we had was a bit of a klutz and gave us a really shoddy presentation for our uni plate. During our time here several other workers who passed by asked us if we needed anything else, I felt like service is decent here. At the end of the meal, a server merely asked us what we ordered and tallied our check on a napkin. I guess they work on the honor system. Also, be prepared to get cozy with the people next to you, they really pack in the place like sardines.
author: Cecile S.

description:
Fresh seafood. Funny, genuine, and sometimes gritty extremely experienced  charismatic servers/fishmongers. (I mean that as a compliment.) This counter-based restaurant is a raw bar in the most extreme sense of the concept. One long bar with a crowd of people waiting to get in, to sit shoulder-to-shoulder with strangers, all of whom are indulging in and enjoying freshly shucked oysters, crab louie salads, clams, clam chowder, and the most delectable smoked salmon I have ever had the luck to enjoy. 
I love this place. Had I the time and money, I would eat here every day. I WISH they had an eating competition, if you can eat X amount of oysters, your meal is free, because I would try for a win every time. Seriously the best seafood I have found in the city, simple, honest, fresh, and delicious. Consistent. Fantastic. Go here. Or better, don't, and keep a counter seat free for my oyster-loving butt.
author: Sarah H.

description: Best oysters I have ever had. Maybe it's a mixture of the atmosphere and the quality of their products but this is a must if your in San Francisco. Some bread, a few stella's, 6 types of pacific oysters and a killer seafood salad left me in heaven. Oh yeah we went to a dive called Mr. Bings in Chinatown the night before and notice one of the workers had a Mr. Bings shirt on so we shouted out about it. One of the co-workers promptly chimes in with, "he was conceived there in the bathroom". Tip of the day is get in there before the lunch crowd.
author: Chris L.

description: I absolutely love this place and I make sure to stop by every time I am in town.  The staff is super awesome and are eager to help. On my last visit I tried the "Sicilian Sushi" sampler and it was incredible! Great oysters, prawns, fish, you name it... and the chowder is delicious!
author: OKae H.

description: Waited over an hour and so worh the wait.  Love this place. What an experience.   Freshest fish anywhere.  Excellent service.   I am in love !
author: Laura S.

description:
Let me start by saying I'm not a lover of seafood mostly because I don't like the fishy taste and/or smell. 
Swans fish is so fresh that  there is no hint of "fishy" taste, their seafood is quality. 
I do enjoy a shrimp cocktail and picked up 8 large shrimp to make a nice cocktail at home. The shrimp I bought tasted like they were just plucked out of the ocean. I also make my own shrimp cocktail sauce with Swan's home made horseradish........let me just say, their horseradish is spicy and delicious.
These guys are a San Francisco institution!
Thanks Swan guys!!
author: David P.

description:
Was visiting a friend in San Francisco over the weekend and my girlfriend kept raving about this place so we had to check it out.
