Perhaps if this is like the fifth time your parents/brother/sister are in town and you're out of tour guide options, I can see how the combination of killing time and being in the know with a locally acknowledged hole in the wall with a reasonably priced fresh catch may warrant a longer wait. Chances are good that when they return home and tell someone else that's been to San Francisco that they went to Swan's Oyster Depot that the reference will stick and they'll then be able to say "Good!" when they get asked how the oysters were and that might be quite pleasant.
author: Bryan P.

description: Miss this place. First stop when ever i am in SF. I havent been there in 6 months and still wanted to give it a great review.
author: Matt T.

description: I think everyone has captured how good the food is and we concur.  Just finished our lunch here and we enjoyed the vibe as much as the food.  We got in the first seating and they never rush you even though there is a line down the block.  We tried: chowder (good and briny), oysters, seafood salad, and half crab.  All delish!  The people working there are great! So casual and comfortable.
author: c k.

description:
Ate there last Friday and had the oysters - both Miyagi and Blue Points.  Wife said the Blue Points smells bad, but I ate them anyway with Tasbaco - bad move.  I've had "mud-butt" since Sunday night and just starting to get over it.

Also, the place was so crowded that  the three A-holes that arrive next to us muscled themself into a a two seat and shoveled my wife over- almost got into a fight with a biker type.

I had good experience there before, but this time was not good.
author: Jet T.

description: The best crab salad ever. One of my favorite places to go when I'm in San Francisco.
author: Sheri L.

description: I went again after years of staying away. I should have stayed away! While the seafood is fresh, it is hugely overpriced for what you get. The clam chowder curdled - how does a fish place do that! And the owners/staff, while all friendly, they take money, use dirty dish clothes and then go grab the crab for your salad bare handed! Never did I see one of them wash their hands - its pretty disgusting and I don't think I will ever go again.
author: Joy A.

description: A fun little bar. Nice crowd. I've had some fun conversations with the people sitting beside me. It's a very social atmosphere, and the oysters are really fresh- shucked in front of your eyes.
author: Mikey S.

description: Oh My Gosh, this place is like heaven. Thank goodness the bf and I don't live anywhere close to this place or we would be broke (over $100 for breakfast)!!! One of my top five favorite foods is oysters on the half shell and Swan Oyster Depot does not disappoint. We had one dozen of the mixed oysters, one dozen of half kumomoto oysters and half of a local oyster and all of them were delicious though the kumomotos are our fave oysters. We also had a few stellas and the cherry stone clams on the half shell which were delicious as well. The clam chowder was good but it was not my favorite part of the meal. I wouldn't even really call it a chowder, more like a clam soup. Either way I wouldn't hesitate to come here again if I was in the area.
author: Grace B.

description: Lived up to all the hype. Fresh fresh seafood and great service. Arrive early for lunch to avoid long lines.
author: Simon M.

description:
There's a line out the door for clam chowder and shrimp cocktail? Yeah, it's pretty good but I don't know if I would wait 20 minutes for it...but I did. 

Although the food really isn't that special I love the Old School San Francisco feel to the place. It's what Fisherman's Wharf was before it became a parody of itself with its Alcatraz Psych Ward t-shirts and the hats with fake bird shit on them that read, "Damn seagulls!" (I totally want one of these but I'll have to wait until I'm old enough to seem senile. I'm figuring two or three more years.) One star for making me feel San Francisco-ey without making me feel like a tourist.
author: Josua P.

description:
I never thought I would enjoy slimy food so much until I met my wife and went to the Swan Oyster Depot.  The quaint little joint on Post almost ALWAYS has a line because inside there is roughly 15 seats and it's all at the counter.  You know a place has got to be good when people wait in the cold, lined up like it's the Great Depression and there's hot soup inside.  

Swan Oyster Depot has all kinds of shellfish imaginable.  Personally I always get the Miyagi's and a couple of anchor steams.  You can't go wrong with the crab salads or the shrimp cocktails.  They won't hold back on the crab meat or shrimp either.  They know you have come for it, and they will give it to you.  Combine that with some good ole' dark crust San Francisco supreme sourdough bread and you've got yourself a meal my friend!

I never have really cared for the chowder.  Too watery and too damn salty.  It would the only thing I would pass on.  Everything else here is extremely fresh and tastes great.  Just remember to bring good ole' American currency (read cash).  This place has been and continues to be very successful and they don't take credit cards.  Robert DeNiro may have an American Express card but it isn't worth dung if you want food here.

If you love oysters, shellfish and seafood, you have got to check out the Swan Oyster Depot.
author: Bill P.

description: Super fresh and sweet seafood, served with no frills.  Chowder is OK if you're from the east coast (due to the less creamy variety served in SF).  Beer is cold.  Seating situation is atrocious.  Go early (before 11:30 am) or late (after 2:30pm) on weekdays for lunch, otherwise forget it.  Can be cheap or expensive depending on what you order.  Lunch for 2 can easily top $60-70 if you're hungry.
author: David S.

description:
My Saturday was great, well except for the neon green cricket on steroids that stalked me for a week before finally getting into my place to torment me late Friday well into Saturday morning, ok, getting back to the point.... Ah, first of all, Saturdays are great because they are simply Saturdays and mean no work and lots of sleep for me, so I'm usually in a really great mood on Saturday.  Well after an amazing facial treatment from Joyce(http://www.yelp.com/biz/skin-for-life-san-francisco#hrid:qiTGyopK7Uk25JV9jszxFA), I decided to stop at Swan for my favorite seafood combo salad.  (See, proves how great Joyce is because I'm usually red and running home to hide after a facial, but not today, and never with Joyce, dang, getting off the point again.)  

Without even trying, I quickly found a parking spot a few doors down from Swan's, yay!  Realized I only had $10 cash (seafood combo salad is $17 something, and this place only accepts cash) and was able to get across the street to Walgreen's without getting hit by a car, hit up for money, and was able to check out and get cash in no time at all.  The bf used to always pick food up for me, so I had never been myself, and was a little turned off by the line halfway down the block, but quickly found out that if you're getting food to go, you just walk in, order and you're outta there.... sorry hungry people!  I LOVE this salad!!!   Next time I'll have to try the clam chowder too!
author: Jessie B.

description: For months, I walked by this place and saw the long line going down the street and wondered what it was all about.  So I went in there.  The food was amazing, super fresh and good.  It was extremely expensive, there is limited seating and there is usually a long wait to get in.
author: Susanne R.

description: i can't come to the coast without eating every oyster i see.  and i will definitely put swan on my "gotta do" list, every time i'm in san fran.  this place opened in 1912 and they probably haven't changed much.  an eclectic wine list that includes LEWIS CHARD BY THE GLASS!!!  not to mention a really tasty french muscadet.  my suggestion: try everything and let jimmy or patrick suggest their favorites.  every single thing i tasted (kumamotos, HOG ISLAND sweetwaters, cherry stone clams, crab cocktail, calamari salad, smoked salmon, smoked trout, clam chowder) was incredible!!!  you might have to stand or wait in line, but it's definitely worth the wait.
author: Jason G.

description:
Worth the wait!  
Seriously, you probably will stand in line for around an hour, unless you get there early.  It is not cheap, however, it is worth the price and worth the wait.  If you love oysters and are in San Francisco, this is an absolute MUST stop.  They have Anchor Steam on tap.  A great place to have a decadent lunch.
author: Robert J.

description:
small, popular, expensive, WORTH IT.

louis sauce, SO GOOD. i wanna put that shit on everything. 

one of the only places i'll get oysters at, but everything on the menu is to die for. which is by the way all fresh sea food so don't go there looking for anything else.

and of course, get the chowder.
author: Stephanie D.

description: Many breakfast seafood feasts at Swan's over the years, always at 8:00 AM sharp to best the crowd. But apparently things have changed. No more 8:00 AM sit-down service, as we abruptly learned when we arrived. "Haven't done that for years." Really? Considering we'd confirmed an 8:00 AM visit by phone we should've been served without question. Instead we were quite brusquely and unapologetically turned away, as if we'd somehow made a mistake. Their mistake threw off an entire day. Thanks for the past. Won't be returning.
author: tegen d.

description:
I love the environment of this place! Everyone is super nice and friendly and eager to help you. All the seafood is super fresh and delicious! The only downside is the wait. This little store probably only seats 20 people max at a time, so the wait can be a little long. But once you get in, you can get the freshest oysters. I can probably eat 3 dozens of the oysters alone! haha! The shrimp salad is soooo good! The clam chowder is delicious too! 

Oh you can also ask for the crab shell or they call it "crab fat". I saw an Asian couple slurping out of it. I thought it was crab soup and tried to order it. Turns out that it's the "crab fat" and they give it out for free. For those of you that like it, definitely ask for it!
author: Cynthia C.

description:
This review is solely based on a negative experience when the restaurant was unexpectedly closed on Memorial Day.  We made a special trip to Swan Oyster Depot, after their voicemail said they were open on Monday's.  The voicemail gave no mention of holiday closures, and I was unable to confirm this since they didn't answer their phone in the days leading up to Memorial day.   Also, they don't have a website.  While I understand that the old school experience is part of their charm, this was not acceptable and their customers should expect more. 

Communication with the customer needs to reach the 21st century - a website, or at the very least an accurate voicemail is absolutely necessary!
author: Andrew D.

description:
I've been here twice and I haven't been able to go back again because I just don't have the money. ($40-50 per visit. :() Oysters, oysters, and more oysters. Tried the clams once, but I prefer the oysters. The house wine is nothing to rave about, but it was just nice to have something to sip on. Love the tabasco, mignonette sauce, and cocktail sauce and lemon. I do sometimes eat just the osyter w/the lemon and tabasco, but I love piling on the other stuff, too, because it's just that good.  I didn't think the clam chowder was all that great, but maybe I just don't know my chowders. The seafood salad is alright, and so's the seafood cocktail, but it's all about the oysters. Oh man, I really want some oysters right now...

Oh, and the service is great and the guys working the counter are super nice.

Definitely avoid the lunch hour, get there before or after, or you'll find yourself in a very long line.
author: ML N.

description:
This place sets the standard for what an Oyster joint should be like. The Oysters were fresh (he was shucking them 4 feet from me), the service was great with a family style feel to it, and the atmosphere made you feel like you were sitting on the boat as they hauled the oysters in the boat. Also, had the crab salad which was delicious. It was a lot of crab sitting on a bed of crisp lettuce with dressing on the side.

I have had oysters as fresh as this, but it is the whole experience that is what sets this place apart.

Also, I advise you keep the group small (2 people or less) or  it will take forever to find a seat (together).
author: Alvin S.

description:
This place reminds me of a seafood bar my parents would take me as a child in Chicago where I would sit at the barstool and slurp down clam chowder. I went to Swan Oyster on Saturday and walked right in an hour before closing. I shared an order of oysters, some clam chowder and a crab salad along with a couple glasses of white. This place is a favorite of mine when I can get out for lunch. It is the type of place you go to and leave thinking "I love living in San Francisco!".  Then, we continued on at Bigfoot.

DEJAVU - same program last night 3/1. Swan Oyster Depot to Bigfoot.
author: Amy E.

description:
The creme de la soul of San Francisco seafood, hands down.

Anthony Bourdain, et al are spot on. Well worth the wait.
author: Adam Z.

description:
Just awesome. My Grandfather sold these guys fish back in the day. Back when there were markets on Market Street.

Dungeness crab, the most awesome oysters from Washington and Canada, smoked salmon . . .

All washed down with a fresh Anchor Steam.

No brainer . . . the best.
author: Jeff D.

description: This institution is way over rated and uses it's history to rip you off, how unfortunate. If you want great seafood do the Anchor Oyster Bar.
author: christopher c.

description: Sooo good. Don't think about it - just do it. You wont be disappointed....except for the long line line and lack of seating - but hey it gives it it's charm and presence. Very much worth it. Grab it to go!
author: Rah F.

description:
Pros:

- Neat atmosphere.  
- Tasty and fairly priced fresh oysters.  
- Great service.

The seafood on the salad was fresh, but the salad itself was pretty boring.  Iceberg lettuce with seafood sprinkled on top, served with oil & vinegar or a home made thousand island dressing.  That's all the salad is.

I'm not sure that it was worth the wait.
author: Chris R.

description:
Minus 1/2 star for letting not cleaning the front of their store enough to eliminate the urine stank. Minus 1/2 star for giving me tummyache afterward. I actually waited 90 minutes to be seated because we got there noontime on a saturday. Was it worth it? Meehh i would only go again on a weekday or odd hours. When we left at 4pm there was almost no line. BTW what is it with NorCal eating establishment not cleaning their storefront enough to eliminate the stank of urine.

OK let's talk food:
Clam Chowder: Worth coming for. More soupy than thick -just the way I like it.  Real flavor, not just salty. Having lived in New England and faithfully attending all the chowder festival I am VERY PICKY when it comes to my chowda.

Lobster Bisque: A bit too buttery but still OK. But my standard is the one I had in Maine.

Miyagi Oyster: They were out of the kumamoto,  but not being an oyster lover I really would have preferred the smaller, tastier kumamoto. 

Smoked Salmon Sandwich: OMG totally TO DIE FOR!!! I have never had such fresh lox. You get to see the guys cut into the fish and fillet the piece right infront of you. 

Crab Sandwich:  If it's any fresher than this the claw would still be attached and the crab is pinching your nose under water. Served with Louie dressing it's good. Real good.

Sea Urchin: Hmm it was a bit to briny for me but I just never really go crazy for uni when I go for Japanese either.
author: MaRISA Y.

description:
Hard to add to what's been said, but it's true.  Absurdly fresh seafood, served up in absurdly large portions in an absurdly small space with what's often an absurdly large line out the door.

Oysters, smoked salmon, crab, shrimp... you name it, they got it.
A few tips - I strongly recommend getting the sauce on the side if you get one of the "salads", which are basically huge piles of seafood on iceberg lettuce.  It makes the lettuce better, but overwhelmes the delicious fishies.  Also, don't order the chowder if you have some foolish idea that chowder is in fact healthy.

Is it cheap?  No.  But when you're getting a plate covered in a giant pile of fresh shrimp & crab, it ain't gonna be cheap.  You can also buy fish there that you don't have to eat on the spot.

Last tip: go there when the weather's crappy - the line forms a lot later, and is much smaller.
author: Don H.

description:
Haven't been to the Oyster Depot for a while.  I like it because at the end of your meal they give you an expandable sponge that looks like a coaster until you soak it in water, and mais voila, wipe up the counter.

There is always a line in front of this place, owing to its limited hours and limited seating.  I remember the days when I came here and waited in line for a seat at the counter.  There are no tables, just a counter with a row of seats, a window display of fresh fish, and some boisterous and fun guys shucking oysters and pouring beer.

I would say go here more for the experience than the oyster quality.  I have had better oysters elsewhere, and since it is a quick place, don't expect elegant plating.  You might have a shell bit or two in your oyster.

The clam chowder and crab cocktail are delicious.  Come here for the crab cocktail, which is good value for your money.  Prices are a bit expensive for what you get, and if you are faint of heart, which I am getting to be in my old age, perhaps belly up to the bar at Hog Island in the Ferry Building, which is like a civilized version of Swan.

If you are not deterred, come here.  Every San Franciscan should have a taste of Swan at least once in her life.
author: apple r.

description: Simply put, you will wait about an hour and a half to eat, sit, whatever. But it is well well worth it! Definitely eat here at least once if you're in San Francisco.
author: Jeff B.

description:
The line may be long, but that's only proof of the goodness.  Actually, it's proof that this place is tiny and has a seating problem.  The smallness adds to the charm because you get to talk to the chefs and they are extremely friendly.  I had a blast!  I was introduced to raw scallops.  Let me tell you!  They are buttery goodness from heaven!

My friend took me here because she knows I love raw oysters.  What's sweet is that she doesn't even like raw oysters.  By the way, the oysters were fantastic!  I tried to get west coast oysters and local oysters so they would be the freshest.

Try this place out, but anticipate a line.  It's worth every minute.
author: Christopher L.

description:
Great oysters! This place seems so traditional and a good place to take tourists. The staff is really nice and they all seemed to be like a family. The clam chowder is more soupy than milky, but still good. We got a dozen of the assorted oysters. The ones from Washington were the best. 

They have all kinds of seafood there, even whole sea urchins! They have dungeness crab there as well. The place is small but still seats a good amount of people. The seats are a bit uncomy, but I think its party of what makes it authentic. 

I like this place and would recommend it .
author: Jaein L.

description: Finally Finally Finally got in here.  Just had to take the day off work to make it happen.  Kia B. and I enjoyed shrimp cocktail, a bowl of chowda and the mixed seafood salad (shrimp, prawn and crab).  A couple of beers to wash it down and we floated out of here on a cloud of seafood ecstasy .  Under $50 for all that and friendly service to boot.
author: Corey V.

description: There's maybe one other person out there in the world who hasn't had a good Swan Oyster experience.  So the majority is probably right -- I'm sure the food is usually great.  But that doesn't change the fact that my clams were crummy... what else can I say?
author: Laurence W.

description:
As soon as I picked up the rental car I put Swan Oysters address into the GPS and drove straight here.  Waited in line for about an hour.  Ordered the combination salad.

Are you serious?  This is the best seafood in SF?  It was terrible.  Shrimp and crab over iceberg lettuce served with Thousand Island dressing.  No flavor what so ever and I left thinking "Is this really what people here consider good?" 

Lunch for two=$50.  A complete rip off.  We could have had a better lunch at the Wharf for around $10.  and not have a wait.
author: Meredith M.

description: Love the fresh seafood but hate the long lines!
author: Cam N.

description:
I used to like this coming to this place a lot more when I had friends visit from out of town. It is really one of the quintessential tourist stops where you get to meet all sorts of folks who aren't from the area or even the country for that matter. Kudos to management for running a tight ship in the 2nd generation of the business. Out of towners just love getting that business card that actually doubles as a sponge once you dunk it in water.

The servers aren't overly friendly, but the place is so small that a no-nonsense approach works best when there are lines out the door.

My favorites are the clam chowder with sourdough bread. I took a peek at the back of the house one time and the clam chowder is made with a canned base but they do add lots of clam juice and other things inside to produce a wonderfully flavorful if not runny version of the soup.

I prefer the cherry stone clams over the oysters and usually get a selection of half dozen clams and half dozen selected oysters. The clams are so fresh and sweet, you can't really decide whether or not to douse them in the various condiments or just pop them into your mouth.

The must have hear is the seafood salad with louie dressing. They really pack on the fresh seafood, which somewhat makes up for the sticker shock of having to pay over $17 for a salad. It's a wonderful combination of creamy and fresh flavors over crispy lettuce that makes the people waiting silently want you to eat quickly so they can sit down and enjoy the same thing.

Nice collection of rubber duckies on the back counter.
author: Mark Y.

description:
As an SF native, I have never felt like a tourist in this town until I sat at the counter of Swan Oyster Depot.  Service is friendly, wait was to be expected.  Window filled with seafood made my eyes bigger.

I found it interesting how each server who prepared a salad, carefully placed each seafood piece on the bed of lettuce.  Lots of seafood in the salad!  Clam chowder is tasty with the fresh oyster crackers and sourdough bread.  Yum.  Oysters - 3 different types were yum as well.

It's a tad cozy and it wasn't until the guy sitting next to me left that I could actually move my chair up to the counter.  I didn't realized till after we ordered that there's a whole other off the menu list of items that you could ask for.

Honig Sauv. Blanc - excellent choice!
author: Denice L.

description:
This is one of my favorite restaurants in the city, which is why I chose it as my first yelp review:  I went with a couple of friends recently, and the seafood and service definitely lived up to our (pretty lofty) expectations.  The oysters were amazing, and the smoked salmon was so delicious that I had to buy a half-pound to take home with me.  It's also always fun to have a beer and joke with the staff.

Which is to say, the service is uniformly outstanding; the staff clearly love working there, and take a lot of pride in their restaurant (I think that most of the staff are related in one way or another).

Despite the fact that it's cash-only and pricey for lunch, I would highly recommend it for a long lunch during the week (or weekend if you don't mind the wait).
author: Derek K.

description:
Go. Do not hesitate. Do not go late. Enjoy the angels of seafood as they lavish it upon you. And be thankful. Dangit. =)

Anchor Steam, lotsa fresh sourdough, clam chowder oh yes, oysters on the half shell, prawn and crab salad oh my...just keep eating.
author: Cassandra G.

description:
Don't ever go to Swan, that way I can get a seat faster. 

I love this place, it is too expensive to go all the time but once a month is certainly in the budget. I always get the combo salad. FYI, you can get a small salad instead of a regular sized one if you aren't all that hungry.

The line is generally long, so I only try to go at off hours. The people that work there are all characters and are part of the fun of eating there. 

How fresh is the food? I ate some raw oysters at Swan the day before my wedding (in July). Afterward the thought entered my head, "Aren't you supposed to avoid oysters in r-less months!?" but then I remember that I ate at Swan and I feared no longer.
author: Ryan S.

description:
Not much to say here that others haven't already. But, I loves me some Dungeness Crab Louie salad, sourdough and a pint. It's pricey but worth it every once in awhile.

I was there today and we didn't want to wait in line so we got it to go drove up Sacramento Street to Layette Park. We ate a bench with an incredible view of the Bay. You don't get the cool ambiance and service of being inside of the place, but it's good alternative.
author: Scott M.

description: Any place that stays family owned for that long and still has great service and GREAT eats gets two thumbs up in my book! Go on off peak days and hours for the best atmosphere.  When was the last time they moped the floors? Who cares?! It adds to the ambiance! As long as the oysters are fresh this little butt will keep subjecting itself to those ridiculously uncomfortable stools!
author: Tessa R.

description:
I hate to have to hate this place despite the hype and the long lines of diners waiting to dine inside.

One word: Disappointing. The clam chowder was oily and hardly contain any clams, mostly watery and filled with potatoes. Seafood in general wasn't very appealing... I would not go back.
author: Yan M.

description: Best lunch I've had all year. Friendly staff. Really fresh oysters and shrimp (from the shrimp combo salad I had). Had to wait for about 35 mins to get in and it was around 2:45pm. The whole time I was eating, there was a constant line outside. I will definitely wanna go back again to try the raw clams next time, can't wait!
author: Jenny L.

description:
I just decided that my perfect last meal on earth would be Swan Depot, and hopefully my last meal will be brought to me, since they do have takeout.  So even with 258 reviews and all, I'm going to write about it anyway.  Here is my perfect meal, which I've actually had before in one sitting, after eating lunch right before w/ only the 20 min break from waiting in line.  Yes, it's that good if you're a seafood lover.

-Clam chowder: I love that it's more liquidy than creamy -- you get more of the clam flavor that way. 
-French sourdough bread: deliciously chewy, with magically creamy Clover butter.
-1 dozen mixed raw oysters with delicious red onion-vinegar-shallot-lemon sauce and fresh horseradish on the side: Miyagi, Blue points, Kumamoto, local variety, etc.... great for figuring out what you like.  I've learned that I prefer the Pacific ones (sweeter and less creamy) to the New England ones (saltier and bigger)
-Crab cocktail: peeled and piled into a goblet, with Louie sauce on the side (crab salad is good too, but why bother with lettuce that just takes up space in the tums).
-ice cold Anchor Steam Beer: absolutely perfect with the oysters.

Finger-lickin' good, fresh seafood.  This family-owned place of ~3 generations exemplifies SF friendliness and great service.  The place is small with just one counter, but go around 3-4pm and the wait is really not so bad -- plus it's totally worth it in the end.  Yes it may be pricey, but it's fresh seafood shucked and prepared in front of your eyes. Bring cash since it's cash-only.
author: Erica Y.

description:
I'd been hearing Bourdain rave about this place on his show for years, so thinking he knew something I took my family there for lunch during our SF vacation last April. 
It turned out to be the low point of our trip. After standing in line for 30 minutes, we finally got to the counter only to find out they were out of crab, and the bread isn't free. Not wanting to leave without trying something we ordered the clam chowder which was a watery mess. 
We got lucky when we decided against ordering one of the over-priced salads after seeing how they were prepared. The ol' boys behind the counter go from the register or whatever else they're doing, and with bare, unwashed hands grab shredded iceberg lettuce and pile it on a plate. From there they grab a handful of boiled shrimp from the window and dump it on top of the lettuce. That's it. That's the salad, and it'll set you back $15 and up. 
This is your classic tourist trap. The old timers working the counter put on a show much like you'd expect to find on a busy night at Cheers if Ted Danson was behind the bar. The food is really just incidental, even if the prices are not. 
The whole thing smells and feels like an audition for a reality show starring some jolly old guys and really bland seafood.
author: Pat M.

description:
I was reading the SFGate article a few months back about restaurant hygiene ratings and, to my dismay, I immediately identified the unnamed seafood restaurant of the article that rated a score of 54 out of a possible 100. When I go here, I amuse myself by speculating how they've managed to not be shut down by food inspectors. Bread is stacked on dusty shelves, they're cutting up fish in front of you while you eat, and I've seen them bring in whole salmon to scrub in the sinks used for all purposes. I guess I have strange standards for amusement. 

That being said, it is still my favorite seafood place. I am careful where I eat, and I've never had concerns that their food was anything but absolutely fresh.  They will rush you a bit if you dally at the counter, so it's not the place for a casual hour-long lunch. But it's hard to beat the price and surly ambiance for a tray of oysters and a beer. I pretty much stick with that and their smoked fish plate. Yummy!
author: Bubbles L.

description:
I'm loath to post about this place because it's such a treasure, and it's already so small and the lines already so long, but ...

This place is a San Francisco institution,  Go.
author: Asteridae A.

description: I never thought I'd like raw oyster, but after eating Swan Oyster Depot's oysters, I'm more than willing to go back for more.  The seafood here is so fresh and flavorful.  The clam chowder is pretty good, and has lots of clam in it.  The staff here are super friendly.  I came around 11:15-11:20 on a weekday and there was no line and 3 seats left.  I got my food to go, and 5-10 minutes later after arriving there, all the seats had been filled and there was a line of 3-4 people out the door already.  So, come early to avoid waiting.
author: Karen W.

description: we ordered the clam chowder with a side of raw oysters and sat on the mini seating area up the block. i must say, this is the best weekend brunch ever. the clam chowder wasn't overly creamy and the seafood in the chowder wasn't too pungent either ( you know how seafood has that natural odor/taste?). lets not forget about the oysters, so juicy, so satisfying, so...raw! i was in complete bliss.
author: Jen C.

description:
Best sashimi in the city, it's not on the menu, but they'll make it if you ask nicely.  Also love their oysters, the crab louie salad, bread, smoked fish, and everything else on the menu.  

When my family is in town, this is a must stop.  Came here after a particularly not fun medical experience and was smiling by the time we left.
author: Kristen N.

description:
Man... if you don't like seafood, HEY! I MEAN REAL SEAFOOD INCLUDING THE RAW STUFF, please don't go to Swan and leave bad reviews here.

If you want to have frozen seafood at a fancy restaurant and enjoy the customer service and soft sofa seat while you chat your life, your previous life, and your past life, away with your friends, please don't go to Swan and leave bad reviews here.

This place is for some hardcore seafood, especially raw clams & oyster, eaters. You eat the very fresh seafood here, taste the best shelled clams & oysters (barely any bits of shells), enjoy the sweetness of raw stuff, and you get out of here. Very efficient. Very tasty. Very fresh--probably fish everything early morning and sell them out in a day--never frozen or left-overs. Very friendly fishermen.

If you can't stand the pressure of people waiting for seats, just don't turn your head. Keep your eyes on the food. Dang it, who the heck cares! It's not like you don't order anything but still taking the seat. I can't believe someone is complaining about the customers waiting in line here. It's an oyster depot, DEPOT, like an oyster bar! You want comfy seat, go to Red Lobster, and let me tell you, you are probably getting frozen seafood. 

Again, it's true what the others have said. You can't go there for the cooking, the sauce, the creativity, the dining environment, the presentation, because there is none. You go there for the freshest, most original taste of seafood. 

By the way, if you like the creamy clam chowder, don't order it from Swan. To be honest, I don't like its clam chowder either, but it's another way of making it. Swan uses powder form instead of Safeway-canned form so it's not thick and creamy. But it's full of real clams though!
author: HsuMeow L.

description: There were probably 3 groups in front of us and it still took an hour waiting in line. Some people just never leave once they sit down I guess. It was good, seafood salad and the clams. Not used to the "east coast" style clam chowder here, but I've had it elsewhere and I liked it. It seemed to do with soup stock they used. I think the price is a slightly high for some things..
author: Angela W.

description:
Amazing fresh seafood!  The oysters are great.  The service is fun.  A hole in the wall place that is well worth the wait. 

Only downside is that they close pretty early, every day of the week.
author: Gloria J.

description:
Get your aphrodisiac on!

Swan is my favorite excuse to play hookey from work. EVERYTHING is amazing on the menu... chowder, sea urchin, caviar, smoked delites, and the Ooo-Ooo-Oooysters!

The guys that work here are super friendly, and make you feel like you're part of the crew. Take their advice on any menu recommendations!

So take the day off, grab a pint or two, chat with the friendly folks in line, and get your aphrodisiac on. If you're not turned on when you get there... you will be when you leave.
author: Elizabeth L.

description:
Swan's is one of my most favorite places, anywhere, ever.

Good natured shit talking, the best collection of rubber duckies around, homemade hooch and unbelievably fresh, tasty bi-valves. Not to mention excellent seafood salads, great calamari cocktail and periodically fresh, imported Maryland Blue Crabs (for which I could kiss each and every man working in the place).

God I love Swan's. Just thinking about it makes me happy. I could sit at the counter eating bowls of chowder and slurping down oysters with delightful mignonette while shooting the shit with the guys all damn day long. 

The only drawback is the line (although it does heighten your sense of anticipation). Don't get there after 11 a.m. unless you're willing to wait. That being said, the wait is so totally worth it.
author: Catherine H.

description: I ordered 2 cleaned cooked and cracked crabs to go for $30.  Crabs to go is a good and tasty idea.
author: Wakako U.

description:
I laugh at you, you poor ignorant tourists at the Wharf. I know you want crab, clam chowder, and anything seafood.  That's why you're there. Frommer's, Fodor's, and even those Idiot's told you to go there.  "Can't miss out on a unique SF experience."  Go back home with your postcards, pictures, and stories on how fresh everything was.  What a joke.  Only true locals know Swan's got the BEST seafood in the Bay, hands down! Their long ass line (out the door) just to sit on their rickety stools to eat their food is proof. 

Excuse me tourists, if I don't attempt to hide my smirks.  You guys are suckers, and you don't even know it.
author: Ezduzit S.

description:
Seems like this is yet another one of these - not the prettiest but f'n awesome places that I like... something very appealing about substance over presentation... a key to life...

The oyster freshness can't be beat, the variety can't be beat, the clam chowder is like butter... it's not cheap but it's not Farallon price either... Farallon is very good too but Swan Oyster Depot has character. The wait can get bad but not like Dottie's bad...
author: Joe M.

description:
Another OMG review classification....

First time ever and was worth to wait.

I was here recently. I have been into the oyster mood lately and I can only say two words about this place and I hope it does describe my experience....1.- HOLY   2.- SHIT!

We got there late it was about 3:30 the line in the place went two doors down (not like the song) and it was windy but the window sea food looked soo good I couldn't give up.

We ordered a beer, we figured that by the time we were inside a beer would be enough. Well because we were there late and the boys in the place close around 5:00 or 5:30 they gave us a note that says that we were the last in the line, meaning that if someone got behind us we needed to hand the sign and break their heart telling them, sorry we are the last ones.

Well I was in my third beer and we were still nowhere inside the place but we met three fun people. Steve which was a local customer, very friendly, Arby and Ab.....  (I can't remember how to spell it, please make a note I had alcohol over the driving limit).  Anyways, it was so much fun, at one point I forgot what was the line for since we were simply having fun in the line.

When we got in and found seats available the ambience was incredible, it reminded me of my "ole times" I basically ate 3 dozens of oysters, a shrimp cocktail, a calamari cocktail salad and a shrimp cocktail with two more beers.

Well...the guys kept asking -"Does anybody else want more Oysters" DUH... I kept saying yes! I ate until I could become a maritime beast, not like I am not one already! 

Well The guys are simply the best. We pretty much closed the place and the people there is extra friendly which is super nice. We met people from Ohio and Boston and yes we had a blast! The line was nothing but the appetizer for a marvelous meal. If you are planning to come to have sea food arrive early or expect a friendly line. I heard from Steve that this place is nicely relaxed during weekdays and earlier before lunch. They do serve take out orders and there is nothing in this place that is negative. No credit cards are accepted.

T...thanks for the food, the tequila shots, the sponge and the history, it would look awesome in my fav restaurant memoirs! 


XOXO
Claudia
author: Claudia D.

description: This place is awesome!!! The workers are so nice and make you feel comfortable right away. It's really small and you're lucky if you find a seat... we waited for around 10 minutes, which isn't bad at all. We weren't planning on having a full dinner here so we opted for the clam chowder soup and a plate oysters. To be honest, the clam chowder soup was to clam-y for me, but that is only in my opinion. They have a big bowl of crackers you can put into your soup. The oysters were so fresh and amazing and you get a side of cocktail sauce to go along with it. Everything at Swan Oyster Depot looked very fresh. Next time I'd like to try the crab cocktail or maybe even one of the salads! As we were walking out, they handed us a postcard and a sponge as a souvenir. Everyone at this place is so friendly! I highly recommend that if you're in the area and craving seafood to check them out!
author: Anna K.

description:
The cat has been out of the bag on Swan for as long as I have lived here (and then some).  

Combo salad with extra louie dressing (to dunk your bread in) is the way to go.  Get the mixed dozen of oysters with mignonette on the side.

I really don't want to write this review because it will only make the line longer for everyone else but the place is one of the best seafood restaurants in the country.

That said, if the line is too long, get some take out and hit wash sq park and tease the dogs with your prawns. 

Enjoy!
author: Rob K.

description: Unbelievable!!!!! Waited in line for 30 minutes and worth every minute.  Started off with the clam chowder.  Awesome!  Moved on to shrimp cocktail and then the eastern oysters.  I will definitely go back to Swans when we visit San Francisco again.  The staff is very nice and sociable.  I love the place!!
author: Colman R.

description:
I was super excited when I was told I was being taken out to Swan Oyster Depot.  I always saw a line outside and wanted to see what all of the talk was about.  Plus, this was the first week of crab season.  Score.

Went with a group of five, waited in line for about 45 minutes, but it wasn't a big deal at all.  We were lucky enough to get seats next to each other... I guess we just had good time.  However, the people that worked there were more than willing to coordinate with us.  Awesome.

We all ordered a cup of chowder.  Bomb.  The oyster crackers made it even better.  It wasn't too rich, but just right.  Their sourdough bread was also quite delicious and perfect to dip into the chowder.  I ordered the crab cocktail and it sure was fresh.  My friend next to me got the combination salad and his Louie sauce was amazing!  

All in all, this place was awesome.  Everyone was really friendly and not pushy at all about trying to get everyone in and out as quick as possible.  Just straight up good food and service.
author: Cara D.

description: Not sure I get the hype.  It's classic, I'll give you that, but the two hour wait for some streamed or boiled seafood seems like a long time.  Bar seats only and roughly 16 or so at best.  Five guys making guys making everything to order every time.  Combo salad was OK but nothing amazing per the other posts.  Some boiled shrimp / crab and the standard thousand island dressing.  Everything is roughly 10, 12 & 20 dollars.  Better lunches are had elsewhere in the city without the wait.
author: Brent K.

description:
I was super excited to try this place after seeing such raving reviews on yelp. I love oysters and the dozen mixed oysters were really good. I enjoyed the variety we got to sample. The clam chowder is unique in that it is very "soupy" and thin for boston clam chowder-- the clam taste is very good though. I actually liked the thin consistency because it was different. The crab salad was very good, but unfortunately I don't like thousand island dressing so I had to wipe off some of the dressing. The meat was very fresh tasting and awessssome.

My main gripe is the size of the place in relation to the number of customers. It is so small that there is a consistent line out the door. It is a good idea to come by yourself or only one other person because seating for more than that is not guaranteed. 8We waited in the cold for maybe half an hour. Other than that, it was a good experience.
author: Shizuka L.

description: Fish is fresh and melts in your mouth. Great atmosphere and greater staff. I loved every minute!
author: Ronen B.

description:
This place is very good for seafood.  Not cheap, but very fresh.  The atmosphere is great.  This has become an annual tradition with coworkers and the group gets bigger every year.  Everyone loves it.

Hint:  Half Cracked Dungeness $16.50 & some manual labor required; Crab Cocktail $8.50 (or $10.50 can't recall exactly) and almost just as much crab meat WITH NO LABOR WHATSOEVER (completely shelled already).  That's the better deal.  HOPE this Helps.

CLAM CHOWDER a must!  Not thick & creamy like campbells or "clam gravy"...it's a real soup with real clams!
author: Sequoia S.

description:
I wish I could afford to eat here all the time, because I love this place. Amazing oysters - everyone knows that by now. Ask them to give you a sampler of what they have, they'll gladly oblige. The perhaps lesser-known house smoked salmon is simply sublime, and I will always get this if I have room in my belly and even more cash in my wallet. Oh seafood, why do you have to be so pricey when you are high quality?

Come with one or two other people at the most - no room for larger parties. Eat bread, slurp chowder, be happy.
author: Andy M.

description:
Awesome food




Terrible neighborhood
watch for human feces while in line
author: Spencer G.

description:
First of all, there will be a line.  Don't be discouraged.  I have to admit that when I saw the line as I was approaching, I did think about turning around.  However, I was determined to give this place a shot and figured that the food must be good if there's a line.  We finally got seated about an hour later.  

The wait got us hungry and we wanted everything!  We started off with a dozen of assorted oysters: Blue Point, Drake's Bay and Tomales Bay.  They were so fresh and nicely chilled that we ordered another dozen.  :)  Then we had a dozen of the Cherry Stone clams on a half shell.  Again, very fresh and nicely chilled.  To me, these 2 aspects are important when having oysters and clams on a half shell because they're just gross warm even when sitting on a bed of ice.  Then we had scallop sashimi.  This was served carpaccio style with butter, olive oil, chopped onions and capers.  The scallops were fresh and sweet.  We had seen pictures from previous Yelpers on some fish sashimi, so we decided to have some: Blue Fin tuna and salmon.  We all agreed that this was a dish we could've skipped.  The fish were fresh, but definitely not sushi quality.  Next came the smoked salmon (flavorful and buttery) served with chopped onions and capers on a sliced baguette.  We finished off with a bowl of clam chowder.  Different from what I'm use to (the creamy style) and runnier but it was delicious.  There was a purer clam juice flavor that I liked a lot.

The service was outstanding.  All the previous reviews about the service was spot on.  Everyone there was friendly and happy to answer any questions you have.  Our main server was Jimmy.  When we started to rattle off our order, he suggested the order to have them as to not mess with our pallet.  Although he was the main person that helped us, everyone there was helpful.  There was a nice warmth and family feel amongst everyone that works there.

All in all, a great first but not last experience.  Any place that has great service, atmosphere and food will always keep me coming back.  The only negative was the cramp bar style seating.  If you want fine dining, this isn't the place for you.  The reason I gave this place 5 stars is for the freshness of the food and the awesome service.
author: Q O.

description:
After passing by the place countless times and noting the huge lines and the "SF institution" atmosphere, I planned to one day pop my cherry on this place.  Well today was the day, and I must say I was thrilled with it.

Started off with a quick half dozen oysters.  I'm not a huge fan of oysters, but these were fresh; the flavor rich.  The shrimp louie salad was outstanding -- the portions ample and the shrimp to lettuce ratio commendable.  

Finally I must mention the clam chowder.  I LOVE clam chowder.  I eat it every chance I get.  I like it nice and thick and creamy with plenty of clam and little to no potato.  The clam was nice and chunky -- NO grit either. You usually have to expect a bit of grit, but theirs was totally sans.  The soup itself was a bit thin, but by no means watery.  Despite that one mark, I still give their clam chowder top marks.

I can't wait to go back, dig into some cracked crab and another louie salad.  Three of us ate there for lunch and spent $35.  The staff were friendly and jovial, encouraging a friendly, talkative atmosphere of regulars and welcome newcomers.  This will definitely be added to the list of must eat restaurants for visiting friends.

The only caveats are that it's a small place with uncomfortable stools and limited space.  Even at 3pm on a Tuesday, there was a line.  I can't imagine getting in here on the weekend or prime lunch hours.

UPDATE:
Returned today (3/07).  My wife got major food poisoning from the miyagi oysters.  Have to knock a star off for that!  I wonder how often that sort of thing happens.
author: Eric X.

description: What can I say about this place that hasn't already been written....purely awesome experience, food, service, and the real San Francisco.
author: Craig S.

description:
My friends have been harassing me since I have no reviews. But there's just too much too much pressure to be funny! So I'll keep this one short and simple... and save the rambling for next time.

Some people won't get what the fuss is about but I think Swan's setup is cute. AW. will appreciate this place! And yes, the menu is limited but it hits the spot when I crave something tasty yet simple.

I usually get the crab cocktail. They're quite generous with the amount  they give you. For me the cocktail is a better deal than the cracked crab, plus no messy fingers and juices squirting all over the place! Once I took my leftovers on the bus and everyone shot me daggers.

Love this place but wouldn't wait in line for it. Get it to go! It's just as good. But beware it closes at 5:30 and isn't open on Sunday.
author: Princess Pompom Patootie W.

description:
In line for 45 minutes, in the rain with a sinus infection that I was pretty sure would make me bleed out of my ears, the guy behind us in line asked us, "Would you really want to eat here if there hadn't been a line?"  Well, yeah, I would have.  But truth of the matter is that I just didn't care, not even with a nuclear headache and a worsening case of the DTs.  

The Depot is kind of like In & Out Burger, except with raw shellfish in place of biblical scriptures:  The servers are as nice as Mormons, you wait in line for a long time to get your food, and the menu only has a handful of items on it.  But oh, what items!

Get:
Oysters:  The kumamotos and miyagis are my favorites -- very briny, small, not chewy.  The blue points are bigger and sweeter, but don't pack the same brackish goodness. 

Crab salad: It's a plate of iceberg lettuce with "louie sauce" (I think it's just thousand-island dressing) with heaps of dungeness crab. 

Get if you're brave:
Raw Clams:  They're meatier, chewier, and a little sour....Imagine a shell full of cold, pink mucus flavored with horseradish and you've pretty much pegged it. 

Also:  They don't have horseshoe crab, but the guy behind the counter assured me that they are related to trilobites, and that made my day.
author: Phil K.

description:
The only reason for 4 stars is the guaranteed wait time.  If you want to eat at a normal lunch time, you will surely have to wait.  If you can eat at 11:00 or even earlier, I would.

The Crab Salad is my go to dish.  The combo salad is great too.  The chowder tastes great, but is not "thick and creamy."  I'm not an oyster guy, but people suck 'em down like crazy.

Service is great, fast, and friendly - once your at a stool.

MUST GO!
author: Mike A.

description:
my daughter and i went into swans today and ordered some fresh oysters on a half shell for the first time and a crab and shrimp cocktail, i dealt with a man named steve there, he was a excellent person to have take your order, being that  it was my first time having fresh raw oysters, he recomended which one i should start off with and you know what he was right, i love them, and the combination cocktail that he made me was excellent as well, the service was outstanding the food was so fresh and the environment was nice and clean and everyone there was enjoying themselves, if you are ever in san francisco and you want to eat some really fresh seafood, and also have great service i recommend that you try swans oyster depot, it's a great place to go and relax, eat and be comfortable all at the same time, so once again thank you steve for a wonderful experience and when i come back i will be asking for you!!!!                                               


                                        thank you, monique & porsha
author: Monique C.

description:
The anachronism of an old school San Francisco family business that still lingers on into modernity is a rare gem in the City. Swan (Quiznos commercial aside) embodies this for me.

Almost all of the restaurants and shops that existed in the pre-war years, those foggy years after the quake and before the jet-age, are gone, mostly long gone but a few still lay hidden in plain sight.

Swan Oyster is too good and too well located to have ever remained a hole in the wall (though the size of the restaurant is not much bigger than a hole in the wall). The fact that they continue to exist in the near perfect state we find it is amazing. I think the secret of this success is no secret. It is plainly obvious that a strong family business that embodies the spirit of old time blue collar jovial San Francisco (ala Herb Cain) is a winning and profitable formula. See's Candy, located right next door to Swan also embodied this formula, and Warren Buffet bought that company and didn't change a thing. I think Buffet would love to eat here and would agree - Don't change a thing Swan.

When the last fish in the ocean is served - it should be here.

So Long, and Thanks for All the Fish.
author: Jack K.

description:
My wife and I had the oysters.  Now, tell me, why is it considered an aphrodisiac?  Is it really?  Who made up this stuff?  Is there a scientific basis for this?  C'mon, I know about food and culture and the occasional jib jab about health, but really.  It's a mollusk.  I mean, I don't hear about people raving about the scaffolding effects of licking the benevolent Santa Cruz banana slug.  Some might get all technical and say, well a slug is a gastropod and not a marine bivalve... well, then technically tell me why... is it then...considered?  Yeah!

ANYways,  

we thoroughly enjoyed our dinners, the service was smashing on a Tuesday night, and we ran back home after paying a substantial but well- worth-it sum of money.  

And the answer is "yes".
author: John L.

description:
On the strength of reviews here I trekked to Swan from my hotel on 3rd and Market after a day at Macworld. I spent the holidays sampling east coast oysters - Belons, Beau Soleils, Malpeques, etc. so I looked forward to some west coast flavor.

No disappointments. I sampled Blue Points (not a Western oyster originally), Miyagis, Kumomotos, and Olympias. All were delicous. Blue points had a great meaty texture, Miyagis, my favorite, had a heavier brine with woody tones. Kumos had the famous creamy texture, and the little Olympias surprised me with a great brine and hints of chocolate, believe it or not.

While I savored the bivalves, a rickety, bearded old fisherman sauntered in quietly and ordered a sea urchin. After it was cracked open, he stopped the guy behind the counter. "Gimme a whole one," he said. "To go."

Seeing no hint of urchin on the menu, I couldn't resist. Long after the fisherman absconded to the docks with his booty, I had half an urchin in front of me. I pulled Steve, who seemed to be in charge, aside. "How the hell do I eat this?" He suggested thinly sliced bread and some lemon juice, or soy sauce, provided all three right away, and checked in later to see my reaction...

Prior to the oysterfest, I had a bowl of clam chowder. This may have been the best I've ever had. The consistency is not too heavy, but satisfying. It sticks to your ribs.

50 bucks for a dozen excellent oysters, a bowl of clam chowder, a prime urchin, and a few pints of Anchor Steam. Not too bad.

My only problem? The Anchor Steam wasn't cold enough. Overall, a great spot. Can't wait to come back.
author: Liam L.

description:
Wow this was delicious. I'd give it five stars, but i'm not that easy. I came here on the weekend which was a mistake. I had to wait over an hour just to get inside (This wasn't as big a deal as it sounds. Everyone on line was pleasent and friendly). 

Once I got inside though, I was greated by outgoing and quarky waiters. I had come with the intention of eating just Oysters, but while online I heard rave reviews about the Clam Chowder, and the Seafood Salads. Never one to miss out on anything, I tried them all.

I started with a combination plate of Oysters, which were sooooo good. Then the soup, and finally, the salad. The oysters were by far the star for me, but the soup was rather good too. If I came back, I would get both again. The seafood salad was also quite tasty, but I'd rather spend the money on MORE oysters.

Definitely stop by here.

P.s
Even after all those entrees I still ordered more Oysters!
author: David R.

description:
It's been 2 years and I'm still thinking about this place.  This dive is small... there are only counter seats....about 15 or so.  You wait in line...but it's so worth it.  We tried 3 different oysters, the shrimp salad (which looks like nothing but lettuce and shrimp but the dressing is to die for).  Clam chowder was really good too.  If you like oysters, I demand you go here if you're in SF.  Seriously.  I wouldn't lie!  

I wish I could go back to this place.  It was so wonderful.  If you live in SF, it's shame if you don't go there often.
author: Minnie E.

description:
Loved it! 

Oysters, fantastic

Combo seafood cocktail-the tiny dish it comes in is very deceiving! More than enough, I couldn't finish mine. Next time I will request the cocktail sauce on the side. 

Clam chowder-not the best, it was "broken". I hate that with cream soups. Great clam flavor though

Anchor Steam on tap-keep it coming

I loved the pace. No rush, take your time, and enjoy. Even though the wait was about an hour standing in line.....everyone was pretty calm. Keep your eyes on the prize. Savor your spot inside when it comes available.
author: Ahna P.

description:
Oh seafood how do I love thee so. Swans is obviously a tourist spot, but it is still something to check out at least once if you are local. Seriously. 

Some highlights: Crab salad is all crab and no salad, just the way I like it. The fresh bread and clam chowder was to DIE FOR. And the oysters taste as fresh as the ocean they come in (get a couple different kinds). You will seriously not find better oysters anywhere else.

Bring a friend and only one because you'll want to squeeze into a seat. Large parties will have to wait even longer. And just accept that you will stand in line for 45 minutes or else you'll be bummed before you catch a bite of your fresh catch.

Would I be a regular customer? Prolly not, been there just a handful of times since moving to SF, too much of a hassle. Not giving it 5 stars because of this.
author: Ali K.

description:
I have lived within walking distance from Swan for a couple years now and man, this is a tough place to go to!  There are just too many reasons not to go:

1. The line is ALWAYS at least 30 minutes long. Trust me, I've walked by at all times of the day

2. They are officially only open till about 3pm - and one time I left work early just to go to Swan and got there at 2pm. The must have run out of fish or something b'c all the workers were having a beer and wouldn't let anyone in.

3. They are only open Mon-Sat. Chances are slim you'll wait any less than 45 min on a Saturday unless you can gulp down oyster shooters and 11am - no thanks!

4.  Oh and they only take cash.

So I FINALLY buckled down and patiently waited in line as it poured cats and dogs outside. One would think in flooding rain in SF, who would want to go to Swan. I was wrong.

Ahhh...clam chowder - hmm...I think the chef was off that day. It was strangely watery and had this oily layer on top. The crab cocktail was good but I know next time to ask for the cocktail sauce on the side. The blue point oysters were the BEST EVER oysters. These are the really fat, juicy ones. They are a little extra but well worth it if you like the big ones. 

I think I'd go back but am now better informed on what all the hype is about this place. Overall, it was good seafood but nothing you couldn't get at Scoma's... The line would have to be really short for me to return.
author: Josephine H.

description:
I was brought to SWAN the other day for my birthday.

I knew nothing about the hype, all my boyfriend told me was, "This place is awesome."

We stood in line for about 15 minutes (which, if you have an iPhone, is like 2 minutes), then we took our seats at the bar.  Besides anyway, in my opinion a line isn't really something to complain about....  Moving on...

Having quit seafood for almost a decade and being a recent consumer again, I was a little overwhelmed and unsure where to start, so I went the safe route and started with the clam chowder.

Clam Chowder = Wow!!!!!!

I'm from NJ and this is the first place that I've had a clam chowder that tasted as good as the chowder from the Jersey Shore and Maryland!  It wasn't thick and creamy which is the route some people take, but for me, it was perfection.

While I worked on that, the boyfriend got a combination cocktail which I had a bite of...  Incredible.

After that we ordered up a combination salad (crab and prawn) and had a half order of the smoked salmon.  They brought us a jar of capers and cracked black pepper, recommending to add it to the salmon.

The seafood is INCREDIBLE here.  It is worth the price.  No where in the city has comparable quality.

The best part is it is family owned and run, and the gents behind the bar are as sweet as can be.

I would definitely come back, and bring any visitors I would get from the east coast.  :)
author: Jess R.

description:
"You like Oysters?" I enthusiastically asked my latest girlfriend.
"Yes," she replied.

Within five minutes of our conversation I was online looking for the best oysters in SF, and most of my resources pointed to Swan Oyster Depot on Polk Street. The following Saturday, I suggested we hit the Depot for lunch, and she eagerly agreed.

THE LINE
There is almost always a line out side, but good things come to those who wait. The line runs right next to a See's Candies so if you just can't wait any longer, you can get yourself a bon bon. Oh, and if you ask nicely, they will sell you a beer or a glass of wine to drink while in line.

INSIDE
This is literally an oyster and seafood bar. The keyword here is BAR, as in stools facing a counter. The staff is primarily made up of relatives or old friends of the original owner so they get along and horse around with each other while serving up some great seafood.

THE FOOD
Get the beverage of your choice and the talk with your server. Tell them what you like in an oyster - small, large, firm, salty, etc. and they will meet your needs.

I really have not gotten past the oysters, but I have heard great things from my co-diners regarding the shrimp salad. I mean, if you go out for oysters, eat some oysters! A lot of oysters! Two dozen shells later I was rolling out the door happy, healthy and with a new favorite oyster bar.

The girlfriend is gone, but Swan's is still one of my favorites.
author: Kemp M.

description:
This place is the Shit, I bring Friends, Family, Neighbors, Second cousins, rustlers, cutthroats, murders, bounty hunters, desperados, mugs, pugs, thugs, nitwits, halfwits, dimwits, vipers, snipers, con-men, Indian agents, Mexican bandits, muggers, buggerers, bushwhackers, hornswogglars, horse thieves, bull-dykes, train robbers, bank robbers, ass-kickers, shit-kickers, and Methodists! 
But the best thing is the fact the food is fresh and delicious. Get there early to find a seat. If you go at Noon you'll be waiting till 1pm.
 The first time I went I ended up ordering 3 dozen oysters and having a bowl of the most buttery tasting clam chowder I have ever eaten. This place has been around for over a century and shows no sign of going anywhere. I love the marble counter top/trough and always try to sit by the window. In fact I think I know where Im heading for lunch today. 
Go often Eat Lots.

P.S. a good portion of this review was plagiarized. Thanks to Mel & Richard and preformed by the talented Harry.
author: Tony P.

description: The oysters were good, crab was great. The clam chowder was ok.The wait was an hour, no reservations. Only 18 seats at the bar. Fresh seafood in the window looked good.
author: Lynne P.

description:
Here's what impressed me the most:  Two guys who were right in front of us got sat at same time we did.  All four of us had been in line for about an hour and ten.  we ended up sitting next to them at the counter.  They ordered two bowls of clam chowder, which comes with their fantastic sourdough bread, and one of them had a beer.  THEY WAITED AN HOUR AND TEN MINUTES FOR SOUP, BREAD AND A BEER.  that's how good the clam chowder is.  or, maybe more importantly, that's how great of a place this is.  the wait adds to your anticipation, makes you know how special it will be once you get inside. Once inside. plunk your booty down on a tiny stool,  take up your one foot of counter space, and wait for the drooling to begin.  

Another special moment:  Watching the care that one of the older counter guys takes when picking out your crab and shrimp for the combo louie salad.  it's like he's selecting jewels, and placing them on a bed of velvet - when in fact he's plucking fat pieces of crab and plump shrimps to nestle in shredded iceberg lettuce, to soon be napped in a rich thousand island dressing.  Such creamy goodness.  

We had the combo raw clam and oyster platter - 6 oysters, 3 of a kind, 3 big neck clams and 3 little neck clams.  All fresh and bright and slippery and yum.  Sides of kicky horseradish, cocktail sauce, and mignonette.  We wanted the steamed lobster but they were out.  Damn.  Were dying to dip succulent lobster hunks in the little copper pots that they serve the drawn butter in. 

We shared the clam chowder soup - not too thick, very milky, very clammy, rich but not cloying.  Little perfectly cooked potato die.  Jig of Tabasco - aahhhh.

The star for me (besides that bread) was the combo salad.  Again, just these big fat pieces of crab and shrimp covered in their super unctuous dressing, over crisp cool iceberg.  My sister needed to doctor the dressing a bit with their cocktail sauce - for her the dressing was too rich.  I loved it - been craving it all day.

Amazingly, we spent only $40+, and were so full and satisfied.

I had a Stella Artois on tap, and next time I'll have a couple glasses of the Pinot Grigio, or better yet, the French Muscadet.  I want to try the salmon roe which they apparently serve sashimi style.  I want to get sloppy with a half crab or a whole lobster.  i want to try their smoked whitefish.  I want to eat four more servings of that bread.  

And I'm going to get their early and turn away from the window so I don't feel bad about the people waiting in line.  I was once you, brother!
author: maria a.

description:
So my best friend decided after maybe 3 months of not hanging out that she wanted to take me out for lunch. She picked this place, (she's a really bossy friend) and of course, I said yes, :(. I went to meet up with her and waited an hour before we got to sit down. While waiting in line, my friend asked one of the guys, Guy (my friend knows his name by heart)  to give us each a glass of wine. So to make the story short, by the time we got to sit down, we were already buzzed and very very loud. Her and I together are definitely trouble.

We feasted on fresh cherry stone clams, oysters, crab salad and crab cocktail. My God! We were in heaven.  

I retract what i said about Sotto Mare being comparable to Swan Depot.  Swan Depot definitely has the ambiance that no other places in San Francisco can offer.
author: Janette M.

description: We went there about a year ago. We arrived about 45 minutes before they opened and were amongst the first party that was seated. Everything was so fresh. One of the best sea urchins I have had in my life. Go for brunch and go early. Would definitely go back.
author: Fatima V.

description: Unless you enjoy curdled clam chowder (they said it was the clam juice) followed by about 24 hrs of GI distress, save your time & $$.  There are plenty of other places in SF that offer much better.  Upon calling to voice my concern, I was overcome by arrogance & snarky behavior which wouldn't allow me complete a sentence.  I was told that "there is something out there called a flu going around".  As an RN I don't know of any flu that hits all members of a dining party simultaneously w/only GI issues, & ceases once the problem food is evacuated.  The fish is fresh, but handled w/bare hands as are the community bowls of crackers & lemon wedges.   They cook, clean & collect $$ w/bare hands.  During our wait we had plenty of time to observe that hand washing is even more limited than the seating.
author: Alena T.

description:
SF's freshest seafood and shellfish served up cheerfully by the same family who have owned it since the beginning of time, I think. My good friend Guy Spanali (also singer/mainman for Rattlecans Rock 'n' Blues Band) is probably the only non-family member working there, and he's had a gig pretty much since high school (so it's like 30 years, maybe more). Sometimes, continuity is good.

I love the old-timey feel of the joint, the friendly banter and the great service. The shrimp cocktails are served up with a killer cocktail sauce/spicy horseradish blend, and the list goes on. Everything is fresh and tasty, if a bit on the expensive side. Good clam chowder,  seafood salad, and the shellfish just rocks.

I also like the fact that if the line is out the door, they'll ask if anyone wants a drink/beer while waiting. Nice!
author: ACE A.

description:
Swan Oyster Depot has been around forever (being open since 1912 seems like forever).  The restaurant is run by the Sancimino family (although not completely, as I doubt the Asian guy behind the counter is related).  The best time to go is actually close to closing time (5:30pm) as the wait during lunch can be unbearable.  Don't forget to bring lots of cash - they don't accept credit cards.

Food:  4 stars.   If you want fresh seafood, this is the place to go instead of any of those pretenders in Fisherman's Wharf.  The combination salad (baby shrimp, crab, and prawns) is a must-try for newcomers.  Heaping amounts of fresh, succulent seafood are placed on shredded iceberg lettuce, served with a sweet louie dressing similar to Thousand Island.  A fantastic combination.  Also excellent were the oysters on a half shell (bluepoint was my fave).  I wasn't impressed with the Boston clam chowder.  Although flavorful, it seemed a bit watery.  Every meal comes with a plate of sourdough bread and butter - I would avoid it if I were you.  

Service:  5 stars.  The staff here is ultra friendly and always ready for any request.  They definitely make you feel welcome, whether you're a neighborhood regular or a tourist.  

Atmosphere:  3 stars.  The place is pure kitsch, with its mounted fish and photos signed by celebrities.  It's fascinating to sit at the counter and watch the staff at work.  The place is cramped and not exactly clean, however.  

Hits:  Raw oysters, crab, combination salad.

Misses:  Long wait at times.

If You Like This Place, You'd Probably Like:  Hog Island Oyster Co., PJ's Oyster Bed
author: Keith C.

description:
If you've won my mother's heart and taste buds, you know you're a shoe in. And you did. The woman who says "yea I guess it was okay" to every meal we ever meet, openly admits to craving the seafood salad. 

I love taking guests here. Cup of clam chowder, an assortment of oysters, fresh seafood salad and a beer--- the perfect lunch. 

Mom approved.
author: Amy T.

description:
This place is an institution, supported by a family whose members all remember your name.

My boyfriend took me here for the first time the other day, and as soon as we walked in the door, we were greeted by several men who clapped him on the back and called him Benny. I thought it was too cute of course. 

The clam chowder is the best I've ever had, made fresh and very flavorful. So good in fact that you may have to go down for an afternoon nap like it's preschool again. It's THAT good.

The crab salad is also amazing and very reasonably priced for all the crab you get.

Also, if you're into oysters, which I'm not but my boyfriend is fanatical about, this is your bivalved mollusk mecca.
author: Christy M.

description:
The good: Finally hitting 100 reviews after Yelping for two and a half years. The not-so-good: It's for a place that has 251 reviews before me. How bittersweet.

The people who work here are very friendly and welcoming, even of touristy folk (myself included). However, it's occasionally difficult to get their attention, since they're either chatting it up with regulars or working (they're quite busy, despite having a very limited number of seating).

The stuff I ordered during my two visits, ranked from best to not-so-best:

- Combo salad with louie dressing: It's silly to not eat fresh seafood when you're living on the coast. The combo salad gives you a hearty serving of seafood, at a reasonable price (~$17).

- Clam chowder: It seems people aren't too fond of their chowder, and apparently I came on a good day since it was very thick and chunky (the guy sitting next to me was also complimenting the cook for it). Best with the oyster crackers on the counter.

- Blue point oysters on the half shell: Certainly good with tabasco and lemon, but they were priced at $12/half dozen when I ordered them. A little painful on the wallet considering how tiny those things were.

- Shrimp cocktail: Wasn't too fond of this, since the amount of cocktail sauce just overwhelmed everything.

It's a fun place to go for fresh seafood. In case the 251 other reviews didn't tell you that.
author: Ryo M.

description:
Friendly enough staff, nice atmosphere and fresh shell fish but a little pricey.  Why the three stars? Your basic garden variety restaurant quality issues.
Hygiene -  I have no problem people handling and serving seafood with their hands.  But when you observe the staff using the same dirty looking rag to wipe counters and their hands, also tough their faces then handle the food.  Things are far from good.  Also a quick trip through the kitchen to the rest room confirmed my fears, back of house is pretty nasty.
Clam chowder - All you sheep that rave about the chowder.  They use tinned  Campbells condensed soup for the base.  That is real lazy and quite a sham for a place with this kind of reputation.
With the right suppliers(plentiful in the bay area) fresh seafood is tough to screw up. Unless of course you have lost your focus.  That is what I sense has happened here. They have gotten fat and lazy, focusing on the dollar and not the food.
author: Ken J.

description: A totally unique and satisfying experience. Great old fashioned atmosphere that felt totally authentic. Really friendly and relaxed service. The seafood was very fresh, very simply served and very delicious. Much of the menu seemed to be of a forgotten era, but tasted great at the end of the day. Would definitely go back anytime I'm in town.
author: Guy D.

description:
My cousin and his wife were visiting from Huntington Beach.  He had seen Swan Oyster Depot on Rachael Ray's $40 A Day and was determined to try it out on his next visit up here.  My sister and I decided to join him on his adventure and thank goodness we did.

We were lucky enough to grab 4 stools with no wait on a Saturday at 11 am.  We immediately ordered a tray of oysters.  Heavenly.  One tray led to another and then another.  On top of that we had the clam chowder and the crab louie salad and the shrimp cocktail.  We were in seafood heaven and had no shame in sitting there and enjoying every minute of it.  

The guys behind the counter were extremely friendly and genuinely happy to be providing us with such gratification.  After about 2 hours of stuffing ourselves we figured we should get up and let some other people enjoy the food.  The best part of the meal was realizing that it was a cash only establishment.  My sister had to run to the bank to cover our $200 bill.  Yes, I said $200.  Worth every last penny.
author: Raquel U.

description:
I've been to this place once. There was a long line so I don't go back to that place anymore. I would go back if it's that good but nah...  I'm from New England! It's pretty good but not that good.
I must admit that I love this place though! Little tiny bar like place really makes me feel like I'm back in east cost. Oysters are FRESH & DELICIOUS!! And we get to try different types of oysters! Yummy! 

They are expensive though. I was very hungry after we came out of that place & I was almost headed to McDonald right after. I feel that way because my hubby & I go to Oyster farm all the time. We get to buy so many Oysters at the farm with same money in our pocket.
author: Sunny K.

description:
1. Watery clam chowder
2. Dirty tile counter
3. Cramped seating
4. Being jabbed on the ribs by peoples elbows
5. Overpriced seafood
6. Oysters had sand in them
7. Eager customers standing behind you, waiting for you to leave
8. Fresh seafood by the window ?
9. Failed my expectations
10. Rachel Ray, what were you thinking when you came here !
author: Alex F.

description:
I have been reading and hearing raves for this place for years, and finally made a visit a few months ago when I went to visit my little sister up in San Francisco. We were both super excited and got into the line just a few people before they cut it off and told people to stop lining up. While waiting, we perused the menu and debated what we were going to get, going off Yelp photos and reviews. 

We finally get up to the front and decide we just want to do take out and eat it in a park somewhere. Someone acknowledges us and says it'll just be a few minutes before they can help us. Now, I work in a pharmacy, so I understand how irritating it can be when you're swamped and people stand there and stare at you, tapping their feet, waiting their turn. My sister and I are generally pretty pleasant & patient with wait times, but we were standing there for THIRTY MINUTES AND NOBODY HELPED US AGAIN. We flagged one person down, found out what we wanted wasn't available anymore, so tried to place a different order. "Give me a sec, I'll be right back." And then he ignored us, forever. Another guy helped the people STANDING BEHIND US, took walk in takeout orders, and didn't help us at all even though we were constantly trying to get his attention. It was as if we were invisible, and it was the most bizarre experience of my life, standing there with my sister while every.single.employee. looked straight through us.
