Needless to say we left, disappointed, having been fools for standing there for almost an hour (wait in line + 30 minutes standing in the actual restaurant being ignored). We were both incredibly baffled by what had happened, and I'm not sure I'm inclined to give this place another chance. 

By the way, we ended up at Woodhouse Fish Company, got a delicious bowl of clam chowder, a great lobster roll, and fantastic, friendly service. We ended up calling the day a success.
author: E P.

description: These guys will take care of you!!!  From the super long lines up the street on Polk, they will get a pint for you while you're in line.  Then when you finally get a seat at the limited seating bar area, you are face to face with the freshest seafood SF has to offer.  Raw oyster heaven, and they will concoct anything you want - we wanted to do some raw scallops, and we decided to create a carpacio with our own made up recipe.  We were also treated to some barrel aged top quality tequila.  It was such a great lunch!!!!  They close early so get there early!
author: Modern L.

description: BEST KEPT SECRET IN SF! This little restaurant has been family owned for I don't even know how long...but a long time! :) It is a little tiny place that probably only seats about 15 down a long bar. The wait can be crazy long but definitely worth it. Their fish is soooo good, everything is fresh brought in daily. They make their own louise dressing that is so mouth watering. If you get to San Francisco you HAVE to stop by the Oyster Depot...this is what fresh fish should taste like!!!
author: Tylene T.

description: Very fresh. All the guys that work there are super cool and nice. The food was good...yep, I said good, NOT wonderful. Pricey and definitely not worth the 1 hour and 50 minute wait.
author: Coño G.

description:
I never really noticed the place until I saw it on food network. I was like- wait- that's my street? Weird. Not that that prompted me to try the place. But at least it made me take notice. I just am not into waiting in line. It wasn't until the Great Unemployment Episode of '06 that I made it in. The plus side of having several friends out of work at the same time is that you can go places at off times, and it doesn't matter if you have to wait because really, the only place you have to be is a bar, and the bar is always willing to wait. 

I digress. The seafood was good. We had oysters and the smoked salmon. I heart smoked salmon. A fun place to take a visiting family member, yes. But for day to day seafood needs, I'm not down with the price point or the waiting.
author: Amanda B.

description:
This place is everything I love in an eating establishment.  They do one thing - and they do it very well.  As much as I love the fine dining experience, this place is really what it is all about.  Oysters.  The best oysters.  Any fan of the bivalve will attest that Swan is the shit.  Nothing fancy -just ice cold beer and the freshest oysters around.
The old guys behind the counter are all business and you never have to beg for someone to take an order.  The chowder is also great as well as the lump crab meat.  For the crab meat cocktail, they do tend do dump a little too much cocktail sauce on top so it is best to ask for it on the side.

Every time I leave Swan, I plot my next return.  This place is the real deal.
author: Debbie W.

description:
We come here for the food, not for service, or décor.  If you love seafood, both raw and cooked, this is the place to check out.  My hubby and I ended up eating couple dozens of raw oysters and clams.  Love their clam chowder! Not over-loaded with heavy cream, which we despise... but it's all about the freshest and sweetest clam taste in the soup that is just awesome!

Restaurant is situated in a residential neighborhood, old-school décor, family owned, with a long counter-top and 20 stools.  Ladies, beware... there is no place to hang your handbags.  You can either place them on your laps, or the staff behind the counter would place your bags behind their workstations, so leave your nicest handbags at home. :)

SOD is all about serving the freshest ingredients.  In a way, that's the beauty of this restaurant.
author: Cynthia K.

description: Very rude. We sit and one old man just asked us stand up and put up the chairs on the table in front of us. And didn't ask us to take away or not but assumed and gave us the bag! what's more, we order three but ONLY gave us two to take away! And didn't give us receipt as well! We are catching the time so didn't go back. Just want to say, DONT GO ! Plus, taste not really good than fisherman wharf and it is expensive!
author: Niki N.

description:
I wish there were more places like this in SF. This is the kind of place that makes sea food, and the city both shine. I love the options, the decor, style, the menu, and the service here. 

Oysters are a must, the clam chowder is great, and the salads are fresh, and simple. I would love to frequent here more often. The only down side to this gem, is that everyone knows its a gem. There is a line 90% of the time and there is limited seating space, so dont show up hungry, again, patience required for pleasant experience.

Why do most of the great places to eat in the city, only seat 20 people or less? It does ensure better quality, but sometimes, its too much work to eat a place like this. But after the meal, you know it was worth it.
author: Jimmy L.

description:
Had a beer and twelve oysters on a Wednesday afternoon.  No wait, no line.  

The oysters were good themselves (six different types, from Washington and CA), but the shucking left much to be desired.  Lots of shell bits in the oyster.

Would have been more of a three start experience, but at around 4 PM (one hour before closing) someone started cleaning the floor with ammonia, so the whole place smelled uncomfortably (and unappetizingly) of cleaning supplies.  They sure were in a rush to get out of there.
author: EZ R.

description: Well worth the wait in the line going out the door and down the street. There were 5 of us in my group and the guy behind the counter was awesome at making sure we were all able to sit next to each other. Had an amazing lunch! Fresh, tasty, delicious. All 5 of us agreed. A must if you're in the city.
author: Jesica L.

description:
Really amazing place... friendly, packed, old fashioned, delicious oysters (tons of choices) and damn good clam chowder...

NEVER get seafood near the wharf... I swear it's all not fresh at all... but if you're visiting SF (or live here) this is a place to get real fresh seafood!

Just be aware of their limited hours!
author: Aaron W.

description:
Word of advice..when given the option of Maine lobster or something else, go with the Maine lobster. My date and I ordered the half California lobster, I think. It was good, but for 7 dollars more, we could have had the hot Maine lobster. Another couple who sat a few seats away ordered it and I was lustful and envious the whole time. 

the lobster I had was good...it just seemed like theirs was better. 

The oysters were wonderful, as was the crab.  I'd love to go again. I went on MLK and I thought there'd be a line out the door, but we walked right in. I've passed by on Saturdays and the line was ridiculous. Oh well...this gives me a great excuse to play hookie.
author: Leslie Ann R.

description:
Holy crab!  The best crab salad EVER is here.  
They load the plate with fresh, sweet, tender, delicate crab, and they put just the right amount of moisture and crispness into the mix.  Then serve.  Simply delectable.
author: regina k.

description:
COME EARLY, AND COME OFTEN!!

FRESH, FRESH seafood; like it just came out of the water.

FRIENDLY service; like going to Uncle Bob's house for lunch.

SIMPLE decor; grab a beer and pull up a stool.

Here's my quick food  REVIEW:
I had the clam chowder, which was filled with lots of clams and potatoes.  The crab cocktail was EXCELLENT!  Definitely get the cocktail sauce on the side, so that you can add the fresh horseradish, lemon, and Tabasco.  

The only downer was the long lines.  Then again, you can skip to the front by getting everything to go or calling ahead.
author: James C.

description:
So I'm not the biggest oyster fan in the world but I ate two dozen oysters in six varieties at Swan and absolutely loved it...that should tell you something about the quality of oysters here. So fresh and full of oceany goodness...heck they even threw in a shucking lesson.

And don't get me started on the clam chowder. Unlike the all-to-creamy New England and why-is-my-soup-red Manhattan-style "chowdahs", Swan's chowder actually tastes like clam and sets the bar for all the other imitators. I was a bit surprised when the bowl first came out as it didn't resemble any chowder I've had before, but after that first spoon full I was absolutely hooked.

Now if you're not full from the oysters and chowder, definitely ask for a sashimi platter. Swan always has a number of fresh fish selections, many of which can be served sashimi-style...however I opted for just the scallops which were buttery and decadent.
author: David H.

description:
Luckily, my girlfriend and I were able to get in right away, but as soon as we sat down, a line started forming outside.  Seems to be the rule of Swan Oyster Depot.  
In short, the oysters were good and the clam chowder was great!  Nice staff (if a little too eager at times).  It's not the most comfortable place (you'll be elbow to elbow with someone you don't know and the stools are rickety), but its got charm.
If you walk by and there's no line, pop in, but I wouldn't recommend waiting for it.
author: c o.

description:
I can eat oysters all day long.  No joke.  I love them.  In my opinion, when it comes to choosing an oyster joint, you should look for quality as opposed to a more-bang-for-your-buck/all-you-can-eat type of establishment .  I have only wonderful things to say about Swan Oyster Depot.  

The 'all-boy' staff was pleasant, attentive, fast and knowledgeable.  I went on a Friday afternoon.  I got there at 4:30pm, there were 5 people ahead of me and we were sitting down by 4:40.  I guess I picked a good time to go.  The staff know their oysters so ask for their recommendation if you are unsure or can't decide like me.  I ended up getting 2 1/2 dozen mixed oysters although 3 dozen would've been perfect. (I told you I loved oysters!)   My personal favorite was a Miyagi oyster from Washington.  It was sweet, buttery and melted in my mouth.  Still thinking of them... I'm going back for seconds!
author: Lisa K.

description:
This place has become my favorite seafood joint in San Francisco.  Sure, the line may run out the door, but once inside you'll realize why.  

I'm in love with their crab salad with Louie sauce.  

The counter men are sweet and wonderful - you'll want to pack them up as well with your food to go.
author: Guava C.

description:
Man this place is good!!! When we got there at 2PM we figured we would have missed the lunch crowd but there was a line out the door. While we waited, a guy came out and asked if we wanted anything to drink. A COLD!! glass of Anchor Steam while waiting in line. Hard to beat.

One inside, we had a great meal and SUPER friendly service.
- Clam chowder
- Mixed Oysters
- Combo salad with Louie salad
- Cherry stone clams on the half shell (didn't even know you could eat raw clams)
- COLD.. COLD Anchor Steam

We got out for $65 cash. No idea if the price was right. All verbal, all cash.

This is just a great laid back place with really great food and really great service. GO!
author: Joseph B.

description:
I love raw oysters, so despite the incredibly uncomfortable barstools (be prepared), I am a pushover for very fresh seafood like that, I must have been a seagull in a previous life, that whole wharf-like, fresh fish atmosphere I become ravenous.  

OK so I had a dozen raw oysters, bowl 'o clam chowder, and the shrimp cocktail, which were all de-licious~~.  My friend had the crab salad, and I regretted not getting that it was sooo good, talkin' about the crab meat!.  The shrimp cocktail was the weakest of what I had, but that was still fine.  Overall, it was hecka expensive though indeed, ala eating at Fisherman's Wharf-ish expensive, 3 of us ran around $90 including beer, and parking is you know SF so, it sucks.  
But you can put me in San Quentin and i'm good if i can eat fresh raw oysters and crab.
author: Keith M.

description: For what it is - an old-school hole in the wall - it's a must-see.  For large groups and leisurely dining, it just isn't that kind of place.  Bring just one other person, be ready to wait, and it's cash only, but well worth the experience of a classic working man's seafood bar.  The staff are really friendly and helpful - ask for recommendations because they can create stuff not listed on the menu if something special came in that day.
author: Carter S.

description: I really wanted to like this place.  There is so much history and no pretensions which should be a draw.  But the oysters here seemed less than fresh -  the taste, texture, were all off.  I had better luck with the shrimp and crab louie.  Lots of seafood plus a decent sauce.  It's worth a visit once, but I am still trying to figure out why the lines.
author: Peter L.

description:
Had this been my last meal, I'd not have complained. 

This was one of those days when the stars all aligned. No intention of going here, just driving bye. Made a little bet as to how far the line would be down the sidewalk, and we were both way off. Practically no line at 1pm on a Saturday. Now, Ive never been here, but my dining partner goes often and was in total shock. But an even bigger shock is that upon seeing a tiny queue, we also see a park right in front! Crazy!

So, you figure, with all that working for us, our food is going to suck and one or both of us will get sick...right? Oh no. Not by a mile...

A sublime, brothy, clam chowder, with amazing sourdough crusty bread (butter completely unnecessary.) A plate of clams on the halfshell that brought back memories of summers way back when on LBI in NJ when you would eat raw clams with impunity. And then a crab and shrimp salad with "louie" on the side, which put you right over the top. 

You walk outside and you get that feeling like you walked out of a summer matinee movie, blinded by the ordinariness of every day life, your belly full just to the right amount, and your taste buds still tingling.

Ah, this is the life....
author: Geoffrey D.

description: Died.went.to.heaven.  Okay, still distracted thinking about the oysters and crab here. My husband and I went once, the stars were in alignment and we didn't wait at all!  We had the cracked crab and way too many oysters. How much did we love it?  We blew off the museum we had planned a few days later and went back...this time, not so lucky with the wait, but the line moved, they do drink orders and the food IS WORTH IT!!  The local 'louis sauce' for the crabs (mayo and maybe some tabasco?) was good and worth trying, but I prefer my crab naked + lemony.  My advice: for those who love fish, keep it simple and order the cracked crab, incredible assortment of west (and east) coast oysters, and the clams.  The atmosphere here is also great: they still have the beautiful marble counter tops and stools. Now I'm thinking I want to book a trip back to SF!
author: Elle N.

description: One of the very best places you can go to in San Francisco.  Famous and loved for all the right reasons.
author: Christin A.

description:
dirty, gritty, no parking, small portions, slow service, long line to get in, cramped counter to eat at, expensive menu.  and great food!

We can't wait to go there again!
author: C J.

description:
Very small place.  Line out the door.  Super fresh seafood.  When we are in town, my wife and I always make it a point to go here.  Recommendations are the crab salad, clam chowder, cracked Dungeness crab.  My wife always gets a dozen oysters, she has no idea what to get so the very helpful staff make the selections for her.  She hasn't been disappointed yet.  

If you are going for lunch and don't get there by about 11:00am, plan on waiting a while in line.  The place only sits about 15 people.  But, you can order a beverage and drink it while you wait.  And it is definitely worth the wait (if you like seafood).
author: Paul C.

description:
This is one of the more unusual places that I have been to in San Francisco. Calling this a restaurant would be stretching the term. The place basically consists of a long marble counter-top and 20 bar stools with about a 100 people queueing up for the privilege to eat here. It is open only for lunch till about 3:00pm and you need to be here by 11:30am if you want to aviod being diner number 100. Decor is basically a fish shop with stools.

The food is cold beer and the freshest seafood you can get aside from actually doing the fishing yourself. They have a large variety of oysters (duh!) and the staff shucks them right in front of you on the other side of the marble counter. Their Clam chowder is also very yummy, as is the shrimp cocktail. Their horse radish dipping sauce goes very well with the Oysters.

The staff is very friendly and helped us through our oyster selection process. If you love seafood (and love is the operative word) the you need to try out this unique place.

Bottomline:
Food: 8/10
Presentation/Decor: 2.5/5
Service: 4/5

Forget about those tourist traps on Fishermans Wharf, for really fresh seafood this is the place to go.
author: Rohan G.

description: Anchor Steam on tap...fresh tasty oysters and a great old school friendly vibe. One of my favorite stops in SF.
author: Rich W.

description: I LOVE LOVE LOVE this place! Their seafood is soooooo fresh! Words can't describe the tastiness of their food. I got dungeness crab meat cocktail style so it's chunks of fresh dungeness crab meat that's ready to eat. That was GREAT! The meat wasn't flaky at all and it's sweet. I also had a dozen of mixed up fresh oysters on the half shell from them and I can't stop dreaming about them! They are absolutely the best of the best! Do watch out for 1 thing tho- this palce isn't cheap :-(
author: yinmeng y.

description:
My boyfriend has been telling me about this place for over a year but we work for the entirety of their open hours and don't dare venture here on the weekend so its taken a long time to get there.

His birthday was last week and we decided that we would take the day off and do all those prime time activities that we can't usually do. After a tour of our neighbor, the Anchor Steam Brewery (a must do for beer lovers) we  headed over for some glorious food.

I was frightened that I would not enjoy it at first - the line I knew about but the small cramped bar I wasn't expecting. However, once we sat down and started shmoozing with the owners, sipping our beer, and looking over the delectable menu - my worries melted away.

We had a cup of the clam chowdah - too brothy for my taste but my other half prefers it this way. We then partook in the combo salad - shrimp, lobster, etc over a bed of iceberg lettuce and their homemade sauce. A dozen perfect oysters and we followed our happy full stomachs home for a nap. 

Bring cash and a friendly attitude.

An experience in itself.
author: Inna H.

description:
Just what Swan Oyster needs...another 5 star review.

But who the hell cares. This place rocks, and I'm adding to their praise!!!

Even though I lived just a few blocks away for a few years, I didn't go for the first time until a few days before moving away from San Francisco and was so relieved I did. This place definitely lives up to its hype - these are the things that I love about them:

1) BEER IN LINE - yeah, the line is always out the door and long, but they allow you to drink some draft beer (Anchor Steam - yeah!) while you wait in line, so you can stay warm and cure your hunger a little...there's also a See's Candies next door, so you could hop in and grab a sample while you wait ;)

2) SEATING/STAFF - this isn't the place to go to have a nice talk with your meal partner because all the seating is on stools facing the cooks, BUT it is so fun to watch the cooks go at it! Shucking oysters and cutting fish - oodles of fun! Kind of cool to see how all this stuff is prepared. Plus you get to chat with all the guys that work there (yes, they're all men) and they're very open to answering any questions you may have :)

3) MENU/OFF MENU ITEMS - while they have a huge variety of seafood on their menu, make sure to ask about special items they have that day that aren't displayed on their menu. I saw they had scallops, which weren't listed, and ends up they prepare 3 types of scallop sashimi - I tried the the mediterranean style - delicious!
author: Dalia K.

description:
Very communal place.  Pretty fishy and not very clean place.
They are very friendly here.  We got the raw oysters and some sashimi.  It was kinda neat to see these caucasians who work there offer us soy sauce, chopsticks, etc.  They're so well-prepared and it also just goes to show how many asians there really are in SF.  My husband and his cousins said the oysters were really good.  I thought the sashimi was alright.
author: Amy L.

description:
Yes, it's worth the ten hour wait in line! 

How many places do you think are left that serve superb food in a friendly and unpretentious setting run by the same family for many generations?

It ain't just food; it's history!

Grab some crab to go or sidle on up to the counter. Are you all alone? Even better! The guys behind the counter are ridiculously friendly, and you can learn a lot about their intriguing family history. 

If you can, go on like a Tuesday at 3 PM---you'll likely get seated right away. If it's brunch time on Saturday, fuggedaboudit, unless you have the patience of a saint or a box of See's from next door...

The best part, besides the other notable locals dining incognito for the love of super seafood (if it were any more fresh, you'd slap it for grabbing your ass!), is watching the dexterous shucking of those weird black spiky urchins and watching folks suck up the orange guts. 

I still haven't worked up the noive!
author: Stephanie B.

description:
Usually there is a line out the door so I've never had the time to indulge in the swan oyster depot experience.

Although 11 am is, in my opinion, a little too early to suck down an oyster shooter or 6, my friends and i saw there was no line so we stopped in and ordered a couple of rounds.

The service was great- the servers are charismatic and fun, not even slightly overwhelmed by the crowd that progressively queues out the door. The oysters were fresh and delicious (seriously) and I would gladly wait in a line for the experience if I had to.
author: Jacqueline H.

description:
Wow! Could not get as "local" as this! Swan's has been an institution for over a 100 years and still a family business.
Fantastic group of guy's that truly love what they do and it shows! Everything was as fresh as it gets and goes great w/ a pint of Anchor steam!
author: David C.

description: Best $90(70 w tip) lunch ever!!!!  I know it's a little pricy for a mid-day meal but I came to SF for seafood and we got it at Swan!  Started with a couple cups of chowder which was the best we've had in SF (night and day compared to Boudin).  Next we shared a half-cracked crab which was cut in half and cracked... who would've thought. It was good!  For our main indulgence we enjoyed the assorted oyster platter which included 3 each of blue point, local, kumamoto, and miyagi oysters.  At that point, we were in seafood heaven! They make their own cocktail sauce and have a good raw horseradish!  For dessert we slurped down a fresh whole uni (sea urchin). Like butter baby!  Tom, one of the owners, was very hospitable. Next time in SF, I'll be there!
author: David M.

description:
For someone who doesn't really like shellfish (and no, i'm not allergic to them), this is the only place I will enjoy crab and the occasional shucked-on-the-spot-for-you kumomoto oysters. The secret is to get there at around 11am when the line hasn't stretched all the way down the sidewalk. As soon as you secure a spot at the counter, go ahead and order the crab salad. 

I don't normally use a word like "divine" but I think this situation calls for it. A bed of crisp, fresh lettuce salad, a heapin' helpin of crab meat and the o-m-g thousand island-esque dressing. To top it all off, a refreshing Hefferweizen will do the trick. Every now and then I'd hanker for the thick, rich, creamy clam chowder. Dee-licious. 

The open faced crab sandwich is an option too. Off the menu, just the way I like to order! Remember the following 2 things and you'll love the experience: 1. Cash only  2. Get there really early.
author: nic t.

description:
we waited in line 45 minutes and there were 10 people in front of us. then a few people left the line. i would expect to wait about 7-8 minutes for each person in line who is in front of you. now that the bitching is over...

we had the oyster sampler(miyobi, kumayoto and blue point), white clam chowder and live sea urchin. the oysters are served with a side of locally made horseradish, housemade cocktail sauce and 2 vinegar choices between habanero lime and a sweeter(red) sauce of which the name escapes me. also on the counter you will find red tabasco, dozens of lemons and hefty oyster crackers. sourdough bread and butter for a buck.

the miyobi and kumayoto oysters were our favorites. very delicate, not so chewy and delicious flavors. num num.

the clam chowder is thin, so be warned. there also seemed to be an excess of oil on the top of the chowder which wasn't properly boiled down to smaller bubbles. no big deal really, an average quanity of high quality clams makes this a winner for sure.

the live sea urchin was very nutty. im not sure that I prefer it over any other particular variety iv'e had(namely from Sea Rocket Bistro or off the docks in San Diego) and the price was a bit steep(around $18-20). the pieces were tiny and there was still some sea accessories inside, but it was a ncie way to end the meal.

the place is good, is it worth the wait? im not so sure...i forgot to mention that the smart ones call their order in it. it sounds like it still takes about 45 min. to shcuk the oysters for you, but at least you can wait at home.
author: Shane B.

description: Great service, awesome clam chowder and love the oysters!  Just that the wait can get ridiculous sometimes.  The crab cocktail is good as well.  A bit over priced for the oysters as I can get same types of oysters at other places for a bit cheaper...but they have it year round...and NOT just during Happy Hour.
author: Patrick C.

description:
Hands down, the best place for oysters in San Francisco.  

Warning, this is not a place to go if you want to have a nice long quiet meal.  I've been coming to Swan's for the last decade and it's always been consistant.   The wait is ALWAYS long (at least 30 min) unless you're a single.  

SERVICE:  The service is fantastic and very fast.  This is a family run business that prides themselves in keeping things simple.    

FOOD:  Oysters are the best in the city.  Clam Chowder is one of my favs....fresh and brothy, filled with tons of clams.   I also recommend the combo seafood salad and the smoked salmon.  

Cash only place so be prepared.  If you want good seafood and do not mind sitting on little stools in a tiny place, then go to Swan"s.  This place is the best in the city and I highly recommend that it's on every oyster connoisseur's list.
author: VIOLA L.

description:
My boyfriend and me went to this place to celebrate our third year ann. what a great lunch. I am a big friend of seafood and found Swan oyster farm on yelp so I wanted to give it a try. As many reviews had said, they usually have long lines and the place is small and the place has been there for more than 100 years. But it is a great dinning place with cool servers!! 

We started with their clam chowder with bread and butter, it's not as creamy as I wanted it to be, but it's fresh and just like it's homemade.

We ordered the sea urchin next, the guy literally cut it alive in front of us and serve, it's amazing fresh and creamy. The sea urchin melts in my mouth. YUMMY~ :)

Then we try their crab cocktail. thumbs up!

The lobsters at this place is amazing, the best lobster I ever have, super fresh and yummy!  It's a huge lobster that costs $45 each. it's a little bit expensive for me but i will definitely order it again because it was super good!!!! 

I highly recommend this place for seafood lovers!!  :) and I am totally going back SOON!! Lobster, lobster, lobster..seafood seafood seafood, I can't ask for more..:)
author: Onionhead Y.

description: I've never had oysters that tasted so delicious! I'm very, very impressed. My friends brought these little guys to a bbq in the Mission. They're not easy to shuck, but it's well worth it! All of the fixin's were definitely complimentary. Thank you for making seafood delightful, Swan!!
author: Mei F.

description:
-The staff is very friendly, fast and family run
-great price performance
-excellent, fresh seafood - no frills - just yummy shellfish/seafood.. on the counter there are plenty of stuff to squirt:  cocktail sauce that you can add as much as horseradish, house special sauce (request), lemons, tobasco, etc.  If you want drawn butter, you may have to ask for it...
-Try the crab and miyagi oysters!
-Tip:  Go during a little off hour and seating may be easier but it is worth the wait.

I brought my Korean mother here, and she LOVED everything.
author: Sheila W.

description:
My husband and I were in San Francisco over for Valentine's weekend.  After searching for a good seafood restaurant I had to try this place once we landed in San Francisco.  We got there around 11ish and we were in line for 2 hours!  We ended up meeting some interesting people while in line and that was fun, not to mention the occasional rain that greeted us as well!  

This is the reason why I gave 4 stars..... the seafood is very fresh and the service is very friendly and warm.  The person who takes your order takes good care of you and is very caring.  Even with 20 stools of people and a long wait line they make you feel as if you are the only customer they are serving....awesome service. 

We ordered a bowl of clam chowder, cup of chowder, a combination salad (crabs and shrimp) with louie dressing along with bread and 2 Pepsi.  Our bill came out to around 30.00 ish.

The flavor of the clam chowder was delicious...just the right amount of salt and tastes very homemade.  The only thing I wished it had was a bread bowl instead of cut up bread on the side if anything and wished that the soup itself was a bit more thick.  Our salad was stacked with shrimp and crabs...they definitely do not go short on their seafood.  Very fresh and delicious.

I notice when I finally got to the front of the door that there was a separate line for take out.  I would find this very useful if I lived in town!  We definitely enjoyed our food.  We waited in line for 2 hours and ate our food up in about 30 minutes, probably because we were so hungry! lol!  Would we stay in line for 2 hours again?  No, I don't think we would stay in line for 2 hours, maybe 30 minutes.  Next time I'm in town I think I'll stop by and take food to go!  It was a fun experience though!
author: Sharona R.

description:
FRESH SEAFOOD.

My favorite is the crab leg salad with oyster crackers, or Boudin sour dough bread. Whole crab legs over a bed of lettuce on a big platter with lemon wedges.

Incredibly helpful waiters.

Restroom is like the "head" on a fishing boat...it's o.k., considering.
author: Burgess W.

description:
I can't speak for the rest of the menu, but the oysters here are absolutely awesome. They are SO fresh -- they taste fresher than the ones I had AT the actual oyster farm. Really.
My boyfriend and I stopped by to try them out and we weren't disappointed. The service was friendly and fast. We didn't know what kind of oysters we wanted, so the guy who helped us offered us three different types. All of them were great, but I really liked the Blue Point best. 
I would recommend this place to everyone, especially if you come by at off hours. I think we stopped in around 3:40 or 4 p.m. and sat right down.
author: Caroline S.

description: Location was very small and contained approximately 15 seats along the counter. Staff was very friendly. My favorite was the Blue Point Oysters which had a nice touch. The crab was fresh but lacked juicyness probably when it was just boiled. Cute family owned place that is better for 2 people than a large group.
author: Angela M.

description: Really great family that runs this place. Cheap and fresh seafood. Gotta have the oysters, the smoked salmon and the combo salad. The clam chowder is not bad either. The wait here can be incredibly long cuz they only have limited seating at the bar. I would go very early before the lunch rush(or after). The owners here will make you feel very comfortable eating here. This place is what SF is all about.
author: Stanley C.

description: This place is dirty. They handle the food with bare hands after shucking oysters, opening register, handling money, etc. Counter is dirty. They need to close it down and hose it top to bottom. For the amount of money you pluck down, just buy your steamed crab, get some lettuce and make your own crab salad at home. There is nothing special to their recipe.
author: Eve B.

description:
I wanted to try this place since last Dec. But I got here at 4:45 and they were giving out the last number and I had to leave and went to Blue Anchor instead. The Blue Anchor was very nice and fine dining at a small place. However, Swan Oyster Depot is always at the back of my mind.
Came here today around 1, and very lucky that only waited for 5 mins. When first got seated and I looked around this place, was not very impressed with the environment, or menu. There were not restaurant entries here, only oysters, clam chowder, seafood salad and steamed fish, smoked salmon. 
But when our a dozen of Oysters came, I changed my opinion about this place. The Oysters were fresh and the sauces came with it were interesting, But I liked the horseradish and cocktail sauce the best. Oysters were very sweet and juicy. Then the smoked salmon swerved with red onion & caper on rye bread was very delicious, the salmon had strong taste but not too much to handle. The Cherry Stone Clams were very interesting and "solid", it's strong but not fish. Also the clam chowder was nice, very different. It's not very creamy like other places, instead you can really taste the seafood in it and soup was lighter. Surprisingly like it. 
I still prefer Blue Anchor more since that place is more suitable for a real meal, but this place is interesting to try and look.
author: Michele S.

description:
FINALLY tried this place & wasn't disappointed! FRESH seafood in a no-frills family environment.

FOOD: Fresh as can be.

~Clam chowder: was excellent if oily. It's super good to dip your sourdough bread in it. I actually prefer the clam "chowder" @ Hog Island (divine).

~Oysters on half shell: really excellent, especially considering those oysters were HUGE. I usually prefer the small ones, but these were fresh & tasty with rice vinegar spooned over.

~Combo cocktail: Don't get the cocktail--it's drowning in watered down cocktail sauce. Get the salad. Combo comes with crab, bay shrimp, 1 jumbo shrimp, 1 oyster, & 1 clam. A bit on the small side for a cocktail (or am I just used to Vegas-sized seafood cocktails?)

~Crab salad: awesome! Loads of crab, great dressing, & the salad fills you up. The best deal. Scanning the length of the counter, I noticed everyone had a salad.

SERVICE: Awesome, cool, big guys who are so laidback yet attentive. There was no pressure to order or rush anything despite the line out the door. You feel like you're in good hands, & they'll absolutely take care of you. & they gave me a free sponge that looks like a piece of cardboard & expands when you put it in water!

DECOR: What's with all the rubber duckies? They even had one that resembles James Brown on top of the Tabasco jug. I like the cute hand-painted menu signs, & the kitschy decor makes one feel at home. Very S.F.

BATHROOM: Take a trip just for fun. Peek into the workers' cubbyholes. My friend said the "bathroom is like Chinatown." Very small, cramped, but interesting.

OVERALL: I'd get my seafood cocktails from the hustlers at Fisherman's Wharf, but Swan Oyster is a classic that must be visited at least once. Freshness guaranteed. A seafood lover's heaven!
author: miss b.

description:
Undeserved hype. 
Surprisingly expensive for such plain food and dilapidated surroundings.
Faux friendliness = long wait in long outdoor line, no credit cards, inconvenient hours.
Better can be had for similar prices elsewhere with reservations, credit cards, nice tables, reasonable hours, and no phony BS.
I can't believe I waited in line 45 minutes for this. 
Strictly for suckers and masochists.
Fool me twice?  Not a chance.
author: David F.

description:
I'm not able to come here often, but when I do, it's a wallet breaking experience. Not because of steep pricing, but I just want to have everything. Here's a sample of a typical swans experience.

Frothy Ice Cold Anchor Steam
Crab Louie Salad
Clam Chowder
Jumbo Prawns w/ cocktail sauce, extra horse radish
Dozen Oysters (Kumamotos, Miyagi's and Olympia's)
Dozen Clams
Dungess Crab, pre cracked for your convenience
Thinly Sliced Sardines
Smoked Salmon

This SF treasure is worth the wait, it heightens the anticipation of having some of the freshest seafood served by an old school bunch of guys while sitting on a rusty stool leaning against an antique marble bar. Eating there feels like you're experiencing something truly historic.
author: Eric C.

description:
I saw this place featured on the food network, and my boyfriend and I finally got to go in for lunch last Friday.  We absolutely LOVED it!!  The clam chowder is probably thinner than you're used to; but its chocked full of fresh ingredients!!  We also had a combo salad and 6 oysters.  The man that served us picked two of each kind that they carry.. and they were all fresh and delicious.  

We were there around 2:00 on a Friday afternoon and we found a parking spot around the corner within minutes!  The staff here is super friendly!!  And the counter is equipped with lemon wedges, bowls of oyster crackers and condiments.  I'd recommend this place to anyone local or just visiting.  Oh yeah, don't let the line fool you.. this is a tiny store front and people come and go quickly!
author: Regina B.

description: Hands down best crab and combination seafood salad! Yummm! I went here for the first time and was shocked with the line out the door but I ordered to go, to get things moving a little quicker, if not I would have waited an hour to get seated. The food here is prettier pricey but you get a good amount of crab on your plate. Come with time and with plenty of cash cause the dishes are not cheap and no credit cards are accepted. A crab salad alone is about twenty two just to give you an idea. Will come again to have lunch.
author: Ella P.

description: We travel a lot for work and pleasure and we own a farm-to-table restaurant.  So, we understand the industry pretty well and this place is great!  We arrived at 10:40 AM and waited about an hour, which seemed to be average.  No problem...we expected it.  The food (sashimi plate with 16 pieces...bay shrimp salad...smoked trout with a small shrimp salad included) were all excellent and portions were good.  We left stuffed.  It ain't fancy, but the owners/employees really take care of you.  Our bill, before tip, was $104 for 2 Anchor Steams, 3 glasses of sparking wine, the above mentioned food, a cup of chowder and bread.  Completely fair in my mind.  They will make off-menu combos for you, they made us a separate dressing for our salad, we never lacked for a drink, etc.  If you want a white table cloth or comfortable chair, go elsewhere.  If you want quality food and an "experience," then this is it.
author: Scott A.

description:
I love seafood so I really want to love this place. The seafood LOOKS so good but everytime that I order it, it's just not. It's not too old, but it's either overcooked, mediocre quality, boiled in something that obfuscates the natural flavor, or previously frozen. The cocktail sauce sucks, they charge for bread, and the line is unbearable. Watchout when you order a crab/shrimp/prawn cocktail -- it comes doused with their watery cocktail sauce.

Admittedly, I haven't tried the oysters and the waitstaff is amusing. But if you're really into the pure flavors of fresh seafood, skip this place.
author: Marina N.

description:
My absolute, 100%, totally, and completely favoritest restaurant in San Francisco - maybe even anywhere. I know I tend toward exaggeration, but in this case and this case alone, it is not possible to hyperbolize the wonder that is Swan.

Swan is all about simplicity. It is not about fancy menus, experimenting with taste combinations, or ornate marinades and sauces. It is about quality and purity. And quality and purity is what you get. Swan is classic seafood, through and through.

The louie salad is a must. I recommend the combo (a handful each of dungeness crab, prawns, and bay shrimp over crisp lettuce topped with the perfect amount of creamy louie dressing) for first-timers, though I myself often order the bay shrimp louie. I've eyed the lobster version, but still have not taken the plunge and ordered it. They serve their impressive assortment of oysters freshly shucked with perfectly tangy mignonette and cocktail sauce with just the right ratio of tomato and horseradish. I especially appreciate their offering of local choices as well as options from the Puget Sound and Vancouver (tastes like home!) The seafood cocktails and fish are nice alternatives. Watching them slice the salmon is especially impressive. The clam chowder is creamy and classic, but I only get it if we get there early. Later in the day, after it's been heated for a few hours, it tends to separate and even get a little lumpy. Even fresh, it's not my favorite chowder, which is disappointing since it's one of my favorite foods.

If the food isn't enough of a draw, the delightfulness of the family behind the counter should get you into a stool. Everyone is treated as a friend, and watching them shuck oysters and create the masterpiece salads offers almost as much enjoyment as you get from eating the food. Almost. Be sure to ask for a sponge business card for any out of town guests.

Swan is worth braving the line at any time of day, and it's even fun people-watching and observing the food preparation (especially the giant $400 to-go orders which they make from memory - nothing written down!) while you wait if you're ready for it. But, the earlier the better if you're in a hurry. Going after the lunch rush is also an option if line-avoidance is a priority, but only if you're not going for the clam chowder. Don't forget, you can always skip the line and get your order to go.

Come with cash and an empty stomach. The servings leave nothing to be desired except extra room in the belly for more seafood goodness. I just wish they were open on Sundays!
author: Veronica L.

description:
This place really stinks and is fairly dirty. But.. we came here knowing we aren't payinig for the atmosphere.

So! the food was great. Wouldn't say best oysters I have had but it would be up there. Great clam chowder! 

absolutely amazing how early people eat seafood at. We got there at 11am and the line was about to form! You see most customers are very much enjoying their meals. Dozen and dozen of oysters... one after another. Fair pricing. Good food. Would give it five stars if seating was a bit more comfortable.
author: Becca L.

description: Food is fresh. Oysters are awesome. Service is great. Better if you were a regular recognized by the owner as you can see how select he is when offering service. If you're a hot white chick he'll definitely hook it up as what I just witnessed lol. Try it out!
author: Ian C.

description: I think this place got a little too hyped up. It's good but it offers nothing out of the ordinary. For example, the prices, well, they're comparable to any other decent seafood place in the city. The food, well, it's the same quality you'd get at any other seafood decent place. The ambiance is kind of interesting with it's homey feel, seriously, it's like eating in someones dirty kitchen. Anyways, to conclude, I did enjoy myself and have a fabulous meal at the Swan, however, I don't know if waiting in that epic line is really worth it.
author: Colleen J.

description:
One of the best seafood experiences I have ever had, hands down!!!  Serously, the key is in the simplicity.  We had the combo seafood salad, which is loaded with the freshest lump crab and claw meat, prawns, and rock shrimp.  Someone wrote that $17 was pricey for this salad.  They must get fresh seafood a lot cheaper from where they come from, because a salad like that would run $27 or $30 here in Austin.  
My girlfriend and I shared that salad and one bowl of their awesome clam chowder and were full.  Have all of that with a Stella served in a cold glass and damn son, heaven.
No trip out to SF should be without at least one visit to the SOD.  Treat yourself.  And the gentlemen behind the counter are some of the friendliest guys you're going to meet during your visit.  They actually love what they do.  Getting up early, buying fish, selling it with a smile, and closing early.
This place will eternally have a soft spot in my heart.
author: david w.

description: So good we went 2 days  in a row.  Freshest seafood you will ever eat, period. Limited menu. Nothing fried or greasy no fries just sweet succulent crab, lobster, shrimp, squid, octopus,clams and oysters galore. 6 different varieties when when went.  Clam chowder was excellent.  Not that thick gloppy full of potatoes and minced clams from a can.  Oh and the service, never have I been treated better ANYWHERE!  Now for the place itself, it's a fish market that happens to serve lunch from 10:30 until the run out of stuff. Marble counter, 20 stools, elbow to elbow, jostling for room to stuff fish in  your mouth.  Beer and wine, wear what you may, these boys don't stand on formality. By our second visit we felt like family. Cash only, whiners can walk.
author: michael d.

description:
A-MAZING!!! Swan is an absolute must every time I visit SF. I am one of those people that always orders the same thing when I really dig something at a restaurant. At Swan it's the Seafood Combo Salad, Clam Chowder and a glass of Chardonnay. The guys (I think they are all brothers) behind the counter really make you feel at home. It's one of those places that even if the food wasn't as pleasing as it is I would eat here anyway due to the unique atmosphere and great service. 

I chuckled when I read Nicosh A.'s review and completely concur. Initially I thought I also would have my ashes sprinkled at Swan. In fear of being swept up and landing somewhere less desirable I think I will ask them if my Urn could be placed on a shelf in the restaurant. Maybe open my  lid and fling me a shrimp on occasion.
author: Scott N.

description:
I enjoy coming to this family owned place for an afternoon seafood lunch. The oysters are always fresh and I like to get the house smoked salmon which they serve on delicious sourdough bread its slightly salty and melts in my mouth. The crab salad is also not to be missed with plenty of large pieces of crab and homemade louie dressing...the place is small and the seating tight but the fact that they always recognize me and my bf as his family has been coming here for generations is a nice touch. Everyone is very friendly and the food always so fresh. I particularly enjoy the clam chowder as it is not as creamy as the traditional but still packed with flavor. 

It is a small place and gets busy around lunch time so prepare to wait in line to sit at the tiny bar, but trust me it is worth the wait.
author: Cristina F.

description:
I went to Swan Oyster Bar to celebrate the outcome of the 2008 Presidential Election. For those of you who haven't heard, Obama won. 

Three friends and I donned our Obama shirts (them), Sarah Palin dresses (me, but don't get me wrong, I'm 110% for Obama) and set foot in Swan Oyster Depot for some congratulatory beer. Already feeling at the top of the world, I didn't think I could feel any happier, but the men at Swan Oyster Depot warmed my heart.

The salmon lox was out of this world - I've never had better. The staff supplied us with an ample supply of Stella beer, and, as we were one of few patrons in the bar at this early, they were eager to answer our questions about their family business, how to cut calamari (I asked) and sample their crab cocktail. The highlight was when the owner cooked us some "eggs in a frame" which he was cooking for his two sons, who also work at the family business.  Glorious, glorious. This is what America is all about: good beer, good seafood, and most importantly, good people.
author: Julie P.

description:
The long lines out the door and people walking out saying "it's worth the wait" tells you something about a place.  

This little seafood bar (and by bar, I mean bar.  NO other seating available) has been in operation for 3 generations.  It has really made a name for itself in the SF area as the go to place for seafood outside of Fisherman's Wharf.  

The wife and I stood in line for about 20 minutes before we got in.  Ordered oysters, clams, chowder, salad, and fresh uni (sea urchin for the non-sushi eating folks).  

Oysters and clams were superb.  Very fresh.  They make this vinegar sauce that is pretty darn good to go with it.

Chowder was extremely flavorful.  However, if you are looking for the thick white kind of chowder, this is not the place for you.  The texture is soupy.  Kinda like when you used regular Campbell's clam chowder and mixed in milk like the old days but with 10x more flavor.  

Crab salad had about a whole crab worth of meat on it.  Their louie dressing wasn't bad either.  It really is just iceberg lettuce with crab and dressing and nothing else.  

Fresh uni was fresh, creamy, and just plain delicious.  

Only con is the price.  Pretty expensive but then you get what you pay for.  Service was like going to your favorite bar with a bartender who knows your name.  

Cheers!
author: Jerry W.

description:
Now this gem is MY KIND OF PLACE. It's small - 10 bar stools total - family run, and a total hole in the wall with one of SF's most SUPERB menus of local oysters, and seafood...oh, and there's also Anchor Steam beer on tap!

Always a long line during lunchtime hours so I recommend catching a late lunch, and only leaving after you place an order for more fish or crab to be delivered to your home for dinner.

On my first trip to Swan, I went with 4 people and our bill was nearly $500. Let just say it's not cheap, but either is seafood and you gotta pay for quality, right? 

Swan's food and staff (who tell great stories) are truly worth every penny. I try to visit once a month, or at least 6-8 times per year.
author: Sam C.

description: If not for having to stand in a line to get in (in the middle of the afternoon), this place would get 5 stars - but then the line is part of the deal. Wonderful crab salad and chowder, delicious combo cocktail and lots of good sourdough - with a cold draft. Got a taste of awesome smoked salmon. Staff is busy but we found them to be very friendly and they did not hurry us. Will try to go anytime I am in SF!
author: Dan M.

description: I know it's touristy, I just don't care.  Get here early, the line can get really long.  Worth the wait, worth the pain of finding parking, worth the price (note: cash only), worth the uncomfortable stools.  MUST HAVE the italian style sashimi, which is not on the menu.  The oysters, crab cocktail, and smoked salmon are also favorites.  This place is historic and fun and I'll never stop coming here.  Oh, and get a Stella which they have on tap.  It will come ice cold and delicious, perfect match for the food.
author: Julie A.

description:
Swan's.  I've been here a handful of times and I definitely love it!  It's either here or down near Fisherman's Wharf that you go for fresh raw seafood.  This is the no-frills option for sure.  It is charming (very old school) and quaint (tiny) but without having to focus on those details they have more energy to focus on what their customers really want - fresh delicious seafood and great service!  

My most recent trip was a post-Thanksgiving treat on "Black Friday" while the drones were all distracted with their shopping tasks.  HA!  Yea right.  We got there around 12pm and had to wait over an hour in line.  Yep.  So much for that logic.  FYI - bring a book or some other distraction unless you want to make small talk.  Got in finally though and took our seats at the 20-max single bar who's barstools must be the originals from when the place first opened (which you shall see when you get there).  Of course by then we were STARVING so I started with an Anchor Steam and a 4 count variety of Kumamotos.  My friend and I refused to share - going Dutch we just ordered whatever we wanted for ourselves.  By the end of it all, I'd had 22 oysters, 1 combo seafood cocktail, 1 crab cocktail and 2 beers.    Yum and OWIE at the same time.  I was fine until we were ready to leave, when suddenly I felt as if I was going to heave up every single morsel I'd eaten.  I held it down though, thankfully because at almost $70 just for my meal what a waste that would have been!

Best points of Swan's are obviously the fresh seafood.  The service = great because they are so attentive to your needs empty glass or no food in front of you and they are quick to offer you more.  Once you get to a certain point in line they will even offer you a free drink of your choice.  They have wonderful house-made sauces...all you have to do is ask!  The wall shows most of the items they offer, but there are some things that are NOT on the menu that you just have to ask for:  sashimi, raw scallops, a complimentary helping of the house tartar (normally $2, so ask for the stuff while you are eating).  They also make the usual vignette but also one that has spicy chiles and is the BOMB! on oysters :)  Really the only downside is psyching yourself up to wait in that line.  I wonder why they don't just expand the place, make it two stories or something??  But then, I guess after nearly 200 years in business they have a strategy down...tease you with a window full of fresh seafood, make you drool over the lucky ones nonching away at the bar...because once you get in you are ravenous and want to go for everything!  Don't suppose it'd be that way necessarily if you could just saunter in anytime huh?  

All good things come to those who wait so, I suggest you hurry up and wait for Swans cause it is sooooo worth it~!
author: Stasha A.

description: Great Food, A little pricy. LONG WAIT. Clam Chowder and Smoke Salmon is a must!
author: Eric Y.

description: Great seafood. Service is friendly and oysters are yummy. Had prawn cocktail and shrimp cocktail. The sauce was a bit on the sweet side but otherwise good with some lemon juice. The raw oysters were yummy however the price point is a bit higher than other happy hour places where they have dollar oysters. Their sashimi Sicilian style was ok. It was served with capers, diced red onions and olive oil. They are only open til 5:30pm so go earlier for an early dinner.
author: Eva Y.

description:
after living in SF for uhm,,,,,12 years! - I had to try this famed destination. Well, all that I can utter is FAB!...:)

had the combo seafood louie salad; prawns and crab..too delicious for words.  where the heck have i been???  lol.

also, customer service from all the guys behind the counter: priceless.

mahalo Swan Oyster Depot..2 thumbs up!

Patrick :)
author: Patrick I.

description: The freshest sea food you can get in the city. Over a 100 years of business so they must be doing something right. If you want to be serve quickly I suggest that you go first thing in the morning when they open up to beat the crowd. The only down side is the don't accept credit cards so bring cash... or you can just walk across the street to chase to get some.
author: Carlos G.

description:
Lines, lines, lines. SF is full of lines! At Swan Oyster Depot, we only waited about 20 minutes to be seated, so this was actually a plus. 

We ordered 6 miyagi's, 6 blue points, 2 clam chowdahs, 1 seafood salad with their louie sauce on the side, 1 lobster. This all set us back about $100, but what a good meal overall!! The clam chowder was really nothing to rave about, especially after having the seafood chowder at Bar Crudo. I liked the seafood salad and I'm glad I got the sauce on the side because it's pretty heavy. The oysters and the lobster were the real stars. SO FRESH AND DELICIOUS!!

I wish I had something like this around my area. I would be all over this place every week to get my fresh seafood fix.
author: Kathryn C.

description:
So, I came here on a weekday afternoon & fortunately did not have to wait at all (based on the reviews & constant long lines, I was prepared to be veryyyyy patient).  I ordered the clam chowder & found it to be a little too watery & greasy.  It's texture was more like a juice than a traditional thick clam chowder.

On a positive note, the actual clams were fresh, chewy & tasty, which is usually rare, since most places use clam chowder from the cans (don't tell the tourists at the fisherman's wharf that).   Also, they were very generous with their oyster crackers.

For what you pay for, this place is a bargain!
author: Sheryl S.

description: I would eat here every day if I could. As good as the oysters were, I could live solely on the clam chowder and crusty bread. We got there a little before 11 am and had the place to ourselves on a Wednesday.  They certainly don't need the extra publicity, but it doesn't hurt that Bourdain shows up from time to time.  I can see why.
author: Ken S.

description: My first review.  My first time to Swans.  Got in around 11 am so no wait.  Unbelievably fresh.  My friend sharkey and I started with the chowder, ordered a dozen oysters, 2 of each offering, then had 2 plates of sashimi. Finished up with a crab Louie cocktail.  Try the habanero cilantro Mingonette, it's really great on the sashimi (we had scallops, albacore, smoked salmon and halibut.  Great job guys!  Great family run business.
author: Rich B.

description:
I must say the wait is a little long, however you can just tell that the fish is quite fresh. The fellas behind the counter are like New York fishermen, funny but to the point,  due to  the "busyness" of the place.  Great selection of Oyster's very good.  plus the salads are very good

Oh bring cash
author: adams l.

description:
Just get it in your head that amid the festering tourists and starved business lunchers spilling out of the door, you'll get the best shellfish, served low-fi ANYWHERE.  Well, at least in Northern Cal and maybe the whole damn coast.
Don't expect fancy trimmings or a gleaming, hipster hot spot; just expect that you'll get top quality without all the bullshit.  Old school and just the way it's supposed to be.

The staple primo dungness crab and oysters are just the beginning.  Experiment with the smoked fish, the variations of sardine or soft shell crab.  The stuff is seasonal so the goods on ice are constantly in rotation.  If you're looking for a budget-fill-your-gut pit stop with a bunch of deep fried shit - this is not your scene.  If you want home spun salt of the earth staff, ready to serve succulent, absolutely fresh seafood with a smile, this is where you wanna be. 

Dammit, I got myself hungry again...

p.s. as an added bonus, the inherent aphrodisiac effect of the food has been proven several times, without fail - Oysteragra = GOOD TIMES
author: Stephan J.

description:
I can't believe I've lived 3 blocks up from the Depot for nearly 15 years and have never been, but after Anthony Bourdain recently remarked to the Chron that this is his favorite spot in the City I had to see what all the fuss is about. 
In a nutshell, he's right. If you want boring details I won't provide them here, plenty of other reviews have that. It's a bit pricey but it's worth it when you know they haul in the day's catch every day, and they only serve the best. I did feel a little strange as everyone around me was clearly tourists, but I yucked it up with them all the same and the guys serving are genuinely nice.
The clam chowder is unique. It is buttery and creamy but doesn't have the consistent milky appearance of other chowders. The buttery taste comes through along with generous bits of clam, and sopped up with great SF French Bread it's a slam dunk. I also had a crab / shrimp and bigger shrimp combo salad. Again a bit pricey at nearly $20, but you won't find fresher ingredients anywhere, so suck it up and get some while it's still in our oceans.
author: Matt H.

description: Some of the best oysters I've ever had. Glad that my boyfriend and I got there early, when they first opened. Actually, got off the plane from an early a.m. flight, dropped off our suitcases, and headed over to this place. There was a line when we left. The staff really knew their product, and seemed to take a lot of pride in working there.
author: Kelly D.

description: The staff here was AWESOME. Really, great guys working behind the counter. I had a combo salad that was packed with seafood, but honestly it wasn't that great tasting. Neither was the clam chowder that I had, and everything was very expensive. I grew up eating local seafood on the coast in Oregon and this just didn't compare for me. Personal preference, I suppose - nothing against this place, they obviously have a huge fan base, as the line went out the door when we left. I don't think I would go back, though. The friendly service alone isn't enough for me to spend that much money on lackluster seafood.
author: Stephanie P.

description:
If you're in the mood for cavorting with a few salty dogs on Polk Street, pull up a stool (if you're lucky to snag one) and enjoy this little gem of a hole in the wall. The men behind the counter are characters. 

If your luck is good you'll be offered samples of smoked salmon as it's cut off the fish. Or you may get a heal of the bread to go along with your clam chowder. It's one of those places that's easier to order once you've been before, simply because it's unique and has it's own system. Confusing at first, I wondered if I was sleep deprived or in a foreign country... not quite understanding what was going on or how to answer questions regarding options for my meal. But I wanted to try it all and realized trial and error is the way to go! There are no mistakes when the seafood is this good.

Oysters on the half-shell were absolutely delicious. As was the smoked salmon. Next time I am ordering one of the seafood salads because I couldn't keep my eyes off my neighbors plate. 

Have you ever shucked oysters before? Well, you probably wore a glove and rightfully so! Those raw babies from the sea are hard to open and full of aquatic micro-creatures. If you cut yourself with a shucking knife it's a big deal and the consequences come with a hefty dose of regret... and painful infection! Anyone sewing you up in the Emergency Room will just shake their head at you for playing the odds.  Well, the guys at Swan shuck barehanded! They're tough and must seriously know what their doing. It's been around for generations and is a great place for entertaining your senses and enjoying fruits of the sea.
author: Audra K.

description:
I don't know what the neighborhood was like when Swan opened, but this establishment is certainly surrounded by ugly ducklings -  if ugly ducklings were homeless people wallowing in their own feces.   However, Swan makes a walk through the loin well worth it.  

The crab salad is great and the chowder is better than anything you will find on the eastern seaboard. Don't let Bostonians fool you.  You'll find the best chowder at Swan in SF.
author: Alex D.

description:
I lived for years in Snob Hill and never made it to this place, what a shame!

The crab louie salad is to die for, as are the oysters....the guys behind the counter keep it entertaining, and with great service. The line isn't even that bad considering you are getting some damn fresh seafood at a really reasonable price.

Only disappointment was the clam chowder, too watery for my taste, but passable sopped up with mounds of oyster crackers.

One word: GO!
author: Alison P.

description: Amazing spot for raw seafood goods.  They have a wonderful selection of delicious oysters, but you can also find some other goodies.  I had the seafood salad that included crab meat, baby shrimp, and prawns.  I also had some friendly neighbors that shared there sea urchin with me.  It was a special for the day and if i wasn't full i would have ordered another to myself.
author: Jeff F.

description: I rarely write reviews, but I just can't take all of the raving that  people do about this restaurant.  Everyone seems like they like this place just because it's the cool trendy thing.  I will be honest with you:  Eat at Swan Oyster if you like waiting for 3 hours on the street outside while homeless people come up to you constantly asking for handouts.   Eat at Swan Oyster if you like tight spaces and way overpriced food.   Eat at Swan Oyster if you like your chef to handle a wad of dirty cash right before they plunge their unwashed hand into your shrimp cocktail.   Eat at Swan Oyster if you like seafood that is good, but tastes the same as seafood from any other seafood restaurant anywhere in San Fran.  Finally  eat at Swan Oyster if you are just trying to be a cool unoriginal hipster like the rest of the clientele and the people who are writing these rave reviews about an honestly unimpressive restaurant.  Consider yourself informed.
author: David L.

description:
I had exactly seven minutes before I had to go to an appointment nearby --- so I ducked in and grabbed some clam chowder to go.  

Kevin knew I was in a hurry --- so he made it easy, asked me if I wanted oyster crackers, needed a spoon, grinned and handed me my change all in one fell swoop.  I have gotta admit I was impressed!  

All this in less than seven minutes.  NOT bad at all!  I'll be back!
author: BrasilPo P.

description:
Very good touristy hole in the wall oyster bar...It's been around for a long time.. since 1920s i think the guy said? and its family owned!
The raw oysters are SOOO fresh and nice and sweet.. reminded me of when I was in Austrailia...

their shrimp cocktail was really good too! Must try! NOt extremely pricy! We went int he afternoon cuz I heard it gets JAMMMed packed later.. we went at like 10 am...
author: Stephanie C.

description:
When have you ever forked an oyster so creamy that it resembles something spreadable?  For me, it was this morning.

I awoke with the words, "Swan's Oyster Depot" on my lips and before I could force myself to take a shower, I was out the door to catch the bus.  All this would have been reasonable had I woken up in the afternoon, but who's ever had oysters at 9 in the morning?  I'll tell you who.  Everyone else already seated before I arrived at 10.  

The young men behind the bustling counter were all so charming and not at all rude.  I don't know, maybe the rude one had a day off?  Who is this rude one people complain about?  

I was seated immediately.  But then I got up immediately to go to the bank because this place was CASH ONLY.  I despise places like that, and I took off 2 stars.  But when I got those oysters, they deserved 7 stars so it all works out.  

The guy who sat next to me ordered a crab louis and it certainly looked like what people said, seafood with some lettuce underneath.  The salads were between $15 and $19.  Maybe next time I'll try one of those.  Or maybe not b/c I was SO HAPPY with what I got.

Six cherrystone clams and six mixed oysters later, my mind was on the moon.  The last few oysters were so creamy and delicious, the taste lingered in my mouth.  For anyone who's ever had really really good hamachi toro nigiri, you'll understand what I mean when I say it was fragrant and intoxicating.  The sensation swirled around as I inhaled, the heady sensation mixing with oxygen and tantalizing my taste buds.  

Being the informed consumer that I am, I knew better than to order the clam chowder.  But a lot of people at the counter did order it and they did slurp it down.  The gigantic bowl of oyster crackers was there in case you wanted company.  Slices of lemon in a bowl were placed every few seats.  Tabasco sauce a-plenty, salt, pepper, other garnishes were available upon request.  

One last thing.  This was the only place where I savored and sank in to the enjoyment of oysters.  It was a secular experience.  Did I use that word correctly?
author: Christina C.

description:
Only thing is the counter and chair is so uncomfortable.
But also that's the charm that they just don't change at all.

Super fresh sea food. I love love the combination salad (dressing on the side- important). Their crab is the best I ever had in SF!
author: Green Mango Y.

description:
I am emotionally tied to this place.  When I miss "back east," I come here because their oysters and cherry stones taste like home and the men behind the counter are those salt-of-the-earth types that I knew growing up.  I've been coming here for over 6 years, and I have more magnets, sponges, pins and antenna balls than I ever imagined.  

The food is always amazing -- fresh and delicious.  As it should be, the clam chowder is made up mostly of clam juice, cream and clams rather than gooey potatoes or cornstarch.  Depending on my appetite, I usually get the Seafood Combo Salad (finally, a good use for iceberg lettuce) or the Seafood Combo cocktail.  Both with Louis on the side.  And an Anchor Steam.  Yum.

As far as decor, check out the photos on the walls of Swan's earlier days.  It was nice without so many tchochkes!
author: Michelle E.

description:
There are some things in life worth waiting in line for. Some will do it for the newest video game console; others, for the hottest new toy for their child this holiday season. For me - a single, child-free, non-gamer of a gal - it's food. Specifically, Swan's Oyster Depot.

Nestled cozily between See's Candies and Nara Sushi on Polk Street (close to California St), you may be inclined to mistake the line snaking down the street as tourists jonesing for SF's famous candy. But don't be mistaken - they're waiting for the tastiest, freshest seafood in town. And there's only one place to get it - Swan's Oyster Depot.

There's not a bad item on the menu - the smoked salmon is so fresh that you'll see one of the employees slicing it directly from the fish. Definitely try the clam chowder (not as thick as you're used to but maintains all the delicious flavor) and the Salad Louis is to die for (think mass proportions of fresh crab, shrimp and lobster. TO. DIE. FOR, I say.)

The staff - I believe it's a family-owned business - is genuinely friendly and loves to strike up energetic conversations while you're dining: never annoying, always entertaining. I highly suggest coupling your meal with an Anchor Steam (or two); if the line is especially long, you can sometimes even order a brew while waiting...seems to make it go faster.

An interesting thing to note about Swan's is that tourists seem to know it more than locals; somehow it's been kept a bit of a secret to those of us who include dining out part of our daily routine. But that's ok - while I'll happily wait in the line any day (it's worth it), I don't mind if it doesn't get much longer.
author: Aubrey S.

description:
I'm not American but this place to me is the example of how American food should be served: fresh, delicious, with nice friendly people in front of you talking about everything while they serve you the freshest seafood ever.
I gave only four stars instead the average five just because I told my new friend I was going to pay for lunch, not knowing that we were going to try almost everything: result $120. I'm sure we'll become good friends!
author: Sergio D.

description: Great for a first time experience.  30 minute wait.  Oysters fresh fresh fresh but pricey.  Clam chowder delicious - wished for a couple more clams.  Combo seafood cocktail had a good selection and we sent it over the top by adding a spoonful of the habanero sauce into the cocktail sauce.  Would I go again?  Maybe - if I had time and inclination to line up.  Service was very friendly and efficient.
author: Ash A.

description: if u love Oysters and ur in SF def need to check this place out. Theres a line outside when we went. Its def a small place. Only can fit about 10-15? i would say. But they are definately friendly people. I got there Seafood Salad Its good and fresh i only wished they had a different dressing. There clam chowder is BOMB though (must get). The oysters are pretty fresh. Its pricey though dozen for 2o something bucks. I would come back but next time Ill come back with more $$ hahaha
author: Grace K.

description: If it's an "ER" month, and your in the mood for some oysters, this place is a good treat! Last time I was there, had put back 4 dozen or so, and I won't tell you what the aftermath was, but all in all, was a great...
author: Gleanlife G.

description: This place is worth my cab rides from the financial district.  They make the chowder the way I like it... not overly thick. You can order uni and watch them crack open and clean the sea urchin. Oysters are good as expected and the crab salad is excellent.  They really pile on the crab!
author: James W.

description:
It is definitely a different experience. Old and simple very busy and definitely worth the wait. The food was extremely fresh and delicious, you have to try their seafood salad, oysters and seafood cocktail. 
There was a picture of this place taken long time ago, still black and white and it looked pretty much the same, even the chairs are the same! I loved the feel that i hasn't changed as much and so you feel like you're back in time. 

Loved the imperfect appearance of this place which makes it stand out.
author: Genevieve K.

description: I had heard a lot of hype about Swan before going for brunch with my sister last week, so I expected a lot.  Unfortunately, my high expectations were not met.  I have to say, though, that the seafood was very fresh - the cracked crab, oysters and crab salad were good, but I was pretty disappointed when the clam chowder came.  Not only was there hardly any clam meat in the soup, but it looked curdled, like the milk separated from the broth.  My sister and I tried it anyway and it was ok, not great.  I couldn't get over how it looked though.  The service was good, very nice family.  I don't know if I'd go back though.
author: Christa T.

description: I got here at around 3:30 pm on a Saturday afternoon, while vacationing solo for a few days, and the guys running the place put me in a great mood. They reminded me of the Sheepshead bay party boat deckands in Brooklyn. Just really happy to be in their business. I had the half cracked crab and clam chowder and a couple of anchors. I was thoroughly satisfied. Do what you have to do to get here before they close. That line out the door is there for a reason.
author: Richard B.

description: really GOOD raw oysters, esp with the lemon and tabasco sauce, the clam chowder is slightly more watery than we thought. fresh seafood on a saturday morning-- priceless.
author: Ellin C.

description:
Seafood Salad, Dozen mixed oysters & Bowl of Clam Chowder is to die for. There is a reason people are willing to wait for the food. FRESHNESS. 
Very entertaining watching the family behind the counter.
author: C J.

description: Best place for fresh oysters! I would come here and get a couple of dozen oysters, a couple of beers and the crab salad. When you order a dozen oysters they always throw in a a few more just cause there cool like that.  There is something about the dressing for the crab salad to, very tasty.
author: Mike K.

description:
A fishmonger around the corner that imports my favorite food in the world, Chesapeake Blue Crab?!  Count me in.

I ventured out to this place during the "Grand Storm of January" last Friday just to check out the hype.  As always, long lines remained out the door and fresh seafood lined the front window.  Fortunately I live just down the street so I was able to pop in and order to go.

I chatted up one of the staff, Kevin, about blue crab while he prepared my dungeoness crab salad and poured the clam chowder.  Excited about my lunch, the mood soured a little bit when I realized I had to fork over $24!

In any case, the seafood was indeed very fresh and the chowder a delicious hit on a cold and rainy day.  While I wish it was quite a bit thicker and with more sherry, I'll happily order the $4.50 bowl again.  I can't say the same about the crab salad, but I think that's just because dungeoness crab is such a poor, poor substitute for the good stuff.  Growing up on the Chesapeake Bay spoils a boy.

I look forward to buying some fish from these guys and having a beer or two next time.  I can see why the line is out the door.  Four stars simply because I can't get over the price.
author: Tim C.

description: I love this place! I've been coming here for 25 years and its still the same! Fresh fish, great service and a nostalgic feel to it. Love Love it!
author: lisa b.

description:
This weekend's oysters reminded me of this wonderful little find.  After four failed attempts to visit, my piqued taste buds were finally satiated. Now I know: get here before 5:30 and never on Sunday.  There's usually a line so be prepared to wait for one of the few seats at the counter - but it's worth it.

We had the seafood combo salad, and two dozen mixed oysters.  Have the big guy make your salad, he sure piles it up.  oh.. and omgawd.  Kumamoto oysters..  i need a plate full.  NOW.
author: Donny C.

description:
So, I saw this place on Rachel Ray's show $40 a day when she took a trip to SF.  LOL, she made it look soo good I was suckered in and came to try it. 

Me and a friend decided to come here one day, so we called in 30 minutes before then came here during the busy lunch hour surprised to find the line out the door.  Upon approaching the front of the line I repeated my name & order & the owner (I'm assuming) was the biggest A HOLE ever! For some reason he thought I cut in front of a regular customer, and I didn't even know she was standing in line! I simply said "I called over the phone so I would think my order would be ready by now!"  He said ,"Hey maybe next time if you call at 6:00am we'll be able to accommodate you & get your order!" Yeah, a jerk! On top of that he had the MOST distracting BACK & CHEST HAIR sticking out of his shirt. Ugh so gross lookin like Chewbacca! Anyways, luckily he didn't make my food!
