Onto the food, the salad was sooo good! Really pricey, I think like $16 or $17 for the salad but soo worth it.  It came with fresh crab, lobster, & huge prawns. They give a plentiful amount of seafood so it was definitely filling.  So yes, I definitely recommend this place, you like seafood, you'll love Swan Oyster!
author: Kristine R.

description:
Update 12/2/05:  STILL the best crab salad in town.  AND you can drink an Anchor Steam while waiting in line.

Don't go if you're in a hurry.  There is usually a line way out the door.  But it is soooooo worth it.  I always go for the crab salad and an Anchor Steam.  The crab is oh so fresh and sweet.  Some of my friends like the combo salad with shrimp.  They also have oysters, clam chowder and so much more.   All seating is at a long narrow bar where you can watch all the behind-the-scenes action.
author: Amme P.

description:
I'm only giving it 4 stars because the average wait is pretty long if you want to eat here.  That said ...

This place is like a San Francisco institution and has been here for as long as I can remember.  Owned and ran by the same family.

I've had various things here over the years.  Their seafood (d'oh that's the ONLY thing they serve?!) have always been the freshest I've had.

I tend to like the smaller oysters better than the large pulpy ones.  Just better flavor and texture.  Swan always has a good selection of them to choose from.  There are also cherrystone clams, that are always yummy.

Their bread is mild sour dough.  Crusty on the outside and soft and chewy on the inside.  Just the way bread should be.  It is NOT FREE, however.

By far my favorite thing there is their clam chowder.  It is out of this world good.  It's the white one, not the manhattan-red one.  This one, unlike the ones from the can or the ones at Fisherman's Wharf, is brothy and not thick and goopy.  It has lots of clams and clam juice in it.  Words cannot describe how much I love this stuff, except to say that it's the best, most clam-y clam chowder I've had and my favorite from any restaurant anywhere.

The place only has counter seats for about 20 people.  Decor doesn't look like it has changed since a few decades ago, which kind of adds to the charm.

You'll think an old place like this will be dirty and gross.  I've never had that feeling though.

Sometimes you'll run into fresh sea urchins that they sell, but not always (if you're into Uni).
author: Winnie C.

description:
There are lines, after it's long history and reputation, lines are going to form. Get there before 11 or be prepared to queue up.

The guys behind the counter are very friendly. Let them know it's your first time and they'll walk you through the menu.

My standard meal would start with a cup of chowder and some crusty sour dough. In case you're wondering, the chowder is "white" not "red".
Then a combination salad with both Louie and cocktail sauce on the side. A dollop of the really good horseradish goes into the cocktail sauce... they have a collection of hot sauces behind the counter too, just ask...

This is a definite take the relatives on a cable car destination, you can walk to the Wharf from there.
author: Geordie E.

description:
Oh my gosh!  I went with Annie [see review below] and was blown away!  The oysters, scallops and chowder were AMAZING~!  I'm still craving more right now.  Dean was a fantastic server!  He was fun, attentive and very personable.  If anything, try the assortment of oysters they have available, try the chowder which had the most tender clam ever, and lastly the raw scallops with capers and olive oil...  it was pure heaven I tell you!

We will definitely be coming by the next time we're in the Bay area!
author: Michael D.

description: tips: don't go at noon!  the wait is around an hour during lunchtime, so try going at an off-time.  The place is tiny - kind of like Art's Cafe in the Sunset, where it's a tiny diner that is narrow and long.  However, the fresh seafood is totally worth it!  I had a dozen assorted oysters and the crab cocktail.  It's so awesome having a mound of crab in front of you, and you didn't have to de-shell it yourself!  Makes it taste even more delicious.  The only thing is be ready to spend $$$ because it's hard to get full on seafood and all the dishes are at least $10, more around $20 I'd say.  The one thing I didn't really like was the clam chowder, but that's because I prefer the really hearty, creamy kind; this one was kind of watery, but very clammy (clammy is a good thing).
author: Tiffany D.

description: The best oysters in the world can be found at SWAN! Absolutely fell in love with this place, the guys working the counter were entertaining and made us feel right at home! The short 20-30 minute wait for seating was well worth it!
author: Eisa m.

description: Went to the first time yesterday. Great funky enviroment, delicious oysters and a quirky, yet attentive staff. Cash only, wine is served in what appeared to be 4oz glasses and quite pricey overall. But fun to stumble into when there is no line. Oh - as other reviews have stated - they start putting the stools on the counter to close up at 5:25PM promptly!
author: Lisa W.

description:
God I miss living in Polk Gulch... Wait in line and keep the See's Candies doorway clear (The ladies just might bring you some free toffee for being courteous). Worth the wait as you finally get your seat at the ancient marble counter. Let local flavor and conversation entertain you and enjoy the best Seafood Salad ever. Plenty o' crab, Prawns, Shrimp, Lobster  mmmmmm all served with crusty french bread.

Oh and Tessa, they mop the floors every day with bleach solution, I know because I walked by at closing on the way home for several years.
author: Amanda L.

description:
We finally braved the line for a Saturday lunch. The guys who run this place are fantastic - they really make the whole experience and if it weren't for the long lines and our tendency to really rack up the bill, I'd be back often. Great fresh seafood, served chilled with homemade horseradish to mix your own cocktail sauce. Decent clam chowder, among the better ones I've tried but a little greasier than I am used to. bar stools not so comfy. All the seafood combos, i.e. salad or cocktail, come with an abundance of bay shrimp - the teeny tiny ones you're only supposed to eat in salad, 1-3 "prawns" which are misnamed regular sized shrimp, a few crab claws, and some delish crab meat. 

Can't quite figure out the deal with the rubber ducky collection proudly on display....but I had a good time whilst dining here.
author: Angela N.

description:
Talk about a lopsided supply demand curve. With only 12-15 booth seating, the turnover at this pace is pretty slow while ppl continue to pile in line.  We finally got seated after 40 minutes of waiting and continuou ritual of refilling our street parking.  

As told, we ordered their popular shrimp cocktail and a dozen of the miyaki oyster.  We both thought the shrimp cocktail, while refreshing, was too sweet and we would have been good with just 1 order rather than one each.  The dozen of oyster definitely satisfied my craving for oyster. It was so fresh and tasty!

Be sure to show up by 4pm since they cut off their line by 4:15 and close at 5pm.
author: Jeannie L.

description:
Love this place. GREAT, fresh seafood at totally reasonable prices in a casual atmosphere. The staff here is so friendly and chatty; they'll make you feel like you're an old customer who has been going there for years. You can tell everyone there loves what they're doing.

Warning: because there are only 12 (or 14?) barstools in the entire place, be prepared to wait. This place is an SF gem, so people will be lining out the door the moment Swan Oyster Depot opens. But it's totally worth it!
author: Cee J.

description:
I think I had the best oyster of my life here.  Get the oyster, shrimp, crab, clams, lobster, AND a beer, yum.  Everything is super fresh, and you can ask them to do a sashimi combo here.  Too bad they are not good at cutting fish for sashimi though.  Love the food, love the vibe.  Old fashioned and genuine, like the good old tapas bars in Spain.   

Go during non-work hours, cuz the place is small and it gets crowded.  The staff are really happy and friendly and they've been here forever (weird how there's only one Asian lady assisting).
author: Amanda L.

description:
All I can say is:
I LOVE THIS PLACE.
I ask to go here each time I am in town.
Such friendly faces, serving up great shellfish.
I've learned so much about how to properly get all the meat out of claws and other parts of a crsustacean.
Mmm, oysters, crab, clam chowder, shrimp, and a beer at 10am.  Life is good!
author: Tatertots Rock X.

description: Let two separate "regulars" ahead of us, ignored us when we tried to order.  This place is a waste of time.  Also a filthy mess.
author: Kevin O.

description: A bit pricey when you eat as many oysters as I prefer, but the ambiance and the seafood are unparalleled anywhere! I don't mind waiting an hour for a seat, especially when they serve samples and heinekens while standing in line. The epitome of fun in the City.
author: David B.

description: I've been here a few times.  They have good crab salads and clam chowder but this place is slightly over rated.  I've found better/fresher oysters at other places.  Because of the hype, the wait is long and it's fairly expensive for what you get.  If you haven't been here before, I do recommend you try it at least once.
author: Shelly W.

description: Love the Swan Oyster Depot!!  This is my favorite place to eat lunch in the city on a Saturday. This tiny place is old school seafood bar at its finest!  It is all about the freshness of the seafood and the service.  I'm a connoisseur of Dungeness crab and this place has the sweet sea air taste of great crab.  It's why so many of us stand in line.  My favorites are the Blue Point Oysters and of course the Crab Louie.  Wish they were open in the evenings!
author: Laureen M.

description: great classic spot. My dad's a foodie and researcher and every time the fam comes up for a visit he's got a few places on his wish list. Swans was on his list a few times and finally we made our way to polk st and decided to wait in the line. It was worth the waIt. Coming to a place like this with the folks is the way to do it too - because big dad orders about 1 of everything on the menu, mainly because hes curious and excited to try them (as are his guests) and his eyes are always bigger than his stomache and he really thinks hes that hungry. So the chowder was great. The oysters, i cant remember which ones we got but i believe we tried 3 different kinds - were all stellar and very tasty, super fresh and went down quickly. i had a crab salad which was devine and the few other dishes i got  to taste - a louie and a few others were all delish. Will definitely come back again.
author: Audrey V.

description: Delicious delicious seafood.  I am a sucker for a good oyster, so when in San Francisco, this was an obvious must-do.  We went about 30 minutes before the opened on a Monday, and even that was overkill (15 minutes might have been sufficient to get a seat in the first wave, though there was a long line by the time we left).  We obviously had a good idea what we wanted after staring at the menu while waiting for 30 minutes, but when we went to order everything, our server (is that the proper term? maybe "seafood guide" is better) insisted we only order one item at a time.  Works for me, as I always appreciate not feeling rushed.  We did some chowder, a spread of six different types of oysters, shrimp cocktail, and a plate of their "Sicilian Sashimi."  Everything was extremely fresh, well prepared, and delicious.  I easily could have sat in that stool, as uncomfortable as it was, for the next 6 hours drinking Anchor Steam on tap and pounding oyster after oyster, but alas, the real world was calling. Sadly, there were no crabs available that day, nor did we have time to do a seafood salad, so that will have to wait for my next trip (as I will most definitely be back).
author: Julie M.

description:
I love raw oysters and I stumbled upon this gem when I was staying close for a conference.
Ended up going 3 straight days for lunch.
Great seafood and amazing oysters with a large variety.
author: Chris P.

description: Our favorite seafood in San Francisco! Clam chowder, prawns, oysters, crab, clams, and smoked salmon are all sensational! It really is true that you should get there early to ensure a seat before the lunch rush! Worth every penny!!
author: Trey C.

description: You were worth the hype & the wait. Both blue point and kumamoto oysters was amazing. One of the BEST oysters I've ever had. The clam chowder& the shrimp salad was ridiculous too. I'd definitely come back everytime I'm in the bay
author: Arnold N.

description:
OK,  i really really REALLY wanted to love this place. And I could have if I didn't know any better nor ever ventured outside of SF. BUT I HAVE.

The quality is fine in comparison to what's readily available out there, (tho i wasn't impressed by the clam chowder--- more chowder than clam) and you're paying more than just a pretty penny for it.  Considering the long wait to sit on crusty stools that have been around since the dawn of time (and it shows) at a dingy seafood bar, I can't help but feel a little more than jipped from the experience. I guess go if you wanna be touristy and be able to say you've gone...
author: Ikeb I.

description:
I like Swan Oyster Depot mostly for their Chowder. I am not a fan of the super thick chowders and so this is my place. Very light and definitely one of my favorites in the City. Tourist trap? Yeah, it's been getting more and more tourists, but I really wouldn't call it an actual "tourist trap" at all. It seems to have a pretty steady mix of tourists as well as locals in my opinion. 

The fish is always fresh and as long as you know what to expect (possible wait in line, no frills, limited seating, etc...) you'll probably like it. If that isn't your thing, go elsewhere.
author: Anita B.

description:
I go for the oysters, that's it.  As long as the fish market is open the day you show up, they are fresh and delightful.  All other offerings here should be considered sideshows and supplements only.

I don't use the mignonette.  I like my oysters with lemon and tabasco sauce.

I like the way they fully sever the oyster from the shell before serving.  You don't have to fiddle around with those stupid little forks at risk of flipping an oyster into your neighbor's glass of water.

The place is located in that seedy inland part of town.  But, I don't come for the ambiance.
author: Nathan J.

description:
Well worth the wait!  A neighborhood favorite.

Do not be intimidated by the line of people queuing outside of Swan's on a Saturday afternoon.  Swan is not open 7 days a week, nor is it open for dinner, so the faithful happily line up to enjoy.

Inside, the restaurant has probably 20 or so stools lined up along the bar.  Don't bother coming with a large group.  You'll either wait forever, or be forced to break up the group.  Patrons are treated to a fairly simple menu, but the freshness and taste cannot be beat.  There are at least 5 or so types of oyster on supply at all times and all are worth trying (go for a mixed dozen), but my favorite item on the menu has to be the smoked salmon.  Served atop french bread with plenty of the usual toppings to choose from, it is a must have.

Almost as good as the food itself is the service.  Each time I have been there, the staff has been extremely friendly and talkative.  The joint is clearly a family-run business as is obviously apparent from the pictures on the wall, but also the fact that they all seem to look alike.  There seems to be 2 generations of family members working at all times, and all are extremely cheerful.  I know I've heard that oysters are an aphrodisiac, but now I also wonder if they have some sort of anti-depressant effect, based strictly on how absurdly friendly everybody is.
author: Brian J.

description:
I dream about this place at night; I'm salivating as we speak!!

We came here for my boyfriend's birthday and loved it!!  The food is super fresh and the service  is very friendly and easy-going.  

We had to wait about 40 minutes outside (since the place is so small) but did not mind it a bit: we got to enjoy a beer while we waited in line.  I love the feel of this place and the food is AMAZING!!

This is a restaurant that you HAVE to go to!!!!!
author: Michi R.

description:
wow.  That's the best I can say about this place.  I can't think of a better place in the city that says "San Francisco" than this gem.  The smell of raw seafood, the awesome staff that take care of you, the pictures of past employees and old time SF, and that's just a bonus to the amazing food here.  I suggest the Crab Louie, which is as fresh as it gets.  The Clam chowder is also top notch and different because it's not thick like most chowders.
My wife and I have been here twice now and we will go anytime we are nearby.
author: drew d.

description:
SOD is one of the things I miss about living in San Francisco and one of the places I like to go when I go back for a visit. I get the crab louie salad. I skip the dressing and just squeeze some lemons on it. No need to drown that fresh, tasty crab in dressing. 

It's a San Francisco institution and deserves all the 5-star reviews it gets.
author: Sophie Y.

description: This place is really good. Try the clam chowder!! Feels family owned and operated, educational and funny. I cool place to eat when in SF!
author: James C.

description: If you want fresh fish....Swan Oyster Depot is the place. I love it for the clam chowder that's made daily and for the coziness of the counter where my mom & I were served. Their service resembles what you would get if you were at someones home sitting in the kitchen. Everything sold there is caught that day and you can't get better than this in the city.
author: Metris E.

description: We came here after lunch for a raw oyster stop before catching our flight back home to LA.  But boy, was there a line.  We ended up getting a  1/2 dozen oysters to go so we wouldn't have to wait in line.  And WOW... it was so darn fresh + no sand (HUGE plus for me).  They mixed in some really good cocktail sauce with horseradish + Tabasco sauce + lemon on the side.  Even though we were downing our oysters on the side walk next to some commercial trash cans, we felt like we were in HEAVEN.. it was that GOOD~
author: syrus f.

description:
Honesty, I don't wait an hour and a half for ANY restaurant, but I must say I was just fine to do so here.  It was freezing outside, and one of the gentlemen served us beverages to keep us warm while we waited.  The guys behind the counter couldn't be nicer and more knowledgeable.  We had the omakase ... a little of everything if you will.  Started with the clam chowder (more brothy than usual, which I liked), then on to the smoked salmon on toasts with capers and onions, then a sampling of half dozen oysters (the blue point were my favorites - served with three different sauces), and finished up with a combination seafood cocktail (the crab was just spectacular - coming from someone who had the 'famous' crab at R and G Lounge just yesterday).  The cherry on top was the fact that they pour one of my favorite sav blancs ... Honig ... I didn't see a wine list but I recognized the label from afar.  The pacing of the food was perfect, all in all an excellent casual dining experience.

I loved the vintage music playing (Let's twist again by chubby checker) and the old cash register ... what a gem ... would highly recommend to anyone who has the time to wait for a really really great meal.
author: Lindsay N.

description: Seriously? I'm frankly amazed that people rave about the clam chowder here. It's very thin, and was mostly liquid. I'll admit, the broth was tasty, but come on. It's a red flag when I have to add tons of oyster crackers (and I rarely do). You guys who think the chowder is amazing here clearly haven't been to Sotto Mare over in North Beach, who serve the clam chowder to end all others.
author: Maximillian M.

description: I don't even like seafood and I thought the oysters here were delightful. Let me just reiterate that one more time -- I don't like seafood, and I loved the oysters. Everything was so incredibly fresh and tasty. Discovered I like my oysters with their green habanero chili sauce (at least that's what I think it was) and a dash of tabasco. Cash only and long waits, so plan accordingly.
author: Cynthia T.

description: I heard that this place has the BEST clam chowder in town, and when I finally tried it, it wasn't that impressive.  Maybe it's because I like my chowder to be thicker, but the flavor was very good.  I would love to come back and try the oysters and their crab!  The staff is so friendly and awesome!
author: Allie D.

description:
Take this place for what it is: friendly, knowledgeable service, great fresh seafood, crowded, no-frills, and expensive. If you go expecting all that, you will truly enjoy your experience. This place is unique, and that's the best part about it. Counter seating only.
The $17 crab salad is incredible just for the amount of fresh crab meat that is piled on top of it. Tell them to go a little light on the Louie dressing, though. We also got a dozen raw oysters - a kind of oyster sampler platter, with 6 different kinds of oysters. Pretty impressive. And tasty.
author: J. R.

description:
You MUST try Swan's if you like: the best and freshest oysters, fresh seafood w/ combos, waiting in line, tiny diner experience (I'm talking elbow to elbow TO ELBOW - with maybe room for 15 ppl!), and chatting up the family who owns this old school joint.  They're such good people, extremely friendly and quick.
Try the oysters.. all of them!  Their salads are to-die-for, I like getting the shrimp and crab or lobster with louie dressing..  Also, smoked salmon on bread w/ capers.  Bring lots of cash, they don't take credit cards or ATM.  And it sucks they are closed on Sundays.  But it's definitely worth the wait in line and you'll enjoy the "intimacy" of the place once you have your first oyster and swig of beer!
author: Francine S.

description:
You haven't had FRESH seafood until you've eaten here.  I swear, it's like they pluck'em out of the ocean minutes before they're served.

I didn't have enough in my wallet to go all out, as this is a relatively pricey place.  But you get what you pay for, it's so awesome.

I had the Combination Cocktail which was a small sampler of everything on the menu.  And for the first time, I actually ENJOYED OYSTER!  I've eaten'em before and deemed them passable/edible.  But these were soooo good!

They're usually pretty busy and have a short line going out the door, which is why today was my first time there...even though I live just 2 blocks away.  But it looks like Thursday afternoon is the time to go.  There wasn't a line at all!
author: Jonathan B.

description:
Hmmm..  As much as I can understand the points of Kenneth N.'s first review, it really is as pessimistic as can be.  A definite "glass half empty" viewpoint.  Let's do the "glass half full" review.  

Now, I have been a San Francisco resident for only 7 years.  I do though, have very close friends who were born here, grew up here, and swear by Swans.  

I guess an interpretation of "fine food" is subjective to a certain degree, as with most anything.  However, this is basically a fresh fish market/restaurant.  If the food was mediocre, I suppose that it would be safe to surmise the seafood was not fresh.  Ultimately, whatever it means, mediocre would not have this place still around since 1912.

Yeah that line is long.  It sucks.   "Insipid"?  Hmmm... I don't wanna agree with that.  Traditional?  Family inspired?  If it ain't broke, don't fix it?  Definitely.  Sure I've had better dressing and better salads.  At Swans, I always get the same thing.  Seafood salad, which is basically just chopped iceberg with bay shrimp, some 16-20 count shrimp, and dungeoness crab.  A dozen oysters and a beer or two.  Sure I could prepare all of that at home for a fraction of the cost.  The question though...WHY?  Swan Oyster Depot....  Its boisterous, its messy, its expensive.  Its also delightfully charming, fresh, nostalgic, warm, fun, and makes you feel great to be a San Franciscan.    
Cheers!
author: Barry A.

description:
Our trip to the Swan Oyster Depot started with a few blocks of walking from a parking lot, which I did not mind. Outside of the restaurant we waited in line for a while. Standing by an open door to the See's Candies shop was not helpful as I really wanted to go in for a sample and a few of their caramels. When we were closer in line, we were asked if we wanted anything to drink (water, beer, soda...). We also saw the display of sea creatures that are available for eating. The selection is great and very tempting!

Once inside: The service is very nice and friendly. There was a number of regular long-time customers there who asked the owners about their family members and health. Even though all customers had to wait in line for a while, everyone was happy to be there. Some people heard about the place in a TV show (can't remember which one) and came to see the restaurant while visiting the US from Europe. 

The food is very tasty. The oysters are fresh. The sauces and the availability of other condiments is very good! I liked seeing the big bowl of lemon wedges right in front of me. The crab cocktail is amazing! I wanted to have two of those. The clam chowder is also very nice and tasty (obviously not from a can, like in most restaurants).  This restaurant buys bread from Boudin bakery and impresses its customers who want to take the remainder of their served bread home or even buy a loaf to go. 

My overall experience here was good. The food is very tasty. The service is great, but it can get very busy in there. If you want to use the restroom, try not to look around too much or be too picky....
author: Taissia B.

description:
There's two lines at the door, the right line is for getting a seat.  The left line, sometimes non-existent ,is for ordering take-out or picking up phone orders.  

Even if you do have to wait in line you can marvel at the fresh hunks of dungeness crab and crisp fresh shrimp piled on each plate by hand, source of multiple forgivable health code violations.  This place has great product and is equal parts utility fish monger and hole-in-the-wall-raw-bar.
author: Andy G.

description:
The food and quirkiness of the staff (all brothers, sons, cousins that have run the place for decades) make it worth the inconvenience of their limited hours and the wait.

I get the seafood salad, but rarely get to the lettuce.  What the heck, have an Anchor Steam while you're there.
author: David F.

description:
The experience of eating here is A++. The guys that serve you are a lot of fun and it almost makes you forget that you are sitting on the world's most uncomfortable stool ever in the world. 

The seafood was all very fresh and most of what we ate was extremely tasty. I don't know that I'd ever go back mainly because those stools? REALLY uncomfortable. It's good for a one shot deal, though.
author: Catie A.

description:
I'm in San Francisco, I'm feeling good, I've declared myself a (temporary and pretty unsuccessful) vegan...so what better way to start the day than with breakfast at a local seafood joint?  Admittedly, the only other time in my life I've eaten raw seafood before noon was at Tsukiji Fish Market in Tokyo and it was not a memorable experience.  But first impressions rein me in and as we walked into Swan Oyster Depot, an indisputable favorite spot for San Franciscans and visitors alike, I knew I was in for something very special.  

Seated at the long, narrow counter, I ordered from the simple menu of the morning's freshest catch of sweet Dungeness crab and oysters. The cheerful mood of the no-frills, no-fuss men working behind the counter was contagious and everyone was joyful and talkative, coo-ing over strangers babies, sharing bowls of buttery oyster crackers and plunking them into cups of clam chowder.  The counter was strewn with heaping bowls of lemon wedges, essential for squeezing onto sweet little Kumomoto's and large, briny Blue Points.  When I finished, I seriously considered ordering everything all over again.  But I talked some sense into myself, finished my Stella, declared to anyone who was listening, "Save a seat for me tomorrow," and went off to tackle my next meal.
author: T. L.

description: Fun and friendly, with fabulously fresh sea creatures on the half shell.  There's not much more to ask for (except maybe less of a line or a longer bar for more patrons).   Beware that it's cash only, and that it gets expensive (before I knew it, I was about $100 in for lunch -- but well worth it!).
author: Han L.

description:
"Meh. I've experienced better"

We had been to Swan Oyster Depot ("SOD") a few times before and since we were craving oysters at 2:00 on a Monday afternoon, we thought we'd go back. Plus, we really like to support smaller establishments like SOD, especially since they've been around for a long time.  Also, the last time we went, my husband had sardines and loved them, so he was looking forward to more. 

Highlights: Celeb sighting - Jason Ritter, currently on ABC's Parenthood, which I love. And watching the lady next to us put 4 pats of butter per slice of bread she ate (WOW). 

Lowlights: Feeling like we wasted a meal (we love to eat, so that's kind of a big deal) and $60 bucks on barely fresh seafood and mediocre experience.

FACTS
- We ordered: 
1. A cup of chowder
2. 6 each of cherry stone clams and Kumamoto's on the half shell
3. Scallops, served raw, with onions, capers, and olive oil
- Sardines didn't come in that day, unfortunately.
- Floors, walls, counters, seats, and tables were dirty
- They recycle their condiments (small containers of horseradish, cocktail sauce, and mignonette)--as in, when we were done eating, our server took the condiments and gave them to the couple next to us.

OPINIONS
- Chowder - good, not super thick and rich like the kind you get at Fisherman's Wharf, but too few clams. 
- Cherry stone clams (extra large) and Kumamotos (extra small, the way we like them) were fresh enough, but not super fresh like we've had at Hog Island or Zuni Café or other places, where we just couldn't wait to slurp the next one down.
- Scallops, not super fresh and they were warm, for some reason. We LOVE raw scallops and usually, when fresh, they melt like butter in your mouth. We had to squeeze a bunch of lemon and even splashed some mignonette on them. 
- Recycling condiments--WOW! What if we had double-dipped? What if the people who used those before us double-dipped? If SF had a law that would require food establishments to post their letter rating (like they do in LA), I'm pretty sure this place would not be higher than a C. I get that it's supposed to be rugged, and etc., but you know, sanitation and cleanliness, especially when serving seafood, kind of important. 
- The vibe from the staff...I don't know. I mean, they love to talk, but not really friendly or warm. Does that make sense?

In sum, I really wish I had better things to say about this place, it being an old San Francisco standard and all, but I just don't. Sorry, SOD, but we won't be coming back.
author: Ali A.

description: Great old school joint still left in SF. Wonderful seafood, esp oysters and crab (when in season). Only issue is that there is always a long line. get there early, staff great.
author: Robert P.

description: the best benjamin i've spent at a place.  its a big step up paying the extra $3 for the larger oysters....they come so fresh on crushed ice, and for my first time, had horseradish and habanero chili to go with.  we got here at a good time to saddle up on one of those few barstools.  with anchor steam & more oysters, we were set.  talking about it makes me drool.  did i say we had sashimi with 4 types of fish too, and chowder & shrimp cocktail?
author: John P.

description: One of the places in San Francisco that demand more than one visit in a week long stay.  Sure there is Hog Island Oyster at the Ferry Bldg., but for oh-so-fresh Oysters and the best crab salad (perhaps in the world?), there is just no other place but the Swan Oyster Depot on Polk.  It is good to see the sons and nephews of the older staff working there in the "depot", that insures us all that down the road we will still be given the same friendly service and cut-before-your-eyes sashimi, and fish dishes.  Certainly the Oysters are the stars, but do NOT overlook the other fish, including the smoked salmon, the Albacore tuna and the mixed plate including scallops.  This place is a DESTINATION/REQUIRED stop for any of you other traveling foodies.  Give me a crab salad (with some huge chunks of crab) and put the "Louie" sauce on it every time.  I wish I could give the place 6 stars.
author: Gadget G.

description:
Pass me another oyster buddy! 
Swan Oyster Depot is simply fresh and delicious. I went here for lunch around 11AM on a weekday with the hubby and there was barely a wait. I guess we were lucky because it was freezing that day. It's a small joint with a line of bar stools and you'll be bumping elbows with your neighbor as you enjoy your meal. We ended up ordering the combination seafood salad loaded with tons of crab and shrimp, hot clam chowder (with clams you can actually see), and a variety of a dozen oysters. We were told the type of oyster it was and what kind of taste we might expect. 

As we waited for our order to be filled, we watched one of the staff fillet a smoked salmon for another customer as he chatted with my hubby. He even offered him a taste. The staff is super friendly and will offer suggestions if you can't decide. 

There are a variety of condiments to choose from that you can add to your seafood adventure. The cocktail sauce is without horseradish, but it's available and you can add as little or as much you want for that spicy kick. 

We ended up dropping around $60 for the both of us for food, drinks, and tip. But we were stuffed. All in all it was a great experience. I'll definitely come back. Dress warm, come hungry, and don't for get to bring $$ when you come here.
author: Janet E.

description: Super good.  My only complaint would be that they don't open at 8 am if you want to sit and have oysters and a beer for breakfast.  You have to wait until 10:30.  Arrrgh, agony.    Was very happy with the mixed selection of oysters and ordered another few of my favorite.  Window was beautifully full of fresh goods and got a good eyeful of what others were eating.  Lady from the back brought out prime crab legs and meat, but also the crab shells filled with the good goop that hardly nobody wants.  If I could only go more often, or eat more at one sitting, I would be a happy, happy girl.
author: stacy c.

description: good food if you succeed the line. little pricy though but food is good.
author: Lyra S.

description:
It's like I found some long lost family members up in here. 

Kid was craving oysters from the minute he woke up and, since we were stuck helping my sis move at the Fillmore Center and weren't anywhere near the Ferry Bldg, we cruised over to Swan Oyster Depot. The Mia Familia atmosphere totally drew me into this place, where all the good ol boys gather and work damn hard to serve up the freshest shellfish your heart desires. Darren graciously gave me a beer to pass the time in the line on a beautiful Saturday afternoon, and after we finished a pint of that, Kevin offered wine. Before HR-squared and I even sat down to enjoy a plate of various oysters, we had a couple drinks and met two awesome people in the line. That's the kinda place this is -- cozy and inviting, with a nice mix of local folk. It felt less touristy than hanging out at the Ferry Bldg which I liked. I like places that feel familiar and homey and that's the feeling I got here. I also got the feeling that I'd be returning for more oyster/combination salad feast since our food was the bomb. Try the salmon -- we got some to go and had it for breakfast with bagels the next day. Creamy, not too salty, melt-in-your-mouth INCREDIBLE. 

Love this spot.
author: Anita A.

description:
After years of passing this place and complaining about how long the line was, we finally made the effort to go. I'll say it's certainly a unique experience- the atmosphere alone makes it worth going at least once- but all-in-all I wasn't that impressed. 
I randomly met chef Anthony Bourdain at a bar in town, and he said his two favorite spots in the Bay Area are French Laundry and Swan's. Maybe I'm just not as sophisticated as some. 
Too expensive, too long a line, and just a little scary for a closet germophobe like myself.
author: Justin M.

description:
I'm with Justin M. in that the iceberg lettuce was too retro for some of the best fresh looking display of seafood on that side of Polk.
The clam chowder I had in Boston was better and I really wanted to like this institution; at least that's my Swan song for this depot.
author: miriam b.

description:
Wonderful food, wonderful atmosphere.  I've been here several times and it's always a treat, even though there's always a wait.  I love going here on a lazy Saturday for their smoked salmon, oysters, and a glass of wine.  The staff is friendly and knowledgeable.

I see one of the reviewers took issue with the fact that the staff doesn't wear gloves to handle the food/money.  As a former waitress I say, if that kind of thing scares you, stay home and eat in  your hermetically sealed, hosed-down with bleach, plastic bubble, because you ain't seen HALF of what goes on in a restaurant kitchen.

Swan's is old-school done well, and I love it, ungloved hands and all.
author: Jamie C.

description:
I have always loved Swans.  The food in incredible, and always fresh.  The staff is cheerful, and they love what they do.  There is nothing like this place in SF, as far as I can tell.  
The pricing is fair, and even on the higher side for a lunch, but worth ever penny.  Yes, there is a line if you going during lunch hours, and that is why I minus a star...but really, part of the charm is the intimacy of this fish-house/bar, and with that comes a wait.  I bring a friend here ever time she rolls into town...all the way from Indonesia.  She knows good fresh seafood as good as anyone and gives Swans constant praise.  It is the first place she wants to go and each lunch when she arrives...
author: gordon w.

description:
This place is an institution in San Francisco. Everytime somebody comes to visit, I take them there and,............no surprise, they always LUUUUUV it.... !  Indeed, this place has nothing of your typical american restaurant, it's original, it's not money driven (or little), it is an amazing experience both culinary and socially...!

Seafood lovers will find it amazing, others will find it very charming. The service is friendly and "bon enfant", as this is a family-run business. Try the clam chowder is fantastic, and the salads are to die for. 

Definitely on my top 5 restaurants in SF.
author: Steph S.

description:
As the old saying goes, you're never unhappy with quality.

I so lucked out. I used to live 1/2 block away. Take away shrimp cocktail and clam chowder for lunch any day of the week - you know I was happy.

Family owned by a bunch of great guys for about 100 years or close to it. This is the kind of place that can only be experienced in our beautiful city.

You wont find a more unique experience than Swan's.  Yes there is always a line, it's only open during the day while you are at work, and it is more expensive than your average lunch - but get around all that and you will understand why that line is always there! 

This is the real San Francisco. Take the cable car there and make some memories. Cheers.
author: Matthew C.

description:
I used to live in the Tenderknob and noticed that every time I went down to Polk St, there would be people lined up out the door and down the sidewalk from this place. As a big Seinfeld fan, I always thought of the well-known Soup Nazi episode, and when I realized this was a seafood place everyone was cramming to get into, I was excited to try it out!

This place did not disappoint me at all. I went 3 times, both with one other person, and we had a long wait, but when you get close to the door, waiters come outside and start serving you beer before you're even seated! 

The second someone leaves you have to kind of hurry to the seat because, if you're like me, you feel a lot of pressure from holding up the big line behind you. Depending on what you get, the food is either amazing or so-so, and the cleanliness...it just seems "OK"- but I choose to trust it because the food tastes so good. 

There's something kind of gross about the idea of seafood to me, in general, (a lot of it is stinky and squishy, maybe, and you see all the dead fish lying there on ice in the front window?) so I think when I stepped through the doorway I think I made the subconscious decision to not be a clean freak and enjoy my fish.

So I would give:
-Five stars to the oysters...amazing, fresh, lemony and perfect!
-Three and a half to the clam chowder...I would have some of this as "filler" maybe, so I don't break my bank on oysters. Nothing special to merit waiting in line just for the chowder, though.
-Four stars for the shrimp / crab cocktail. You have to make your own cocktail sauce - you are given ketchup and have to add horseradish, lemon, etc. - this could be a plus for some people who like it to-taste, but I would have rather had some better cocktail sauce. But the seafood chunks were generous and very dee-lish!
author: Heidi G.

description: I love their calm chowder. Writing about it right now makes my mouth water. Their calm chowder tastes very much of calm broth and has less cream compared to Boudin's. I also will order the Kumamotos oyster. If you have not shucked a Kumamoto yet, you have to try it. It is to die for. I tried their crab thing that comes in a cup. It's fresh, but lacks flavor, because it's just boiled crab! I am sure that I can duplicate the same dish if I boil a fresh crab at home.
author: Helen L.

description: A-MA-ZING.. I went for lunch and got a combo salad and some clam chowder to go. I love little wholes in the wall places and this was deffinately it. The atmosphere was "family" it was so comfortable. I wish I could fly in my whole family from wisconsin and beyond and take them here. They would love this place. Next time I will bring some friend and sit in. One of the guys was a cutie too. ;) Thanks guys!
author: robin l.

description: Great late lunch.  Walked in to zero wait @ 4:00.  Thank you Yelp.  Wonderful atmosphere.  Enjoyed 2 plates of oysters and cups of chowder, along with a few glasses of wine.  Staff was fun to chat with and very open to talking about options.  Will definitely come back next we are in town.
author: Kari A.

description:
Expectations are set high when you wait in line for a place for over an hour. By the 45-minute mark, I started internally panicking that we fell for some tourist trap and wasted our lives and meter money for nothing.
Luckily, Swan's fulfilled those expectations, and those quarters weren't wasted.
A quaint, old-fashioned oyster bar with a seating capacity of no more than 20, with fresh seafood displayed in the window and behind the bar. You pretty much get what you see.
We tried Blue Point and Miyagi oysters and Cherrystone clams. For sure this is some fresh stuff.. no fishiness at all, although there was a little sand. The miyagis are local, so they were a little brine-y and tasted like the ocean. Pretty crazy.
I wish they had cocktail sauce to go with their stuff (they only have ketchup), but what made up for it was their special sauces of horseradish and another pepper sauce. Make sure to try all of it out.
We also all split a bowl of clam chowder, which was good and flavorful. It was thin and brothy, but I prefer restaurants not pouring tons of flour into it.
There was a giant slab of smoked salmon in front of us that I was drooling over, but I didn't get a sample like some people said! Boo.
Haha, I also agreed with the sanitary things that some people mentioned. Bare hands and open seafood everywhere. BUT the guys were super friendly and courteous. Great service and overall a very chummy environment. Also, loooved the old-school cash register they use.
But we came away unscathed. I'll make note of this place next time I have friends interested in some of SF's freshest seafood. Just don't be surprised if there's a line!
Another one knocked off my 7x7 list!
author: Jen T.

description:
mmm.....got the assorted raw fish sampler and it was great. really fresh topped with lemon, onions and capers. so tasty.

service was great.

my bf LOVED the clam chowder, he said it was the best hes ever had.

oysters were good but its not my forte so im not going to touch on this subject as i dont want to offend the serious die hard oyster eaters.

seating is MINIMAL, so try to come at non peak times!
author: Melanie F.

description: What an amazing find! You know when the line is out the door it must be good. This place apparently has been around since 1912, and our server said he had been working there since the 60s. The seafood is beautifully presented in the window as you walk in and all seating is at the bar. I ordered the combination cocktail and clam chowder. It was delicious and very filling. The seafood tasted very fresh and the staff were friendly. This is a great spot if you love seafood.
author: Paige L.

description: Wait was waaay too long...I guess I expected to be amazed, but was a bit disappointed that it was just ordinary seafood.  Oysters were my fave.  Clam chowder was average, and combo cocktail was the same.  My stiomach wasn't full, but my wallet def felt the pinch.
author: Linda F.

description: The food was good but it was not worth an hour 20 min wait. And the chowder was watery and unimpressive. We got there at 10:30am on the dot and still had a long ass wait. When we got in we realized that at least 2 out of the 4 people working were working at a sloth's pace. There was no hustle at all.  It took these guys 3 minutes to make a salad that consisting of throwing some seafood on some lettuce. The guy would pick some shrimp and spread it around then pick trough the crab for the best pieces then back to the shrimp and hen pick through the prawns. Omg it was like senior citizens in the kitchen. Then we started getting adventurous and ordering things we saw other people getting but were not on the board. We got some sashimi (very good) and a sea urchin (not a fan) lots of people were ordering it. If you have a problem with texture I would skip this. Anyway those two things we ordered added 55 dollars to the meal.  I would only go here again if there was no line. Dont order anything off the menu or expect a ridiculously high surprise on your bill.  Seafood salad and bread is the way to go!
author: Flash Z.

description: Excellent Place for Oysters.  Keep in mind, you may need to exhibit patience before getting a seat. This place is well known, and usually packed.  The line goes out the door
author: Johnny G.

description:
it can be pricey BUT you'll be tempted to go back again and again and again.. they deliver which is the best!!!!!

I LOVE THE MIXED-SEAFOOD SALAD! i love their thousand island dressing! 

DELICIOUS Seafood
author: nice m.

description:
Do you want the best fresh Oysters, Shrimp, Crab, Crab salad? Go to Swan's. 

Don't dress fancy, it's a hole in the wall.

BE WARNED...Once you eat there you're different. You are not the same. Consider it the "Forbidden Fruit" of Seafood Restaurants.

I cannot stress this enough. It will change your life.
author: Isaac N.

description:
GOD I Love this freakin' place! Read to the bottom for a few secrets to maximizing your enjoyment at Swan.

I've been going for almost 20 years now and the quality has not dropped a notch.  The only downside are the lines, which have gotten worse over the years, presumably due to inclusion in travel guides and the like. There are certainly a lot more tourists there than in the old days, and while part of me is annoyed by this, another part is heartened that there are folks coming to SF and eating here rather than at "The Wharf."

Anyway, Swan is everything fresh seafood should be. If you have quality fish, the best thing to do is to do as little as possible, and this they do.

The wild thing is that each and every item, from the fish to the oyster crackers are the best of their kind (possible exception the lemons which are just normal.)

So here is my standard meal, which I vary from it once or twice a year and get a mixed smoked platter:

Cup (not bowl) of white chowder.  This is BY FAR the best chowder I've ever had.  It is relatively thin - not thick and gloppy.  The broth is perfectly savory with great mouthfeel and bitesized pieces of clam.

A few folks have criticized the chowder as being too "thin" or watery.  With all due respect, these people must be used to Cambell's Chunky or something. Clam chowder should not look like library paste.  In fact, it is the relative thinness that makes the chowder here so sublime.  It is principally a fish broth, with a bit of fresh cream and butter, along with the usual clams, potatoes, etc.  Yeah, you could add corn starch and your spoon would stand up, but whats the point.  All rigth thinking people know that this is what chowder should be.  There, I said it.

Oyster crackers tossed into the chowder.  Can oyster crackers be good or bad? Why yes!  These are super fresh, crunchy, and add the touch of salt the chowder needs.

A small Anchor Steam.  Even if you eat early, as I suggest below, get an Anchor.  It is fresh from the keg, and a San Francisco original. Remember, beer is food.

An order of sourdough bread.  You have to order and pay for bread here (butter pats are free) which is as it should be.  Why eat crappy bread for free when you can have really great sourdough (which I don't normally like as its such an overdone cliche.)

A mixed seafood cocktail, sauce on the side.  This is the cocktail, no the salad.  A perfect combo of baby and large shrimp, some dungenesse, and usually a nice oyster or two.

The cocktail sauce gets its own note.  Its just great.  Sometimes I add a squeeze of lime, and I always add some fresh horseradish.  By ordreing on the side I dip the seafood, rather than have it bathe in the sauce.  A point of personal preference, but the way to go, imo.

Speaking of the horseradish, it is super fresh and super hot.  Use sparingly, but use!  They sell it by the bottle if you want, and you shoudl want.  I always have some around at home.

So thats it, Quite simply, some of the best, simple seafood you will ever eat.

Now the tips. I already told you to get a glass of Anchor.  I know it can seem wierd to drink a glass of beer (thus I get the small) at 10:30 am, but it is perfect with the food.  If you want something harder, they sell (under the counter - no liquor license) aged tequila.  So go for a shot if you feel like it.

The big thing, to avoid the crowds and get the best food, is go early.  By 11:15 there is ususally a line out the door.  Go VERY early, and call it breakfast. I usually go around 10AM and can get seated immediately.  Its also a bit less crazy and everything is fresher.
author: hOWARD y.

description:
If you're a oyster lover...this will be your favorite place.  Keep in mind that they're close on Sundays and one week every year during July 4th.

The employees in here are awesome, they are the sweetest and most personable group of fellas.  The place is small and the line is always long...but it's well worth the wait.  The clam chowder is a little on the thin side but it's so flavorful.  The oysters are fresh, great selection and decently priced.  So if you like raw oysters, this is like heaven!
author: GreenThumb L.

description:
This is a nice little hole-in-the-wall style joint that does seafood fresh without the smell!  The oysters were fresh -- would definitely come back again for the freshly-shucked oysters -- but probably not for the other stuff. 

Tried:
Combination Salad - shrimp and some crab and lettuce; while there's nothing wrong with the shrimp,  just go with the crab salad next time - or maybe crab cocktail

Cup of Boston Clam Chowder - nice and flavorful with tasty clams - but it could be a bit thicker for my personal preference  (not quite how they make it in beantown)

Blue Point Oysters - very mild flavor, bigger than the other ones -- refreshingly fresh

Miyagi Oysters - tasty - had a fresh batch that had a gentle sweetness to it - new favorite

Local Baby Miyagi Oysters - these were good too

Half Cracked Crab - have seen better in most homes; priced for profit at $15 for HALF a crab
author: mardou o.

description:
Clam Chowders and Oysters are "A MUST"!! SF MUST COME !


I rarely give a full star to a restaurant. But this one is definitely a must when you come visit SF! The oysters combination include many different types of oysters. Some are sent from Washington State daily. Some are from California. You should order the combination when you come here for the oyster. When you eat it, adding any other thing except lemon is a complete waste! I know, I know, some people just cant tolerate "fishy oyster taste/smell". But, trust me, here, lemon is way more than adequate. The oyster is very very very very FRESH! I had to add cocktail sauce and bunch of lemon before, when i ate oyster. But, NOT HERE!

The octopus/squid salad (this is different than the seafood salad. Dont confuse! )is very refreshing to. Good taste.

The other food we had was the seafood cocktail. it was nice. The crab and the shrimp was just good. "standardly good".

the Clam Chowder is also a must. When it first arrived, I and my friend, we both was quite disappointed. It looked very watery, not creamy. But, after the first sip, I think it was the most unique and tasty clam chowder. I would call it "idealist's clam chowder". you can taste the CLAM and FRESH SEAFOOD  in the chowder! And it is creamy enough. (well, at least for me, who sometime prefer lighter taste). Very very impressive!

We spent low 50 dollars for the 1 bowl clam chowder, 12 oysters (combination), seafood cocktail, squid salad. 
Great experience and very very well worthed.
author: Cindy M.

description: Had lunch here during the weekday so there wasn't a wait. Definitely one of the best places for oysters and if you love uni this is the place to go. The clam chowder was probably one of the best I've had in the city. The people working were super friendly and made you feel comfortable. Would go back for sure!
author: Jb M.

description:
I was visiting my buddy in SF over Labor day weekend and i told him from day one " I don't care what we do, i just want to get some fresh sea food", and he was like " I know just the place". We strolled down to Swan around 4;15 pm (the place closes at 5:30) and we got in line, within 5 minutes one of the servers came out with a piece of paper on it that said "Last One" and gave it top the group behind us, he asked them to tell anyone who tried to get in line that they were the last ones. (GET THERE EARLY) in return he hooked em up with some beers. the attitude of the server was was very much like your one of the family, no big deal, ill bring you out a couple beers asap. So just be prepared Swan is run by a family, and these guys make you feel like one of their family before you walk in the door. 

We finally got in after about an hour fifteen minute wait and sat down at the counter. I don't remember our servers name but a great guy and honesty their all very approachable, have tons of story's and love to shoot the shit. My buddy and I ordered a dozen mixed oysters (Blue points and two kinds of Miyagi), two cups of clam chowder, and a crab cocktail. The oysters were shucked perfectly, no grit or shells bits in the oyster and very very fresh. I loved the clam chowder not too thick with a nice balance of clam meat and potato's ( my buddy said he wished it was thicker so....) , the Crab cocktail was delicious... honestly some of the best crab i have ever had cooked to perfection nice and moist beautiful chunks of crab. Bottom line, everything was fresh and delicious! Next time I go I'm going to get a dozen oysters, a cup of chowder and the crab salad because it will be more filling than the cocktail. 

A couple notes on this place: from what i was told by one of the guys working there, this place is first an foremost a seafood butcher. They are not a restaurant, you will not find white table cloths, napkins, a waiter etc. you will find a long counter with about 20 stools, you will sit elbow to elbow, you will place your order and you will be spoiled. These guys aren't going to sit and fill your glass unless they see it, they have pickup orders to fill you need more drink ask for it don't expect someone to refill you cup every second its half full. Basically what I'm saying is if your looking for a 5 star restaurant, keep looking. But if your looking for ridiculously fresh seafood, amazingly friendly people who love their jobs and will make you feel at home..... this is THE place to go. 

If you see the smoked salmon out don't be afraid to ask to try a piece... it has this deep delicious smokey flavor with zero hint of fish... amazing!
author: Reza F.

description: If you like shellfish, smoked salmon, Anchor Steam beer and great friendly service this is the place!  The only thing missing is an ocean view!  Love it!
author: Brian L.

description: Probably the best oysters I've had - I think I prefer this place above Hog Island Oyster in the Ferry Building.  You are charged per oyster, versus the 6 minimum you have to get at Hog Oyster - it's also a little cheaper and you have a great hole in the wall atmosphere with a lot of great characters serving you.  We got there at 2 on Saturday - there was a line of 8 or so....got the clam chowder (it was a little watery), combo seafood salad, and a sampling of all the oysters (there isn't an official oyster sampler - they just put together whatever you want.  The oysters were all fabulous - the kumamotos were a little small...but all the oysters were wonderfully fresh, as well as the clams we got.  We got a smoked salmon to go...it was nice but I agree with the other - you could skip it for the price.
author: Paul K.

description: This place is special. No frills, just good food served in a fun environment. The guys behind the counter are all super nice and helpful. You can't beat an Anchor, some sourdough with butter and some of their oysters (or whatever else you choose).
author: Matt D.

description: Ah yes, I can finally write a review about this place...and I agree that my expectations were actually higher than I am rating this place right now.  This place gets packed but luckily my friend and I only waited 15 minutes for a seat.  The seafood is NO DOUBT the freshest but this rating loses my 2 extra stars I would've given it if the clam chowder met my expectations.  Sadly it did not.  So sad to say but Boudin and Sizzler clam chowder still win my heart.  This chowder was thin and oily looking....I even found a caper in it, I've never had capers in mine but the 1 caper didn't make a difference but still...1 caper, that was just weird!  A friend and I shared a dozen oysters--6 miyagis and 6 blue points.  I was indeed disappointed by the size of the miyagis because my friend was saying that they were suppose to be a lot bigger than what was shucked onto the ice.  Eh...the oysters were deeeelicious and super fresh so size at that point did not even matter.  This place is pretty pricey for a hole in the wall looking joint.  The salads on the menu were like $17 and up!  Yikes...!  My 3 stars will not stop me from going back every once in a blue moon so I will keep this place on my list.  Ah yes and don't forget....CASH ONLY! enjoy =)
author: Mary-Anne C.

description:
So funny how my buddy who is a true native to SF, has never gone into this place.  Somehow I was lucky enough to talk him into it today.  We were both virgins.... and Michael our server was amazing. He was super friendly... smiling the entire time, giving us his advice which was incredible...  Emily, a local regular who was in line with us also gave us tips on what to order.  Yes there is a line because they to do not take reservations, but if you enjoy fresh fish, it is so worth the wait.  And it's not your typical sit-down-table type of restaurant.... which is what makes it so different and appealing at the same time.  It has one long bar that probably seats 12 or more people... not sure exactly how many, but it is small... thus the long wait out the door.  Swan Oyster Depot is only open for lunch and is very casual... not fancy at all.  Perfect... because I was wearing my baseball hat, yoga-Marina-gear... and was so craving Crabs since they are now in season.
We had the clam chowder... which is totally different from what one would expect... still very good.  Sashimi... scallops, salmon, halibut, and ahi tuna... that literally melted in your mouth. Crab Louie (not sure if I'm spelling that right) and the dozen oysters were also delicious. 
I have to say the food was great, but the service is phenomenal... Michael catered to us like our own personal seafood chef.  Excellent customer service and of course the delicious fresh seafood entices me to definitely come back again and again.
author: Myra M.

description: First rate fo' sho'!  My brother and I knew that Yelp was right (again) when we showed up at 3PM for lunch and there was a line out the door.  But the 40 minute wait was well worth it (not to mention the friendly staff serves beer/wine once you get close to the front).  Their clam chowder was like no other I've ever had, but absolutely amazing; which set the stage for the incredible oysters which followed.  Matter of fact, everything we had was entirely worthy of the full 5-star's.  And this review would be incomplete without a tip of the cap to the family owners/operators; they make you feel like a welcome guest in their home.  But be prepared to spend some cash (no cards), the hardest part for me was not ordering everything on the menu.
author: Josh H.

description: Visiting from East coast, this place was a must-see. We waited in line at 12:30 for nearly 2 hours. We also ate in, which was when we realized we could have ordered ahead for carry out. Having stood in line for nearly 2 hrs tho we wanted to sit and eat there. It's tightly packed in there too, shoulder to shoulder seating. We ordered half dozen west coast oysters, half cracked crab, and smoked salmon. Love raw oysters, but I gotta say East coast oysters are better. These oysters were extremely salty, or very grassy tasting. Great to pair with a summer beer or Sauvignon blanc. The crab was ok, but for the price I'd expect more. The smoked salmon was the best I have ever had (I was practically raised on it). Smelled and tasted like smokey woodchips. Delicious! $20 for four slices on extremely thin toast though? Especially since they don't smoke it themselves? Way overpriced. I do wish I could have their supplier ship it to DC where we live though.
author: Laura N.

description:
if you don't like raw seafood, you have no business reading on or going here. 

i wish i could afford to eat here everyday.  it is fresh and delicious and the perfectly attentive staff makes everything so effortless.  and did i say they take care of you??  they take care of you.  i hadn't been in a while but they still seemed to recognize me the last time.

very fresh clams and oysters. and they always tell you what's good and fresh to help you decide what to get.  (and if you're feeling particularly indecisive or adventurous you can ask for flights of any of the shellfish).  shrimp cocktail and lobster salad are also good.  all the horseradish and tabasco you need right at the table.  great chowder.  great bread.  good wines, even.  but sometimes steam beer is all you need.  if you come for lunch, don't plan on going back to work or anything afterwards because a meal this good deserves to be savored with follow up beers or a bottle of wine.  raw seafood is magical feel good food.

note: no AMEX, well to be more accurate, no credit cards period.  So hit the ATM and careful not to get pickpocketed.

oh yeah, p.s. some paranoid folks have gotten really crabby about the way they calculate your bill right in front of you.  sometimes they have to ask what you had, since everything is done right there at the counter. so be honest, tell 'em what you had. and when you get the bill, don't be all paranoid thinking you got ripped off.  for some reason seafood is very expensive, and it shouldn't be, especially in the bay area by the ocean of all places, but it is and we have to live with it.  so relax and just try to enjoy your meal.
author: Nikki F.

description: Why would you go to a place like this for sea food? You wait in line, you sit (uncomfortably) at a counter, & you pay quite a bit for a meal that's good but not great. On top of that, you have the feeling that people are breathing down your neck waiting for you to finish & get out. I love sea food, but there are too many other excellent (& non-touristy) restaurants in this town to bother with this one. I live here & I say: Over-rated.
author: Helen P.

description:
So good! Seafood is incredibly fresh tasting. The atmosphere is fun. 

The chowder is fantastic, they don't congeal it with thickener. It was a very fresh, homemade tasting chowder.

The service was excellent - considering how busy they were.
author: sunshine c.

description:
Oh, my God. Oh, my God. Oh, my God. When I die, I want to stop here first.

After weekday Mass at Grace Cathedral, I asked the canon, "Where would local people go for lunch around the hill?" She immediately told me about Swan Oyster Depot.

I didn't mind a little line, as the place was indeed from a by-gone era and you could see the fresh fish in the front window. The place was started in the 20s by a Dane and then puchased in the 40s by an Italian, whose grandson helped me figure out what to order. Not sure? "Why don't I fix you a little tasting plate of..." So I got two different oysters, a plate of smoked trout and two kinds of smoked salmon and half a crab. (You could tell the regulars love the clam chowder--it's just not my thing.)

While he fixed my plates (as his brothers and cousins and father and uncles worked with him), I was offered a generous hunk of peasant bread, sliced, to enjoy with butter. Most of the lunch crowd enjoyed a glass of wine or a beer. 

My West coast oysters were better than any I've ever tasted. Of my trout and salmon, I liked best the "hot-smoked" salmon but all was good. The crab was perfect--succulent and tasting like crab should when it's fresh.

I ate every bite and my only regret is that I couldn't go again. Indeed, my next trip to SF will be planned to allow for as many lunches at Swan as possible.

Other diners got the crab or combination salad. Yes, it's on iceberg, which is part of the charm--none of that mod cuisine with 10 kinds of baby lettuces that taste like dirt--and you have to ask for the house dressing--a sublime concoction of olive oil, lemon juice, red wine vinegar, Dijon, horseradish and salt and pepper. I asked the young lady next to me for a taste on a piece of bread and I wish I had ordered some for my crab--gilding the lily, not out of necessity. They also had a Louis dressing that looked good if you like a heavier accompaniment.

I'm pretty picky and there's not a thing I'd change about this place! It's not cheap but it's sure reasonable, especially because after lunch here, you won't need supper.
author: John Divine M.

description:
What makes this place awesome is the family running the business.  Don't get me wrong, there's no better combo than seafood and beer but what's going to keep me coming back are the funny lads behind the counter. 

I had the combination cocktail which consisted of crab meat, shrimp, clams and an oyster.  Delicious!  It's rather small, so be prepared if you order on an empty stomach, you may be disappointed.  My girlfriend ordered the smoked salmon sandwich.  Personally, I was expecting to cheat on my girlfriend sinking my teeth into this SF Weekly 2008 award winning sandwich - quite the contrary.   And for $18 bucks for the "award winning" sandwich, I was expecting to at least get a boner.

Anyway, I ended up dropping $40 for a cocktail, smoked salmon sandwich and an Anchor Steam.  I would come back to try something else on the board, but mostly to be served by some stand up guys.
author: Nefer L.

description:
Swan has to be my all time favorites. 
1) fresh seafood
2) great service 
3) great atmosphere
4) get in line . It's worth it
author: Jane f.

description: I am not an oyster fan, so really this is shame on me. I ordered the seafood combination salad and holy crap does that say $17.50, yes it does! What is with the SF people, do people really pay that much for food. I personally would rather go to a place where I can hear my friend talk and enjoy a seafood salad for around $13 and not worry about the people standing in line wishing I would get up already.
author: Sophia D.

description: After a brief wait in line, we sat down at the far end, adjacent to the seafood case. We were immediately asked what we would like to drink (Anchor and Stella are on tap) and served delicious crusty ,chewy bread and butter. I don't eat shellfish so I ordered the smoked salmon plate and asked if I could have some smoked trout as well. I have had quite a bit of smoked fish in my life and this was the best ever. My partner in life had magnificent clam chowder and crab salad and said it was definitely worth going back for.
author: Bleep S.

description: Oysters! Me like them lots. The line was long and bearable but I could do without it. However, I would be willing to wait again for a taste of fresh oysters and sashimi. The sashimi plate was drizzled with capers (!!!) and olive oil. A combination that I've never had but instantly adored. I double love the scallop sashimi. It was sweet and melted like butter in your mouth with a wonderful texture. The service was great also, chatty and very friendly.
author: Faye P.

description: Oysters on the half shell. Mmm. Mouth watering. This place is definitely worth the wait during lunch rush hour. We've been here several times and we usually go with 2 dozen assorted oysters, a Combo salad, a few Stella's and 2 cups of clam chowder ( Tip: get 2 cups, rather than a bowl. A bowl is simply too hard to share. when it was my turn to eat clam chowder, I didn't want to give the bowl back.) Will be coming back for many more meals.
author: Anne T.

description: This place definitely lived up to my expectations. After reading other reviews we got there early on a Friday (around 10:30am) and were lucky enough to snag two open spots along the bar. The place was small but full of charm and you could tell from the employee/patron interaction that many of those dining in were regulars. Upon sitting down I ordered us waters and the shrimp cocktail since that is my boyfriend's favorite. We watched them prepare it in front of us and a few minutes later were enjoying the freshest shrimp I have ever had. After the shrimp I informed the guy helping us that we were first timers so would need a little direction. He told me to try a cup of the chowder, a 1/2 dozen of mixed oysters, a full helping of smoked salmon and if we were still hungry to get either the crab cocktail or calamari salad. Feeling adventurous we took his advice and were not disappointed. I am not a huge oyster person but whatever variations he gave us were wonderful. The texture was just right and they did not have the usual "fishy" taste that you can get with shellfish.  The salmon had the best flavor and they gave us a very hearty portion - it will be hard to order in back home now! As good as everything was my absolute favorite was the crab cocktail. It came with a creamy Louie sauce and was so tender. I was already stuffed beyond belief from the rest of the meal but could not seem to stop myself from polishing the bowl off. The only thing I will not order next time is the chowder (good but not great) but everything else was a slam dunk. Be prepared to drop some serious cash in here though!
author: Micah C.

description:
This place was very good. A local favorite for a reason, but it didn't blow my socks off and I have no real desire to return. 
People LOVE this place, and as a lover of raw fresh seafood I thought I was going to hit the jackpot here after hearing so much about it. My husband and I waited an hour plus to get in, which wasn't the issue- we expected the wait. We eagerly waited in line with returning patrons espousing praise of SOD. We ordered 1 bowl of NE clam chowder, 2 crab Louie salads, 1 dozen raw oyster variety, and each had a beer for a tip & tax total of $100 (only accepts cash). The staff is friendly & attentive, but I sat on a wobbly uncomfortable stool a foot taller than my neighbors making it awkward- plus I couldn't put my legs under the bar because of the height (sitting on the floor would have nicer and probably cleaner than the dirty bar countertop). Anyway, about the reason of our visit- the food. The chowder was very good- any higher praise neglects noticing the scant amount of clams and heavy hand of salt of this rendition of New England chowder. I did not mind the watery milk base (like canned Snow's Chowder) because it still had a pleasant clam taste. But let's face it people- this chowder is NOT winning any awards. The oysters were properly shucked and served, and were fresh and satisfying- the better part of our meal but still not extraordinary. The crab on the crab Louie was fresh and portions generous. But the shredded iceberg was a total bore- just order the crab cocktail for half the price with a side of Louie sauce for dipping. All in all not a total waste, but not memorable. Given the cost and cleanliness issue, you are all welcome to take my place in line.
author: Eva D.

description: It's kind of silly to write a review for a place that's this over-reviewed (word?), but I do love my Swan's when I'm in SF. Don't get there after 11 am unless you plan on a long wait. My kids love the clam chowder and the oysters. I don't eat either one, but my boys are pretty picky and they love 'em. I love the smoked salmon and the crab. It's really not that expensive for great seafood in San Francisco, and I've always loved the guys who work there.
author: Wendy T.

description: Had a funny feeling of being a tourist in my home town!  Good food, ok service, but do you really feel like standing in line just to have some overpriced seafood in a "grab-and-go" hole in the wall?  To be completely honest, their oyster sampler was great!
author: Lana L.

description:
In November I'm going to the Bay Area for work.  I will be on the east side of the Bay during the week but spending one precious day in SF.  I will be in the lunch line here that day, because this place is the real deal.  Only one day in SF, and here is where I choose to be.

I will ride the cable car there.  I will stand in the line and enjoy thinking about buying See's Candies afterwards (assuming there is still a store right there).  I will get a seat relatively quickly because I am alone and will fit in any empty seat at the counter.

I will order oysters and those dear folks behind the counter will tell me which is which.  I will get an Anchor Steam.  And Crab Salad or maybe Crab Louis.  All the dull and drab cares of my daily life will drop away while I enjoy eating at the Depot.  

The last time I was there I had a Hollywood producer on one side who was looking at locations and a nice young couple from Corsica on the other.  We ate a lot, laughed a lot and the dear fellow behind the counter gave us spoonfuls of free caviar.  Yep, you heard me, caviar.  The Corsicans bought some (the dollar was especially weak at the moment).
author: Charlotte K.

description:
Best oysters in town - hands down.  It's a San Francisco institution and there's always a line, so come early.  It's a must for me to come here for my birthday, my partner's birthday or any other celebration.  The only downsides are the wait, wines (generic non memorable wines) and the tiny place - probably seats 15(?) along the bar.  I even ordered for my NYE parties for a few occasions and they pack the shucked oysters so well!  Great friendly stuff - all in the family....

5 stars for the oysters, 4 stars for everything else.
author: E W.

description: Went here on a Saturday morning before 11am and found several open seats. As others have noted, right after 11am, a line started forming, so get here early! Had the clam chowda which was very good and the combo salad which came with shrimp, prawns, and crab w/Louie sauce. My friend had the half crab. All very delicious. $ seemed on par with other similar places. Chickened out on the raw oysters but will try it next time. We BARTed in so it was a bit of a walk, but hey, it was good exercise to burn off the calories.
author: Michael C.

description: Fresh food..fun service. The stools are small and wobbly if you have a big seat. The Seafood combo salad was good nd the chowder is okay but watery. I think is the owners and staff are what make the place so special
author: Kimmy C.

description: This place was an experience, for sure.  I recommend the oysters on a half shell.  I had better clam chowder at scomas.  But the oysters were sure fresh and delicious, and cheap!!!
author: Candace O.

description:
if you like seafood and oysters on a half shell... this place is a must.
oh by the way the best freaking clam chowder i have ever had....  

six stars...  you are an idiot if you are a seafood lover and dont go here... an IDIOT for not going!

enjoy
author: Kwang C.

description: My favorite restaurant.  I live n Seattle and we have some great seafood, but I truly miss this place.  I cave lunch there more than sex.  If they have fresh sardines there, get 'em, raw.  Don't knock it until you try.
author: John E.

description: the orsters were great and the scallops, the bar is uncomfortable to sit at, skip the salad
author: pochini m.

description: A teeny place with AMAZINGLY fresh seafood. Literally it is one gigantic counter and you have to find yourself a stool. But you will not be disappointed with the food of this hole in the wall. Oysters are to die for, clam chowder is delicious! Come here for a casual good time and be prepared to walk out overly full.
author: Ella V.

description: It's really good, really tiny, really long line, but I don't think you could get any fresher seafood unless you're  swimming with your mouth open in the ocean.
author: Tina D.

description:
bypassed the lunch queues as we arrived shortly before 11am.
