the oysters were delicious and fresh, and great with their homemade mignonette. we got their sashimi plate (salmon, ahi tuna, scallops, and sardines) italian style, which had olive oil, capers, and diced onions -- great twist to sashimi. we also had the crab cocktail with louie sauce, and a cup of their clam chowder. out of all the above mentioned, i loved the crab the most. the meat was so sweet, and they did not skimp on the portions. 

the servers are great, and work hard to shuck, slice, and crack all the seafood.
author: Sheri N.

description: Just stumbled on this kick oyster house last Saturday morning The Oyster were crazy fresh n super good! My girlfriend had the shrimps, some prawn, some bay. Both were super fresh however the bay shimp were a little over cooked and mushy. Clam Chowder was  pretty good too. The best part was the employees! All family that made you feel like you had just joind them at thier home! I cant wait to go again, real good food, real great people.
author: Scott A.

description: Love this place! We look forward to coming here on our yearly San Francisco trip. Always the freshest oysters and the best service in this old timey raw bar. We missed their live sea urchin this time but tried the smoked salmon instead -- incredible! Will return again next next year for more!
author: Ange B.

description:
What can you say- it's a SF  classic up there with the Tadich and Sam's, but much more low key, family run, eat at the bar  lunch only kind of place. They also sell fresh fish to take home.Seasonal sand dabs, seafood, tuna , smoked salmon etc.
If the ingredients did not cut it there is very little any raw bar can do to redeem themselves. Happily, that is  not an issue here.
I had mixed a mixed dozen oysters and the clam chowder both were outstanding. Extremely fresh, flavorful blue points, kumos, and others-
you could eat these all day. The chowder was rich and full of clams 
with the taste of the sea suggested but not overpowering. Bread costs extra. 
They serve a wonderful Italian style sashimi  rawfish 
(tuna, salmon, halibut and scallop) plate with olive oil, onions and capers which I will go back for. They also do a Asian version with ginger and soy. It may be the only dish like this in town.
They also do a mean smoked salmon carpaccio.
It's a rawbar layout , so you are never far from your server. They take care in all their preparations and seem to take pride in the place , the regulars and the vibe in general. It's tight, friendly atmosphere. 
The service is good, I can imagine you might catch someone in a bad
mood at times. If you are in a hurry , I'd skip it.
The down side might be the prices. 1/2 a dungie crab for $ 18-
the seafood salads range from $ 12- 18, not exorbitant but not your 
$ 5 -10 lunch either. Unless a bowl of soup will hold you.
but this place is an original, and worth it.
Every local seafood lover has to try this place at least once, I know I'll go back.
author: Aaron Z.

description:
OMG..Beware the hype.
I used to live in SF and loved to go to Swans.
We arrived in town and wanted to take my daughter to Swans because she loves oysters. We got on the long line and waited 1.5 hours.
We finally got 3 seats at the 16 seat bar. We continued to wait and wait watching regulars getting To go food and getting helped immediately.
We waited and waited maybe 15 minutes with finished plates of food and drinks in front of us. OK they are small and busy but please. We finally ordered 3 bowls of there famous chowder and 2 dozen oysters. The chowder arrived and the cream was totally broken and so gross without any clams to be found. I was so hungry by then I ate the funky soup concerned it might take another 15 minutes to get something else.
BTW the oysters were fresh and good but nothing special.
Well the sourdough bread and butter was the best thing we ate.
The 3 bowls of chowder and 2 dozen oysters without drinks were $79.
Total rip off.
Anthony Bourdaine sure can ruin a good thing!
author: alan l.

description:
Well, I read the last review on this awesome place and felt quite compelled to say a couple words about it. Some people just don't know how to be normal. Matt, can you really expect the clam chowder to be  at it's best  when they are about to close?  Seriously, i have been there and it was one of the most exciting experiences when it comes to seafood. And it wasn't that I was lucky that day, because I went with someone who has been going there every week for years, and he can't stop talking wonders about it. The place was completely packed, people waiting at the door and still, we were served with the best smiles and the best attention we could get!
I gave only 5 stars because i couldn't find the 100 star button.  ;-)
Matt, next time, go at a normal time, and you will change your mind.
author: Sophia B.

description:
I was curious about this place because it always had a big old line flowing out the door.  The first time I tried to go, I didn't feel like waiting so ended up at the unremarkable sushi place next door.  The second time my friend and I were first in line since we came at 11:30am on a Monday, but we still had to wait about 20 or 30 minutes for a place at the bar.  

I liked the atmosphere inside- no frills but classic depot.  The clam chowder was 5 stars, and the seafood cocktail was 2.5 stars.  I would surely like to come again some time and try the oysters, since it is 2 blocks from where I live.  Recommended for a casual seafood chomp, but be prepared to WAIT.
author: Lisa X.

description: good oyster and smoke salmon  out standing uni but dam 1.5 hour wait it pretty small in side. Hog island is better  fresher oysters and less wait would come here again but next time not during  lunch rush hour
author: sushiatown s.

description: Line out the door, but only waited about 20 minutes to be seated at the bar....this place is tiny, but well worth the wait. The waitstaff is friendly, good beers on tap, and you cannot beat the quality of oysters. I only split a dozen on the half shell with a friend and they were to die for. Only reason for 4 stars was due to the fact that they shuck them in front of you, the shells arent cleaned to the extent that you would find at a high scale restaurant, definitely had bits of shell in my mouth...I just chalked it up as part of the experience. Want to come back and try the various fish dips and ceviches they had.
author: Dana V.

description: Surprisingly inexpensive seafood, prepared simple and fresh, served to you by a bunch of salty dogs - sounds good to me.  I hate waiting in lines for food but this one was worth it.
author: Victoria G.

description: This place is rad. Get the Oysters on the half shell, a beer, and enjoy the scenery. The guys that work here are super cool and funny, and really take you back to how the place might have been 50 year's ago. I've had better clam chowder, but it's still worth ordering.
author: Noel A.

description:
good fresh seafood, authentic san francisco guys, yet see below, and stripped down preparation which allows the seafood to be really enjoyed without masking it with fancy sauces, etc. I enjoyed everything I ate which was oysters, crab salad, crab shell, and one other item i can't recall. I ate well, and enjoyed it very much. The service is not good for the price of the food, it is cramped, and there is a line usually, and only go there if you don't take being ignored or told in response to my loud "I want to pay my bill and leave" after quietly and politely asking three times, "I'm busy, someone will be with you when they aren't busy"

The guys that work here are authentic, but kind of jerks from the perspective of an urban professional. The guys are not particularly clean hand washing and handling different people's food and dirty dishes, etc.  While I give it four stars for fresh seafood without pretentious preparation, I really don't think I would go back here in light of the cleanliness issue and attitude of the guys who work here. Just not the type of people i want to support with my business, and physically uncomfortable to eat there.
author: Andrew Z.

description: I live right by here and there is always a line down the block. It's a really cool place to try out. It's just an old fashioned lunch counter and you take what seat is available. The seafood is top notch and the service is really good. The guys are friendly and helpful and it's a really worthwhile experience.
author: jen w.

description:
Mmm.. this place is exactly what you think of when you think: men, baseball, clutter, fun, simple and old town San Francisco... this is where it's at. There is a line becasue they do not take reservations. There is a line out the door because the same folks have owned it for so many years and the spot is long and very narrow. Jackets on the wall, purses on your lap ladies.. folks need room to get by you to get to the bathroom, Way in the back. It's a bar style seating so the guys are all in front of you the whole time, easy to get around and quick. People know to kind of eat fast, the service is fast, these guys have the routine down because they have such a following.. So the crab goes first, if you are there after 1 then don't count on getting yourself any crab or the combo plater: tiger prawns, shrimp and crab.. But the prawns and shrimp louie is good too! The clam chowder is where you start, nice little cup with a glass of white wine: $7, all the glasses are $7.. (it's easy.. simple men, it works). Then you go to the oysters, if you feel good about it and don't kow much about oysters, let the guys pick them for you or just get the... yes, the combo plate..because it's easy.
Finish with a louie.. some sort of louie. They do the louie salad dressing and they also let you have the vinegar dressing instead if you'd rather. Their vinegar is so yummy and tangy, they make it there.. and there are post its all over the jugs reading "don't touch", simple.. to the point. I love this place. No confusion, you come here and wait a bit and you leave happy.
author: Jess P.

description: The best in the city. Gotta get there early or you will have to wait. Great Staff and great fresh food.
author: John R.

description: We had a great experience at Swan's.  We waited for about half hour, the people in line were nice and friendly.  The three of us were ended up at the far end of the counter, kinda squeezed in.  My daughter does not like seafood, so they made her a lettice salad, and did not charge for that.  I had the crab salad, so amazingly good.  OK here is the big question, is that chowder supposed to be good?  I did not like it at all.  It was thin, and not flavorful, almost yucky.  I will go back for that salad!
author: San Jose Girl M.

description:
seafood: 5+ stars
salads and chowders: 3 stars

i'm torn about this place. there's one counter for seating space, and it's cash only. my entire meal of bread, a cup of soup and half a dozen raw oysters came to $14.10.

the new england clam chowder i had was very good, but nothing to i could describe as jump up and down fantastic. it had a great seafood-brothy taste that soothed my poor sick self, congested chest, sore throat and all. and for $0.75, i pretty much got half a round loaf of fresh, dense whole wheat sourdough bread, where the crunchy crust and chewy bread soaked up the chowder nicely. i really appreciate a fine chowder that isn't overwhelmed by cream and potatoes, and has a lot more taste of the sea's bounty.

i've had their salads before, but a bed of chopped iceberg lettuce and about 1/4-1/2 lbs of seafood laid atop it with either a vinaigrette or louie dressing on the side isn't worth the $14-$20 something dollars per salad. call me a salad snob, but it should have at least a few other vegetables to enhance the flavor of the fresh seafood.

now on to the oysters. i had half a dozen mixed oysters as they were out of the blue points this afternoon. 2 miyagis, 2 locals from tomales bay and two kumamotos. MAN, they were fresh. i squeezed a few drops of lemon juice, a drop of tabasco and sucked each one down. the local oysters from tomales bay had the best and meatiest texture, with the most incredible buttery taste to them. mind you, the miyagis and kumamotos were fine too, but DAMN, those locals put me into a tailspin, coughing and wheezing and contemplating treating myself to another half dozen.

i am deathly sick after all. i could kick the bucket tomorrow, so it would be all right to just keep eating these wonderful tomales bay oysters, right?
author: May T.

description: Best place for seafood in San Francisco.  I will always stop here when I'm in town.  It gets crowded with a line down the street and they don't take reservations.  Either plan on waiting a bit for a seat or arrive early.
author: Brian H.

description: All I wanted was yummy fresh crab for my birthday dinner this year. I searched yelp like crazy trying to find affordable seafood in SF. I noticed that everyone on yelp had  good review for Swan Oyster Depot. They were right. What a great yummy place with a small fun atmosphere. Amazing crab, shrimp and much more. The wait can be a good one but thankfully you can have a beer or two to kill some time. I can't wait to go back.  What a fun place
author: Jen J.

description:
=) HEH, okay im not a big seafood eater at all.. this dig though has some really good clam chowder!! im saying this even after waiting in line for over a hour and a half hahaha so i say just seriously be patient and wait in line and you will be handsomely rewarded... =)
good food and good atmosphere!
author: Michelle W.

description: The oysters are fresh and expensive. The line is a 45 mins wait. I love oysters/seafood but its not worth the wait. Maybe fun for tourist but I live in the city and rather go somewhere else. There are plenty of great places which are cheaper, bigger, less wait, and cleaner.
author: Sylvia V.

description: I am another one of those Anthony Bourdain Layover watchers--so I had to go check this place out and see what all the hype was about.  Read ALL the reviews and they all said to get there early b/c there will be a wait. Went on a Saturday morning arrived at 11am they open at 10am and there was already a line down the sidewalk.  Got seated at around 2pm!! I didn't give up--and neither did anyone else in the line--everyone patiently waited.  Once you get closer to the door they start taking your drink orders--which I think is a fantastic idea!  Makes you feel like you are almost there, and you are invested at this point, no turning back.  The place itself only holds about 20 seats.  Once we were seated we were greeted and welcomed in by a couple members of the staff.  We decided to start out with a cup of clam chowder-- it was a bit cold outside so this was a pefect starter to warm up-- It was good!  It wasn't heavy and not greasy or oily at all (like some homemade clam chowders can be), and it had a good amount of clams in it.  Next I decided to order the Seafood Salad.  This was the best Seafood Salad I have ever had.  Huge amounts of Seafood on this salad--I shared with my friend.  She ordered the Crab Coctail which was wonderful too!  We then decided that we were at Swan Oyster Depot --we needed to get some oysters!  So we got 1/2 dozen oysters which were great--nothing was bad at this place other than the wait--and even that wasn't bad because everyone in line were fun, had some good conversations and it made the time fly by.  When you are inside you might feel a bit rushed-b/c you know people are standing outside waiting for you to hurry up so they can have their turn--but the guys working there were very nice and patient--didn't try to rush you--and in fact told us to relax, take all the time you want, and enjoy yourself--   I am really glad I tried this place the seafood is super fresh and good, and doesn't smell like a fish market in there!   If you are in town check this place out!  They only accept cash so bring a lot of it--b/c you will be hungry from waiting in line!
author: T J.

description: I hate this place.  I liken it to eating at the worst Dennys on the planet.  The food is horrible, tasteless and overpriced.  Waiting in line for the poor quality ended up just pissing me off.  Leave this place to the tourists because the establishment will never change and try to serve food of good quality.  One star is too generous.
author: Richard R.

description:
Found this place through yelp. Went there around 3 or 4 pm on a wednesday with my gf. We had to wait maybe 15-20 min for a seat, but were served a beer while we waited. Ordered the clam chowder, combo cocktail, and bread. All were pretty good, but we were still a little hungry, so we ordered the smoked salmon. It usually comes with a salad, but our waiter offered to replace it with more salmon since we had already eaten some appetizers. The salmon came on top of more bread and was great!

Overall, great food and great service.
author: Joe B.

description: not worth it for the long wait and $$$.  i can find better quality seafood at a cheaper price else where.  The shrimp cocktail and oysters i got one time were  so tiny, and the texture of them were as good as the ones u can get out of cans.
author: Tadaa T.

description:
I'm in love. I finally decided to try out Swan's based on much prodding by a friend, M, she may be their biggest fan. We decided to go for a late lunch/early dinner so we got there about a quarter to 5pm on a Saturday. Ten minutes after we got in line, they handed the "end of line" sign to the guy behind us. But we made it and that's all that mattered --- I was really hungry.

Per M's suggestion, we went for a bowl of chowder and the seafood combination plate. There are 2 combo plates and we got the salad-variety. The chowder almost made me swoon on my bar-stool; I haven't had chowder that good since like a stupid amount of time. It was beautiful; the soup was delicate but so flavorful, I really wish I'd gotten some to go. Soon the combo salad arrived. It was generous amounts of crab, bay shrimp and large prawns spread throughout a bed of chopped lettuce, topped with sauce Louie. I didn't think I'd ever finish that salad. It was bigger than I'd realized. And the guys working behind the scenes are real gems. They were good-natured and gave us good customer service. A friendly, seemingly loyal crowd seated at the counter packed the place. Be ready to stand in line if you are eating on the premises (there's not a lot of seating) or just step up to the counter, just inside the door, in to order to order take-out.

So I'm a fan of Swan Oyster Depot, excited to head back and try something new.
author: Jen A.

description: THE OYSTERS ARE THE BEST! My boyfriend and I came yesterday and ordered 2 dozen of oysters, clam chowder, prawn cocktail, and cherry stone clams. The first dozen was an assortment of different oysters, the ones that stood out were the blue point ones (both of them), the ones I liked most were the blue points from washington, so fresh and sweet! My boyfriend liked it too so we ordered another dozen. Besides the oysters, the other things were okay. The clam chowder was good, but not the best, the prawns were just a teeny bit overcooked. I did not like the Cherry Stone Clams at ALL. But the oysters were so good, it made up for the other not so good items. Can't wait till I come back!! I will try their sashimi and salads next time =) and of course.. OYSTERS!!!
author: A L.

description: Went on a Saturday, arrived at 11 am, was seated at 12:30 pm. Staff was very friendly and helpful. Chowder was out of this world good. Tried sea urchin for the first time. Fun but I'll choose something else next time. The prawns and crab were über fresh. Totally worth the wait.
author: Jeff A.

description: LOVE LOVE LOVE this place! Old school family run dive seafood joint. The line is so worth it especially if you have a beer while you're waiting and with people you actually like talking to! We had oysters perfect. The best smoked salmon I've had ever on perfectly sliced sour dough and onions and capers. Sicilian (totally not bias or anything ;)) style sashimi plate...seriously, amazing. I wasn't sure how i'd like all the raw fish, but I like it here!!!! We also had the crab cocktail...it's dungeness crab in sf, need i say more? Checking out is the honor system which is cool. When you want to pay they just ask you what you had and then they ring you up. It's nice to see that some places still believe in the good in people. All in all, go. If you don't want to wait, go there by the time they open 10 or 10:30. I will be back often!
author: Erin T.

description:
OK....I really, really want to give Swan Oyster Depot 5 stars BUT gotta deduct one star for their watery clam chowder...BUT EVERYTHING ELSE is STELLAR...well everything but standing in line in the cold for a seat...but damn it was well wort it.  
Hubby and I got to the Swan at about 12:30 on a Saturday afternoon and we waited about 40 minutes for a seat (on a chilly day).  Once there, the service was prompt.  We ordered a combination seafood cocktail ( I agree that the cocktail sauce may be a bit on the sweet side); clam chowder (too watery...didn't care for it much); and a dozen miyagi oysters...YUM!!!  I prepped my oysters with their homemade horseradish which was perfect and two ice cold Stella's.  Hubby has a crush on their sourdough bread...slightly burnt/dark on the outside and nice and chewy on the inside!!  
I agree that the service at Swan is very attentive and friendly and makes the experience much more delightful....
author: Karen B.

description: I finally made it through the line and into seafood island. I ordered the seafood combo lots of meaty crab and shrimp and prawns, real fresh and dressing was good too. I also got a cup of chowder, real good! It's good seafood but pricey! I would think since it's Crab season right now (crabs are $2.99 a lb) price would go down, why are they still selling it for $30 a crab!! Don't get it.
author: Karen T.

description: The staff run and hide when they see the Kumamoto Kid kickin' down the door lookin' for his Oyster order. One of the best places to get Oysters, especially my Kumamotos. Best to shuck at home for instant flava!! Swan's clam chowder is also legendary. Friendly old-school staff running the line to deliver top-stuff counter service. Fab to go in and order some Blue Points and a beer! No better place to get your aphrodisiac on!
author: Johnny C.

description: Let the tourists have at it... I can't sit idly by on one of the most overrated restaurants in SF. Nothing special foodwise at all. Staffed by mouth-breathers. For fine, fresh oysters, go to Zuni or Hog Island. I hadn't visited in over 6 years until today. Boring.
author: Brandon R.

description: I've been wanting to go to this place for the last 4-5 years and I have to say, it totally exceeded my expectations. Awesome, awesome, awesome seafood - so fresh and so tasty! I had the kumamoto oysers, crab louis salad and clam chowder, and all I can say is, "yummmmmm." But what was most surprising, was the incredibly warm and friendly staff. They definitely completed the entire dining experience.
author: Donna A.

description: Mmmh... crab louie salad hits the spot. You can always walk up to the front and order takeout and cab it home to eat if all you care about is the food. which is all I care about.
author: Teresa Y.

description: Everything was incredibly fresh, flavorful, and just seriously fantastic. I just moved around the corner, and even though it's a good deal I will probably go broke from the amount of time I plan on spending there. The guys behind the counter are helpful, friendly, and knowledgable, adding to the enjoyabe experience. It's worth the line outside.
author: m t.

description:
I love this place and have been going there for many, many years.  Great chowder, amazing clams, very good oysters. 

Today, the food was great but the customer service left lots to be desired.  Quite simply, don't ask how everything is if you don't want an answer.  And if you're going to ask, then you have to do something to rectify an unhappy guest.  Don't shrug and tell me to order it on the side NEXT time.  It just doesn't work that way.   There might not BE a next time.   Don't act bothered and blow me off, and don't ignore me, which was how the first two guys handled me.  The third guy couldn't have been nicer.

You serve a quality product, but a plentiful crab cocktail (with subtle flavors) DROWNING in cocktail sauce might as well be crab cocktail served at a county fair in the midwest.  Don't shrug off my comment, tell me to order sauce on the side NEXT time. Finally, after talking to THREE people, I was offered another one with no sauce.  Thanks.

Times are changing; three other people around me all had sauce on the side.  Maybe it's time to change it up and ask guests if they want sauce on the side...just like you do with many of your other items.

For the record, the chowder, bread, clams, and oysters were as friggin amazing as always.
author: JR D.

description: AMAZING. So fresh, so unpretentious and worth the price. The Blue Points here were better than any I've had back home. The "sashimi" plate which was off menu was perfect! Halibut, salmon, ahi and scallops drenched in lemon, olive oil, purple onion and capers! Delicious! The sourdough was amazing, spring the buck for it! I'll be back fellas!
author: Michael P.

description:
More like a 3. 5. We came for lunch on our first day in san fran after reading the reviews as a must stop location, eager to chow down on some good seafood. The seafood itself was only okay. There were some things that were good like the smoked trout, a sashimi plate of anchovies, sardines, albacore and ahi tuna. The chowder, the cherrystones, the oysters were all just okay.

What we really enjoyed and why we still consider it a must stop is for the ambiance. It is a single counter family run restaurant. The guys serving you are up close and personal and extremely genuine. Again, with our 1 and 1/2 year old baby I was nervous with such close quarters but they did not seem to mind at all and even interacted with her. You come here for the experience and the guys preparing fresh seafood made to order. Buyers beware though, it is fairly expensive for what you get so you decide what you're willing to fork out for ambiance.
author: T R.

description:
If you're looking for a foo foo seafood restaurant with fake French sommeliers, guests with fake breasts and their 94 year old sugar daddy, dress codes, and servers with sticks up their asses...you've come to the wrong place.  

If you want some fresh oysters and a kick back atmosphere without the pretentious "I think I'm the shit" snobs...come here.  This place is a no frills no tables no dress code no nonsense seafood eatery...more specifically...an oyster bar.  

So gorge yourself on fresh oysters, have some brothy clam chowder, gulp some Stella, eat some bread, be happy, start up a convo with the person next to you, compliment his/her slurping technique, and eat more oysters.  You'll be glad you did.
author: Stan C.

description:
I am so annoyed, I would give this AWFUL place zero stars if I could.

Sushi was on the menu for dinner, I decided to try and buy fish from this place as it often gets good reviews and it is just up the street from my apartment.  There is always a crowd when I walk by so I took that as a good sign. 

I walk in and stand at the end of the counter, I try to get someone's attn to see if there is a line or what.  Some guy from behind the counter barks at me and tells me to be patient he will be with me when he has a free hand.  I know they are busy and I don't mind waiting, but the guy insists on continuously telling me to be patient.  I'm standing here watching it all and just waiting, what else does he want me to do?  

Anyway, I'm standing by the window and watching the servers prepare food.  No one is wearing gloves and they are all grabbing shrimp by the handful and plopping it on plates of lettuce.  Not sure what the SF healthcode is, but I don't think not wearing gloves is up to par.  Especially when the same person is delivering the food and handling money.  Gross.

Finally, after being told to be patient about 15 times, the original db decides to help me.  I ask him if they have sushi grade fish and he looks at me like I have three heads, "well, yeah, I can give you salmon, halibut, scallops, tuna, what do you want?"  ok, I order my fish and then ask for a dozen oysters.  During the time he is preparing my order he tells me that they get very busy and I have to be patient.  Yeah, I got that.

He digs for my oysters and I ask him how I should keep them unitl we eat them later tonight.  ie on ice, in the fridge, etc?  Again, he looks at me like I had 3 heads and was like "yeah, in the fridge".  ok.

so blah, blah, blah he bags up my 1/4 lb of salmon, 3 scallops, and 12 oysters (NOT shucked), and charges me over $40.   whatever, I'm going to my old faithful grocery store in Japantown to get good sushi grade fish for way less $ and zero attitude from now on.
author: Esther M.

description: The crab is great!!! (actually...everything is...even the bread) the staff is totally friendly and the seafood and old-fashioned restaurant is worth the wait. if you don't have time, just get take out because that'll be faster than waiting in the at least ten people deep line that doesn't seem to move when you're hungry. The only thing is, you have to wait for take out also. Either way, the food tastes good both in the restaurant and out of it.
author: Maureen B.

description: May this place be here after the Big One hits and remind San Francisco that Dungeness Crab is the best Thanksgiving dinner!!  Turkey sucks, if you grew up here you'd know it!
author: tim w.

description: The guys behind the counter were definitely helpful and super sweet!  The seafood is fresh and amazing!  I'd give it a 5 star if it wasn't for the high prices and long wait.
author: Yelp T.

description: this is the best place in the world for oysters and other shellfish; the staff it so fine, the service it impeccable, and if you leave unsatisfied, it's you neurotic problem :-)
author: Tom F.

description: We just stumbled in on a hum-bug...Hell yes, lets go stand in that line!! The food was fresh, simple and delicious. The guys who run the place were Super-Cali cool. We each had a bowl of chowder that we ate with lots of Tabasco and a delicious hunk of sour dough bread. We shared the seafood salad and marveled in every bite. We really enjoyed the hot ass home made horseradish. I mixed a bit in the homemade cocktail sauce and lil lemon squeeze. I am sure that I could eat there everyday...too bad I live in Atlanta
author: Tanya C.

description: 2 stellas, 12 kumamotos and a crab salad so gosh darn full of lump meat make it more than worthwhile to wait for a seat at the bar. Service is old world stellar.
author: Ben L.

description:
who: lunch for two
date: 9/19/2009
time waited in line: 11:40 am
time seated in the restaurant: 12:45 am
ordered: a dozen of oysters, crab salad, and fish and scallop sashimi
drink: coke
total: $62.20
happy camper: yes
good food: yes
good customer service: yes
author: Linh N.

description:
This is a SF landmark that I actually love going to, see Sears Fine Foods review. 
I love all the guys, the oysters are delicious and reasonably priced. No one confuses me for a tourist here. 
I am not a huge fan of the chowder but everything else really works for me. Had some beautiful uni here once that was just like a swim in the ocean. Also they have a crab salad which I love. It is really just a bed of shredded iceberg and at least a pound of fresh shucked crab with thousand island over it. It is $18. This is a good deal. Crab is expensive. If you take yourself to the Wharf (though I never recommend this) for a crab Louie you will pay $38 and there will not be nearly as much crab and you might accidentally fill up on all the other crap they put in that salad. 
I try to avoid the long ass lines by going at odd times on weekdays. I especially like to go around 4:30 right before they close and just pop in and get a couple beers and some oysters and chat with the guys while they clean up. 
Swans is the perfect antidote to Sears.
author: Melissa H.

description:
the crab tasted a bit like piss. its true about the bread scam. 

place is run by daniel day lewis (gangs of new york) types. i found the owner (or at least the guy who acts like the owner) to be, quite simply, an asshole.
author: H K.

description: Swan always has a line out the door but it moves quickly and is well worth the wait.  The place has character and charm as you enter the long, narrow shotgun style, family-owned establishment- the great history and tradition becomes apparent. The dark stained wood bar table and 16 stools run the length of this divey seafood gem! The food is amazing and everything is as fresh as it gets- the oysters will not disappoint you, the clam chowder is great to get you started, smoked salmon is prepared in house and is a must try- served on rye bread!  Other favorites include the cracked crab, shrimp cocktail, the salads are great and of course this is a fine place to get your lobstah craving taken care of!  Two thumbs up!
author: Akash D.

description: Wow, 342 reviews.  What the hell is there to say?  They do seafood correctly.  If they have scallops, order them.  The combination seafood salad Louie is fantastic.  Bottom line:  you have to wait,  it takes a while, cash only, twenty stools, nice people, impeccably fresh, very old school, NOT cheap, worth it, the end.
author: Jessica F.

description: "Fresh" is the word around this place.  My favorite was not the oysters.  It was the UNI!!!!  Wish i had brought my own sushi rice.  Then I can make a gigantic uni hand roll!
author: Davis W.

description: Nope, don't do it, tourist trap. The shellfish is good,not great and the wait not at all worth it. I'm still searching for a good hole-in-the-wall seafood place in the city. I'd rather pay the prices at Hog Island. I'd here go if I wanted a quick dozen on ice but this place is not quick. Maybe I'm just spoiled from years in New Orleans when this quality raw bar was the rule not the exception.
author: patrick g.

description:
when bigger is better......

well, i wish this place was bigger so the line wouldn't be so long.  but i guess you wouldn't get the friendly service and front row view of the people shucking oysters.

my friend likes the kumamotos but they are tiny depending on the season and place.  i guess my taste buds are not as refined as hers and i like the biggest and baddest oysters in season.  so i ordered a dozen and plunked myself down on the barstool.

the cocktail sauce is average.  next time i'll bring in my own special mignonette aka curtesy of whole foods.  you'd think the prices were going to be cheaper based on the following they have but nope, sadly they are not.

i did get my filling of some of the biggest oysters i have ever seen.  good thing i had a nice little walk home to digest.  it was fun to watch and chat with the guys so 4 stars for experience and minus one for the teeny venue and wait.
author: Anh V.

description: Jennifer S., it appears that you are the only one here that does not have the palate of a f$%#ing truck driver.. This place has fantastic ambiance, and character, I will absolutely give them that. That's it! There food is worthless! The chowder is tasteless water, and their seafood is fresh, but terribly bland and minimal culinary effort is exerted.I know, American seafood is traditionally very boring, but come on!..When I see you clowns lining up at this place day in and day out , it truly boggles my mind.... Iceberg lettuce drenched in water, mayo and plain crab meat.. That's what you people are going apes#$%t  over????....... They get 2 stars for ambiance, and history........Bon Appetite....
author: Tim E.

description: Totally classic. 100% worth the wait and the price. Have an anchor steam while you're waiting in line and chill out...why are you in such a hurry anyway?  Love this place.
author: Ryan W.

description: I am in love. Truly, madly and unconditionally in love. I read about this place in the Continental Airlines magazine (I know, I know... tres chic, right?)  on my way to SF today, stumbled out of SFO and made a beeline to Swan Oyster. There was no line (weekday at 2pm), sat at one of the few seats at the bar, and then sequentially inhaled oyster crackers, sourdough bread, outrageous clam chowder, amazing raw oysters and clams and a smoked salmon plate. (Okay, I can't take all the credit, I did have a little help.) The service at this family run establishment is incredibly friendly and the atmosphere is perfectly relaxing after a 6 hour cross country flight. So many places with a raw bar have attitude to match, and this tiny gem is truly an exception. I NEED a Swan Oyster  Depot in NYC.... PLEASE! A definite must for any raw seafood lover.
author: Courtney P.

description: Go after 1pm to avoid the crowds. The oysters were excellent. The crab salad was full of whole pieces of crab meat, making the $19 worth it. But the clam chowder was a bit disappointing, lacking flavor. Very friendly staff.
author: Raymond P.

description:
After 274 reviews...should anyone even bother with mine? ah oh well..

Before going there, my friend warned me that it would be a long wait, i didn't expect there would be a line on Polk st in front of a restaurant at 3pm.  30 mins or so after, I was pretty hungry but my friend was alright after consuming a BBQ chicken leg from Shalimar near by while standing in line.  I guess best to come with someone so that either one of you can run to near by store grab something while wait, because if you come here hungry, by the time you are ready to be seated, you probably already pass the stage of starvation.
Anyhow, not big fan of raw seafood, I had crab Salad - 18$, I didn't get their Louie dressing, I asked them to mix some olive oil, vinegar and mustard as the sauce, which came out superb on salad.  I got a generous amount of crab, fresh, very fresh, along with my Stellar, I was pretty happy.
My friend ordered a dozen of clams, I tried one.  I didn't know how to eat raw shelled live animals, i slurped the poor thing in my mouth, didn't know what to do with it, should i bite onto it or should i swallow it?  I had an awkward moment which i hope no one noticed it.
Their clam chowder is a must have, liquidy but full of clam flavour.
Not a big fun of their bread, granted this is not a bakery.
author: Ting R.

description: We got there at 10 AM. Reading a review from last Saturday, it said a 20 min wait. We waited over an hour. Nice people, good atmosphere, and they will serve you drinks while you wait in line. The cold beer, fresh bread, and variety of condiments at your fingertips were all great. Clam chowder was light on the clams. Combo salad was OK. The oysters rocked. All in all, I probably wouldn't go back unless there wasn't a line.
author: Phillip B.

description: Hands down the best raw bar in town. Worth the wait. Easy to beat the crowd if you get there early before the lunch rush though.
author: Robert W.

description:
This place gets five stars for being an SF institution with really fresh seafood, super fast and efficient service, and a motley crew of patrons.  
My gf and I decided to try and sneak in for a quick lunch and we lucked out by showing up before the onslaught.  We scored a spot next to this uptight "three martini" lady who could barely control her wine glass.  
I decided to ignore her and focus on the crusty bread and Anchor Steam in front of me.  We both ordered salads...I went with the Seafood Combo and M with the Crab Salad.  Their Louie dressing was off the hook and the crab was sweet and tender.  
I also did a half dozen oysters with Kumamotos and whatever they picked for me (assuming Blue Points).  They were what oysters should be and I shot 'em without any accoutrement.  
In the end we had to jet quick style which worked for the guys behind the counter.  They got me my bill, I paid, and that was that....just as it should be!
Thanks guys for keeping it real!
author: Sheila Y.

description:
This place is literally half a block away from me, and a couple of weekends ago my roommate and I were finally able to make it down for the 20-25 minute wait one Saturday.

I expected the seafood to be great, and it did not disappoint. Clam chowder- delicious. I tried my first oysters, and had no complaints. We shared a combination seafood salad, and since they had unfortunately run out of crab for the day minutes before we sat down (some storm caused a shortage that week) they added smoked salmon and trout to our salad. It was heavenly.

But the best part about this place are the people. My roommate and I must have met two-thirds of the staff, shaken their hands, and gotten asked about our lives about five times each. These gentlemen constantly checked to make sure everything tasted great, brought over capers and onions for our salad, and topped off our Bloody Beers (a delicious creation!) when they noticed them dwindling.

I will be patronizing this place as long as I live in San Francisco, and recommend it to anyone who wants to have an amazing experience!
author: Casey M.

description: A small, traditionally San Franciscan establishment.  As stated in other reviews, this place really is a hole in the wall type of establishment and if you don't get there early enough for lunch, you can expect to wait for a while.  The pros:  the seafood is FRESH, the shrimp cocktails and the OYSTERS are wonderful (of course), there is a large selection of beer and they offer "food to go".  The cons:  waiting in line (get there EARLY), bumping butts with the customer next to you (the seating is not only limited but not spaced out very well), the smell (I understand, it is SEAFOOD and it is supposed to smell like fish) and parking in that area can be a nightmare.
author: Hiromi N.

description:
I first heard about this place from a friend a few months ago and after much praise I knew that I had to go.  So we arranged to go the next morning despite a late evening out.  Bright and early Sunday morning we treked over to Swan Oyster Depot.  Much to my dismay, we discovered it was closed!  I've never felt such traumatic disappointment in my life.  It's been a long road to recovery, but finally I've had another opportunity to satisfy my craving for those delicious mollusks.  Suffice it to say that the wait was worth it.  We managed to beat the lunch rush and were seated promptly at the last few stools at the end.  The seats weren't terribly comfortable, but I wasn't there to get comfortable.  I was there for some good, fresh seafood and fresh seafood was what I got.  

First we started with a couple of cups of clam chowder.  The chowder was a little looser than most of the chowders that I've had, but the flavor was very nice and there were some decent chunks of clam.  Next we tried a sample platter of oysters featuring some kumamotos, virginicas, some blue points, and a few others whose names escape me.  All of them were excellent either alone, with mignonette, or just a little lemon and tabasco.  Next we tried some little neck and cherrystone clams.  I've never tried raw clams, and while I still prefer oysters, they weren't bad and the cherrystones had a pleasant flavor to them.  Next we followed that up with another couple dozen oysters.  While we waited for the oysters, I couldn't help but order some smoked salmon as it teased me in my periph.  I was not disappointed with that either.  The salmon was perfectly smoked, not too strong and still with good texture.  

Since the SOD is so small, the service was excellent as every party had their own server to themselves.  Our oyster guy was super friendly and helpful in explaning the different types of oysters and in taking our orders.  It was a little more expensive than I would have expected, but worth the occasion every once in a while.
author: Gary L.

description: Great spot in SF. Awesome if you like seafood and the family friendly environment will keep me coming back again and again.
author: Scotty B.

description: fresh as you can get seafood without catching it yourself.  staff is friendly and helpful.  I cant imagine anything wrong with this place.  you do have to wait a little at times to get a seat but thats only because it is such a small place.  in fact dont go here so that I wont have to wait as long when I go.
author: seth r.

description: Heard about this place from someone while eating at Hog Island (also a great place..but different) Really really great experience. Awesome clam chowder (yeah, it's not the thick stuff).  Great combination seafood salad, killer awesome oysters. Perfect with the Anchor Steam on tap. Super nice folks. Worth the wait.  We'll be back.
author: Kalama K.

description: Swans is amazing. Ive only been here once..I need to go back. It was for my friends 21st birthday...eveyone working there was so friendly giveing us ample glasses of wine on the house with our tray after tray of wonderful seafood delights, oysters, crab, lobster..you name it. this place is super crowded but worth the wait. old time feel, eveyone sits at the counter and orders. its also a market,,,people get lots of fresh fish to go. heartwarming family owned place, with 3 generations of one family working side by side. they gave me a Swans calender and i had them autograph it for me, maybe it was the wine talking but they are as good as celebrities to me:)
author: melissa c.

description: Swan is a wonderful place, with consistently high quality seafood. I like to sit in the back at the marble counter. There is simply no bad thing you can order at Swan. I like the clam and prawn cocktail and the clam chowder, oh I wish I had some right now..everything is good there. A seafood cocktail, a piece of fresh sourdough and a cup of soup make a meal. The brothers who run it are super nice. Wonderful place. The Polk St. bus stops right across the street, and the California St. cable car going west from downtown lets you off right on the corner. I have never, in 25 years, been disappointed by the food or people at Swan. Good vibes abound. A true San Francisco gem!
author: Sharon J.

description: Love this place but its always a wait but totally worth it.
author: Fannie C.

description: i love the history of this place. you can tell just by looking at this place from across the street that it's an institution that's been around for quite some time. there's no evidence of an attempt to revamp the place to make it more appealing to the newer generations, which is awesome! the old men inside serving you fresh seafood have been doing it all their lives and want you to have a good experience without being overly friendly or too standoffish. if there's anything i really like about Swan Oyster, it's the environment. it also helps that the seafood is fresh and served in it's simplest form, which allows the ingredient to shine on it's own. if there's anything i would recommend getting, it's the crab salad. a bed of iceberg lettuce with loooads of fresh crab and louie dressing. that's it. oh so very good. but personally, i wouldn't waste my time and tummy space on the clam chowder. it wasn't great and the cream was separated from the clam juice/broth. just stick with the cold stuff, it's your best bet!
author: Regina C.

description: Been eating here since my feet couldn't touch the ground while sitting on the classic stools!  Just an amazing local joint which has a lot of history.  Fresh seafood and smiles all around.  Get there early cause there is always a line and they don't stay open all day.  If you are a local or a visitor you will be charmed and amazed by this establishment.  Enjoy:)
author: Velvet V.

description: I LOVE SWAN OYSTER DEPOT....yes I am yelling that out.  I have been eating there for nearly 40 years.  The crab melts in your mouth like butter.  The gang that work there are all wonderful.  I drive back from Hayward to the neighborhood I grew up in just to eat here.  They also help you out on good ways to cook fish if you need it.  Well worth the trip.
author: Linda L.

description:
How many places can you say this: 

"It was worth the 45 minute wait." 

I can't believe that for the past 20+ years, I've been going to touristy Fisherman's Wharf instead of the Swan Oyster Depot. THAT won't ever happen again! 

FOOD: The clam chowder here is the best clam chowder I've ever had in San Francisco. It's not too creamy or butter-y or flour-y... it's not too anything because it's perfect. It tastes like it was made with fresh clam and fish stock (it probably was)... and it's not too thick or thin either. It's got a great mouthful of flavor and seasoned just right. Dip their tough, chewy, sour sourdough in it and thank the stars that you live in San Francisco. I also ordered their combination salad and it's worth every penny. While standing in line, I watched the gentlemen behind the counter build plate after plate of these - each adding the shrimp, prawns, and crab in their own artistic way. They seriously pile on the seafood and the crab is soo fresh and the prawns are huge and "crispy." Mmm... and the cocktail sauce was the best cocktail sauce I've ever had. The bf ordered 3 different kinds of miyagi oysters and they were shucked fresh right before our eyes (his favorite was the huge, sweet Steamboats). 

ATMOSPHERE: I love, heart, adore places that look like the Swan Oyster Depot - even though decades have past, nothing's really changed and nothing big probably will. Even though the place is old, it's timeless and still clean as whistle. The men behind the counter are super friendly, efficient, and kind. Seriously, I'm not even going to complain about the line.
author: Christine N.

description:
Oh dear god, how do I not spend all day and all of my money in here?
Pure, unadulterated seafood which is allowed to speak for itself.  If you don't like seafood and are able to only enjoy the riches of the oceans with sauces and gelees, go elsewhere.  This is the real deal.
When I lived out on the coast I went there, when I visit the city, I go there.  And I make sure to bring the wad of cash because there is no telling what might be looking great that day.  Last time it was freshly fileted anchovies with olive oil and sea salt - HOLY CRAP that was tasty!
And then there are the tried and true standbys: mixed seafood cocktail, clam chowder, crab salad (with enough crab to choke a mule) - it's all good.  
And lest we forget the oysters.  A great variety of briny, oceanic goodness.
Makes me want to fly out there just to eat.  It's worth the wait to be seated, and certainly a wonderful seafood camaraderie sets in once inside, side-by-side with the patron next to you.
Maybe Jax is in my future here in Denver - Damn, they're great, too (especially considering how far they are from the ocean, to have such high quality oysters...).
I wonder how many frequent flier miles I have???
author: Kyoko W.

description: What a great place.  Quintessential San Francisco Seafood with some down home locals.  The boys at Swan are a gregarious bunch that serve up the No-BS plate of grub with a passion.   I'm never one for lines (why do I feel like I say that all the time?) so you'll never catch me hanging out front waiting for a seat.  But if I'm in the mood, I'll head on in.  A couple of nights ago after picking up a friend from work, we headed over there knowing that the wrapped up shop around 5:30.  2 patrons sitting at the bar, we walked right in sat down and ordered up some Clam Chowder.  The stuff is awesome.  Not too creamy or sweet, done just right and served up with sourdough and butter, of course.   After that a few Anchor Steams, a Crab Salad, too big to eat (makes for great Crab quessadilla with the leftovers BTW), shrimp cocktail, and a Seafood combo salad.  All in all it's not that expensive in my opinion for what you're getting.  Give em' a go at Swan and open yourself up to the possibilities of fresh oysters and seafood.
author: Brad C.

description: Perfect place when you have a hankering for some fresh fish and an ice cold beer.. Crab salad was light and went sooo well with their home sauce and fresh bread. Pops got the clam chowder and it was off the hook- sort of heartburn free in comparison to fishermans warf's best.
author: Megan M.

description: If you like oysters and beer, and who doesn't, this is the West Coast must place to be. Nuff said?
author: Don K.

description:
complaining about having to wait in line is dumb.  i feel that too many people have been spoiled by fast food and apparently hate their friends so much that they cannot talk to them for more than five minutes without food in front of their face.  

order the smoked salmon (its the jam) and bring your wallet.

while standing in line i noticed the staff making sure people weren't cutting in line.  that's service to me.  and, yeah, they don't coddle you, but treat you like a real person which is something that the service industry is sorely missing.  sorry people who hate lines.
author: Markus B.

description: If you had one day in San Francisco to eat lunch I would take you to the Swan oyster depot. It is a San Francisco institution. You might have to wait in a line but it is all part of the experience, Fresh sour dough bread, a hot cup of clam chowder and a cold draft Anchor steam will put you in the mood. Shrimp cocktail and crab Louie are so fresh and so gooood here. I usually eat way too much when I come.
author: Fernand P.

description: This place looks like a dump with a long line extending down the block.  I look inside and there are no tables just ten or so bar seats.  The people behind the counter look like drunk sailors.  I'm curious and I'm already here, so I go stand in line with my girlfriend.  An hour later...well worth the wait.  Clam chowder, scallop sashimi, oysters, and the seafood salad were all delicious.  Washed it with some Stella.  My philosophy is If you wait an hour, you might as well order the kitchen sink and make it worth it.  Why I like this place?  Fresh seafood, generous portions, local feel, and fair price.  You're definitely not here for the foofoo atmosphere.
author: Kevin K.

description: Accidentally stumbled upon this gem. Had to wait awhile in line, but SO worth it. Oysters were fresh and delicious. Great seafood selection. Restaurant has an awesome history and every single person that worked there was so personable and knowledgeable. I am so glad I experienced this place. Swan Oyster Depot makes me want to move to San Fran.
author: Rachel S.

description: I love Swan Oyster from the first time  when I had to stand in-line for 1 hour. Their Oysters are fresh fresh fresh. I am also a fan of their smoked salmon. I have been coming to Swan for some years now. Recently, I found out that they also serve fish sushimi, the clam, and even sea urchins....
author: Daphne A.

description: My bf took me here before dinner for oysters. I was really excited to try this place since there's always a line waiting to get in. It's a very small little oyster bar with just a counter top seating. I'm not sure why I didn't have a great experience here. It may have been all the flies flying around, or it may of been the old man sitting up next to me. (way too close!) Everything around me felt "dirty." The oysters were fresh and delicious, but I don't think I would wait in line to eat here again. Maybe I'm just too much of a snob.
author: Denise L.

description:
Swan Oyster Depot is a San Francisco institution.  Would we go there if there were no lines?  It probably would be less desirable; it would be shellfish was no longer cool.  Luckily shellfish is still in.  The Depot has what seems to be bounteous supply of crab, shrimp, oysters and other curiosities.  I am delighted when they have a gorgeous lobster tail; actually it is not a tail it should be called lobster belly (sounds better than lobster abdomen).  Come here for super fresh seafood; served most often as a salad or cocktail.  Order the combination salad (shrimp and crab); never mind it is Iceberg lettuce; I don't eat it either.   The crab is sweet, it is chunky; quite simply it is ambrosia.  The shrimp are fresh; just recently acquired from the ocean; the crunch is re-assuring of freshness and a delicate sweetness.  You wish the shrimp were steak size.  Order your salad dressing on the side; if not it will be drenching your iceberg and shellfish; and God forbid it will add to your waistlne (and In San Francisco that could ruin your social life).  Don't come here for a lengthy wine list or comfortable seating; prepare to not look at your dining partner as it is all counter service.

 If I did not have knees I might be more comfortable; prepare yourself for maximal discomfort.   I guess when the Depot opened up nearly a century ago that no one had knees and perhaps shrunken legs.  There is almost no where to put yourself.  You might be sitting in the strangers lap left or right of you.  I like my fellow dinners who ask if I can move (I laugh a little louder when I am a foot and half away from the counter and there is no where for me to go).  Ahh those San Franciscans are funny people.  

If you go by yourself (or even if you go with several people -- chances are your group will be broken up) be prepared to let your server know that the person who arrived at the same time you did is not your boyfriend or girlfriend--(I think I had a cute boyfriend next to me for about 45 minutes) a diplomatic way of letting your server know would be to ask for your own supply of sourdough.  

I read another review and it mentioned that some of the seafood was frozen?  I hardly believe anything I had or was being served was ever frozen.  Frozen (or fish once known as frozen) is flavorless and often tough.  I am not sure where they were eating.  I am fascinated to see the servers readying a crab or thinly slicing smoked salmon.  Seafood is one of my favorite things to eat.  Swan Oyster Depot makes me think why are there more of these types of eateries in San Francisco?  

I like the service; I know many people do not.  I think the service is minimal yet pleasant.  I think if you engage your server they tend to not just answer yes or no.  I asked about the sea urchin I saw and got a colourful commentary on it's flavor profile.  Nice guys that man the counter at the Swan Oyster Depot.

Go to Swan Oyster Depot for clean, fresh, simple old world style seafood and feel like you are in a restaurant that is stuck in time; San Francisco's phases have been it's own accord which have little to do with the Swan Oyster Depot --it has kept it's identity the same.

Buen Provecho!
author: Jaime Patricio M.

description:
okay, it's really all been said, but i just wanted to add my yelp since i created that perfect polk street walk o' food in my crustacean review.

i do have to say that i would always bring my seafood-loving visitors here when i lived in sf.  we would of course come for the food, but also for the fish monger ambiance.  but it's the food that always brings me back =)
author: becky k.

description: The seafood is fresh, service excellent, and the atmosphere is one of a kind...   This beats anything on the wharf and has loads of authentic character.  Can you believe that I have lived about three blocks from here, for almost my entire life, but it has been decades since I've eaten here?  Like catching up with a long lost friend!
author: Collin W.

description: This place is great.  They really take care of their customers and the food is amazingly fresh.  This place makes you feel like you are several decades in the past with the level of service you just cant find anymore.
author: P T.

description: This family-owned Polk Street institution has its drawbacks - the stools are uncomfortable, the wait at peak dining times can be long, and parties of more than two likely will be split up. So come at an off-hour and enjoy some of the freshest seafood, raw or cooked, in the city. The chowder, thick and creamy, is outstanding. More reasonably priced than one might expect; were they in the Marina, they could and probably would be charging more.
author: Gourmet G.

description: I gotta tell ya, I love oysters.  I am always on the lookout for the perfect one, two, three...twenty...The oysters here are very fresh and the mignonette is spectacular.  There are only a few seats so the wait can be quite long, but once you get there you won't want to leave!  If you have an oyster purist with you then this is the place to take them.  They do have other things such as clam chowder, shrimp cocktail, and crab salad.  The menu is on the wall and trust me it is hard to decide what to have, so you might as well order one of each. I have to admit I like it a bit better than Hog Island, just for the old school feel of it.  Otherwise they are both pretty comparable.
author: Chris W J.

description:
i don't really like oysters.  at least i thought i didn't.  however, i enjoy them with the bf. i think it's because he does some strange mystical thing to 'em, sort of like an oyster-magical-potion...nonetheless, after a little master-manipulation what originally was just kinda slimy is now a delightful gulp of sour, salty, and spice!

having said that, i was excited to take him to the swan oyster depot because i had tried to get some grub there with my family but were cut off while standing in line because they had run out of food.  with this possibility in mind, bf and i headed to swan's promptly after having breakfast...

i attest that it's not the cheapest seafood around, but it's definetely fresh and worth the wait that's inevitable...while i wasn't able to get any crab (because it was sold out before 2p!),  the calamari salad was GREAT (the calamari was the perfect texture), the clam chowder was DELICIOUS, and the combo of oysters were AMAZING!

will probably go again one day...but make it a lunch time event if you wanna make sure you get to eat something (and perhaps even earlier if you want crab!)
author: Grace O.

description: I can't wait to go back.  An American sushi bar.  Everything I ate was fantastic and incredibly fresh.
author: Carolyn S.

description: Great place. Great place! The guys are super friendly, it's completely unpretentious, it's a REAL oyster bar and not some knock off wanna be east coast crab shack that people try to con people into thinking. The pics  are real, the staff are real and the food is always fresh. Stella Artois on tap? Getthefuckoutta herah!
author: Kevin C.

description: Every restaurant in San Francisco should be like Swan Oyster Depot. Amazing service, fantastic seafood quality, great beers on tap, what more could you ask for? The prices are a little steep but you're paying for quality  and freshness which means you won't be yakking up your oysters later on. The line out the door is a definite turn off for any new comer so plan on a late lunch (anytime around 3pm is best). The staff is friendly and attentive, give this place a try, you won't be sorry.
author: Carson L.

description: Great seafood, incredible service, long wait.  Granted, we went at lunchtime on a Saturday, so we expected to wait...took about 45 minutes to get in.  They served drinks to people waiting in line.  I have never seen better service...very relaxed atmosphere, no pressure, no judgements...just great seafood.  I think the barstools are original to the place, though...Loved it.  Plan on paying at least $20 a plate.
author: K B.

description:
Cool hole-in-the-wall oyster spot, great SF tradition with great oysters.  It's a little small, which I know is part of the charm... but it can get annoying when you just want to eat a few dozen oysters at 11am and you need to elbow wrestle the guy next to you.

-great oysters, usually they have half a dozen or more types.
-good mignonette.
-great smoked salmon, one of the best I've had.
-reasonably priced, considering it's oysters.
-not a fan of the New England clam.  It's a little watery.  If you're into that kind of thing maybe you'll like it.
-very limited wine list with Pahlmeyer Chardonnay, which actually earns more points than having a great wine list.  

-very small.  
-be prepared to wait.
-cash only
author: Billy B.

description:
amazing!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! had oyster variety, and crab salad with Louie dressing. the crab was piled high on the salad and super fresh!!!!!!! so very delicious i dream of it! the oysters were great as well. they had every item you could possibly want to top the oysters with! 
the guys behind the counter were so friendly and helpful. i was eating alone and it didn't feel uncomfortable at all. 
i waited about 30 min in line on a Monday at 2pm. i would wait 2hr for this place if i had to! hopefully next time someone will go with me so i can try more dishes!
author: eli p.

description: Yes it was worth the wait!  The clam chowder was a little lighter than the typical  chowder but I really enjoyed its sublety. The shrimp and crab cocktail was tasty and fresh. Staff was great as they offered a beer while waiting in line. The strangers seated on each side of me chatted me up and helped make this a fun lovin delectable lunch!
author: Dave M.

description: Let me start off by saying that I've never actually dined there. So, I have nothing to contribute on that end. I'm far too intimidated (aka lazy and impatient) to get into the line that is always invariably out the door and down the block. However, if you're willing to forego the onsite dining experience, a great trick is just to call in an order. You can walk right in and pick it up. Just tell them how many people you have, and ask them what's fresh. They'll ask you how much you want to spend and put a little spread together for you. We ended up having a little picnic at home and the seafood was incredibly fresh!
author: Marie M.

description: Whenever I drive past here, I always see people line up on the sidewalk to wait for one of the eighteen stools at the marble counter. They not only have oysters but salads and chowders too. I came here waiting a LONG time to get my seat and when I got there, I orders my clam chowder since I don't really like oysters.. The clam chowder was tasty.. taste like homemade chowder. I'm glad it wasn't thick and creamy cuz that means it's not filled with thickener.. It's real soup with lots of clam.. yum.. The calamari was also good with the sauce.. Everything was definitely really fresh!
author: Juliane N.

description: Super Delicious, super expensive, and they only accept CA$H so have plenty on you!  Worth every penny!
author: Metal G.

description: After being warned about the wait after 11:00 am, we came here at around 10:30 and sat just in time to avoid waiting in line. (yay!) My brunch companion and I shared a bowl of clam chowder, 6 oysters (3 for each of us), and the smoked salmon plate. All were very delicious and fresh tasting. The clam chowder was very good but a little too soupy for my taste (I like mine to be chowdery, esp when eating with bread!) The service was excellent and friendly, and it's great to eat seafood at a place where you don't feel scared that the stuff isn't fresh.
author: Orie M.

description: OMG...I don't think I've ever had salmon, oysters, crab, and shrimp as fresh as I had at Swan Oyster Depot. Seriously, get there early and expect to wait hours. The place is literally a 15 chair counter and it fills up fast. I arrived around noon and finally got seated around 2:30pm. Wow, what a wait! But it was worth it. I ordered a dozen of the mixed oysters and the seafood salad. The salad had iceberg lettuce and louie sauce/thousand island dressing (ok, whatever), crab, shrimp, and since they ran out of lobster, they gave slices of smoked salmon. I didn't complain one bit. Everything was so good and tasty. Simple, extremely fresh seafood. Nice, friendly, very knowledgeable family owned business. There are days I dream of eating the salmon from here.
author: Jan Z.

description: Simply the best for shellfish, period, exclamation point.  Ran into a guy at Nationa Airport in Washington DC and he said it's one reason hge comes to SF.
author: Tom M.

description: When I was younger my dad would always fish for crab (or is it crab for crab? --- you get what I'm trying to say! Anyway...) so by the time I was old enough to choose my food I was not a huge fan of crab. Unless you're allergic or have that weird "ewwww seafood is gross" attitude, everyone LOVES Crab --- except me... But recently on a trip to Swan's Oyster Depot, I have rekindled my love for Crab... My husband and I ordered the Dungeness Crab and it was incredibly fresh and tasty! The crab was huge (2 1/2 lbs. I think) and at the end of the meal we still had some left over --- and that is rare for my husband. You really have to get down and dirty with the crab cracking but it's worth it... Love the crab here but did not have the pleasure of trying anything else. The lines are out the door and despite the slow service it's worth it! This is great crab without the high price.
author: Christine L.

description: I love oysters and getting them shucked for me! :)  They're so fresh here and everything tastes delicious.  You have to try the fresh clams. The look a little daunting at first, but I love the firm texture and the fresh taste to them. We got here at closing time, but they were still happy to serve us take out so we ate in our cars. A little messy and hard to juggle the sauces and lemons, but it all worked out in the end. Don't come here late though! It closes at 5:30.
author: Dune N.

description: This place is a San Francisco monument.  My first experience with anything Swan's related was at my third Christmas Eve at my grandparent's house where I ate about a quarter pound of caviar (roughly $300).  I have been hooked on Swans ever since.  The crab, the chowder, the caviar, and especially the oysters.  The best part for me though is not the food but the service.  There is nothing I love more than to eat at a place where the guys tell me stories about how much my dad used to drink back in high school.  Priceless.
author: Charley B.

description: Another gem in Frisco. The longer you wait on the curb the better the food will taste. Rain makes it even better! Lovely interior, vintage look, not the cleanest place around but heck who cares if all the rest is top notch? Very friendly people, told us a lot of old stories as they know the father of a friend's friend, who seems to be from a rather insane family. Food was excellent. I tried the different oysters, then the mixed seafood salad and finished with a shot of barrel aged tequila. As good as it gets.
author: R S.

description: Very good clam chowder. Fresh oysters and clams. Smoked salmon, shrimp cocktails & all kinds of seafood salad. Beer & drafts. Tradeoff is there are only 10-15 seats. The wait could be longer than you think. Buy to go is an option. Closed for dinners and sundays.
author: cynthia l.

description:
It's interesting that not one reviewer has been very specific about the wonder and beauty that is Swan's. So here goes:

1. This is an S.F. place of worship. It's been there forever, in the same place, with the same damned piece of marble, and same family-ownership for nearly 100 years. 
2. Service is wonderful -- what an eclectic and interesting group of devoted shuckers and cocktail makers. The owner (son or grandson of the original owner) is a gem. Engage them in conversation, they tell stories or at the very least will chitchat about all kinds of things. 
3. Seafood is A+ topnotch fresh and tasty, and they do not skimp on the seafood for the salads and cocktails.
4. They'll mix you "special sauces" if you ask; mignonette, dijon mustard, etc. Just ask! The servers have their own inventions, too!
5. Ask for the goodies! Swans gives out little dehydrated sponges, refrigerator magnets and other tchotckies that you can take home and use or give to your friends back home (if you're a tourist).
6. Don't got during "rush" times; i.e. any time that it be near lunchtime. Don't go between 11:30 and 2:00.  They do close at 5, so time yourself. You might have to wait in line anyway. It's worth it. 
7. This is the single most uncomfortable seating arrangement EVER. Tiny chairs and stools are crammed against a very small bar. So don't get all excited about bringing a crowd. Take yourself and maybe 1 or 2 others. Dress down and comfy. Sometimes it's cold inside so be prepared.  Don't be surprised that you'll be butting elbows (and butts and shoulders) with the person next to you. That's just the way it is and it's worth it. 
8. You put up with it b/c it's Swan's and for $15.00 or so you get the biggest Louie salad loaded with your choice of seafood. No other place else offers a louie this substantial and at this quality for this price. 
9. Do order the clam chowder. It's a soup, it's stew, it's a meal. It's damned good. 
9a. Try the smoked salmon/fish plate, worth every dollar. 
10. Don't miss the shellfish cocktail, you can mix in horseradish, lemon... anything else you want. They have all kinds of additions. You can customize your dressing to suit your tastes.
11. Ditto on the Louie salads; afraid of Louie dressing??? They'll make you up any kind of dressing you want -- or one they've made up. Oh, I said that before, didn't I???
12. Last and probably least is that they have an interesting collection of rubber duckies which they will happily let you play with.
author: Heather W.

description:
Would you rather have 6 oysters for $12 or 6 oysters, a beer, fresh sourdough bread and all-you-can-eat oyster crackers for $6.  It's the difference between Ferry Building or Swan Oyster Depot.  

It's my new fave.  Start with clam chowder. Then get prawn cocktail. Then oysters.  Then crab louie.

try cracked crab
author: around town e.

description: The 49ers memorabilia and San Francisco seafood fare definitely give this place a palpable SF feel.  Also, the aged and spartan accomodations have a nostalgic quality.  However, the food quality is really mediocre.  This is the Sears Fine Food of San Francisco sea food restaurants - a real tourist trap.  Salads, vinaigrettes, Louie dressing are all pretty disappointing and insipid.  After the long lines and sky-high prices, the results are in.  This place is a waste of time for SF residents.
author: Kenneth N.

description: Im giving this place a 5 but I need to give you the 'locals' tip in order to really enjoy it as a 5! When I went, I made the mistake of actually *WAITING IN THE 2 HOUR LINE* and - tho the place does kick a-double AND its next door to Sees Candies - apparently the real way to do it is order out. The seats at the counter do not encourage sitting and staying for a while and - as I was sitting close to the door - I noticed all the locals coming in and picking up orders and the staff knew everyones name! So, that seems the way to go. Fantastic clam chowder and fresh fish. A local landmark to boot.
author: Inome C.

description: I've lived in SF for 6 years, and half a block away from Swan for over a year, and amazingly, today was my first time going there. Delicious seafood, good beer, friendly service, and a fun, no frills atmosphere....now I know why I see a line down the street every day!
author: Tovah L.

description:
I'm going to give you a couple of bullet points and you name a restaurant that matches that description:

-deliciously prepared fresh seafood 
-friendly, knowledgeable staff 
-decent prices 

If you ended up naming a different restaurant for each bullet point, well... that's just sad.  C'mon, guys, there's only 3 bullet points there!!!  Even 2 out of 3 shouldn't cut it!!! It should have been easy to name just one restaurant that can offer these 3 things (and offer them all consistently)!  But, alas, in the real world, we all know that there are certain places we go to when we want great-tasting food, but we have to go a different restaurant when we want to pay for cheaper version of it just to hold us over. Then we end up looking for an occassion that passes as a good enough excuse to go all out and finallly get to that finer diner for that tastier, alberit more expensive, version of that same cut of fish. So, so sad... 

Well, my friends, let me tell you something.  If you go to Swan, you will consistently hit these 3 points every single time.  You will not have to give up knowledgable staff for a better tasting shrimp cocktail.  You will not have to pay extra for another slice of smoked salmon (just ask for a taste while they're cutting one up for someone else!).  And you will not have to sacrifice flavor for friendlier service!  Too good to be true?  Only one way to find out, right?

What else can I say about this place.  The line out the door speaks for itself.  People may say the only reason there's such a line outside is because there's only 15 seats inside.  Butt c'mon... if you've ever sat in there and wondered why they don't just knock down See's Candy next door and put in 60 seats, you'd quickly realize that you're very lucky to be sitting in there. Passersby gawk with envy as you induldge in a combination seafood salad overstuffed with shrimp and crab meat.  You glance to your left and someone is having a cold, crisp beer over a plate of a dozen (+ a half, maybe?), fresh, assorted oysters.  And to your right, I'm sitting right there smiling over a perfectly smoked salmon and bread combo with extra capers. After awhile you realize that no matter how many seats they put inside, there will always be a line outside. Because it is that dayum good. 

So you say you need another example of how good Swan Oyster really is, eh?  Okay, well, have you ever been somewhere like- let's say- Chicago and had an authentic deep dish pizza?  Then you come home and order one from Domino's or whatever and you realize that Chicago just ruined pizza for you- for the rest of your life?  Because it was just that dayum good, right? Nothing will ever compare, right?  You wanna make another trip out there as soon as possible to get that perfect taste/experience back, right?  Well, that's what Swan did to me in regards to smoked salmon.  I used to get it every Friday morning at this deli just 2mins away from my house but after having it at Swan, I can't eat it anywhere else anymore.  Sure I get cravings and I drive by the place daily but now I shake my head and keep on the gas... because Swan is just that dayum good.  So if you want your current standards for seafood, service, and pricing to be forever ruined for you (in a good way, of course), then you gotta try this place. At this point I would say something clever like 'see you in line' but I go really early to beat those suckers out of a seat!!!!  haha!!!  So I'll see ya standin' in line on my way out!!! Peace!!!!
author: Ant S.

description: Not worth the almost two hour wait.  Rude service and mediocre food.  Nothing outstanding at all.
author: Michelle N.

description: A great place to take someone from out of town for some of the freshest seafood in the city. Well worth the wait (and you will wait). Their wine and beer pairings are excellent. For a busy place with extremely limited seating, they still never try to rush you out. Great staff.
author: Phil W.

description: You will always see a line out the door and there's a reason!  If you want to eat in the restaurant you will have to wait a bit longer, but take out is really really fast.
