I kept telling my brother I wanted to go to the Swan Oyster Depot and he kept saying that he didn't like oysters.  I had a hard time to get him to go.  Finally on the last day of our trip...I told him "We are going!"  What an experience.  I had the Crab Louis, my son had oysters( I got to sample) and my brother and his wife(who couldn't sit by us) had the mixed salad.  I have never tasted crab like that before.  So fresh.  And the oysters....I didn't think I would like them but next time, I will order some for an appetizer and then have my salad.  My brother and his wife finished before we did so they were waiting outside.  His first comments were.  "Why didn't we eat here everyday?"  He is hard to please but if we go to San Francisco again together...I know I will get my fill of Crab Louis salad.   Yes it is a small place...absolutely not fancy but the one thing that is very obvious is that the people behind the counter fixing the meals really like what they are doing and like their customers. That means everything to me and on top of that very fresh and great tasting fish.  Can't ask for anything more.
author: Hazel P.

description: I frankly don't see what all the fuss is.  I've had much better seafood elsewhere for a much lower price.  It's not really accessible & the atmosphere is funky.
author: sally g.

description: Fantastic local spot, I take all my tourist friends here to sample good crab and sourdough. Looks like something out of a 20's gangster movie, tiled floor with a worn marble slab counter. Simple menu (on the wall) but what they do, they do right. A shrimp cocktail followed by a crab salad with an Anchor Steam on tap and hunk of incredibly good bread and I'm in heaven. A ritual for me, if I don't hit Swan once a month I'm not living right. Not cheap, but shelled fresh crab is worth the cost!
author: Alessandra I.

description: Truly a San Francisco original. One of the best places for lunch on the entire west coast. It's just plain fun.
author: Jeff B.

description: oysters were very fresh. the clam chowder was a bit watery for my taste.  the people that worked there are very friendly but the place didnt seem very sanitary. ( guy at the counter handled money, did not wash his hands and touched a customers fish.) after seeing that i opted not to try the crab salad. decent place for oysters if there's no wait but after waiting over an hour i was dissapointed.
author: john l.

description: yes the wait can be  sucky sometimes, but when I'm craving oysters, crab, chowder, or smoked trout it's worth it.  this little counter-only eatery is a San Francisco tradition that's been family owned since 1912, and it's great seeing both a line of tourists queing up and regulars who've been going once a week for the last 55 years waiting patiently for their turn to cram knee to tile and slurp up what we often take for granted: fresh seafood.  iit's awesome.  it makes you feel good.  look around & everyone has a smile on their face.  and while I realize that Anchor Steam doesnt make a special steam beer for JUST Swan's, it certainly TASTES like it...a cold pint of another one of SF's traditions never tastes better than it does here.  I dont know why.  they also often have items not on the menu, so ask for something special and you might get lucky.  or might not.  also of note are the wooden casks of tequila that sometimes flow for an extra special post-chowder shot before the next course.  I love this place.
author: church B.

description: i take all my out of town friends and family here for a great, authentic san francisco seafood experience.  great service.
author: R H.

description: The Swan Oyster Depot is another old favorite of ours. We arrived at about 11am and had our pick of seats at the bar...within 15 minutes, there was a line out the door. Let's face it, the place is a cramped dive. But it has a terrific vibe and we had typically friendly service from the many guys behind the counter. We had wonderfully fresh and plump bluepoint and miyagi oysters (you don't get oysters like these in Utah and Texas!). My wife had the clam chowder (too thin for my tastes) and we split a dungeness crab salad which was loaded with impeccably fresh-picked crab. Awesome meal and still a must-do in SF. This place is much better than Hog Island at the Ferry Bld (there, you pay up the wazoo for ambience). Remember to bring cash cause they don't take any credit cards. It can add up rather quickly. A dozen oysters...$24. A cup of chowder...$2.50. Bread & butter...$1. Crab salad...$19. Soda...$2.50. Best seafood in SF...priceless.
author: Jason K.

description: RIP OFF and GREASY CLAM CHOWDER !!!  I've heard about this place and its reputation.  I popped in during an errand run to get a quick cup of SOD's famous clam chowder.  It was already $4.75 for a "bowl" and the guy upselled me to the next size up which the counter guy liberally stated as a "pint".  The physical container sizes made me think that a bowl is 10 oz. and a pint cup was 12 oz.  When he rang me up, he told me it was $7.50 -- which shocked me for the difference.   My expectations of a $7.50 bowl was that I would have chock full of clam meat.  Instead I got this greasy white clam chowder consomme with a layer of grease on the top and balls of cream.  Perhaps this is natural separation after the half hour in between serving and eating even though it was still hot.  But there were hardly any clams at all.  Not exactly your premium soup for $7.50 -- I would have been better off popping open a can of Chunky's.  The menu prices are way to high for what amounts to boiled seafood served with cocktail sauce.  $33 for a cooked lobster -- which amounts to dropping it in a vat of hot water !!  You're better off getting your seafood fix at a Chinese restaurant and paying a lot less for a lot more flavor.
author: Y M.

description: i am so glad i was finally able to visit SOD yesterday!  i mean, you can see why i haven't... its only open for lunch on weekdays and i think saturday.  and there is almost always a wait.  but i took the day off yesterday and so when it was suggested that we go there for lunch, i jumped on the chance.  we did wait a little (about 20 minutes) but thats not too bad since it was noon.  but once we sat down, service was great.  our server helped us right away and was very courteous and friendly.  we started with a dozen raw oysters (how can you not??) - a mixture of 4 different varieties.  i dont really know much about oysters but our server explained about each of them and they were delicious.  we also had the chowder - pretty good, i wished there were more chunks of clams, it was more like a broth.  but they flavor was really great.  the next time i had a weekday off, i will totally go again!
author: Carolyn B.

description: the food gets 5 stars (the best clam chowder ever - although you have to like the brothy boston style), although it's on the expensive side given the ambiance. the prices are about the same as waterfront dining in the embarcadero area, but you wait in line to get into swan oyster depot, sit at a bar, and have people all around you while they wait behind you. i had a lady push her purse into me and a man reach over me to eat out of the cracker bowl, in addition to hearing all their conversation. pretty ghetto.
author: I. K.

description: Use to come here a lot.  Loved the fact that I can sit down, eat a ton of oysters and spend very little money.  Incredibly fresh seafood.  The oysters, prawns, cherrystones, and everything else on the menu does not get any more fresh.  The sauteed softshell crab was incredible, but I don't think they do it anymore.  Definitely worth it to ask though.  When you order the prawn cocktail don't forget to ask them for some tartar sauce.  They make the best tartar sauce in the world.  So good i can eat it by the spoonful. Maybe...    Their clam chowder is more like clam broth.  Very very tasty.  Not the typical thick chowder.  This stuff is good, and not overly rich like most places.  Come here and come early.  The wait can be long.  Try to get yourself a seat closer to the back.  Two reasons.  One... People waiting will be breathing down your neck towards the front of the shop.  Two...  The first few seats in the shop have no leg room.  Those of you who come here often know what I'm talking about.  Service is top notch.  Never seen people so eager to help.
author: Nick H.
